Title: ‘Northwesterly will bring temperature down to 11 degree Celsius-12 degree Celsius in Kolkata’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

A two-degree drop in minimum temperature is expected in the course of the week (File photo)

KOLKATA: The chill is set to intensify in Kolkata this weekend as the northwesterly wind gains strength. A two-degree drop in minimum temperature is expected in the course of the week.

The wind is set to pull the mercury down to 11°C-12°C between Friday and Sunday, according to the Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC). “Snowfall in the Himalayas has unleashed a strong northwesterly wind and it is expected to revive the chill. Once the wind reaches Kolkata, the temperature will fall,” Das said. He, however, added that the chilly spell may not last long and the mercury will rise once the wind loses its sting.

Title: Lost items worth Rs 67.6 lakh found at Patna airport last year
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) personnel found lost items worth Rs67.6 lakh at the Jayaprakash N... Read More

PATNA: The Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) personnel found lost items worth Rs67.6 lakh at the Jayaprakash Narayan International (JPNI) Airport, Patna in 2019. They handed over items worth Rs10.4 lakh to the passengers the same day. Airport manager (APM) returned items worth Rs57.1 lakh to the passengers, who turned up later on.

CISF officials at Patna airport said 12 to 15 passengers either accidentally forget their goods or just dump some to avoid paying charges for extra luggage. “In that case, they just took out few clothes or items that are not costly. Generally, we found the leftover items in the security hold and checking areas,” a CISF official said.

The public relations officer at CISF headquarters, New Delhi, Hemendra Kumar told this newspaper on Wednesday that altogether 2,831 lost items were found by the CISF personnel at Patna airport in 2019, while 1,509 items were recovered in 2018. “The security at city airport monitors the unidentified items on its premises and traces the owners with the help of closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras installed there,” he said.

Patna airport terminal building has over 150 CCTV cameras and 362 CISF personnel for security.

Puja Mehta, a banker in Bengaluru, said she forgot to take her laptop bag from the baggage claim area. “After reaching Patna airport from Bengaluru, I accidentally left my laptop bag. As I was waiting for the cab with my father, who came to pick me up from airport, one CISF personnel came running towards me and returned my bag. I’m very thankful to them for their hard work and vigilance,” she said.

Some flyers thanked CISF on social media. Gyanendra Nath, an IT professional in Victoria Melbourne, tweeted: “Very thankful to BN Sharma, DK Mishra and other CISF and Patna airport staff members for retrieving my hand baggage which got exchanged during my recent travel from Patna to Melbourne via New Delhi. Appreciate your agility and eagerness to help (sic).”

Anshul Agarwal, an engineering student of Pune, wrote on January 15: “I accidentally dropped my ring near the scanner at Patna airport. I informed security personnel about my missing ring. CISF’s official Ujjwal Kumar assured me that even a needle doesn’t get lost at Patna airport. True to his words, he recovered it within 15 minutes (sic).”

The CISF personnel claimed that generally people forget items like laptop, mobile phone and charger, pen drive, sunglasses, bottles, edible items, umbrella, jewellery, wallet and money bag, electronic device, jacket and dress materials among other things. “When no one turns up to claim the items, we put the description on CISF website and if no one turns up to collect their items, these are auctioned by the airport after one year,” the CISF personnel said.

The sources at Patna airport said passengers usually leave inedible items, inexpensive clothes, sunglasses, bags and other things. “In some cases, flyers forget their expensive items like laptop and mobile phone,” they said.

Title: 30 e-buses to ply in Patna by December
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The state transport department is set to launch 30 electric buses ( e-buses ) on major routes in the state capital by December end.

Patna Smart City Limited has approved the project of running e-buses by the Bihar State Road Transport Corporation on its 13th meeting held with different stakeholders on Tuesday. A sum of around Rs 10 crore has been sanctioned to BSRTC under the Smart City Mission Fund.

The buses will be procured on the basis of a tripartite agreement which will be signed by the Central government, PSCL and the state government. The Central government will provide funds under the FAME II scheme (Fast Adoption and Manufacture of Electric Vehicles). The state government has already launched electric car last year in July while the electric two-wheelers also available in the market.

Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said the state government is promoting the use of electric vehicles using green technology by giving 50% reduction in road tax. “We will soon invite bids and begin procurement work for e-buses. Bihar will get the buses by December 2020,” he said.

He added, “All the electric buses would run on major routes in the city including Bailey Road, Ashok Rajpath, Digha, Gandhi Maidan, Rajendra Nagar, Station Road, Airport Road and Phulwarisharif.”

The e-buses are costly and one bus will cost around Rs 1.5 crore to Rs 2 crore. The e-buses can cover a distance of 250 km after being charged once (four hours) and these buses do not emit fumes, thus helping reduce air pollution. Recently, a delegation of transport department had visited West Bengal where e-buses are being used by the state government. Another delegation of transport department would soon visit Mumbai.

Agarwal said that the delegation members will learn from the experts in Mumbai and get the details required to run the e-buses in the city. “A plan to run the electric buses will be prepared accordingly. As for the maintenance of e-buses, the company from where we procured the buses will take care of it. According to transport secretary, to charge the e-buses they need high-powered charging point because it needs more power supply than e-car or e-rickshaw. A high-powered charging station would be developed at Transport Complex, which would come up at Phulwarisharif near Patna airport. We are preparing a detailed project report on this. We will also put up charging stations at several locations in city where it is required,” said Agarwal.

Transport department is preparing an electric vehicle policy to promote e-vehicles in state, rebate and plan to set-up charging stations. The department is also in the process of converting 100 city buses that runs on diesel into compressed natural gas (CNG).

Title: tata nexon ev: We would like to promote electric as a mainstream solution: TaMo
Content:
File photo

Will all Tata Motors vehicles now also have an electric variant? Is that part of the plan?

What other spin offs will you offer from the Omega architecture?

As part of your cost control measures, you have shut down your Thailand subsidiary. Will other overseas subsidiaries also face the axe? What about Tata Daewoo for instance which is facing headwinds in Korea?

Are you capping your investment plans to ride out the slowdown?

CHENNAI: With Altroz and its new BS6 ready passenger vehicle range, Tata Motors is readying itself to ride out the slowdown and the transition to BS6 smoothly. In a chat, Guenter Butschek, CEO & MD, Tata Motors, talks about electric plans, cost cutting and more. Excerpts:Not yet. In principle all future launches will provide an EV option. We already are offering a Tigor EV, a Nexon EV and an Altroz EV. All the new products based on the Alfa architecture will provide an electric variant. As for the Omega architecture, this too is battery electric protected. We had in fact debuted a concept in Geneva 2018 that was based on Omega architecture. So it’s technically feasible but not commercially viable. We would like to promote electric as a mainstream solution. The sweet spot in India to accelerate the adoption of EV is the segment below or just above 4 metres.Harrier has done well and December in fact was the best ever month for the model in retail and wholesale. The Harrier upgrade will be presented in the Auto Expo. Like the others, the BS6 version will be packed with other features including automatic transmission and a sunroof. Harrier is a flagship product and needs its own space. But there is a 7-seater variant on the Omega architecture which is in the making which will be launched in the market soon. There will be more products in 3-5 years to improve market reach. The two new architectures will have 12-14 products, taking our market coverage to 90%. We are looking at a larger share of the upper end of the market coverage.We took a call on our subsidiaries like Thailand. As for Tata Daewoo Commercial Vehicle, yes the economic environment in Korea is very tough. Medium heavy trucks have declined, competition brisk but Tata Daewoo is in strong recovery mode. It is a strong performing asset which complements Tata Motors truck range in medium and heavy duty segments.The last 9 months has demanded strong focus on cash management. We are focusing on receivables but also on spend. There is serious review going on and we are controlling not cutting our spend. The adjustment is to keep control on our cash because cash is king in difficult situations.

Title: Over three fourths of Crisil revenue now come from global biz
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Crisil , India’s first ratings agency, now draws almost 75% of its revenues from its global analytics business. The company is set to demerge the ratings business into a subsidiary in 2020 to comply with regulations.

Crisil, which was originally incorporated as Credit Rating and Information Services of India Limited, was majority acquired by global ratings agency S&P. Since then, the company has gone on a global acquisition spree of non-ratings businesses and a majority of its employees in India are now engaged in analytics and providing support to the operations abroad.

Although the ratings division has always been a separate unit, the regulators felt that there should be a separate board of directors for that business. Sebi had directed credit ratings agencies (CRAs) to segregate the non-ratings business into a separate entity by May 30 this year. However, given that the non-ratings business is the dominant one for Crisil, it has decided to subsidiarise the ratings business.

Speaking to TOI, Crisil MD Ashu Suyash said that the company would be seeking shareholder approval for the demerger next month. It would be completed, subject to the approval of the National Company Law Tribunal and regulators. She said that the acquisition of Greenwich Associates — a provider of benchmarking data and analytics — in December 2019 had increased the share of international business for the company. Greenwich was the main rival to Coalition, a British analytics company that Crisil bought in 2013 for Rs 250 crore.

Besides this, the global business division includes Pragmatix, which Crisil acquired in 2017. Earlier, the company had expanded globally by acquiring UK-based equity research house Irevna, another London-based advisory company, and a Caribbean ratings agency. Besides India, the company’s businesses now operate from the US, the UK, Argentina, Poland, China, Hong Kong , Singapore, and the UAE.

The restructuring comes at a time when ratings agencies are under fire from regulators — both in India and globally — for failing to highlight default risks in time. A slump in corporate investments and risk aversion among lenders has also impacted the ratings industry.

With seven CRAs offering their services in India, the RBI had warned of ‘ratings shopping’ by companies for long-term bank loans based on indicative ratings given by CRAs, which are not available to banks or investors.

Title: Govt adopting tech for better healthcare: Eatala
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Hyderabad: In a bid to provide quality treatment to patients from poor financial backgrounds, the government is keen on adopting robotic surgery technology, said health minister Eatala Rajender.

Addressing the media after inaugurating a Robotic Assisted Joint Replacement & Advance Orthopaedics Centre at Medicover Hospitals on Thursday, the minister said, “Such technologies should be adopted for the benefit of poor people and I request Medicover Hospitals to extend such services under Aarogyasri and EHS schemes.”

Robotics-assisted surgery combines artificial intelligence, augmented reality and the surgeon's mind who control the robot to achieve perfect results.

Access to good healthcare is the basic need of every individual and the country needs sustainable and better healthcare facilities, said Dr Anil Krishna, MD of Medicover Hospitals. tnn

Title: Adani aims to be world’s largest solar co by 2025
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Ahmedabad: In a major push towards promoting green energy , billionaire Gautam Adani , chairman of Adani Group , on Wednesday announced plans to become the world’s largest solar power company by 2025 and the largest renewable power company by 2030.

The $15-billion Adani Group, which has, among other sectors, invested heavily in coal mines and thermal power projects, has now drawn out plans to invest over 70% of the budgeted capex of the energy vertical into clean energy and energy-efficient systems.

In a blog posted on a social media platform on Wednesday, Adani said that in 2019 they were ranked as the sixth-largest solar player globally. “And as part of this journey, we are well within reach to be India’s largest renewable energy company by 2020 and one of the top three global solar energy companies by 2021,” he wrote. The group’ existing portfolio of renewable power generating assets presently stands at over 2.5GW. “This is expected to more than double by 2020, with the implementation of 2.9GW under construction capacity and further record three-fold growth touching 18GW by 2025. To make this happen, we have committed to investing over 70% of our budgeted capex of the energy vertical into clean energy and energy-efficient systems,” he wrote. Another key project that has begun taking shape as part of this journey, is the expansion of our 1.3GW state-of-the-art solar cell and module manufacturing plant in Mundra , which will turn into a 3.5GW manufacturing facility, he said.

“We are also in discussions on ventures to enable the world’s only 100% green energy-based chemical manufacturing and data centre facilities,” according to Adani. The group has entered a partnership with Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, German chemical giant BASF and Austria’s Borealis to study the feasibility of setting up a $4-billion chemical complex at Mundra. The project, if materialised, would mark the entry of Adani into petrochemicals. The power to be supplied for the project will be using 100% renewable energy.

The diversified conglomerate, with investments in sectors including ports, real estate, defence, city gas distribution, LNG and agri-business, has chalked out massive plans for building data centres across the country. The group has in the past announced to invest Rs 70,000 crore for setting up data centres in Andhra Pradesh.

Adani Group has moved quickly into a position to lead the clean energy transformation taking place not just in India but on the global stage that will see the group building one of the largest integrated energy portfolios, he said. “The age of renewable energy has dawned upon the world faster than most could have anticipated,” Adani wrote. “India has been the founder member that initiated the Global Solar Alliance constituted of 122 countries, and over the past few years, our nation has shown the greatest intent taking some of the most concrete actions for the world to look at it as one of the main the beacons of hope for managing the challenge of climate change.”

A majority of India’s COP 21 climate change goals set for 2030 are expected to be achieved almost a decade earlier, according to Adani. “PM Narendra Modi’s announcement at the 2019 UN conference to further raise India’s share of non-fossil fuel mix to 450GW is easily one of the most ambitious global commitments ever made by any nation. We must all be proud of this.”

He said India’s energy strategy finally has a line of sight on providing consistent 24x7 electricity for all segments of our population. “Efficient, supercritical and ultra-supercritical power plants will be needed to provide baseload power. This will be significantly complemented by capabilities such as renewable sources, natural gas, hydrogen, increasing electrification (EVs), energy efficiency technologies and innovation across the energy value chain,” Adani said. India was well on its way to achieving the optimal mix “perhaps better” than most other large nations in the years that lie ahead, he said.

“Given our goal to become the world’s largest solar power company by 2025 and the world’s largest renewable power company by 2030, we feel confident that we will be able to lead one of the fastest global carbon offsets. We are looking forward to this transformation,” said Adani.

Title: ‘Amend tax laws to help mining cos sell rough diamonds at SNZs’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Surat: Even as the country’s second Special Notified Zone (SNZ) for rough diamonds has opened up at the Gems and Jewellery park at Ichhapore, diamantaires will not be able to purchase rough diamonds from the mining company directly. Reason is that the foreign mining companies (FMCs) have not been given any specific exemption under the Income Tax Act, 1961 for sale of rough diamonds from SNZ.

Urging the central government to allow level playing field for the FMCs and its trading arms, the Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC), an apex body of the diamond industry has asked it to include suitable provisions in its budget proposal. It has demanded providing presumptive turnover linked tax rate of 0.125% for these FMCs to help them sell rough diamonds at the SNZs.

According to GJEPC, the FMCs are permitted to display, trade, auction rough diamonds in the SNZ. While there is no direct tax implications on the display of rough diamonds under the exemption given under section 9(1)(i) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, there is, however, no specific exemption for sale of rough diamonds from SNZ.

Hence, the rough diamonds are kept only for viewing or for display purpose at the SNZs.

The country’s first India Diamond Trading Centre (IDTC) Special notified Zone was opened in Mumbai in 2015. Many foreign diamond mining companies including De Beers, Alrosa, Rio Tinto have been regularly displaying roughs for viewing here. Later, diamantaires have to place order for the selected goods which the FMCs then ship directly to the company.

The Surat International Diatrade Centre (SIDC) has opened up an SNZ at the Gems and Jewellery park at Ichhapore. Recently, the customs department declared the SIDC SNZ as the customs area for the trading, import and re-export of rough diamonds.

Vice-chairman of GJEPC, Colin Shah said, “SNZs are beneficial for small players in the industry as they get an opportunity to directly view the goods displayed by the mining giants. We have been demanding amendment in the taxation laws, so that there is level playing field for the mining companies like Israel, Belgium and UAE.”

Shah said that the apex body has been demanding presumptive turnover tax since for the past couple of years to help the SNZs turn into trading hubs for rough diamonds. “India is the largest consumer of rough diamonds with small and medium diamantaires taking major benefit of the SNZs,” he added.

Title: 40 hours on, textile mart inferno rages on
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Surat: Raghuvir Textile market on Puna-Kumbhariya road has entered Diamond City’s record books by breaking all previous time records of fire incidents. While it’s 40 hours and still counting, Surat firemen continue to battle smoke accompanied by occasional licks of flame that is coming out of around 600-odd shops in the 12-storeyed market.

On the second consecutive day on Wednesday, the fire department had deployed more than 250 staff for the complete cooling down of the market premises that gutted goods worth crores of rupees.

While the firemen are still struggling to put a lid on the mess, more than two-third shops in the complex have been completely turned to ashes with shops mostly on the front side of the building being the worst sufferers in the inferno, said a fire personnel.

About 20 teams comprising 10 firemen each from Surat Municipal Corporation’s (SMC) fire and emergency department have physically entered into the premise and started breaking open the shutters of the closed shops, said Basant Pareek, chief fire officer (CFO). Talking to TOI, he said, “By 2 am on Wednesday the fire had stopped completely. Later, smoke started emanating from certain parts of the market.”

Pareek further said that at certain places, flames were still seen coming out of the shops and so, the fire brigade has flooded all the shops to bring the temperature down. “We did not want to take any chance of fire recurring and decided to perform the exercise in each of the shops,” he added.

An official engaged in the exercise said that the origin of the fire is still unclear. “The materials stored in some of the shops included sarees, dress materials, yarn and tent fabrics, which are highly inflammable. The aluminium elevation in the front of the building created a lot of heat inside the premises and it was difficult to stand even for a minute without protective gears,” the official said.

Box

Fire safety installations must within 30 days

Surat: The Surat Urban Development Authority (SUDA) organised a meeting of builders, CREDAI, architects, engineers, textile owners’ association and Federation of Surat Textile Traders’ Association (FOSTTA) on Wednesday. In the meeting, chairman of SUDA, Banchhanidhi Pani ordered fire safety installations to be implemented in the city, high-risk and high-rise category buildings, within 30 days.

Pani also stated that the builders will have to take special permission and registration for all types of outer elevations in the buildings. All these elevations must have proper ventilation and should be made such that in such emergencies can be opened.

He also instructed to have at least one trained person to act immediately at the time of fire in every high-rise building.

Photo quote

“The fire safety norms in the high-rise buildings must follow the National Building Code (NBC) norms. Elevation material must be non-combustible. If builders flout the norms, they will not get permission for other constructions.”

Banchhanidhi Pani, SMC commissioner and SUDA chairman

Title: Sensex sheds 1.1k pts from high in 3 days
Content: Mumbai: Quarterly numbers by top names in India Inc, mostly below analyst expectations, are weighing on investor sentiment on Dalal Street as the sensex on Wednesday slid for the third consecutive session to close at 41,115, down 208 points.The BSE benchmark, after scaling a lifetime high at 42,274 points on Monday, is now down more than 1,100 points with brokers turning cautious ahead of the Budget next week.Rising inflation that has pushed benchmark yield higher this week, which in turn would make it difficult for the RBI to further cut rates in its next meeting, is also weighing on investor sentiment, bond dealers said.The IMF cutting India’s economic growth rate for the current year drastically to 4.8% further affected investor sentiment.The slide in the sensex came despite some positive news, brokers said. According to Siddhartha Khemka, head — retail research, Motilal Oswal Financial Services, global crude oil prices fell as the International Energy Agency forecast a market surplus in the first half of this year. “Further, China’s attempt to contain the coronavirus outbreak cheered the global markets,” he said. “Institutional activity (in India) has been subdued for the past couple of days, which indicates their cautious stance before the Budget. Also, the market is awaiting some of the heavyweights to report their quarterly numbers to gauge further direction.”In Wednesday’s market, HDFC, ICICI Bank and Kotak Bank contributed the most to sensex’s slide, while buying in software stocks, mainly due to weakness of the rupee, cushioned the fall. Institutions, both foreign and domestic, remained net sellers on Wednesday with domestic funds outflow at Rs 326 crore and foreign funds’ at Rs 176 crore, BSE data showed.

Title: MSC, Rupee co-operative banks submit joint merger proposal to RBI
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

TNN

Pune: Maharashtra State Co-operative (MSC) Bank and Rupee Co-operative Bank have submitted a joint proposal to the RBI on January 17 for merger of the latter with MSC Bank . However, according to officials, the RBI could take as much as six months to give its approval to the merger.

The merger proposal, if approved by the RBI, will grant relief to over half-a-million depositors of Rupee Co-operative Bank, who have not been able to access their own deposits since the lender was put under directions in February 2013.

The two banks clarified that the depositors will not lose any money as a result of the proposed merger. “Those with less than Rs 1 lakh in deposits can withdraw the amount within the first year of merger in five tranches of 20% each, at a gap of two months between two withdrawals. And those with more than Rs 1 lakh in deposits can withdraw their money over five years in slabs of 20% per year,” MSC Bank said.

Vidhyadhar Anaskar, chairman, MSC Bank told TOI the RBI wanted the two lenders to submit a joint proposal, so that the process can move faster. “The RBI wanted to know if both bank’s agree to the proposal and terms of merger,” he said.

MSC Bank said it will give 6.5% interest or higher rates on the deposits kept with it after the merger. “This will be the best possible option for the depositors. A liquidation might have meant that those with more than Rs 1 lakh in deposits get only 35% of it. In this case, they will get their entire money even if it is in a phased manner,” said Sudhir Pandit, chairman, board of administrators, Rupee Co-operative Bank.

Title: Reconsider decision on MEd course: Patna University to NCTE
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Patna University

PATNA: Taking exception to the recent decision of the National Council of Teacher Education (NCTE) to withdraw its recognition to the MEd course of Patna University ( PU ) from the next academic session (2020-21), the education department has written a letter to the council for reconsideration of its decision.

PU education department head Khagendra Kumar said on Wednesday that the eastern regional committee of NCTE at its meeting held from January 16 to 18 considered all the necessary documents furnished by PU with regard to the requirement for imparting MEd course and decided to withdraw its recognition on the ground that it did not have the required built-up area as per NCTE regulations. The regulations state that an institution running MEd course should have a built up area of 2500 square metres.

What surprises PU authorities most that citing reasons for withdrawal of recognition to the course, the NCTE has pointed out that the built up area is less than that prescribed as per Appendix-V of NCTE Regulations 2014 to run two units of BEd course and one unit of MEd course. They had pointed out that the BEd course is run separately in two different institutions, namely, Patna Training College and Women’s Training College and the MEd course is run by the postgraduate department of education located in a separate building at Dariyapur on Bari Path.

The PU education department head said that “We fulfill all other conditions including the required number of teachers, instructors, laboratory, library and other infrastructural facilities.”

It may be mentioned here that the PU education department is one of the oldest postgraduate departments in the country, serving the needs of teacher educators of this region since 1954. “If the NCTE does not reconsider the case on PU’s request, the university would file a formal application of appeal to the NCTE’s governing council,” said Kumar.

Title: Kolkata: KMDA to start soil test for Chetla Lockgate Bridge
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Only light vehicles are currently allowed on Chetla Lockgate Bridge

KOLKATA: The KMDA will start conducting soil tests and topographic survey at both ends of Chetla Lockgate Bridge to prepare a report to set up a new bridge. “The study will show how much load it will be able to take and identify the spot for constructing the new elevated corridor,” said an official. The authorities will then come up with an alternative alignment for the new bridge.

The test and survey are scheduled to be taken up from the first week of February and will be completed within 25 days.

Chetla Lockgate Bridge was shut last year after experts found it to be in a very bad shape. KMDA took up emergency temporary repairs and reopened the bridge just before the Pujas. But only light vehicles were allowed on it to prevent a complete traffic shutdown during the festive season.

The bridge is currently being maintained with temporary repairs and constant supervision, but with heavy vehicles permanently banned, its utility has already decreased. “The bridge’s load-taking capacity has decreased drastically. Only light vehicles are allowed to take the bridge, and under constant supervision,” said an official.

KMDA is also engaging an agency to conduct soil test for a new canal bridge over Tolly’s Nulluh between Usha and Bansdroni canal bridge.

Title: New fire safety rules: Rs 10,000 fine & jail term proposed in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Violation of fire safety norms will lead to imprisonment of up to three months or fine of up to Rs 10,000 as per provisions of the proposed Bihar Fire Services Rules , 2020. The proposals were presented by the home department at a meeting chaired by CM Nitish Kumar on Wednesday.

The proposed provisions will make it mandatory for owners of large commercial buildings such as malls and cinema halls to appoint fire safety officers and they will face penal provisions if found violating the rules.

The presentation on the proposed fire safety rules was made by the home department’s additional chief secretary Amir Subhani at the meeting chaired by the CM, during which he asked officials to link the fire safety rules to ‘Jal Jivan Hariyali (JJH)’ mission. Nitish said the JJH mission can be linked with fire services in order to ensure supply of water for dousing fire.

“Common ponds and other sources of water can be used for fulfiling the requirement of water for dousing fire. Ground water should be used only in case of emergency. Environment conservation should be given equal treatment as disaster management and behavioural changes should be introduced accordingly,” a statement released by the government quoted the CM saying.

State fire officer-cum-DIG Pankaj Sinha told TOI: “The rules have been made for effective implementation of Bihar Fire Services Act, 2014. Violation of any provision of the rules can lead to penalty of up to Rs 10,000 or imprisonment of up to three months and Rs 500 per day in case of continuing offence.”

He added: “Similar punishments have been introduced for non-installation of fire-fighting equipment in buildings and not allowing fire officers inside the premises. Till now, we used to conduct fire audits and send advisory to building owners in case they failed to comply with the norms. But these rules have provided “teeth” to the fire department and we can now initiate penal action, if people fail to adhere to fire safety norms.”

Title: Holding ‘Free Kashmir’ placard not ‘anti-national’: Siddaramaiah
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mysuru: The protests seeking to withdraw the sedition case against students of University of Mysore got a shot in the arm on Wednesday with the leader of Opposition Siddaramaiah arguing that holding a ‘Free Kashmir’ placard is not ‘anti-national’ even as he criticised a section of Mysuru advocates’ move not to represent the accused in the case, describing it as ‘illegal.’

He said ‘Free Kashmir’ is a movement to restore normalcy in the troubled Union Territory and it is not seditious in nature. “What is ‘Free Kashmir’ movement? There is prohibitory order imposed under Section 144 of CrPC even now. There is no freedom and a state of emergency exists there. The student has questioned this and asked it to be freed. It is not sedition,” he said.

The sections related to sedition do not apply in the protest that took place at University of Mysore, he said. Prime accused Nalini B is targeted as she is a Dalit. “Indian Constitution has granted her the right to protest, which she has utilized,” he said, adding she has not committed any crime.

The Mysuru Bar Association has resolved not to represent the accused in the case, which, he said, is illegal and goes against the basic tenets of their profession. “Some advocates are not acting as per the law,” he said, adding that when it was questioned, they behaved in an unruly manner. Some lawyers tried to attack advocate Manjula Manasa, former chief of Karnataka State Commission for Women, he claimed, and condemned it.

The former CM said the state government is targeting immigrants from neighbouring Bangladesh. While they say the CAA is to help immigrants from Bangladesh, they are at the same time targeting workers from Bangladesh evicting them. The government lacks clarity, he said.

Title: 51-member Japanese delegation visits city
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Ahmedabad: To explore more opportunities on economic cooperation by investing in Gujarat and collaborating for initiatives on the academic and cultural fronts, a 51-member delegation from Japan is expected to arrive in Ahmedabad on Thursday. The delegation comprising top officials of Japan External Trade Organisation (JETRO) in addition to bureaucrats and policymakers from Kobe City Assembly, and academic and business support organizations from Japan, will be led by Kizo Hisamoto, mayor of Kobe City in Japan and Kasuhiko Adachi, chairman of Kobe City assembly.

Part of the delegation will first attend the seminar on investment opportunities in Gujarat organized by JETRO, Ahmedabad. Following the investment-opportunities seminar, the delegation will participate in the Kobe-Ahmedabad and Hyogo-Gujarat Economic Cooperation Seminar organized at Ahmedabad Management Association (AMA) by the Indo-Japan Friendship Association (IJFA) – Gujarat, and Japan Information and Study Centre (JISC).

“The delegation from Japan is visiting a month after a 15-member delegation from Ahmedabad, led by Mayor Bijal Patel visited Japan. The seminar will promote exchanges between the two countries on academic, business and cultural fronts. The setting up of a Japanese Garden in Ahmedabad may be finalized after the delegation visit,” said Mukesh Patel, president, IJFA – Gujarat.

Title: Baby wipes market doubles in 5 years
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Driven by new-age ‘supermoms’ who are financially independent, educated and internet-savvy, baby wipes has emerged as a big category. This segment was practically non-existent 10 years ago.Though still nascent, the category has been growing fast over the last couple of years. Data by Euromonitor International reveals that baby wipes doubled in size over five years. According to the market research provider, the size of the baby wipes category increased from a little over Rs 100 crore in 2014 to around Rs 270 crore in 2018. However, it is small compared to the around Rs 5,000-crore baby diapers market.Kimberly-Clark India marketing director Chella Pandyan said, “The wipes category in India has been growing fast over the last couple of years, but remains in a nascent stage of development as far as household penetration is concerned. While hygiene and convenience are the key consumer needs driving adoption, it is the growing availability and access — enabled by more affordable price-points and e-commerce — that is helping expand penetration.” For ‘ Huggies ’ baby wipes made by Kimberly-Clark, according to Pandyan, the primary driver has been the fact that it is made from natural fibres.A study by JL Morison found that financially independent mothers don’t shy away from spending money to buy products for their babies, which provides time as well as convenience for themselves. In the qualitative part of the study, a lot of mothers indicated that they do strive to get some ‘me-time’ for themselves, which is difficult during motherhood phases, especially if they are working. Whenever they get this time, they spend it on socialising, catching up on their sleep, catching up on their hobbies and interests, surfing the net, or spending time with their spouses.JL Morison India group brand manager Nitin Bhandari said, “From a marketer’s point of view, this indicates that mothers are now willing to spend on products that provide them quality, convenience, comfort and safety for their babies.” These ‘supermoms’ are aware about the products and they also have a plethora of choices at their disposal. “While this provides an opportunity to marketers, the challenge is to provide the best quality and benefits at value-for-money prices. One of the biggest examples is the emergence of baby wipes, which did not exist around 10 years ago. Today, it is among the fastest growing categories,” said Bhandari.The research by JL Morison was conducted on a sample size of more than 400 mothers across five cities to understand their usage and attitudes regarding motherhood, babies and the product usage related to the same. The key trends that are driving growth in the baby care category are increasing birth rates, urbanisation, more working mothers, enhanced purchasing power and increased concern for child care.

Title: Kolkata: Officials conduct spot survey for Jadavpur flyover
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The flyover will decongest the perpetually busy Jadavpur police station intersection

KOLKATA: Officials from Kolkata Metropolitan Development Authority (KMDA), RITES, Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) and Kolkata traffic police officers on Wednesday conducted a spot inspection of the stretch connecting Prince Anwar Shah Road to Lords Bakery More to work on the plans for a flyover that has been planned to go over Jadavpur police station. Sources said RITES has been asked to conduct the soil test.

For the past few years, the authorities have been working on plans for the flyover that will decongest the Jadavpur police station crossing. According to plans, Jibanananda Setu will be extended a little over a kilometre to terminate at Lords Bakery More. Two ramps have been planned at the Jadavpur police station crossing for vehicles coming from EM Bypass intending to move towards either Jadavpur University on the left or towards Dhakuria on the right.

KMDA and Kolkata traffic police will need to sort out a few issues before the plans for the flyover materialize. Officials said there are about three houses close to Jadavpur police station that would obstruct the flyover’s alignment and the authorities will have to work on compensation and rehabilitation.

Cops said they have two requirements — the flyover on the Prince Anwar Shah Road side should not obstruct movement of vehicles towards either Katjunagar or Jodhpur Gardens. The police have also insisted that the three bottlenecks on the the access road from the Bypass-end of the bridge be sorted.

The cops have also wanted to know what kind of help and road blocks will be required during construction of the flyover. “This area witnesses heavy traffic. The Metro Railway has asked us to allot them space at Abhishikta crossing for the upcoming station, but we will need much bigger planning here. We have pointed out that the two constructions cannot be allowed at the same time as that might choke the Prince Anwar Shah Road connector completely,” said an officer.

Title: Justice Clock unveiled in Calcutta High Court
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The Justice Clock in the HC

KOLKATA: Justice TBN Radhakrishnan , Chief Justice of Calcutta High Court , inaugurated the Justice Clock on the court premises on Wednesday. It will display status of cases in subordinate courts.

“There has to be a performance audit, not a financial audit, which reflects the credibility of the institution,” he said. Incorporated Law Society’s secretary Paritosh Sinha and Barrister Promit Roy of the Bar Library Club were present on the occasion. Justice Sanjib Banerjee said, “The status of the cases in the subordinate courts will be easily available to litigants now.”

Title: Tribal dance competition held at Bhamragarh
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: The Gadchiroli police had organized a ‘tribal dance (rela) competition’ at the highly sensitive Bhamragarh taluka in the Maoist-affected southern part of the remote district as a part of their community and civic action.

Different teams from the police stations of Bhamragarh, Dhodraj, Tadgaon, Nargunda and Koti had participated in the dance competition which was judged by head masters of different ashramshalas and other prominent citizens, including ward member of Panchayat committee Vasanti Madavi. Around 400-500 local tribal population from different parts of the Bhamragarh taluka had attended the programme.

The first prize of Rs 7,000 was won by Jai Persapen Ahramshala of Bhamragarh followed by Halewar Sangha of Nargunda who got Rs 5,000 for being the runner-up and third place winner was Koti’s ashramshala team which got a reward of Rs 3,000.

The programme was conducted under the supervision of SP Shailesh Balkawade, Addl SPs Mohit Kumar Garg and Manish Kalwaniya apart from Sub-divisional police officer (SDPO), Bhamragarh, Kunal Sonawane.

Earlier in January this year, police department had held a similar tribal dance (rela) competition at Purada. Lingo Dance team from Mohgaon in Kurkheda had bagged the first place followed by Navyuvak rela nitya mandal Dholdongri and Hiramanji Pandav high school tribal dance group of Yengalkheda had won the third place.

Title: Navsari MP’s Instagram account hacked, plaint filed
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Navsari BJP MP C R Paatil

SURAT: Navsari BJP MP C R Paatil approached Surat city police commissioner on Wednesday alleging that his Instagram account was hacked. Paatil alleged that some unidentified person was chatting using his Instagram account with a girl.

“I was informed by my social media account handler that somebody was chatting using my Instagram account with some girl. I was told that the account was hacked. So, I immediately contacted police and asked for investigation,” Paatil told TOI.

Paatil wrote a letter to police commissioner providing details about the suspected ID which was mentioned in the chat.

“We have received the information and cyber crime cell has been asked to investigate,” said R B Brahmbhatt, city police commissioner.

Title: 17 tableaux on different topics for Republic Day parade
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Tableau of govt departments being prepared in Patna on Wednesday ahead of Republic Day function.

PATNA: Preparations are in full swing in the state capital for the Republic Day celebrations on January 26. The main event, to be held at Gandhi Maidan, will witness cultural programmes, ceremonial parade and display of tableaux. Besides, police personnel will be felicitated on the occasion.

A total of 17 tableaux with social messages will be exhibited by different government departments. “Government departments and agencies, including transport department, Women Development Corporation (WDC), State Election Commission and urban development and housing department among others will display their tableaux on the occasion. As of now, the rehearsal is in the final stages,” development commissioner Arun Kumar Singh said.

Divisional commissioner Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said January 24 is the deadline for tableau rehearsal. “All departments have been instructed to complete the rehearsals latest by Thursday evening. The final trials will be held on Friday,” he said.

The WDC theme is ‘Mahila hinsa ke viruddh’ (on violence against women). “For the last few years, we had been showcasing tableaux on dowry and child marriage only. This year, we will create awareness about the growing violence against women. People are unaware about numerous facilities, including the One-Stop Centre (OSC) that provides medication, shelter and other facilities to the victims,” said Chhavi Ranjan, state project manager of WDC.

The urban development and housing department, on the other hand, will display a tableau on rainwater harvesting. “Keeping in mind the incessant rainfall last year, we will showcase rainwater harvesting techniques,” an official in the UDHD said.

Besides, the Bihar Renewable Energy Development Agency (BREDA) will showcase a tableau on ‘Niche macchli, upar bijli” theme. The environment and forest department will send the message of climate change and plantation through their tableau and transport department will focus on ‘Mukhyamantri Gram Parivahan Yojana’ on the Republic Day this year.

Title: Bihar: ‘JD(U) workers get best training’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

JD (U) Rajya Sabha MP and senior party functionary RCP Singh

RAJGIR: JD (U) Rajya Sabha MP and senior party functionary RCP Singh said here on Wednesday that his party has successfully trained workers at booth-level across the state and that is why they have an edge over other parties for the upcoming assembly elections in the state.

Inaugurating a two-day party workers’ training programme jointly with deputy chairman of Rajya Sabha Harivansh Narayan Singh at Rajgir's International Convention Centre, RCP said: “People said JD(U) had leaders but no workers. But the situation changed after we successfully trained hundreds of booth-level worker across the state to make the party strong at the grass roots level. This has provided us an edge over all other parties.”

He added that 400 master trainers have been invited to train party workers and functionaries ranging from state committees down to panchayat committees in the two-day training camp—’Sabal Panchayat Sakriya Booth Abhiyaan ’. “Party workers got the best of training in terms of organisational strength for the upcoming assembly elections. The trained functionaries will, in turn, train other workers,” he said.

Addressing party workers, Rajya Sabha deputy chairman, Harivansh said JD (U) is different from other parties as it has a different ideology.

Title: Deposit arms after duty, Bhojpur SP orders policemen
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Bhojpur SP Sushil Kumar has ordered policemen to submit their firearms before returning home from duty.

The order has been issued in the backdrop of an incident in Sitamarhi where constable Chandra Bhushan Kumar shot his wife Madhu Kumari dead by using his official AK-47 assault rifle and later committed suicide by the same weapon at Simra under Dumra police station in the district on Sunday. The AK-47 rifle was issued to him from police lines for daily duty in a quick response team (QRT) in town area.

Most of the policemen involved in daily law and order, escort or court duty return to their residences without depositing the firearms at police lines armoury. The Bhojpur SP on Monday ordered policemen in the district to strictly obey the rules of getting firearms issued from police lines while going to specific duties like law and order, escort or court duty and submit the arms and ammunition before going home.

His order also mentions that in case of any lapses, the police lines and armoury incharge would be held responsible.

When contacted, Sitamarhi SP Anil Kumar said the AK-47 used by Chandra was allotted to him from police lines. When asked if weapons like AK-47 are allowed to be taken home after duty hours, Kumar said a weapon like AK-47 is a company weapon and remains with the unit.

Former DGP Neelmani said, “A company weapon like rifle has to be deposited in the armoury after duty. It can’t be taken back home individually.”

Title: Kids enjoy Army’s battlefield weaponry
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

PATNA: It was a memorable moment for hundreds of schoolchildren, who for the first time got a chance to see and handle arms, ammunition and artillery used by Army in the battlefield.

Indian Army’s Jharkhand and Bihar sub-area organized a special event named ‘Know your Army’ for schoolchildren of Patna at Manekshaw ground of Bihar Regimental Centre (BRC) on Wednesday as a part of Republic Day celebrations.

Not only the students got first-hand knowledge about weapon handling, they also got a chance to enjoy Army’s band concert for over an hour. Several patriotic songs and military tunes were played during that period.

BRC commandant Brigadier Jai Singh Bainsla told TOI that such events are held for showing students and youths how Army serves the country and how many avenues it has to make a career. “This connect us to common people and motivates youths in the long run,” he added.

More than 30 types of weapons, explosives and other equipment used by Army were on display for students. The arms included light machine gun, AK-47 assault rifle, Carl Gustav rocket launcher and its tank armour piercing round, tiny anti-personnel to heavy anti-tank mines, light machine guns, sniper rifles, chemical biological radiological and nuclear warfare protective suit and night vision equipment.

Students were also allowed to get first-hand experience of shooting by sports rifles, pistols and gas operated paintball guns.

Army also set up a stage and allowed students to take selfies with armed soldiers in complete combat gear.

Aditi Shree, a Class VII student, said she felt proud of the disciplined Army personnel. Aditi’s classmate Raj Nandani Kumari said she would like to come and visit such programme again. “It’s exciting to know how the weapons are used by our Army. Perfection displayed in each of their action was unimaginable,” she said.

Swastik Sinha, a Class IX student, said it was a dream come true to see energetic band concert and handling of weapons which he had seen only in video games till now.

Title: As 3D imaging ends, conservation of 43 temples in KV Dham to begin
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Varanasi: After the completion of 3D imaging of 43 historical temples, which include those having artistic walls, Kashi Vishwanath temple authorities are set to rope in a company for the restoration of structures unearthed during demolition of 296 buildings to clear decks for Kashi Vishwanath Dham project.

Besides these temples, restoration of Kashi Vishwanath temple will also be carried out.

At least 14 companies took part in ‘expression of interest’ (EOI) session on Tuesday in which a presentation on 3D mapping of temples was made.

According to temple authorities, a provision of Rs 6 crore has been made for restoration of temples which will be completed with the KV Dham project by June 2021.

Talking to TOI on Wednesday, chief executive officer (CEO) of Kashi Vishwanath temple Vishal Singh said, “Proposal for the conservation-cum-restoration of 30 out of 43 temples and other historical structures unearthed during demolition has been finalised.”

“A presentation was made during EOI session on Tuesday in which 14 companies participated. Tender process will be finalized by the first week of February after the companies submit their detailed research report,” he added.

During demolition of buildings to pave way for KV Dham project in 2018, many 18th century temples were found buried under the layers of concrete and plaster.

Threat to KV temple’s architectural marvel was generated after layers of enamel paint were applied 5-6 times on its walls before 2008. A team from IIT-Roorkee was engaged in 2019 to conduct a study on the adverse effects of enamel paint on the temple’s walls.

During its study, the team also conducted 3D imaging of the artistic walls of the temple. After assessing damages, IIT-Roorkee recommended steps required for restoration. After going through study report, Sri Kashi Vishwanath Temple Trust, in its meeting in December, approved the proposal made by IIT-Roorkee.

Title: TaMo debuts in premium hatchback segment with Altroz
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Chennai: Marking its entry into the premium hatchback segment, Tata Motors has rolled out its first vehicle from the new Alfa architecture — the Altroz, to come in in five trim levels at an introductory price starting from Rs 5.29 lakh for the petrol version and Rs 6.99 lakh for the diesel version. “Premium hatchback is a promising segment comprising 12% of the entire passenger vehicle market. The overall hatchback segment is around 49% of the PV market, up from 46% last year and premium hatchbacks comprise one-fourth of that. The Altroz is the first car on our new Alfa architecture. Last year we introduced the Omega architecture with the Harrier launch. We will have 12-14 nameplates on these two architectures,” said Mayank Pareek, president – passenger vehicles business unit, Tata Motors. Tata Motors also rolled out BS6 versions of its entire passenger vehicle range on Wednesday and the company’s overall capex for this year has been around Rs 4,000 crore, said Pareek. “We are comfortable from the BS4 perspective. End-December, we had only 15 days stock with dealers and our BS4 factory inventory on January 1, 2020 was zero,” he said.

Title: R-Day Constitution celebration plans
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolkata: A human chain will be formed from the north to the south of the city on Republic Day to uphold the values of the Constitution. A meeting was held by United Interfaith Foundation India (UIFI) on Wednesday to finalize plans for it.

Without directly going into the issue of the current narrative of protests against CAA and NRC that has rocked the country, the foundation members said the human chain will be a symbol of unity, equality and solidarity that the Constitution guarantees to the people of the country. In its 70th year, it was once again time to remind everybody what the Constitution stands for.

The chain will start from Golpark and end at the Shyambazar five-point crossing. People will stand on one side of the road holding hands to form the chain that will go straight up to Park Circus and then on to Mullickbazar, cross Sealdah, Rajabazar and end at Shyambazar.

“It is time to celebrate the Constitution and to celebrate the values of equality and brotherhood it upholds,” said Father Thomas D’Souza, the chairperson of the foundation.

The UIFI is an organization consisting of religious leaders and community heads from every denomination, who have come together to take forward the interfaith dialogue for promoting humanity, peace, harmony and brotherhood.

The chain will be formed at noon for 10 minutes. “The Constitution will be read out in several languages at vantage points,” said Satnam Singh Ahluwalia, general secretary of the foundation.

Title: Mumbai firm’s director held for ITC scam of Rs 6.74 crore
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Surat: The Directorate General of GST Intelligence’s (DGGI) Vapi regional unit, arrested on Wednesday the director of a Mumbai-based company engaged in trading of plastic granules, for fraudulently availing and utilising Input Tax Credit (ITC) to the tune of Rs 6.74 crore on Wednesday.

Director of Mumbai-based Walambia Plastics Private Limited, Manoj Jain, was arrested for committing offence punishable under section 132 of the CGST Act, 2017. Jain was produced before the Vapi court which remanded him to judicial custody till January 24.

According to the DGGI officials, they had raided Prabhat Traders in Halol in Panchmahal district and carried out searches at 17 locations in Halol, Daman, Silvassa and Mumbai on December 12, 2019. After the scrutiny of records, it was revealed that that Walambia Plastics Private limited based in Goregaon (East) in Mumbai and engaged in trading of plastic granules and indulged in issuance of invoices without actual supply of goods.

It was further revealed that the company received ITC on basis of fake invoices from many entities and further passed on such wrong ITC to various manufacturers in Daman and Silvassa. The Walambia Plastics availed and utilised fraudulent ITC to the tune of Rs 6.74 crore either from non-existing firms or without actual receipt of goods.

Title: SGCCI’s bi-annual exhibition Udhyog to begin from Jan 24
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Surat: The Southern Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SGCCI) has organised a four-day long ‘Udhyog-2020’ exhibition at the Surat International Exhibition and Convention Centre (SIECC) in Sarsana starting January 24.

Udhyog-2020 is the 12th bi-annual exhibition offering opportunity to industrial units to explore business potentials in the textile and diamond hub of Surat.

The exhibition will be inaugurated by minister of state for Health and Family Welfare, Kishore Kanani.

The focus of the this year’s event is to promote and develop the man-made fibre industry by introducing latest technology and insight.

The exhibition will be held in 1.25 lakh square feet area where about 200 exhibitors dealing in the textile machinery, textile ancillary, engineering machinery and machine tools, electrical, electronic tools, banking and finance, government and PSUs and corporates will be participating.

Devesh Patel, chairman of the SGCCI exhibition committee said, “Surat has emerged as the textile machinery manufacturing centre where the production of powerloom machines, yarn dyeing machines, texturizing machines etc. is taking place. We want to project Surat as the manufacturing hub of textile.”

Title: Force Motors invests Rs 1k cr over 4 yrs on new platform
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Pune: Commercial vehicle and engine maker Force Motors said it has invested Rs 1,000 crore over four years to develop an entirely new platform on which BS6 commercial vehicles and electric drive train will be based.

“The platforms have been built to enter more sophisticated markets, where the regulations are more stringent...the existing platforms will also continue,” said Force Motors chairman Abhay Firodia.

Force Motors MD Prasan Firodia said the company’s aspiration is to get significantly into global markets with this “modular platform” and bring more vehicles on the platform in the future. The vehicles will be launched on the platform by the end of the year, when the company said it will reveal the technical specifications and the pricing.

The company said that it will be targeting markets in Middle East, Africa, ASEAN and South America, besides India. “About four years ago, we put together a team of 150 engineers to work on an entirely new next-generation platform,” said Prasan Firodia.

The current slowdown in the automotive sector is temporary and should settle in another three quarters, said Abhay Firodia. He said that the sudden change from BS4 to BS6 regime, lack of financing options due to the NBFC crisis were the main reasons why customer interest was not getting converted into sales.

“I must admit that the government is doing a lot of things right but they should generally get out of business. For example, they should sell their stakes in the public sector banks and bring that money to help the industry prosper,” he added.

There will obviously be opposition, he said, from the trade unions and others who will try and protect their comfort zone. “But why should the government protect the non-performers,” he said, citing the example of Air India.

Title: Eloped couple’s audio call to a friend goes viral
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Surat: Ten days after the textile businessman and his son’s would-be mother-in-law eloped, a recording of an audio call they made to a common friend has gone viral on social media.

In the 17 minute audio recording, the couple is heard inquiring about the health of their families without any mention of their location whatsoever. In the audio clip, the couple is heard talking with the man’s two friends where he is heard saying that he has couriered a gift for his daughter from an undisclosed location and that he has also sent some money.

After the call, the businessman’s mobile phone, however, has been on the switch off mode. Family members of both sides now fear that the duo may take some extreme step after their audio call went viral.

The businessman was heard telling his friend that he had gone too far and there was no other option but to elope. “Nothing is clear what will happen next,” the businessman was heard saying, while his friends were heard trying to convince him to avoid taking any extreme step.

Meanwhile, a meeting of the community from which the couple belongs could not take place on Wednesday. A community member informed that the meeting called to discuss various community issues and not just the case of the runaway couple, will be held sometime in the near future. However, sources within the community informed that the meeting is likely to turn stormy over the ‘love’ issue.

Title: Smoke from inferno reeks of mischief
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

caption

Surat: From ‘how’ , the fire that is still not ‘under control’ at the Raghuvir Celeum textile market on Puna-Kumbhariya road, has turned into a ‘who’. While the exact cause of fire is still unclear, the needle of suspicion now points dangerously to some major human mischief.

Be that as it may, the Dakshin Gujarat Vij Company Limited (DGVCL) has categorically stated that the building had no power supply as it had been severed after the small incident of fire that was reported from the market on January 8.

Fire started at about 3am when the market was shut and without any presence of humans. Slowly it developed into an inferno and engulfed the entire market, even before the fire fighters could reach the spot and start their operation.

Managing director of DGVCL, Yogesh Choudhary told TOI, “Power supply was severed in the building after a small fire incident reported on January 8. Just two days ago, electrical engineer had visited the premises for internal wire checking and power was resumed for a short time only. Prima facie there was no power supply on the day when the fire took place.”

Choudhary further said that the discom is doing an MRI of the power supply of the entire area where the building is located. “ We will also do an MRI of electricity metres and transformers to know whether any sort of power was supplied to the building or not,” he said.

According to Choudhary, overloading in the transformer results in fire in the internal wiring of the premises when power is drawn illegally from anywhere. The DGVCL is also getting data of the power consumption pattern of the entire area to find out if there was any such overloading in the transformer.

“It is very easy to blame DGVCL, but when we have not supplied the power at all, how can it be responsible. Without power, there cannot be a short circuit. This building houses all types of materials that are highly inflammable. However, we will be able to ascertain facts only after the investigation is over. At present, the firemen are still working and we will be able to enter the building only after everything settles down,” Choudhary added.

A senior fire officer on condition of anonymity shared his suspicions with TOI. “Like many other small fires in textile segments, this fire too looks suspicious. We have witnessed large number of small and big fires where loss of life has not taken place, but results in heavy loss of material. The reason may be that the traders want to take benefit of the insurance claim. Interestingly, such fires have been witnessed every year for the past three years during the months of January, February and March,” he said.

Title: HC to hear broadcasters’ response to Trai on Jan 30
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Swati Deshpande | TNN

Mumbai: The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India ( Trai ) has informed the Bombay high court that its new tariff order of 2020 is “to ensure that an effective a la carte choice was available to distributors without being handicapped by the perverse pricing of bouquets by broadcasters at wholesale level”. The new order caps pay channel prices at Rs 12.

Television broadcasters had recently approached the HC to challenge the new Trai regulation. On Wednesday, after former attorney general of India Mukul Rohatgi, appearing for one of the broadcasters, sought time to file a rejoinder to the price curb justifications given by Trai, the HC adjourned to January 30.

Trai also sent 1,700 documents electronically, which need to be analysed, said Rohatgi before a bench of Justices S C Dharmadhikari and Riyaz Chagla. “We are challenging the constitutionality of the Trai action, which is absolutely arbitrary,” he said. And when the bench asked why a rejoinder is necessary, Janak Dwarkadas , counsel for one of the nine petitioners, said the authority has filed a 100-page reply that needs to be rejoined. The court was not keen on allowing an NGO, Telecom Watchdog, to intervene and told its counsel Raju Subramanian that the matter was in good hands. The Trai affidavit, filed through Dhir & Dhir Associates, said, “It was expected that broadcasters will consider consumer requirements and make bouquets of channels demanded by subscribers. However, analysis indicates that the freedom given to broadcasters has been misused.”

The Indian Broadcasting Foundation (IBF) and other broadcasters — including a films & TV producers’ guild, Sony Pictures, Star India, Zee, Disney India, Asianet and TV18 — had earlier this month challenged the Trai regulation. The new regulation requires channels in a bouquet to be priced no more than Rs 12, a drop from the current cap of Rs 19.

Trai, which said it is the “statutory and expert authority …to protect interest of telecom service providers, broadcasters and consumers”, contended that its decision is “lawful” and cannot be assailed “on the ground that it benefits some or hurts others”.

It said that the “focus of broadcasters has been to push as many channels into a bouquet rather than give a choice to consumers on a la carte basis”. The authority said the broadcasters’ practice “defeats the very purpose of the 2017 regulatory framework to protect the sacrosanct right of consumers to choose and pay for only those channels they want to watch as informed consumers”. “Even some free-to-air channels were converted to pay channels” to make them part of a bouquet and “pushed to consumers along with popular channels”, said Trai.

The regulator said the price cap is only to ensure consumers can easily access individual channels, in an a la carte mode, as was intended, and not just bouquets of channels offered by broadcasters. Trai cited a 2018 Supreme Court ruling, which said subscribers are forced to take bouquets if a la carte rates are higher.

The broadcasters’ foundation contended, “A prescription of ceiling of MRP of Rs 12 on a la carte channels forming part of a bouquet or for that matter, fixation of any ceiling… is an invasion in broadcaster’s right to enter into commercial contracts for exploitation of free speech.”

But the Trai affidavit said when in 2017 the framework was implemented with no cap on permissible discount on sum of a la carte channels in a bouquet, it was expected that the broadcasting industry would own more responsibility and price their channels accordingly. But Trai said its main concern is that the “uptake of channels on an a la carte basis still continued to be very low as compared to bouquet subscriptions” and attributes it to the “highly disproportionate a la carte rates of channels”.

It also said that the “twin conditions will not affect flexibility of broadcasters to form bouquets as the flexibility to decide MRP of channels and bouquets continue to rest with them”. It further said the bouquets comprise some popular and many non-popular channels, yet “some broadcasters have declared the MRP of their bouquet as equal to or even less” than that of a single channel in it.

Trai had set January 15 as deadline to publish new tariff, which would come into effect from March 1 this year. In its reply, it termed the claims of the broadcasters that it would be put to extreme hardship as it would need to sign thousands of agreements for publishing their new rates as “patently false”. The amendment in regulations only requires “change of certain rate card annexures to the main agreement”. “The (digital) ecosystem is quite efficient to adopt such changes,” said Trai.

Title: Saroli textile mart is another sitting bomb
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Fast emerging new textile hub has about 26 markets and 20,000 shops

Surat: If Saroli village , some 15km away from Surat city , on the Puna-Kumbhariya road doesn’t learn a quick lesson from Raghvir Textile market fire, it will prove to be another disaster waiting to happen.

In this fast emerging new textile hub, about 26 markets, housing more than 20,000 shops have come up, almost all of them built in the same design with huge front elevation using highly combustible material including aluminium.

Out of 26 markets here, 18 have been built after 2014 which have the same design fault that made fire fighters face serious problem in dousing the fire in Raghuvir market. Even high intensity water sprayers were not able to spray required amount of water inside the burning building due to the presence of this outer elevation that was added primarily to serve as an adornment.

According to fire officials, the heat generated from the burning of the elevation material goes up to 600 degrees, making it impossible for humans to enter the building. On the first day, no firemen could try to enter the building — they could only after hours of fighting late at night — as flames kept bursting from all the directions.

According to Naresh Agarwal, spokesman for the CREDAI Surat and Saroli builders’ association, Saroli is the new extension for the textile market in Ring Road. The idea behind developing Saroli was to decongest areas like Ring Road, Salabatpura and Sahara Darwaja, which houses more than 165 textile markets. However, the principle of safety first has been neglected in many buildings. He also agreed that the elevations are made up of cheap aluminium sheets, pipes and glass are only for the purpose of adornment.

Agarwal further said that the builders association is ready to make any alterations suggested by the authority concerned and also follow the principle of safety first at all work places. “Such cheap combustible material not only catches fire easily and helps spread rapidly. People have used such materials only for cost-cutting, flouting the rule book. Even the internal design in some of the buildings are faulty,” he added.

Devkishan Manghani, chairman of Southern Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry’s (SGCCI) textile committee said, “After the major Orchid textile market fire in 2014, Raghuvir textile market fire is the biggest one in the history. This has shaken the textile traders community at large. Goods worth crores of rupees have been burnt to ashes. If only there wasn’t the outer elevation, the market could have been saved.”

Title: Kolkata gets second Park Circus, in Ekbalpore
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The protesters in Ekbalpore on Wednesday

By: Biplab Mondal

KOLKATA: Over a hundred women, including homemakers, professionals and students, are staging a sit-in in Nawab Ali Park in Ekbalpore for the past four days, demanding a rollback of CAA and NRC. The women fasted on Wednesday morning hoping for a Supreme Court intervention and broke their fast in the evening with a promise to carry on their protests till the apex court decides on the issue.

Shakil Akhtar, a 66-year-old medical practitioner, and one of the primary organizers, said, “We were born in this country. We have been voting in the elections for the past several years. Kolkata has always been home to all religions and thoughts. So why has this law been passed? This must be reconsidered,” Akhtar said, adding that the collective angst of the people is being reflected in the Nawab Ali Park protest. “We condemn this law and will continue our protests,” said Akhtar, who is the IMA’s Kidderpore branch secretary.

Social worker Shaukat Ali Siddiqui said, “The Saheen Bagh protest has encouraged us to take a stand. For many, it is now or never. The protesters here are from every faith and everyone is welcome here. Women are leading the protests and this will continue till the apex court decides on the issue. People from all walks of life have joined our demonstration. This law is ultimately going to harm everybody. The protests will continue.”

Iqra Siddiqui, a medical student, joined the protesters on Wednesday. “The politics over religion by the ruling party in the Centre should be condemned. India has always been about inclusiveness,” she said.

Title: Bihar: Drugstore owners call off strike on govt assurance
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The Bihar Chemist and Druggists Association called off their strike late Wednesday evening after health minister Mangal Pandey and principal secretary (health) Sanjay Kumar assured them to look into their demands.

Earlier, srugstores in the city remained closed as the association had called three-day statewide strike from Wednesday. The association accused the drug inspectors of harassing the medicine shop owners in the name of inspection and cancelling their licences on minor issues.

Association president PK Singh said, “The problem of pharmacists is not new as there are just four pharmacy colleges in Bihar. The state government knows about the shortage of pharmacists. So, the government should relax the rules and allow one pharmacist to handle at least ten drugstores.” earlier, Singh staged a dharna on Govind Mitra Road.

Association member Tarun Kumar said they had exempted drugstores at government and private hospitals. However, that was not enough as many people could not get medicines they needed from the hospital stores. Sexagenarian Sahdeo Pandey was waiting in a queue outside the medicine store at Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) to purchase medicines for his wife Phulwanti Devi, who was suffering from arthritis and chest problem. Of total 11 medicines prescribed by the doctor there, Sahdeo got only three. “I do not know where to go now. All the shops outside are closed,” he said.

A pharmacist at PMCH, Sitesh Kumar, said the number of buyers had increased by 20%. “Few people are also coming with the prescription of some private doctors,” he said.

Title: tata nexon ev: We would like to promote electric as a mainstream solution: TaMo
Content:
File photo

Will all Tata Motors vehicles now also have an electric variant? Is that part of the plan?

What other spin offs will you offer from the Omega architecture?

As part of your cost control measures, you have shut down your Thailand subsidiary. Will other overseas subsidiaries also face the axe? What about Tata Daewoo for instance which is facing headwinds in Korea?

Are you capping your investment plans to ride out the slowdown?

CHENNAI: With Altroz and its new BS6 ready passenger vehicle range, Tata Motors is readying itself to ride out the slowdown and the transition to BS6 smoothly. In a chat, Guenter Butschek, CEO & MD, Tata Motors, talks about electric plans, cost cutting and more. Excerpts:Not yet. In principle all future launches will provide an EV option. We already are offering a Tigor EV, a Nexon EV and an Altroz EV. All the new products based on the Alfa architecture will provide an electric variant. As for the Omega architecture, this too is battery electric protected. We had in fact debuted a concept in Geneva 2018 that was based on Omega architecture. So it’s technically feasible but not commercially viable. We would like to promote electric as a mainstream solution. The sweet spot in India to accelerate the adoption of EV is the segment below or just above 4 metres.Harrier has done well and December in fact was the best ever month for the model in retail and wholesale. The Harrier upgrade will be presented in the Auto Expo. Like the others, the BS6 version will be packed with other features including automatic transmission and a sunroof. Harrier is a flagship product and needs its own space. But there is a 7-seater variant on the Omega architecture which is in the making which will be launched in the market soon. There will be more products in 3-5 years to improve market reach. The two new architectures will have 12-14 products, taking our market coverage to 90%. We are looking at a larger share of the upper end of the market coverage.We took a call on our subsidiaries like Thailand. As for Tata Daewoo Commercial Vehicle, yes the economic environment in Korea is very tough. Medium heavy trucks have declined, competition brisk but Tata Daewoo is in strong recovery mode. It is a strong performing asset which complements Tata Motors truck range in medium and heavy duty segments.The last 9 months has demanded strong focus on cash management. We are focusing on receivables but also on spend. There is serious review going on and we are controlling not cutting our spend. The adjustment is to keep control on our cash because cash is king in difficult situations.

Title: Bihar: Futab demands 15 months’ arrears denied by education department
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Hailing the state cabinet’s decision to pay the arrears of 7th Pay Commission to the teachers of colleges and universities in state without waiting for reimbursement of 50% share from the University Grants Commission (UGC), the Federation of University Teachers ’ Associations of Bihar (Futab) has thanked both chief minister Nitish Kumar and his deputy Sushil Kumar Modi .

Futab’s working president Kanhaiya Bahadur Singh and general secretary Sanjay Kumar Singh have, however, drawn the attention of the state education department towards denial of arrears payment for 15 months from January 1, 2016 to March 31, 2017 without any reason.

They pointed out that the revised UGC payscale has been implemented all over the country with effect from January 2016 and the central government has also agreed to reimburse the 50% of the difference of arrears with effect from January 2016 itself. Then, there is no justification in withholding payment of arrears difference for 15 months, they said.
