Title: This miraculous ‘kalembi’ spurred practice of mass feeding of devotees
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mangaluru: When Yaduveer Krishnadatta Chamaraja Wadiyar, scion of the Mysuru royal family, joined dignitaries at ugrana muhurtha in pouring foodgrains into a wooden storage box to mark the start of the 13-day Brahmakalashotsava rituals at Sri Durgaparameshwari Temple at Kateel near here on Wednesday, he revered a temple relic. This box, referred to as ‘ kalembi ,’ survived a devastating flood that threatened to destroy the temple town on July 28, 1944.

Narrating the tale of the ‘kalembi’ that is valued by the temple and its devotees, Harinaryana Asranna, hereditary priest, told TOI that the raging waters of the Nandini river almost threatened to destroy the temple on that fateful day in 1944. When the river was sweeping away everything in the temple, including this box and other boxes used by the temple’s Yakshagana troupes, it was my uncle Gopalkrishna Asranna who prayed to the deity to spare the town, he said.

When the waters rose, Gopalkrishna held on to the idol of the deity in the sanctum sanctorum tightly, and said a prayer that if the idol got washed away, he too would prefer to get washed away with it. It was then that a miracle happened, when a large boulder that was brought by the water, rested against the outer walls of the sanctorum, and forked the water away sparing the sanctorum and the idol of the deity from any damage, Harinarayana Asranna said.

The water that forked due to the boulder also created a whirlpool at the dhwajasthamba where this kalembi and other boxes got stuck, he said. Devotees used to pour their donation of foodgrains into this kalembi, and after these floods, the temple received foodgrains in ample measure, helping it start and sustain mass feeding of devotees, he said. This kalembi is stored in the folk-art exhibit museum at the nearby PU college, he said.

Title: Select panel to decide Andhra Pradesh capital Bill fate
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

N Chandrababu Naidu arrives in Mandadam village on Wednesday after council chairman sent the capital Bills ... Read More AMARAVATI: In a major setback to the YS Jaganmohan Reddy government, Legislative Council chairman MA Shariff on Wednesday decided to refer the Bills on three capital cities and abolition of APCRDA to a select committee. This in effect means the state government cannot go ahead with its plan to create three capital cities for Andhra Pradesh pending submission of report by the select committee. The panel will have three months at its disposal to submit the report. In a cliffhanger that left the entire treasury benches in a state of shock, the Council chairman declared that he had taken the decision with his discretionary powers. The chairman’s decision is likely to delay the entire procedure related to the trifurcation of the capital city and abolishment of the capital region development authority. The panel will now go deep into the Bills and submit its report. Opposition TDP, which has a majority in the Council, scored over its bitter rival YSRC by insisting that the Bills be referred to select panel. TDP, which had been confident of outsmarting the YSRC in the Council, ensured its strategy worked well. TDP supremo and former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu stayed right in the Council gallery for over three hours to oversee the implementation of the strategy. Stumped by the chairman’s decision, ministers and YSRC legislators raised slogans and created ruckus in the Council. Earlier in the day, the Council chairman adjourned the session several times to discuss the issue with both leaders of TDP and YSRCP. Although, TDP members were upset when Shariff announced that the notice on select committee issue was not technically moved before the Bills were taken up for discussion, they continued pressure on the chairman saying that technical issues should not be taken into consideration. Opposition leader Yanamala Ramakrishnudu said the chairman had to accept the demand of the majority of the House. He insisted that the Bills should be sent to the select committee. He said the chairman could go for voting to find out the mood of the House in order to send the Bills to the select committee. He demanded that some of the ministers, who are not members of the House, should be sent out from the Council before taking up voting. Finance minister Buggana Rajendranath contended that there was no need for Bills to be sent to the select committee. He said that the Council chairman had no authority to refer the Bills to the select committee as per the business rules. He said that the decentralization Bill was intended to take governance to the doorsteps of people and develop all regions. He said that zonal developmental boards would help accelerate the development in all the regions. “Chair had not accepted any notice regarding sending Bills to the select committee while taking up the Bills for discussion. There is no point in raising the issue in the middle,” argued Buggana. Municipal administration minister Botsa Satyanarayana said that they have explained the rule position to the chairman on referring the Bills to the select committee. He said that Bills should not be referred to the select committee after taking up for discussion. TDP members contended that they had served the notice on sending the Bills to the select committee on Tuesday itself. Ramakrishnudu said that they had submitted the notice to the chairman before he agreed to take up the Bills for discussion. He insisted that the Bills should be sent to the select committee for the scrutiny. Meanwhile, the government summoned advocate-general Sriram Subramanyam to the Council to explain the rule position to the chairman. During the debate, BJP member Somu Veerraju lashed out at TDP for ruining the state with ‘irresponsible governance’. He said that Chandrababu Naidu had ditched the farmers of the capital city by showing graphic images. He welcomed the state government’s decision to relocate the High Court to Kurnool. He said that BJP was the first political party to raise the demand for setting up of High Court in Rayalaseema. He said BJP would support the state government’s plans to decentralize the developmental activities. Veerraju said that the government should do justice to the farmers, who voluntarily gave their lands for the capital city construction. PDF legislators KS Lakshman Rao and Katti Narasimha Reddy wanted that the capital city to be retained in Amaravati.

Title: Protests continue, bandh call elicits mixed response in Guntur
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The villagers said they will continue protests till the government withdraws its decision.

GUNTUR: The bandh called by Amaravati Joint Action Committee (JAC) to protest the shifting of the capital evoked mixed response in Guntur district on Wednesday.

Although the bandh was observed in the capital city villages, it had little impact in Guntur city. Police deployed additional forces at key junctions and warned of serious consequences if protestors tried to create trouble.

While several educational institutions declared holiday extending solidarity to the cause, a majority of the shops and establishments remained open and government offices and banks functioned as usual. Bus services plied without any disruption. Tension, however, prevailed for a while when TDP cadre clashed with the police during the bandh. A scuffle broke out when the police prevented TDP workers from stopping school buses. Reacting to it, a TDP worker pulled the shirt of inspector Sitharamaiah prompting the police to lathicharge. Meanwhile, a group of TDP cadre led by constituency in-charge Kovelamudi Ravindra (Nani) held a rally in Guntur West constituency demanding the continuance of Amaravati as the state capital. Nani appealed to all traders and merchants to extend their support by closing down shops. He said if only Amaravati continues as the capital then Guntur city would get additional funds for development. He said Amaravati was not only the capital city of the state but also the pride of Andhra Pradesh.

In another part of the city, police arrested TDP cadre led by party district unit president GVSSR Anjaneyulu and Mannava Subbarao.

Meanwhile, villagers in the capital city area criticised the police for taking local schools into their control to take shelter. The villagers said they will continue protests till the government withdraws its decision. They demanded that Jaganmohan Reddy should quit as chief minister for deceiving them.

Title: HR&CE department demands Rs 450 crore rental dues for court complex
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

TIRUPUR: The Hindu religious and charitable endowments (HR&CE) department has issued a notice demanding Rs 450 crore as rental dues for the Kangeyam Combined Court Complex.

The notice, issued by Kangeyam HR&CE assistant commissioner Kannadasan , irked the judiciary, which shot back stating that the land housing the court complex does not belong to the department.

It all started when the court administration wrote a letter to the department, seeking 10 acres near the Sivanmalai Temple to construct residential quarters for judges. Replying to the letter, Kannadasan said in his correspondence dated October 9, 2019, that the request cannot be acceded since there were rental dues pending for the court complex land. “The land on which the Kangeyam court complex stands belongs to the department. But the judiciary has failed to pay rent for it” he said.

Shocked over the claim, the principal district judge S Alli sought a detailed explanation. Kannadasan wrote back stating that Rs 450 crore was pending as rental due between July 14, 2012 and December 31, 2019.

The judge summoned land documents and held an inquiry with revenue and HR&CE officials and said Kannadasan was wrong.

Inquiries revealed that the .020 hectare land housing the court complex was owned by C Kumarappa Gounder and Thulasi Naicker till 1932, when the government acquired it. In 1999, a government order was passed allotting the land to the judicial and agriculture department. Subsequently, the land was given to the district sessions court.

When contacted, Kannadasan stood his ground and said that he was right in issuing the notice. But he said he does not have enough records to prove that the land belongs to the HR&CE department.

Meanwhile, senior HR&CE officials expressed embarrassment over the incident. “I don’t know why Kannadasan wrote such a letter without having any records. The department will conduct an inquiry into the issue,” a senior officer told TOI.

Title: Hit by iron girder, one dead, 7 injured
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Allahabad: One died and seven others were injured when a group of pilgrims sitting atop a bus collided with the iron girder of a railway crossing near CMP Dott Bridge under Georgetown police station on Wednesday morning.

The deceased has been identified as Sushil Kumar (40), resident of Bahraich.

The injured pilgrims were identified as Mukesh (35), Jawahar (55), Vineet (30), Akash (17), Suraj (22), Guddu (40) and Ramu (45)

Allahabad SSP Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said that the incident took place when a bus carrying around 35 pilgrims including women and children, was moving towards mela area from Phaphamau.

He added that the pilgrims had reached Allahabad from Bahraich on Tuesday night. The bus took a halt near Phaphamau for breakfast on Wednesday morning.

At Phaphamau, a group of pilgrims climbed and sat atop the bus. When the bus reached the railway crossing near CMP Dott Bridge, the iron girder hit them, leaving one dead and seven others injured.

The driver of the bus the scene soon after the incident.

The injured were taken to SRN hospital for treatment.

Upon being alerted, senior police official and administrative officials reached the spot and took stock of the situation at the hospital.

Title: The magic of ‘Yeh Mausam Ka Jadoo...’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: Audience relived their memories of old and famous Hindi-Marathi songs at a musical programme titled as ‘Yeh Mausam Ka Jadoo Hain Mitva’ on Wednesday. The programme was made special by the presence of well-known composer Raam Laxman who was felicitated for his contribution to the music industry.

The programme, organized by Harmony Events at Suresh Bhat Hall, witnessed presentation of 24 enjoyable songs. The show commenced with ‘Deva ho deva and Anjaneechya suta’, presented by Mukul Pande, followed by ‘Dil deewana’ by Manisha Nischal, ‘Pehla pehla pyaar’ by Prasan Nayar and so on.

Anchor Shweta Shelgaonkar gave interesting description of the songs and also poetically appreciated the performers.

Other singers who performed included Akansha Nagarkar, Prashant Valivkar, Uma Raghuraman, Hemant Darvekar, Sagar Madhumatke, Gauri Shinde and Prithvi Ingale.

Singles like ‘Sun dilruba’ from the movie ‘Patthar Ke Phool’ by Hemant, ‘Mere rang mein’ from ‘Maine Pyar Kiya’ by Sagar, ‘Yeh toh sach hai ke bhagwaan’ from ‘Hum Saath Saath Hain’ by Prithvi and many others entertained the audience.

The audience also appreciated duets like ‘Tum kya mile jaane ja’ by Mukul and Akansha, ‘Dil de ke dard mohabbat’ by Prasan and Gauri, ‘Yeh mausam ka jadoo hain mitva’ and ‘Hum tum dono saath mein’ by Hemant and Uma, ‘Aaja shaam hone aayi’ by Sagar and Akansha, ‘Didi tera devar deewana’ by Prasan and Manisha and so on.

Marathi songs like ‘Aayi majhya lagnachi ga’, ‘Jhalya tinhi saanja’, ‘Dholkichya talavar’, ‘Bai ga kelewali mi’ and ‘Dhagala laagli’ also entertained the audience. ‘Jeevan gaane gaatach rahave’, the concluding song of the programme, was presented by the entire group.

The programme was conceptualized and organized by Rajesh Samarth.

Title: Doing Veeru of Sholay, PhD aspirant climbs atop BU water tank
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The PhD aspirant came down after six hours

Bhopal: A high voltage drama continued for six hours at Barkatullah University on Wednesday as a Ph.D aspirant climbed on top of water tank to stage his protest. He alleged that an ineligible candidate was given permission to pursue research, while he was not considered. In 2016 too, some students of the university had done the same act to voice their demands.

Ph.D candidate Pankaj Bhargava climbed the water tank on the university campus at 10 am. He said, "I have been writing and discussing the issue with higher authorities of the university for the last one and a half months about the ongoing fraud in Ph.D admissions, but no action was taken by the university administration. Eventually I had to resort to this act to raise my voice.”

He added, "I has appeared in the Ph.D entrance test last year in physical education. My name was on the first place in the wait-list. After a few candidates did not turn up, BU should have given me the opportunity. Instead, BU gave permission to pursue Ph.D to a person, who did not submit the ‘no objection certificate,” said Bhargava.

He further said, "My demand is that BU should release the wait-list at the earliest." Bhargava climbed down from water tank around 4 pm after the vice chancellor issued a written order assuring the candidate that wait-list of the subject would be issued soon. Members of municipal corporation, SDRF and police personnel were present when the incident happened.

Registrar B Bharti issued the order to form a three-member high-level committee to look into the fraud allegations made by Bhargava. He also directed the departments to issue the wait-list immediately. All the Ph.D candidates serving in government and non-government departments have been asked to obtain a ‘no objection certificate’ which is mandatory. Bharti said, "We are looking into the allegations levelled by Bhargava. However, no one is allowed to disturb the academics of the university by such acts. We will do our work as per the rules and regulations. His name was not on the merit list; and figuring on the wait-list does not make anyone eligible for Ph.D. If his claim is correct, justice would be done in the case. Else, legal action would be taken against him."

Title: IIIT-A sets up educational camp in mela
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Allahabad: At a time when the ongoing Magh Mela has proved to be a platform for achieving solace and moksha, the religious fair has also provided an opportunity to various institutions of higher learning to impart knowledge among people.

Among these institutions is the Indian Institute of Information Technology, Allahabad (IIIT-A) which opened a month long awareness camp to popularise the benefits of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) among the farmers and rural population to avail the benefits of various government schemes, on Wednesday.

The camp, supported by National Council for Science and Technology Communication of the Department of Science and Technology (DST), New Delhi was inaugurated by director of IIIT-A, Prof P Nagabhushan. The main objectives of the camp is to interact with the rural population especially farmers with the aim of understanding the difficulties faced by them and apprise them about the suitable ICT.

The camp would create awareness about the convenience and benefits of various ICT platforms like eNAM, mkisan, umang, BHIM UPI, Ayushman Bharat, Sukanya Samridhi Yojna, NABARD, fertilizer subsidy etc. to masses in general and farmers in particular by preparing and distributing information brochures in Hindi and English.

In addition to this, UP Rajshri Tandon Open University, the lone open university of the state, have also opened its camp at the Magh Mela area.

Title: Nashik corporators fume over defunct streetlights
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representational Image



NASHIK: Local corpoators of the Trimbak Road area have expressed their anguish about the defunct streetlights along the Trimbak road in Satpur division of the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ).

The corporators said that the streetlights were not repaired even after reporting the issue to the electricity department of the municipal corporation.

Responding to the corporators, civic officials said that they were unable to carry out the repair work of streetlights due to lack of hydraulic vehicle lifts.

The mayor has also directed the officials to look into the issue and ensure that the defunct streetlights are repaired at the earliest.

“There are a number of streetlights along the Trimbak road. Lakhs of warkaris go to Trimbakeshwar in January to seek blessings of Saint Nivruttinath Maharaj and pass through the Timbak road. Therefore, I had approached the electric department of the NMC, urging them to repair defunct streetlights in the area, but in vain,” said corporator Seema Nigol.

“I had approached the officials from electric department several times; however, they did not take cognizance of the issue. They should be serious about the problem in view of the dindi of Nivruttinath Maharaj to Trimbakeshwar,” added Nigol.

Besides nigol, corporator Salim Shaikh, too, complained about the defunct streetlights in the area.

“Most streetlights in the Satpur area of the city are defunct. Moreover, there are many areas where there is a dire need of streetlights. Some electric poles have been damaged. The civic administration needs to conduct a survey in this regard and ensure that there are no defunct streetlights in any part of the city,” said Shaikh.

Vilas Shinde, Dinkar Patil, and other corporators also reiterated the same.

“We have already provided a vehicle for each ward, but the electric poles are taller in the Trimbak road area and we have only one vehicle to carry out maintenance work up to that height. Also, the vehicle was not available at the time due to which the work got delayed. But, the defunct streetlights will be repaired shortly,” an official from electric department of the municipal corporation said.

Title: HC refuses to hear PIL against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: Refusing to hear petition challenging Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Wednesday granted liberty to the petitioner to approach Supreme Court which is hearing over 100 petitions on the same issue.

The public interest litigation (PIL) was listed before a division bench comprising Justice Ravi Deshpande and Justice Amit Borkar.

“Assistant solicitor general and additional government pleader have brought to our notice that about 100 petitions have been filed before the apex court challenging the validity of the CAA, which is the subject matter of the challenge in the present writ. All such matters are being heard by the apex court. In view of this, on the ground of propriety, we refuse to entertain this PIL,” the bench said.

Petitioner Urmila Kowe from Bhandara had filed the PIL through counsel Ashwin Ingole stating that she was espousing the cause of the citizens of India, who are not in a position to arrange for the necessary documents in support of their citizenship.

According to her, the CAA is a colourable legislation that violated the secular nature of the Constitution. “It’s discriminatory and violates the basic structure of the Constitution of India,” said Kowe.

She further contended that CAA is class legislation harping on religious identity of an individual. It also contravened the principles of secularism which have been recognized by the apex court in many cases. “The controversial amendment to the Citizenship Act manifestly and arbitrarily violates the fundamental rights enshrined in the statute,” she said.

Kowe argued that the amendment covered only a class of minorities from specific countries sharing borders with India from where there has been trans-border migration and it overlooked other reportedly persecuted religious minorities.

“The legislation also doesn’t cover ethnic and linguistic issues of Tamils of Sri Lanka and that the Act is in contravention of India’s international obligations under Article 14 and 15 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, to which the country is a signatory,” she said.

(With inputs from Sakina Dawood)

What HC said:

* About 100 petitions filed before SC challenging CAA

* Same is subject matter of challenge in PIL filed by petitioner

* All such matters are being heard by apex court currently

* Refuse to entertain this PIL on ground of propriety

* Petitioner at liberty to approach SC

Title: DMK, AIADMK cadres clash at panchayat union council meet
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Thanjavur: Tension prevailed at the Kumbakonam panchayat union council office here on Wednesday after a clash broke out between the elected local body members of the DMK and AIADMK when the council met for the first time. The incident began when the AIADMK members objected to a resolution adopted by the DMK members thanking DMK president M K Stalin for the victory in the local body elections.

For the first meeting of the panchayat union council, 18 DMK members including vice-chairman of panchayat union council T Ganesan, seven AIADMK members and two independent members were present.

The meeting was chaired by council chairman Gayathri. Commissioner Poonguzhali also attended the meeting.

A few resolutions were read out at the meeting, which were passed by Poonguzhali. However, the AIADMK members raised questions about the resolutions leading to a commotion. On hearing the noise, supporters of both parties tried to barge into the meeting hall. However, office-bearers and police prevented them from entering the hall. Both party cadres raised slogans slamming each other.

In the ruckus the glass panels of Poonghuzhali's cabin were broken. Following this, a large posse of police was deployed there. The DMK members demanded action against those who broke the glass panels.

On information, Kumbakonam DSP rushed to the spot and held talks with both party members and cadres. Poonguzhali lodged a complaint with the Nachiarkoil police demanding action against those who damaged the glass panels.

Mayiladuthurai DMK MP S Ramalingam, Kumbakonam DMK MLA Sakottai G Anbalagan and district panchayat council vice-chairman K Muthuselvan participated in the meet as special invitees.

Title: New excise policy will uncork 500 liquor subshops in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: The new excise policy of the Congress government for 2019-20, finalized on January 6, will lead to the opening of 500 liquor subshops in Madhya Pradesh .

A liquor subshop is a sales counter that can be opened by a liquor licence holder if the distance between two regular shops is 5km or more in urban areas and 10km or more in rural areas.

There are around 3,600 liquor shops in the state, with the state expecting a revenue of Rs 13,000 crore this fiscal. Going by the collections so far, it’s unlikely to meet the target and may fall short by Rs 1,500 to Rs 2,000 crore, say sources.

As per initial estimates of the excise department, if 500 subshops are opened, it could yield an additional revenue of around Rs 2,000 crore. Liquor contractors don’t have to wait till the next fiscal to open subshops, but it is unlikely anyone would be willing to do so in the two months left. It may not be financially viable for them this fiscal to recover the subshop licence fee.

For a regular liquor shop valued/auctioned at Rs 2 crore per year, a licence holder needs to pay an additional 15% to open a subshop — or Rs 30 lakh. For liquor shops valued between Rs 2 crore and Rs 5 core, a subshop will cost 15% for the first Rs 2 crore and 10% of the remaining amount. Those owning liquor shops valued at over Rs 5 crore will need to pay the government 15% for the first Rs 2 crore, 10% for the next Rs 3 crore, and 5% of what’s left.

MP excise commissioner Rajesh Bahuguna explained that a liquor subshop must not be misinterpreted as a new liquor shop. “It is just extension of sale counter between two liquor shops in a prescribed gap. How many subshops will be opened depends on how many liquor contractors want to do so. We have an initial estimate, but things will get clear once new liquor shop licences are allotted,” he said. Opening a subshop is not mandatory for a liquor contractor, officials say.

Permission to open subshops has kicked up a political tussle between opposition BJP and ruling Congress. BJP has claimed that the new policy will turn the state into ‘Madira Pradesh’ while Congress justifies the new rule by saying it will prevent adulteration of liquor. Congress has asked BJP why it couldn’t ban liquor in MP in its 15-year rule and why over 890 liquor shops opened in Shivraj Singh Chouhan ’s tenure as CM.

Title: Land woes: Kateel temple may adopt ‘bhudhana’ model
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mangaluru: The 13-day Brahmakalashotsava rituals of Goddess Durgaparameshwari that got under way at Sri Kshetra Kateel on Wednesday will be showcased as a model to the other temples in the state, said Nalin Kumar Kateel , president, Brahmakalashotsava Committee. When the rituals were held in 2007, the committee had taken up a few initiatives that have materialised in the intervening 12 years, and the same will be emulated during this year’s rituals, he said.

Addressing the media at Kateel, Nalin Kumar said a major initiative planned for this Brahmakalashotsava is to create a land bank for the temple. “We are seriously handicapped by a shortage of land to take up various development works for this ‘A’ grade endowment temple. We are striving to overcome this with donors purchasing parcels of land abutting the temple from owners, and donate it to the temple,” he said.

Under this ‘ bhudhana ’ (land donation) concept, a donor will pay around Rs1 lakh per cent of land to the owner, and this will be entrusted to the temple. The temple management committee on its part had also purchased land from landowners to facilitate widening of the ratha beedhi in front of the temple and reduce congestion there. The long winding legal battle to clear shops on either side of the temple’s main entrance too has borne fruit, he said.

While most such shopowners have voluntarily given up their rights to the shops, others had engaged the temple in a protracted legal battle, Nalin said, adding the remaining shops too will be cleared once the Brahmakalashotsava rituals are over. This was one of the reasons why some of the development works planned in the run up to this mega religious ritual held once every 12 years as per agama shastra were delayed and are still going on, Nalin noted.

The temple authorities also demolished the Saraswati Mandir in front of the temple that it owned, to make way for a makeshift ‘ugrana’ or kitchen store, the MP said. Underscoring the need for this initiative, Nalin said the guests and families that poured into the temple town on days considered auspicious for marriage, was such that it outscored the devotees that would come to the temple for the annual temple festivals where the rush is unmanageable.

On the infrastructure side, Nalin said widening of roads leading to the temple town has facilitated devotees to reach it with ease. The roads widened include the road from Ullanje to Kinnigoli and Arasulepadavu to Devaragudde that leads to Nellitheertha. The road from Moorukaveri to Permude has been widened at a cost of Rs 10 crore and a 3.5km long bypass road abutting the temple town was constructed to avoid the narrow road in front of the temple, Nalin added.

Title: Farmers celebrate as bills stalled
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Amaravati: Farmers in the capital city region danced in joy late on Wednesday night after the legislative council chairman referred the bill to the select committee. They s burst crackers and held a rally in Mandadam and raised slogans ‘Save Amaravati’. Women said god has answered their prayers. tnn

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Congress strives to connect with youth
Content:
Rahul and Priyanka will try to strike a chord with people

NEW DELHI: While ground-level Congress workers continue to go door-to-door, organise corner meetings, padyatras and participate in big rallies, the party’s social media team is taking the campaign to a different level.Realising that smartphones are the biggest source of information, Congress has unleashed a huge social media campaign to make people “aware” about the “failure” of the BJP and AAP governments at the Centre and state, respectively, and share its vision for Delhi.After successive defeats in the last two assembly elections, this time it is a battle for survival for the grand old party in Delhi. Congress, therefore, has adopted all possible means to outshine the other two players in the fray. “There can be no political campaign in Delhi without social media. It is our major weapon this time,” said Subhash Chopra, Delhi Congress chief.In the past few days, the social media team stationed in the control room at the state headquarters has produced interesting content — videos, photos and memes — and circulated it on Twitter, Facebook and WhatsApp. The team has also ensured it reaches every single person connected with the party in the city.“We have thousands of people connected on several WhatsApp groups. These groups are active at parliamentary constituency, assembly segment and ward levels. The content circulated goes through various channels and reaches the ground-level,” said Rahul Sharma, state coordinator, Delhi Congress’ social media cell.The Facebook pages of various frontal organisations — Youth and Mahila Congress and NSUI — are also connected with the control room and help forward the posts received from the top.Congress has involved youngsters for ground-level campaigning. “The youth have a better capacity to connect with people and convince them on the legacy of the party, the work it has done and how no development has taken place in six years,” said Jitender Kochar, Delhi Congress spokesperson.On Wednesday, Delhi Congress campaign committee held a meeting to decide on the programmes of senior party leaders and public meetings they would address. The party also released a list of star campaigners, including interim president Sonia Gandhi, former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, Rahul Gandhi, AICC general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, chief ministers of Congress-governed states and almost all senior leaders and functionaries. “We are finalising the rallies and roadshows where our leaders will participate,” Chopra said.

Title: Rs825cr fake purchases used to claim Rs148cr GST input credit
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: An investigation conducted by the Directorate General of GST Intelligence’s (DGGSTI) Nagpur zonal unit has uncovered rampant practice of availing fraudulent input tax credit (ITC), by issuing fake e-way bills. This is in line with similar cases found in other states too.

A search conducted into the accounts of 58 business firms showed that fake purchases worth Rs825 crore were recorded to claim ITC to the tune of Rs148 crore. It was found that 10,000 fake invoices were issued to avail the ITC. The tax sleuths have arrested four persons in the case. Some of the accused are absconding, said a press release issued by the DGGSTI. The sleuths conducted searches at 75 places in this case.

ITC is a crucial component in an indirect tax system like GST. This is a proportionate reduction available in the tax liability for the levy that has been paid at the time of purchase of inputs. For example, the tax paid at the time of buying raw material is deducted while calculating GST on the final product. This is done to prevent cascading effect of tax.

The tax sleuths scrutinized each of the e-way bills to detect the fraud. It was found that the vehicle numbers mentioned in the e-way bills were merely two or three-wheelers in many of the cases. An e-way bill is proof of transport of goods from the seller to buyer’s end. The transaction cannot be validated without an e-way bill.

In order to record fake purchases in the returns and claim ITC, fake e-way bills were issued. There was no transit of goods but to validate the claim fake invoices had to be generated, said the source. The vehicle numbers were of automobiles that were not meant for commercial transport. The registration numbers of random vehicles were quoted in the e-way bills, said a source. In a large number of cases the vehicles did not even exist, the source said.

This is part of a quarterly investigation carried out by the DGGSTI. The figures are expected to further increase as the probe proceeds further.

Title: CM Kamal Nath, Jyotiraditya Scindia in Congress list of star campaigners for Delhi polls
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

CM Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath and senior Congress leader Jyotiraditya Scindia are the two leaders from Madhya Pradesh in the AICC’s list of star campaigners for the Delhi assembly elections. The AICC on Tuesday sent a list of 40 names as the party star campaigners for the assembly polls to the Election Commission.

The list from Congress leader KC Venugopal to the secretary, Election Commission of India, said, “The following leaders of Indian National Congress, who would be campaigning as per section 77 (1) of the Representation of People Act 1951, for the ensuing general election to the Legislative Assembly of NCT of Delhi – 2020.

Apart from AICC president Sonia Gandhi, the other names are former Congress national president Rahul Gandhi, former PM Manmohan Singh, party national general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, Ghulam Nabi Azad, PC Chacko, Delhi PCC chief Subhash Chopra, chief ministers Amrinder Singh, Ashok Gehlot , Kamal Nath, Bhupesh Baghel. Other leaders in the list are Ajay Maken, V Narayanasamy, JP Agarwal, former Lok sabha speaker Meira Kumar , Kapil Sibal, Raj Babbar, Shashi Tharoor, Harish Rawat, Bhupinder Singh Hooda, Shatrighan Sinha, Navjot Singh Siddhu, Jyotiraditya Scindia, Sachin Pilot, Randeep Surjewala, Kirti Azad and National Mahila Congress chief Susmita Dev.

Title: Allahabad: Woman gives birth in train, TTE plays good Samaritan
Content:
The woman was going to her in-laws’ place in Pratapgarh

TTE Manoj Kumar was informed that a 30-year-old pregnant passenger, Manisha Nisha, was travelling to Allahabad

ALLAHABAD: A pregnant woman delivered a baby girl onboard New Delhi-Dibrugarh Brahmaputra Express on Wednesday.According to PRO, North Central Railway ( Allahabad division ), TTE Manoj Kumar was informed that a 30-year-old pregnant passenger, Manisha Nisha, was travelling to Allahabad.She was going to her in-laws’ place in Pratapgarh.“At 8.30am, Kumar was informed that Nisha had gone into labour pain. He informed commercial control office at Kanpur and requested for a doctor at the station,” the PRO said.However, before the train could reach Kanpur, her condition started deteriorating. The TTE searched in the train and found a passenger who was trained in carrying out deliveries.“We had some anxious moments as I had requested the control room to keep the train moving despite fog as it would give courage to the woman,” Kumar told TOI.On reaching Kanpur, doctors immediately attended to the mother and the newly-born was found in sound health. After administering requisite treatment to the mother and the newborn, the family decided to proceed for Pratapgrah by private ambulance.“Both the mother and the baby are healthy. We are thankful to the TTE and fellow passengers. Without their help, this would not have been possible,” said Saddam, a relative of Manisha who was accompanying her to her in-laws village.

Title: Three MP cities including Bhopal leads Smart city race
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Bhopal: Three cities from MP -- Bhopal, Sagar and Indore -- have been recognised by the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs for smart city development. Sagar topped in its category for overall performance, while Indore and Bhopal were recognised for specific projects. Bhopal smart city development too has been recognised.

Sagar smart city development was selected in the third stack of 30 cities for smart city development in 2017.

The Union ministry of housing and urban affairs (MoHUA) has started giving awards for India Smart Cities -- under the Smart Cities Mission -- to felicitate and recognise their efforts under different categories. The awards ceremony will be held on Friday.

All smart cities have incorporated smart measures in the area-based development (ABD) and pan-city development.

“We have worked on all smart city development parameters and Sagar has been ranked as top performing city in the group,” said Sagar smart city CEO, Rahul Singh Rajpoot. The lake front development, pegged at Rs 92 crore along with an integrated control and command centre (ICCC) going live since October worked in favour of Sagar smart city.

Out of 33 applications, Sagar was selected in the last set of eight cities. Amravati and Rajkot stood second and third respectively.

Indore was recognised for riverfront development as a key initiative of the city in ABD area. Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) has started riverfront development work of Kahn river under the smart city project.

The Mission was introduced in the form of a competition, called the smart city challenge. The first stage was in July 2015 when 20 cities, including Bhopal and Indore, were selected. Bhopal has been ranked in seventh position. It's public cycle sharing project was recognised by the Union ministry under smart cities mission.

These cities were required to develop their smart city plans (SCPs) and compete against each other. The SCPs were evaluated on the basis of the solutions, the processes followed, the feasibility and cost effectiveness of the plans, and citizen engagement.

Over the last four years, the ministry has announced winner cities in batches. So far, 99 cities have been selected under the Mission. MP has seven smart cities.

Title: State hires Rohatgi to defend bills
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vijayawada: The state government, which has initiated several austerity measures and listed empty coffers as one of the reasons for shifting the capital to Visakhapatnam from Amaravati, on Wednesday earmarked a budget of Rs 5 crore to hire senior counsel and former attorney-general Mukul Rohatgi to argue in high court on behalf of the government on the petitions challenging the Bills.

The planning department issued a GO on Wednesday allocating Rs 5 crore to hire Rohatgi. It has sanctioned Rs 1 crore as advance payment to the senior counsel. The GO stated that the services of Rohatgi have been hired based on the recommendation of the advocate-general.

Rohatgi, an expert in constitutional matters, was incidentally one of the counsels, who had argued on behalf of chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy in disproportionate assets case. On the other hand, senior counsel Ashok Bhan, who represented the CBI in Jagan’s disproportionate assets case, is now arguing on behalf of the capital city farmers. The farmers, who had given land for Amaravati, moved the high court challenging the capital shift bills passed in the state assembly. Bhan had successfully opposed the bail pleas by Jaganmohan Reddy in the special CBI court and the apex court.

Both the senior counsels are now in a face off over the AP capital city change issue.

Title: Allahabad HC seeks info on charges of fin bunglings against Azam Khan
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Allahabad high court

ALLAHABAD: The Allahabad high court on Wednesday sought information from the state government about the alleged misappropriation of funds by Samajwadi Party MP Azam Khan in the name of Mohammad Ali Jauhar University in Rampur.

Hearing a PIL petition filed by Faisal Khan seeking a CBI probe into the matter, a division bench comprising Chief Justice Govind Mathur and Justice Samit Gopal fixed January 29 as the next date of hearing.

The petitioner claimed that university’s property amounting to Rs 80 crore was being used by Khan for private purposes.

He also requested the court to direct a CBI investigation into the matter and ensure recovery of the amount misappropriated by Khan.

When the court asked about the need to entertain the PIL when several FIRs had already been filed regarding misappropriation of funds, the petitioner’s counsel argued that assessment and recovery of funds could not be done in criminal proceedings initiated through FIR and as per reports of district administration, the matter should be probed by higher authorities.

Title: Fanfare over, traders and tipplers have a free run on Chennai’s Rs 40 crore pedestrian plaza
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Despite the presence of police, shops along the plaza display their products, encroaching up to four feet of p... Read More

CHENNAI: Oxidised jhumkas and antique-style neckpieces were neatly displayed on a roller stand by a hawker from UP. He had placed knick-knacks such as key chains and embroidered handkerchiefs on a green canvas spread on the newly built sidewalk of the pedestrian plaza in Pondy Bazaar . His neighbour, from Chennai, sold stringed jasmines from a large basket. Nearby, another man sold dholaks.

There are at least a dozen hawkers on either sides of the plaza. And it’s not just hawkers who are encroaching the platforms of the 800m-long stretch built at a cost of Rs 40 crore as part of the smart city project. Many shop owners had either rented out spaces in front of the shops or extended their own shops on the platform by up to four feet.

“Unless we put things on display we won’t be able to attract customers,” said a senior staff of a fashion jewellery store. Clothes, hand-made bags, upholstery and many other products were placed on tables and shelves outside the store.

But this was not the plan when hundreds of vendors from the platform on either sides of the road between Thanikachalam Road signal and Pondy Bazaar police station were moved to a shopping complex, the road was shrunk and traffic was made one-way to let people shop in peace. Greater Chennai Corporation had said the space on the platform would be used for music shows, street plays and public awareness campaigns.

“That idea can fade away soon,” said Radhika K, a techie who lives in Ashok Nagar. “I come for a walk here at least twice every week. I see that the pavements are now being slowly encroached upon even when there are policemen around.”

The colourful cement slabs that have been placed for people to sit have been etched with names, initials and love messages. “I chased away at least two young men who were writing on the slabs with pocket knives,” said a constable, who was posted on duty. “We have sought permission from our seniors to book them for defacing public places. If we don’t nip this now we won’t be able to maintain its beauty,” she said.

A little further down, beneath a tree, there were empty alcohol bottles and food packets. “Walking towards the stretch is also painful,” said 65-year-old E Shanmugapandian, a retired banker. “The newly built platform on the other side of the Thanikachalam Road signal is used for parking bikes and autos. Some of the riders honk on the platform asking pedestrians to move,” he said. “The plaza was a paradise to many people like me. I hope it’s not lost soon,” he said.

Title: Activists: Enact legislation to guarantee essential services
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Puducherry: It is high time the Puducherry government enacts the Right to public services act to guarantee time-bound delivery of public services to the citizens , opine a cross-section of civil rights’ activists in the Union territory of Puducherry.

The act will not only ensure quick delivery of essential services but also establish a mechanism to punish the errant government servants in case of delay or default in extending the essential services, they pointed out. “Enacting the Right to public services act by the Puducherry government appears to be of paramount significance. This legislation is in place in many states and Union Territories in India with Madhya Pradesh being the first to enact in 2010 followed by Bihar in 2011. The right to receive public services is the power conferred on the people to obtain the services from the government departments within the stipulated time. This right also empowers the common man to initiate further action including claiming of compensation from the designated officers in case of delay or default,” said former Lok Sabha MP and economist M Ramadass.

The Puducherry government must first evolve a list of public services that will come under the legislation and notify them in the government gazette before enacting the act to guarantee the delivery of such services within a stipulated time limit. Most of the states and Union territories have included the common public services such as issuing birth, death, marriage and nativity certificates, ration cards, voters’ identity cards and extending power connections among others.

Karnataka has included 151 services from 11 departments under the act while Rajasthan 124 services from 15 departments, Delhi 50 services from 18 departments and Jammu and Kashmir 45 services from six departments. The Puducherry government must establish a nodal department to monitor, control and coordinate the public service delivery mechanism in the administration. The government must appoint a designated officer in every department to implement the act.

An aggrieved citizen can lodge a complaint with the designated officers against the government servants if they fail to deliver the services within the stipulated time. The citizens can also appeal against the orders of the designated officers. “The act must clearly mention the time limit within which the services will be delivered. Normally, the prescribed time limit is 30 days. In case of difficulty in providing the service within the prescribed time limit, the designated officer should inform the applicant in writing the reason for not providing the service. The act should also specify the minimum and maximum amount of compensation that the applicant is entitled in case the officers fail to receive the service,” said Ramadass.

People’s Pulse president P Devanathan said the Puducherry government commenced the process of introducing the act as early as in 2013 but failed to show any urgency in enacting the much-needed act.

“When we approached the then chief secretary in 2013 urging him to initiate efforts to prevent corrupt practices in the government departments, he told us the administration has commenced the process of introducing the Right to public services act. But even after six years, the government has not made any progress,” said Devanathan.

Title: Help Mysuru bag five-star status in garbage-free cities category again: Mayor
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mysuru: Mayor Tasneem Bano has appealed to the residents to help Mysuru bag five-star status in garbage-free cities category again by cooperating with MCC.

Speaking to reporters here on Wednesday, she said that Mysuru had emerged as the third cleanest city in the country under ‘Swachh Survekshan-2019 and had also bagged five stars among the garbage-free cities category.

The city had won the Cleanest City tag twice in 2015 and 2016, but slipped to the eighth spot in 2017 and 2018.

The Swachh Survekshan 2020 had just completed two days ago in city. The central team, which had visited the city, surveyed the places on their own yardsticks and left the city two days back.

However, a team of experts from Swachh Bharath Mission-Urban to study the city in garbage-free cities category for star rating initiative will be arriving in Mysuru in the next one or three days.

They will be rating cities on a 7-star rating system based on multiple cleanliness indicators for solid waste management, which will include door-to-door collection, bulk generator compliance, source segregation, sweeping, scientific processing of waste, scientific land filling, plastic waste management, construction and demolition management, dump remediation & citizen grievance redressal system etc, construction of toilets to achieve the Swachh Bharat Mission of ‘Open Defecation Free and Garbage Free India.’

“The MCC is totally unaware of their inspection, when and where they would visit suddenly. They will collect all information they wanted from the residents regarding segregation of dry and wet waste separately and handing over the same to pourakarmikas, garbage collection trucks and vehicles regularly. Residents must focus on keeping the city clean, besides not to throw wastes, dump in drainages and vacant plots,” she added.

Thanking her party leaders and residents of Mysuru for electing her as mayor, Tasneem Bano promised to give utmost importance to keep all roads and layouts in all 65 wards of corporation clean throughout the year. The city will be kept cleanest and beautiful during her tenure, she said.

She also added that she had given lot of attention to fill potholes on the roads and to repair the drainages damaged for laying underground cables.

“I have also given instructions to officials to stop giving permission to lay underground cables as individuals involved in such activities are damaging the drainages and roads”, she said.

Tasneem also said that she had given clear-cut instructions to the officials in all zones to pay surprise visit in all wards including slaughterhouses, meat shops, city outskirts apart from Central Business district areas and arterial roads to check cleanliness. “Directions have been given to them to penalize the residents and shopkeepers on the spot for not keeping city clean,” she said.

Title: MVA clears Rs 2,413cr Nag River project, will also call shots
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: In what appears to be a move to take control of the BJP-ruled Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and its projects, the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government on Wednesday approved the revised cost of the ambitious Nag River Pollution Abatement Project. Now, Pili River too finds a mention in the project name.

The cabinet also constituted a high-profile committee of ministers to execute and monitor the project. While three district Congress MLAs are part of the committee, none of the city’s four BJP MLAs find a place in it.

The name of the project was modified following the recommendation of guardian minister Nitin Raut who, along with home minister Anil Deshmukh and, sports and youth welfare minister Sunil Kedar form the committee.

Environment minister Aditya Thackeray too is a member. The municipal commissioner is the member secretary.

The cabinet approved the state share of 25% in the total revised project cost of Rs 2,412.64 crore. “Union Jalshakti Mantralaya and National River Conservation Directorate (NRCD) had approved the project to mitigate pollution of Nag River. The NMC will implement the project. Centre, state and NMC will bear share of 60%, 25% and 15%, respectively,” reads the cabinet note.

The centre’s share will be Rs 1,447.59 crore, state will contribute Rs 603.16 crore and NMC Rs 361.89 crore. “The Centre will raise a loan of Rs 1,864.30 crore from Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA). State’s repayment of Rs 403.90 crore will come from the JICA loan and will have to pay the balance of Rs 199.26 crore. Cabinet has assured to repay the loan as well as its remaining share to Jalshakti Mantralaya,” the cabinet note added.

The decision to “constitute a coordination committee under Nagpur guardian minister Nitin Raut for execution and monitoring the project”, too has been approved by the cabinet.

In 2010, the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court had treated media reports of high-level pollution in Nag River polluting Kanhan and Wainganga rivers, and Gosikhurd project as a suo motu PIL and directed the civic body to rejuvenate the city’s iconic river-turned nullah.

The NMC, which then too had a BJP majority, proposed the project in 2011. The project got momentum when Devendra Fadnavis became chief minister and Nitin Gadkari got elected as MP in 2014. The state and Centre cleared the project in 2015.

Gadkari, Fadnavis and BJP city president Pravin Datke have been trying to execute the project. Last year, the NMC realized that the project cost had gone up. In November last year, the Centre approved the revised cost and sent it to state for its nod.

Raut told TOI that Wednesday was historic day. “The name of the project has been changed to Nag and Pili River Pollution Abatement Project. Pili river was part of the project but its name was not highlighted. The approval was pending with the government. I got a cabinet approval in the larger interest of the city,” he said.

A good stretch of Pili river falls under Raut’s North Nagpur constituency.

Raut said BJP MLAs and NMC office bearers have no role to play in the project hence “they are not in committee”.

Next, an agreement will be executed between Centre, state and JICA following which the loan amount will be received in instalments. NMC will then float tenders and execute the project.

Title: In 150th year, Kolkata port Trust brings its first Republic Day tableau
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Pankaj Modi, the younger brother of PM Narendra Modi, is supervising the preparation of the Gujarat tableau

NEW DELHI: The Republic Day is just four days away, and various states, Union territories and central agencies are busy giving final touches to their tableaux for the morning parade on Rajpath. One of them is Kolkata Port Trust , the oldest operating port in the country celebrating its 150th year. For the first time, the port, which comes under the Union shipping ministry, will present its own tableau.

This year, 16 states and Union territories, and six central ministries will take part in the parade. The contingent will be led by the Chhattisgarh tableau highlighting its traditional crafts and ornaments. It will have an idol of Nandi — the mount of Lord Shiva — made out of bell metal at the front, while tribal folk artistes will perform Gaur dance, a traditional art form of the Maria tribe, on both sides.

Punjab’s tableau is dedicated to the humane principles preached by Guru Nanak as it’s the 550th birth anniversary of the founder of the Sikh religion. Odisha will showcase the famous Rukuna Rath Yatra of Lord Lingaraja, worshipped as both Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu. Meghalaya’s tableau will focus on the double-decker living root bridge, one of its main tourist attractions, while Jammu and Kashmir will showcase the new Union territory’s ‘Back to Village’ programme, launched last year to empower villages and panchayats.

Gujarat will bring Rani ki Vav: Jal Mandir (queen’s stepwell), an ancient engineering marvel that features on Unesco’s World Heritage Site list. Its preparation is being supervised by Pankaj Modi , younger brother of Prime Minister Narendra Modi . A deputy director in the information department of Gujarat government, he said, “Rani ki Vav is the best example of Gujarat’s traditional means for water conservation that exhibits a unique combination of civilisation, culture and art along with an engineering marvel.”

Besides Meghalaya, Assam will be the other northeastern state to be present in the parade. Its tableau will display the state’s unique craftsmanship and culture through bamboo and cane crafts. Bhortal Nritya, a popular traditional dance form practised in the state, will also be displayed.

The glory of the heritage buildings and sites of Jaipur will be the theme of the Rajasthan tableau, which will be decorated with jaali jharokha to display the city’s magnetic beauty through markets, monuments and grand gateways.

The commerce ministry’s promotion of industry and internal trade department will present ‘Startups: Reach for the Sky’, which will showcase the life cycle of a startup and the all-round support provided by the central government in this journey. It will depict how ideas come to life and positively impact the lives of common people.

Title: CAA stir at Roshan Bagh to continue for 4 more weeks
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Allahabad: The ongoing protest at Roshan Bagh locality continued on Wednesday. The protestors decided to continue stir for four more weeks.

The Supreme Court, on Wednesday refused to put on hold the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and has given the Centre four weeks to respond to petitions on the law, making it clear that it would not grant any stay without hearing the government.

“We have decided that now that the Apex court has given Four week’s of time to the government to submit its reply on the CAA, we will continue with our dharna for the same length of period”, said Adil Hamza, member of Samajwadi Party (SP) who is leading the protest from the first day. Hamza was among the leading protestors against CAA and NRC since the day parliament passed the bill in December.

On Wednesday, the women folk stayed at the dharna site in shifts, managing the household work and the protest alike. While the school going kids were sent to schools, tiny toddlers were seen remain in the lap of their mothers.

While the locals kept arranging for the food, water and other logistics for the protestors, leaders of various organisations and some locals addressed the protestors.

Title: Driver killed, two hurt in collision of trucks in Unnao
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kanpur: A 25-year-old driver killed while two others sustained injuries when a truck plunged off a bridge into the Ganga after being hit by another truck coming from the opposite direction at Nanamau bridge on Bangarmau-Bilhaur road in Unnao district on late Tuesday night.

Police rushed to the spot, fished out the body of the truck driver and later shifted it to the morgue. The deceased truck driver has been identified as Jamuna Prasad, a resident of Bhagwatipur Ahirana in Andiari locality of Allahabad. Jamuna Prasad couldn't come out of the cabin and probably died due to drowning, police said. tnn

Title: Assembly passes resolution to probe ‘insider trading’ charges
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Amaravati: Clearing the decks for a probe into alleged insider trading in the capital city area, the state assembly passed a resolution on Wednesday.

Home minister Mekathoti Sucharitha moved a resolution to take up the investigation in the assembly. The cabinet had recently decided to handover the investigation to the Lokayukta. Following the speaker’s directive to go deep into the insider trading issue, chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy assured that they would follow the speaker’s advice.

Subsequently, the state government moved a resolution to take the House into confidence. Speaking on the resolution, Sucharitha said the initial inquiries revealed that the TDP functionaries had purchased over 4,000 acres in the capital city area just before the official announcement on the capital city was made by the previous TDP regime. The minister said that TDP functionaries got information from government sources and invested heavily in the capital city area.

Civil supplies minister Kodali Nani said TDP legislators from north-coastal districts were doing grave injustice to their region as they had eyed the packages offered by party president Chandrababu Naidu.

Government whip Kapu Ramachandra Reddy said that Naidu had always indulged in corrupt practices during his long political career. He said that Naidu’s encouragement had only helped its functionaries to bet on Amaravati. Tanuku legislator Karumuri Nageswara Rao said that TDP leaders wanted to make billions by duping farmers.

Sources said that the state government is most likely to constitute a special investigation team (SIT) to assist the Lokayukta.

Title: BSNL to rollout 4G services in M’luru city today
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mangaluru: While the state’s capital Bengaluru is still on 3G, tier-II city Mangaluru will join four others districts in the state with 4G services from Thursday. The network switch over will happen at 8.30am when MP Nalin Kumar Kateel launches the service.

The service is being launched after a delay of five months. The first announcement was made in August last year. With this, Manglauru will become the fifth city in the state after Kalaburagi , Bidar , Raichur and Vijayapura to get this facility.

Sources in Dakshina Kannada telecom district’s BSNL said 4G services are being rolled in tier-II cities as BSNL wants to test the service in a smaller population before launching it in Bengaluru. Their services in four other cities have been successful, which made the launch possible in Mangaluru.

In Vijayapura, the services were launched almost a year ago. A person using BSNL services said the speeds were good and the network performance was satisfactory, unlike 3G services, where speeds were pathetic. BSNL Dakshina Kannada telecom district sources said that the speeds would be in the range of 8mbps to 10mbps in areas where 3G services were offering speeds below 12kbps, especially in a busy location like MG Road.

The service is already up and running in 13 towers from Ucchila in Udupi district to Mukka near Surathkal , about 24km from here. Sources said that 151 towers in the Mangaluru area have already been converted to 4G technology, and BSNL has already reformed the 2,100MHz spectrum band, used for 3G, to strengthen its 4G network. The telecom operator is deploying L900 technology in the 2,100MHz band to complement its 4G services.

When activated, 4G services would be seamlessly available from Uchila till Nethravathi bridge in Mangaluru, a distance of about 50km, and till Farangipete on the Mangaluru-Bengaluru National Highway. Beyond 4G connectivity, the services would automatically switch over to 3G services when the customers move out of the 4G range. The district rollout is expected by April 2020.

As on January 21, the 3G sim conversion to 4G was at 37% in Mangaluru and 42% in the Uchila to Mukka area.

Title: HC frowns at Chennai Corporation plan to increase number of hawkers on Marina
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Chennai: Shocked over the submission of Chennai Corporation that it has planned to provide steel carts to licensed vendors in Marina at a monthly rent of Rs 100, Madras high court said authorities must exhibit some sense in fixing such rents and made it clear that the carts should not be rented out for anything less than Rs 5,000 a month.

A division bench of Justice Vineet Kothari and Justice R Suresh Kumar also expressed their disappointment on Chennai Corporation’s proposal to increase the number of licensed vendors to trade in Marina from 900 to 1,352. The issue pertains to regulating vending in Marina and relocating fishermen from the Loop Road to a proposed exclusive fish market in Nochi Kuppam.

As to the corporation’s proposal to increase the number of licensed vendors from 900 to 1,352, the bench said, “The corporation of Chennai appears to have taken a decision to raise the number of shopping carts permitted in Marina beach from 900 to 1352. This court had already expressed that even 900 is much higher. If more number of carts are allowed, it would lead to congestion in the beach, the court added.

Directing the corporation to file a revised proposal for fixing monthly rent for the carts, the bench adjourned the hearing to January 29.

When the plea came up for hearing on Wednesday, additional advocate-general S R Rajagopal submitted that eviction of fishermen from Loop Road could be completed once the proposed market is established. As to constructing a footpath along the beach side of the road, the corporation is awaiting clearance from the Tamil Nadu State Coastal Zone Management Authority (TNSCZMA), he added.

Counsel for TNSCZMA submitted that the proposal has been forwarded to its Delhi office since guidelines framed by the National Green Tribunal prohibits any development in the sea side of the road.

However, expressing its dismay over refusal to grant clearance for the proposed footpath, the bench directed the M Jayanthi, member-secretary of TNSCZMA to appear before the court on January 29.

Title: AAI frees up space at international terminal for construction
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

AAI is planning to shift international arrivals to a new terminal by year-end and rebuild the existing arrival... Read More

CHENNAI: Airports Authority of India (AAI) has begun vacating portions of the international arrival building so that it can be demolished in phases for rebuilding. Work to reconstruct the arrival building is likely to begin by the year-end after the integrated terminal coming up between the passenger terminals is built.

An AAI official said baggage conveyors have been moved closer to one another to free up space that has been cordoned off for pulling down. The terminal has six conveyors. More changes will be made so that more areas can be freed up in the coming months, he said.

A remote bus lounge in the terminal used by airline passengers to alight from shuttle buses will be taken up for work in the future. “The idea is to give as much space as possible for construction so that the rebuilding is quickly done. The existing arrival hall will be pulled down and rebuilt so that it can be merged with the new terminal that is coming up. This will help the airport to handle more international passengers after two to three years,” the official said.

Areas that have been cordoned off will be prepared for demolition soon. Since the building is marked for pulling down after shifting of operations, only required maintenance work is being done.

As per the plan, AAI will complete the integrated terminal, move international arrivals from the existing building to the new structure, pull down and rebuild existing arrival terminal as part of the phase 2 expansion to augment passenger capacity to 30 million a year. The new terminal will have capacity to handle domestic and international passengers.

Since international passenger movement has seen an increase in the past few years and AAI was not able to commission the ground floor arrival hall of international terminal because of lack of personnel and adequate baggage handling facility, focus is being given to add space for international terminal under phase 2 of expansion work.

Title: Severe shortage of special needs educators in state
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vijayawada: Even as CBSE announced its decision to allow children suffering from dyscalculia to use calculators for exams, the initiative may only aid a fraction of the students in AP.

According to CBSE officials, only around 10,000 students from the board’s affiliated schools have been identified as having the disability. Dyscalculia is a learning disability which makes it extremely difficult, if not impossible for affected children to meet developmental milestones in mathematics.

RV Shekhar, a city-based psychologist explained that scolding and beating children as a disciplining tactic won’t help them score better marks if they suffer from dyscalculia. “To identify the problem, parents can make children count from 1 to 100 or higher than that. If the child skips some numbers or gets stuck somewhere then it’s time to seek a clinical psychologist’s help,” Shekhar told TOI.

Teachers who deal with students with learning disabilities welcomed the move of letting them use the calculator, but asserted that a lot more needs to be done to provide quality education for children with special needs in the state.

According to Special Educators’ Federation, there are nearly 1.3 lakh children suffering from various mental disabilities in Andhra Pradesh. Over 1,100 special teachers’ posts for Class IX and X lie vacant.

“A lot many of them did write the exams but the results have been withheld as cases have been filed by teachers working for Sarva Siksha Abhiyan claiming right for those posts,” SEF general secretary Gummala Babu told TOI.

The notification for their recruitment was issued by the government in 2015, but unfortunately, there are not many takers for the posts. While Telangana government has seven schools meant for students with special needs. Andhra Pradesh which is a bigger state has only four in Hindupur, Chirala, Vizag and Vizianagaram.

Title: Chennai: Thanks to Rajinikanth, books on Periyar fly off shelves
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Titles on Periyar were sought at the book fair

CHENNAI: The controversy surrounding Rajinikanth’s comments on Dravidar Kazhagam founder Periyar has led to a spike in the demand for books on the rational leader. At the just-concluded book fair in the city, there was renewed interest in books on Periyar.

Publishers, who participated in the fair, said titles on Periyar were one of the most sought.

Suba Veerapandian, founder of Karunchattai Pathipagam, a publication that deals with books on social justice, said sales of books on Periyar jumped by almost two times. “We sold nearly 2,000 books on Periyar in the book fair last year. It touched 3,500 this year. While repeated adverse remarks by various political leaders against Periyar sparked an interest among people, the recent comments of Rajinikanth increased the demand,” he said. Youngsters aged between 25 and 35 searched for books on the leader, he said.

At the golden jubilee celebrations of Tamil magazine ‘Thuglak’ in Chennai last week, Rajinikanth spoke about a rally led by Periyar in Salem in 1971. Rajinikanth had said that “portraits of Rama and Sita without clothes, decorated with garlands of slippers” were carried by people in the rally.

Booksellers and publishers said there was a growing interest among readers to understand the life and philosophy of Periyar. Nagarajan K, Booksellers and Publishers Association of South India vice-president and publisher of Bharathi Puthakalayam, said Periyar was the most-searched title in the online catalogue of the association’s official portal. ‘E V Ramasamy Engira Naan’ was one the most-sold titles on the leader, he said.

New publishers such as ‘Neelam Publications’, who have a range of titles on social reformers and rational leaders, said political awareness among the masses was palpable. Anbu of Neelam Publications said visitors to the book fair wanted to know the veracity of information available on leaders. “We can see a political awareness among the readers who want to understand the depth of these issues,” he said.

Dravidar Kazhagam said the spurt in demand for titles on Periyar was not related to the controversy triggered by Rajinikanth. V Anburaj, general secretary of Dravidar Kazhagam, said books on Periyar have been in high demand for the past two years. “In the current political scenario and crisis, Periyar’s ideas provide a solution,” he said. “There is no link between Rajinikanth’s remarks and sale of books on Periyar,” he said.

Title: Two arrested for panchaloha idol theft from Arcot temple
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

VELLORE: Three days after a 3-ft panchaloha idol kept in the sanctum sanctorum of a 90-year-old Krishna temple was stolen, the Arcot police on Wednesday arrested two people, including a habitual bike lifter, and retrieved the idol hidden by them in a drainage channel near Konan Colony in Arcot.

A senior police officer identified the arrested as D Sathiya, 40, of Konan Dalit Colony, and K Kannan, 44, of Krishnavaram in the town. The temple is located on Kanar Bajanai Street.

On Sunday, when priest Rajesh Sharma, 30, came to open the temple, he was shocked to find the panchaloha idol of the main deity missing.

According to prime accused Sathiya’s confession, he was involved in bike lifting cases and sought to lead a luxurious life. “Fearing arrest, we decided to hide the stolen idol in a drainage channel. Unfortunately, when we dropped the idol, a hand broke. Believing that the damaged idol would fetch only a low rate in the black market, we opted to repair it before sales. When we were searching for the broken hand, a resident spotted us and alerted police,” he said.

Police retrieved the idol and are on the look out for another accused who is reportedly absconding with the broken idol part.

Speaking to TOI, Anandhan, inspector of the Arcot police station, said the idol is now at the police station and will be handed over to the temple authorities following investigation.

Title: 2 in cop net for faking plot papers & cheating
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Pune: The Shivajinagar police arrested two men from Lonavla for preparing fake documents of a land measuring six hectares at Kamshet and submitting them in the small causes’ court in Shivajinagar as genuine.

Inspector Manisha Zende of Shivajinagar police said, “The incident came to light after the current landowner realised the fraud and obtained all genuine documents from the revenue department. The matter was brought to the notice of the court and a complaint was registered.”

Zende said that police arrested Anil Savji Vadgama (50) and his associate Vijay Haribhau Kamble (52), both residents of Lonavla.

Zende said that a cheating and forgery case was registered in November 2019 against them by a company owner, a resident of Pali Hill in Bandra, Mumbai. “The two men had been evading arrest for a month. Two cheating cases, including land fraud, have been registered against them ,” Zende said.

“Three years ago, Vadgama and Kamble approached the company officials and said that the land belonged to them. Following this, the dispute was taken to the small causes’ court. During a hearing last year, the duo submitted a map of the land with forged signatures and stamps of revenue authorities.

The company officials obtained the original map of the land from the revenue department following which the forgery came to light, Zende said.

Title: 3 months on, Metro Phase II plan pending at Mantralaya
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: The Phase II of Nagpur Metro was cleared by state cabinet in January 2019 and the Union cabinet was expected to approve it in March 2019. However, the proposal is yet to reach the Union cabinet.

A MahaMetro official said that the reason for the delay was change in norms by the Union ministry for housing and urban affairs (MoHUA). “Some months ago, MoHUA decided, after a detailed study, that Metro light coaches should be used for tier II and tier III cities. This is because Metros in middle sized cities do not have much ridership. MoHUA asked us to revise the proposal for Nagpur Metro Phase II as per new norms,” he added.

Metro light coaches are a foot less longer than regular Metro. They can carry 750 passengers instead of 1,000. These coaches can carry 24,000 passengers per hour while regular Metro’s capacity is 30,000 passengers per hour. Their weight is 12 tonne instead of 16 tonne of the regular ones. Consequently, they cost less.

“We explained to MoHUA officials that we planned to use the coaches of the existing Metro for four corridors — Automotive Square to Kamptee, Prajapati Nagar to Transport Nagar, Khapri to Butibori and Lokmanya Nagar to Hingna Tehsil office. They asked us to use Metro light coaches for Wasudeo Nagar to Dattawadi spur. We accordingly revised our project and submitted it to the state urban development department. It has been three months since then. MoHUA officials have assured to clear the proposal as soon as it is received from the state,” said the official.

The cost of Phase II was Rs11,612 crore as per the detailed project report (DPR). Now, it has been reduced by Rs650 crore to Rs10,962 crore.

Many experts feel that ridership of Phase I Metro will not increase significantly until Phase II becomes operational. This is because people regularly travel to places connected by Phase II — for example Kamptee and Butibori — using public transport. They will use Metro instead of buses. Phase I was designed assuming that Mihan will employ thousands of people. However, Mihan is yet to take off.

BJP leader Devendra Fadnavis was chief minister till September. One could have expected speedy clearance of Phase II from Mantralaya when he was at the helm. Now, Shiv Sena’s Eknath Shinde is the urban development minister and local ministers will have to press him for clearing the project immediately.
