Title: Cash stolen from parked truck on Pune-Mumbai Expressway
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

PUNE: A man broke the window of a truck parked near Urse toll plaza on Pune-Mumbai Expressway and made off with the driver’s wallet containing Rs5,500 in the early hours of Tuesday.

The driver Jitendra Kumar of Uttar Pradesh, lodged an FIR with the Talegaon Dabhade police station. An officer said Kumar had parked the truck a kilometre before the toll plaza. He had kept his wallet under the bedsheet and was sleeping, holding his cellphone. Around 4am, he woke up to a man, inside the truck’s cabin, snatching his cellphone. When Kumar tried to catch him, the suspect pushed him and jumped out, the officer said.

Kumar later found that the suspect had made off with his wallet containing cash.

Title: Madras high court notice to Tamil Nadu on NGO founder’s plea
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Madras high court has issued notice to the state government on a plea moved by the founder of an NGO Russ Foundation seeking to set aside the detention order (Goondas Act) against him, after he was arrested in connection with the sexual assault of a minor girl in Madurai district in 2019.

Berlin Jose, founder of the NGO, in his petition stated that he was detained at the Madurai Central Prison, pursuant to the detention order passed by the Madurai collector on November 21, 2019. The order was passed only on the ground that a case was registered against him under Pocso Act.

He stated that the detaining authority could pass the order only to prevent the detenu from indulging in activities that are prejudicial to the maintenance of public order and such orders should not be passed on mere assumptions. Even though a case was registered against him, it would not cause any disturbance to public peace and tranquillity as mentioned in the order.Hence, the petitioner filed a habeas corpus petition seeking to set aside the detention order and set him at liberty. A division bench of justice T Raja and justice B Pugalendhi issued notice to the state government returnable in two weeks.

Title: Docs to take ‘Beti Padhao, Beta Samjhao’ to state level
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: Maharashtra state unit of the Indian Medical Association (IMA) has adopted the model of adolescence education campaign, ‘Beti Padhao Beta Samjhao’, introduced by its Nagpur branch. IMA Maharashtra will run this campaign on the state level in 2020 through its Adolescence Health Education Committee (AHEC). IMA has appointed a team of Nagpur-based doctors for the state-level activity.

Dr Majusha Giri, honorary secretary of IMA Nagpur, will be the chairperson of this committee. IMA president Dr Kush Jhunjhunwala will be executive member while senior member of state IMA and sexologist Dr Sanjay Deshpande will guide the state-level implementation of the campaign.

As part of this campaign, IMA will conduct half-day informative seminar on adolescent health, and how schoolteachers can deal with it, for schoolteachers. Doctors will discuss physical changes in adolescents, brain development and peer pressure, addictions, media, and abuse during adolescent period, relationship and sexuality in adolescent ages groups and other points. Separate seminars will be conducted for students also.

“The model of adolescent education that educates both teachers and students in schools will be implemented statewide this year. Doctors from Nagpur have been given this responsibility. Through its statewide implementation, we are looking forward to making national IMA also adopt this model for the entire country,” said Dr Manjusha Giri.

Dr Sanjay Deshpande said the committee will also work on concept of ‘doctor as a sex educator’. “We will train IMA members from various branches, who will visit schools and conduct lectures for teachers and students. A state conference in this regard will be organized in March,” he said.

Dr Kush Jhunjhunwala said, “Adolescence is a crucial phase in student life. Internal changes affect relationships in both social and academic sphere. It is important for teachers to acquire skills and provide a safety net at school. The committee will provide these skills to teachers.”

Title: Yewale tea masala under FDA scanner
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) officials on Tuesday said they would soon fix responsibility after finding synthetic food colour in the tea masala of Yewale tea .

“We will seek state FDA commissioner’s (Mumbai) permission for filing a case regarding the food Act violation,” S S Deshmukh, FDA’s joint commissioner (food), Pune division, told TOI.

“An FDA team visited Yewale Food Products in Kondhwa and collected samples of tea powder, tea masala (pack and loose) and sugar on September 21, 2019. It seized a stock, worth Rs5 lakh and kept with the distributor, on suspicion and with label shortcomings,” he said.

“The report of the state health laboratory (Pune) stated that the samples were of required standards. We sent the samples again for testing at the referral laboratory in Mysuru on November 13, 2019. The report stated that the tea masala (loose) sample had tartrazine synthetic food colour. The item was declared unsafe,” Deshmukh said.

Yewale tea director Navnath Yewale said, “We do not know about the new report. It concerns our product so we should have been informed of it. We feel it is a conspiracy against us. The analysis report of samples collected in September stated that there was nothing wrong. We use natural products, and not any prohibited or banned substances.”

Title: Pune: Helmetless retired sepoy arrested
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

PUNE: The Yerawada police on Wednesday arrested a retired Army sepoy, Hanumant Gutte (32), for charging at an havildar after being stopped for riding a bike without helmet at the main gate of Dunkirk Line opposite Aga Khan Palace.

Police said havildar Gaurav Shobha Singh (33) was performing duty at the gate of the Armymen’s residential quarters around 10.40pm on Tuesday, when he siganlled at Gutte for riding the bike without a helmet. Singh told TOI, “Gutte abused me, tore my uniform and threw the visitors’ register.”

Assistant inspector Balbhim Nanaware said, “Army officers alerted the military police, who called the police control room. A beat marshal arrested Gutte.”

Title: Gujarat: ‘We expect compassionate stance’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

AHMEDABAD: Nirali Barot (name changed), 39, a travel firm owner in Canada and an overseas citizen of India (OCI), is camping in Anand for the past few days. “I got married 10 years ago and have been trying to conceive for about nine. My uterus is not competent to sustain a pregnancy leading to miscarriages. Surrogacy is the only hope if I want my own flesh and blood,” says Barot.

Hundreds of couples and individuals like Barot have pinned their hopes on the Rajya Sabha select committee which is to examine aspects of the Surrogacy (Regulation) Bill, 2019, which aims to end to commercial surrogacy in India. The committee visited Anand on Wednesday to meet various stakeholders. In the next two days, the members will travel to Hyderabad and Mumbai.

While stakeholders who were part of the discussion refused to divulge details of discussion, sources said that it’s likely that issues from the mandate, such as Anand's surrogacy services, it’s impact on women working as surrogate mothers, the economics of these services, eligibility for services etc, were discussed with surrogate mothers, fertility experts, parents and NGOs.

“We are often advised, why don’t we go for adoption. Have they tried the adoption procedure?” asked Barot. “I don’t mind adoption. But the procedure takes three to four years, doesn’t provide us with choice and is more expensive than current surrogacy cost.”

Dr Nayana Patel, the founder of Akanksha Hospital in Anand, who put the town on the global map through a record number of surrogacy cases over the past 15 years, said that in several cases surrogacy is the only feasible answer. “How would one address the wish of a woman or couple to have their own child when other options are exhausted?” she asked.

Infertility experts from across India have created momentum against the bill’s provisions since November 2019, which aims to end commercial surrogacy and promote altruist surrogacy that requires a close relative of family to step forward and carry the couple’s pregnancy. Already, an MHA notification has prohibited commercial surrogacy for foreign nationals, NRI and OCI couples, couples with children and single parents, among others.

Dr Abhirajsinh Jadeja (name changed), a gynaecologist, wants to become a single father. “I was in a long-term relationship which did not have a good ending. I don’t know whether I will in another relationship now. Should that decide whether I am eligible to have a child of my own? I could have a child when commercial surrogacy had still not hit rough waters but I was not ready then,” he said. “Why single out single parents? I believe from my experience that they are better equipped to handle a child with a family support.”

‘Uncertain about future’

The most vocal opponents of the Bill, however, were the surrogate mothers. Close to 100 women are in various stages of pregnancy at Dr Patel’s clinic. The women are generally from Anand district and are often related. “This is my second surrogacy. In 2017, I conceived for the first time and managed to make money enough to send my two children to school and save some to build my own house. I am separated from my husband and with just a primary education, I won’t be able to earn this much in any organized vocation,” said Alka, a surrogate mother.

Meena, another mother who is pregnant for a couple from Bengaluru, said that she is paid through cheque. “The government should surely crack down on exploitative practices, but indiscriminate action will do more harm than good for both surrogates and aspiring parents,” she said.

Title: MCC ropes in startup to make plastic pavers from waste
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mysuru: The Mysuru City Corporation has found a novel way to recycle tonnes of plastic waste dumped at its solid waste management unit in Sewage Farm, Vidyaranyapuram. The authorities have given a contract to mechanical engineer Darshan C, 26, whose startup converts waste to wealth.

The engineer from Srirampura 2nd Stage, who passed out from Vidyavardhaka College of Engineering in 2015, developed a plastic processing unit he wants to patent. Darshan, who used to travel near the landfill at Vidyaranyapuram while going to college, decided to design a machine to process plastic waste which is a threat to the environment. After graduating, he joined as an design engineer in a company and in a free time, he came up with a machine to recycle plastic waste into interlock pavers.

Darshan said every day nearly 80 tonnes of plastic is dumped at Sewage Farm. “I gave a presentation to MCC officials about my device and they agreed to give me an opportunity to manage the plastic waste.”

His device mixes and melts waste plastic covers and waste granite dust to produce interlock pavers which are used for pavements. “I set up Jagruth Tech Pvt Ltd in December. MCC gave the approval for 100 ft x 100 ft land inside the SWM unit at Sewage Farm where recycling will start in three months,” he said.

The plastic pavers is of better quality than cement pavers. Darshan claimed that cement pavers will have 5-tonne load capacity while his pavers can sustain 60-tonne load weight and can last 15 years. It can also sustain 120 degrees celsius temperature. Making it is cheaper too — Rs 45 per sq ft while cement pavers cost Rs 55.

Darshan said MCC has assured it’ll buy pavers for its civic works. “The authorities have given permission to use 2 tonnes of plastic from which we plan to produce 2,000 pavers in one shift,” he added. Darshan’s college friend Chidananda V and engineer Ramesh Kikkery have been supporting him.

MCC health officer DG Nagaraj told TOI: “We’ve given land at Sewage Farm and production will start in 15 days. He’ll develop pavers under the PPP model.”

Title: Hardik Patel gets bail
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Hardik Patel

AHMEDABAD: A city sessions court on Wednesday granted conditional bail to Congress leader Hardik Patel , who was arrested after the court issued a warrant against him for skipping court proceedings in a sedition case.

Additional sessions judge B J Ganatra placed a strict condition on Patel for bail, mandating that he never seek adjournments and skip court proceedings to delay the trial in the sedition case, in which two other persons are being tried along with Patel.

On Monday, Patel assured the court that he would never act in a way that could result in a delay of the trial. He also promised the court that he would not tender any adjournment application in the future.

On Saturday, the court issued an arrest warrant against Patel on a request by public prosecutor Sudhir Brahmbhatt for Patel’s continued absence in the courtroom during the trial of the 2015 sedition case. Patel had sought exemption from appearance during the proceedings on the grounds that he had to attend a social function, but the court rejected his application.

Title: UP: Two sentenced to 15 years imprisonment
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: Additional district and sessions court (XXII) and designated NDPS court judge Mohd Shafeeq on Wednesday sentenced accused Hari Om Singh and Ajay Singh to 15 years rigorous imprisonment along with a fine of Rs 1.10 lakh on each under the NDPS Act .

During the investigation, they revealed that they belonged to Chaubepur town and were carrying charas for the purpose of selling it. The police later arrested them with 5 kg of charas.

Title: CBSE to provide exam calculators to ensure uniformity
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: After announcing that students with dyscalculia (difficulty in learning or comprehending) can use calculators during exams, the CBSE said on Wednesday that the board itself will provide the gadget.

The CBSE move will ensure uniformity in the type of calculators being used. This comes as a big relief for school principals who did not have a clarity on the type of calculators to be permitted inside the examination hall.

Sanyam Bhardwaj, controller of examination for CBSE, told TOI that the board is already working on the logistics. “We are waiting to see how many applications will be submitted. Based on this, we will ship out the calculators to schools and exam centres,” he said.

TOI had reported on Wednesday about CBSE’s historic move to allow calculators for students with dyscalculia. Many principals had expressed concern over the nitty-gritty of its implementation as the CBSE’s circular had only mentioned ‘basic arithmetic calculator’.

Some principals told TOI that the CBSE “must mention the brand and model number of calculator to be used so that there’s no ruckus during the exam”.

Now, the CBSE itself has decided to provide calculators. Bhardwaj said, “There are different type of calculators available in the market and you never know which a student would bring. So, it’s better for us to provide them.”

ICSE schools too prefer to retain control over the calculators used by their students during board exams. Raziya Hussain, principal of MSB Institute, said, “The school purchases the calculators and keeps it as part of the inventory. They are used as and when required by students during exams.”

Another student-friendly move by CBSE is to keep the calculator option open for all related subjects. Since it was not mentioned in the earlier circular, many principals felt it was restricted only to math. Bhardwaj said, “Students can use it for physics too. We feel a majority will probably use it for math only.”

January 28 is the last day for students to apply for use of calculator. All requests have to be sent to the school principal. CBSE has clarified that this facility is available to only those students who have already registered themselves under the “children with special needs” category.

Title: Blackbuck pelt seized; 2 held
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mangaluru: The Mangaluru City North Division special police squad and forest department officials, in a joint operation , arrested two people and seized a blackbuck pelt , near Tannirbavi Cross on Tuesday.

The arrested are Pradeep , 20, and Anil Narasapur ,20, both residents of Gadag . The arrested have been produced before a court and remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Madras high court notice to Tamil Nadu on cop’s petition against conviction
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court on Wednesday issued notice to the state government on a plea filed by a suspended sub-inspector of police challenging his conviction and awarding of life imprisonment by a lower court for wrongfully confining a man and shooting him dead with his service revolver in Ramanathapuram district in 2014.

Petitioner A Kalidass stated that he was an SI at S P Pattinam police station in Ramanathapuram district. On October 14, 2014, a person named Aruldass lodged a complaint against Syed Mohammed stating that the latter had tried to kill him for not handing over the bike which was given for repair. A case was registered by the S P Pattinam police and thereafter he instructed three policemen to secure the man from the mechanic workshop situated opposite to the police station.

Kalidass said Syed was under the influence of alcohol when he was brought for inquiry to his room and he attempted to assault him using a knife. He fired three rounds using his service revolver in self-defence and Syed died on the spot. He stated that a case was registered against him which was later transferred to CB-CID.

On November 14, 2019, the Ramanathapuram principal district and sessions court convicted and sentenced him to undergo life imprisonment for the offence under Section 302 (murder) of the IPC and imposed a fine of Rs 2lakh. He stated that currently he has been lodged at the Madurai central prison. He said the lower court had erroneously convicted him even though the prosecution has not proved its case beyond doubt.

Title: Cuddalore: Four-year-old boy crushed to death by school van
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

Cuddalore: A four-year-old boy was crushed to death in a freak accident at Nellikuppam in Cuddalore district on Tuesday.

Police said B Athvigiran, a lower kindergarten student in a private school at Nellikuppam, was returning home in the school van along with other students after school hours on Tuesday. The van reached his stop and the boy got down from the van and crossed the road in front of the vehicle. The driver, who could not spot the boy crossing the road, moved the vehicle, which ran over him causing severe injuries.

His parents rushed him to Cuddalore government general hospital where doctors on duty declared that the boy was brought dead. The Nellikuppam police registered a case against the driver and began an investigation.

Title: Sahakar Nagar lanes flooded as pipeline damaged
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

A flooded Sahakar Nagar bylane

Nagpur: It didn’t rain on Wednesday, but many bylanes in Sahakar Nagar were flooded. Not just this, water supply to parts of Sahakar Nagar and Gajanan Dham will be affected on Thursday. The reason: A contractor engaged by MSEDCL damaged underground pipeline while laying the discom cable bewteen Sonegaon Lake T-point and Sahakar Nagar on Wednesday.

Residents informed TOI that Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL) has taken up work to lay underground cables. “On Wednesday afternoon, the workers hit the pipeline damaging it badly resulting in springs of water flowing out from paver blocks of the cement road. As huge quantum of water was flowing out, the nearby lanes were flooded and water also entered a few houses,” the residents said.

After TOI, tipped by the residents, informed NMC’s water works department and Orange City Water, the concerned agencies swung into action and closed the valve to stop water supply to prevent further loss of treated water.

OCW spokesperson said repair work will be taken up on Thursday morning. “A police complaint will also be filed against the contractor for damaging the pipeline. We will also recover the cost of the repairs from the contractor,” the spokesperson added.

Residents also pointed out that the contractor carrying out the discom work was not following any precautionary measures. The pits dug out to lay cable were neither barricaded nor any warning boards were placed where the work was being undertaken, said the residents. Despite complaints to local corporators Pallavi Shamkule and Prakash Bhoyar, no corrective measures were taken, they alleged.

Title: TN: Missing boy’s body found in lake
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

TIRUVANNAMALAI: A 14-year-old school boy , reported missing since Monday, was found dead in a lake at Paingkinaru village in this district on Wednesday.

Police said R Karthick, a Class IX student at Paiyngkinaru village Tamil Nadu Housing Board Government School was reported missing by his father Ramakrishnan, a daily wager, at the Cheyyar police station on Monday evening. Police, after registering a case, were conducting an investigation to trace his whereabouts.

Around 8.30am on Wednesday, some villagers who were passing by spotted a body floating in the lake. Based on the information by the villagers, the Cheyyar police reached the spot and during investigation identified the deceased as Karthick.

Police officers, who collected an empty liqour bottle and a poison container close to the lakebed where Karthick’s body was found, registered a case of unnatural death and are investigating.

Title: Another plea to hold consecration in Tamil
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Madurai: Yet another public interest litigation (PIL) has been filed before the Madras high court seeking to conduct the consecration ceremony of Brihadeeswara Temple at Thanjavur district in Tamil.

Dr D Senthilnathan, a resident of Thanjavur district, in his petition, stated that he is the state organiser of Veerathamizhar Munnani of Naam Tamilar Katchi which works for the cultural resurgence among Tamil people. He stated the consecration ceremony of the temple is scheduled on February 5 after 23 years.

The authorities concerned are making arrangements for the ceremony without allowing Tamil and Thirumarai chants. Several devotees have submitted representations seeking to perform the ceremony in Tamil.

Two years ago when a plea was moved before the principal seat seeking to conduct consecration ceremony of Arulmigu Sundarar Temple at Thirunavalur in Villuppuram district, a single judge had directed to conduct the ceremony in Tamil.

Senthilnathan stated that he had also submitted a representation to the authorities concerned to conduct the ceremony of the Big Temple in Tamil, however, no steps were taken in this regard.

Hence, he moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to conduct the ceremony in Tamil by following the Tamil Saivaite Ahama (Thevaram and Thiruvasagam).

Title: HC contempt notice prompts registrar to act against 6 officials
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: On account of alleged negligence of its own employees, the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court took suo motu cognisance and issued contempt notice to its registrar (administration).

A division bench comprising Justice Zaka Haq and Justice Manish Pitale sought explanation from the registrar in this regard while asking him on why contempt action shouldn’t be initiated against him. It was only after the registrar initiated departmental action and censured six employees that contempt notice against him was recalled and proceedings were dropped.

The departmental action was mentioned in the service book record of four of them including Justice Pitale’s personal assistant, Shirastedar, and his court keeper. The staff of Justice Haq, including Shirastedar and personal assistant, were reprimanded for the lapses, HC officials told TOI.

The suo motu cognisance was initiated after Justice Pitale found that his stenographer wasn’t provided with a set of computer and printer when the HC reopened on January 2 after winter vacations. It hampered the court’s work for some time. Taking serious view of the negligence on part of HC officials, the bench observed that it was causing obstruction to delivery of justice and amounts to criminal contempt.

While issuing notice to the registrar, the judges asked him to conduct a probe and inform them about names of employees, who were responsible for the negligence. Subsequently, the registrar zeroed-in on seven officials and sought explanation from them.

The registrar then filed an affidavit on next day with names of the employees and an assurance was given that the mistakes/errors as noticed by HC wouldn’t be repeated. “Accepting the respondent’s assurance, notice issued is recalled and the proceedings are dropped,” the judges held.

During the same proceedings, the bench asked registrar that if names of erring officials were available with him, he should also inform on action taken against them. The registrar then filed another affidavit on the action taken against HC officials, absolving one as no evidence was found against him.

“Seen the affidavit filed on behalf of the respondent where it’s pointed out that departmental action is taken against the erring officers/employees. It was also informed that some orders are passed against them on administrative side. The officers/employees against whom any order is passed will be at liberty to avail remedy as per law, to challenge that order,” the judges said.

Title: Pune: Lab technician’s organs give new life to three
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Parents of a brain-dead laboratory technician (22) donated his vital organs to give a new life to three patients suffering from end-stage renal and liver diseases.

The organs were donated at the DY Patil Medical College and Hospital in Pimpri on January 18, while the transplants were carried out the next day.

The donor from Bidar in Karnataka was on a home visit to collect the blood sample of a patient when he collapsed. He was later diagnosed with intracranial haemorrhage and was shifted to our hospital on January 17,” said DY Patil Medical College and Hospital’s transplant coordinator Mayuri Ghatge.

An intracranial haemorrhage is a type of bleeding that occurs inside the skull.

Ghatge said he was declared brain-dead on January 18, following which his parents consented to donate his kidneys and liver. “The man was the sole-bread winner of the family. He has a younger brother. He had been staying in Pune for last two years,” she said.

“As per the norms of the Zonal Transplant Coordination Committee (ZTCC), the man’s liver and one of the kidneys were allocated to two patients enrolled with DY Patil Medical College and Hospital in Pimpri. The man’s another kidney benefited another patient of kidney failure at Poona Hospital,” ZTCC’s transplant coordinator Aarti Gokhale said.

Ghatge said, “The man’s liver was successfully transplanted into a 56-year-old man, a resident of Shriganganagar in Rajasthan. The kidney gave new life to a 35-year-old Pune man. Both the patients are doing good after the transplants and will be discharged in the next few days.”

Title: Swachh Bharat: Worker made to enter sewer in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

It seems that civic officials have forgotten the law, as it seems as if their Swachh Bharat dreams have caused... Read More

AHMEDABAD: It seems that civic officials have forgotten the law, as it seems as if their Swachh Bharat dreams have caused them to turn a blind eye to workers being made to enter sewers. One such case occurred in Viramgam town in of Ahmedabad district, where a 45-year-old worker was made to enter a sewer by officials of the Viramgam nagarpalika.

A video of the incident went viral, showing a worker identified as Mahesh Makwana, entering a sewer and removing sludge and stones from it with his hands. When asked what he was doing in the gutter, he said he was ‘just cleaning it’.

Makwana’s colleague, Atul Vaghela, said they work for the Viramgam civic body and for Rs 424 per day to clean sewers.When asked if machines were available to help them clean the sewer, Vaghela said, “Some stones were stuck inside the gutter and Makwana was trying to remove those stones which the machines cannot do. Some type of cleaning has to be done manually.”

The chief officer of Viramgam nagarpalika, Vinod Rathod, said he was unaware of any such incident.

Sources in the nagarpalika said that as the video showing Makwana entering the manhole went viral, Rathod called Vaghela and Makwana and scolded him for entering the manhole in broad daylight and threatened to sack them.Ahmedabad district collector K K Nirala was unavailable for comment on this issue.

In March 2014, the Supreme Court, acting on a PIL filed by Bezwada Wilson, founder of the Safai Karmachari Andolan (SKA), prohibited the practice of making workers enter manholes , septic tanks and sewers. The top court directed the state agencies to pay compensation of Rs 10 lakh for sewer deaths and told the government to identify the families of such workers who had died since 1993, when manual scavenging was first prohibited.

Out of 705 manhole deaths in the country, Gujarat reported 132 deaths between 1993 and January 2019, said activist Kirit Rathod, who blamed the state government’s lackadaisical approach for workers being made to enter manholes. The Gujarat government failed to prevent the practice of manual scavenging and pay compensation to families of of deceased manhole workers. A local NGO had also filed a public interest litigation (PIL) before the Gujarat high court seeking compensation for such families.

While hearing the PIL, the HC had in October last year observed about the state government’s approach, “It appears that, despite pendency of the matter and assurances to the court, the unfortunate situation still prevails under which on one pretext or the other workmen will have to risk their lives.”

“We are at pain to note that there is an absolute lack of sensitivity qua the issue, else this would not have happened. It goes without saying that the follow up, as prescribed under the Act needs to be placed on record qua those deaths also,” the HC stated.

Title: Road safety week: Free eye check-up held for bus drivers in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A free eye check-up camp was conducted at MGR Bus Terminal in Mattuthavani and Arappalayam Bus Terminal by city traffic police wing on Wednesday, in which hundreds of drivers took part and got their eyes checked. It was conducted as part of the observation of 31st Road Safety Week.

Madurai district collector T G Vinay took part in the camp held at MGR terminal, whereas deputy commissioner of police (traffic) K Sugumaran took part in the camp held in Arapalayam. A police officer from traffic wing said that at least 500 drivers, including TNSTC and auto rickshaw drivers, took part and benefitted from the camp held in Mattuthavani. Around 200 people benefitted from the eye camp held in Arapalayam bus terminal. “The camps are organized to make sure that drivers have good visibility, since issues in visibility can cause accidents, which may prove fatal not only for the drivers, but also for the other motorists travelling on the road. Those, who were found with eye issues, were given spectacles,” the police officer said. Many of the participants were found to be having visibility issues. Police officers said that the camp that took place at Mattuthavani was organized with the support of Aravind Eye Hospital and Apollo Specialty Hospitals, whereas the one organized at Arapalayam was organized jointly with Agarwal’s Eye Hospital.

Title: TN: Spurned lover posts nude photo of ex-girlfriend on social media, arrested
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

CUDDALORE: A 24-year-old man has been arrested on charges of posting a nude photograph of his former girlfriend on a social networking site. The arrested was identified as K Kalaiarasan of Kandachipuram in Villupuram district.

Police said Kalaiarasan was staying in the house of a relative in Cuddalore district and was working in a cellphone service shop. He befriended a 22-year-old woman working in the shop and later proposed to her. She accepted his proposal and the couple was in a relationship for the past three years.

Her parents, on learning about her affair, disapproved of it as they both hailed from different communities.

After this, the woman began avoiding Kalaiarasan following her parents’ advice, angering him.

Kalaiarasan decided to take revenge on her. The woman had earlier sent him a nude photo of her following repeated requests. He opened a new account on a social media site and uploaded the photo there. The woman and her parents were shocked to learn about the incident and lodged a complaint with the Cuddalore all-women police station.

Police booked Kalaiarasan under Sections 417 (punishment for cheating) and 376 (punishment for rape) of the IPC and 67 (punishment for publishing or transmitting obscene material in electronic form) of the Information Technology Act and arrested him. Police produced him before a local court that remanded him in judicial custody.

Title: MMC brings online CMEs for Maharashtra doctors
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representational Image

NAGPUR: Doctors working in small towns, villages and in remote areas can now get updated clinical knowledge through online continuous medical education (CME) facility launched by the Maharashtra Medical Council (MMC).

After accessing the online CME for six hours and answering a small questionnaire, doctors will get three credit points. These points are useful when doctors renew their registration with MMC.

“MMC launched this facility on a beta basis. A doctor can earn up to six credit points from online CMEs,” said Dr Vinky Rughwani, vice-president of MMC.

Doctors need to earn 30 points in five years to get renewal for the next five years. Practice without MMC registration is not allowed.

CMEs are held mostly in metro cities and big towns. Doctors practicing in small towns and remote areas are unable to attend such CMEs. Attending online CME is a good option for them. “We will see the response from doctors. MMC may think of increasing the point limit from six to 12 in the future,” Dr Rughwani added.

MMC’s module for the online CME is foolproof. The software is equipped with face reading facility. Doctors opting for CME must attend it by sitting in front of their laptops/computers/tablets for the entire six-hour duration.

After every CME, they have to answer online questions. They need to answer at least 60% of the questions to get online certificates. Credit hour certificates are generated automatically after completion of the CME and answering the questionnaire.

City’s doctors, who have been associated with organizing CMEs on various topics, felt that the online option is better as it will keep CMEs purely academic. “These days, many CMEs are conducted at tourist spots and doctors attend them just for formality. CMEs are more like get-togethers and not exercises in pure academics. The online mode will update doctors’ knowledge in the true sense and will eventually benefit patients,” said a senior doctor.

Title: Eidgah protesters’ number rise after SC devpt, Shah remarks
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Around 500 to 600 women and equal number of men are protesting at Jaffar Nagar’s Eidgah ground where Delhi’s S... Read More

Nagpur: Late on Wednesday afternoon, as the news about Supreme Court’s refusal to pass ex parte interim stay on the controversial law CAA spread, citizens from different parts of city began turning up in large numbers at the Jaffar Nagar’s Eidgah ground where Shaheenbagh style protest is underway.

While the number of women swelled beyond 500 to 600, men’s tally too matched them. The protest, organized by Nagpur Peace Organization (NPO), is meant to provide a platform for city women who had been staging the agitation in support of their Delhi counterparts at Shaheenbagh.

The SC development and reports of Union minister Amit Shah saying CAA will be implemented at any cost seemed to have awaken the minorities, who gathered in bigger numbers than the previous three days of this protest that started from January 19. The police permission for extending the protest till January 27 too was turned down even as cops have already ruled out anyone staying at the venue beyond 6pm.

NPO organizers said the protest will conclude on Thursday while an another permission has been moved for next week. A similar protest is likely to be held at Mominpura’s Farooq Nagar ground after this one.

Lawyer Mohammad Fazal said the matter being admitted by SC is an achievement in itself and that a larger bench will now hear it. “Citizens opposing the CAA must not be disheartened over today’s development. Four weeks time is given and there are number of issues for government to reply. Government representatives themselves are not aware of them,” he said.

On Shah’s comment, Jamaat-e-Islami Hind (West zone) member Zeba Khan, who is among the protesters, said the government is pretending as if it is not worried. “Then, why did they cancel their North-East tours? You don’t have Muslims there. This protest is not for one or two days but will continue for next four years,” she said.

NPO members Imran Noorani and Dr Aves Hasan said the SC development and what the home minister said in Lucknow must not be seen in isolation. “These two events are diversionary tactics to keep the nation busy with protest while the economy has crashed,” Dr Hasan said.

College student Ramsha Patel said the government must initiate a direct dialogue with the people. “There should be a solution through face to face dialogue. The government and police have failed the people,” she said.

Engineering student Yumna Ali said, “Amit Shah should know this is not right when so many people are against it. How can he say that the government will implement it at any cost,” she asked.

Housewife Sabiha Patel warned that the government is mistaking if it feels that citizens will settle down after some time. “Today, it is Eidgah, tomorrow it will be some other place. Protests will go on till CAA is scrapped,” she said.

Another housewife Farhana Syed said after this protest, they will start sending four people from each household. “Women are going to pack Delhi from all corners of the country till the law is repealed,” she said.

Teacher Tarannum Firdos said the protest was limited to Shaheenbagh but will spread nationwide. “We are becoming aware. We will not give up,” she said.

Title: Hyderabad cops help heart reach patient 10km away in 12 minutes during peak hour
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

HYDERABAD: The city traffic police created a green corridor on Wednesday morning to facilitate transportation of a live heart from Yashoda Hospital in Secunderabad to Care Hospital in Banjara Hills .

The police created the green corridor within short notice and escorted the ambulance, enabling it to cover the 9.7-km distance between the two hospitals within 12 minutes, during morning peak hour. The heart retrieved from a 41-year-old donor was transplanted to a 48-year-old recipient, Ashok Kumar.

Title: CBI arrests two from Dehradun Garrison Engineer’s office for taking bribe
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: After laying a trap, the Central Bureau of Investigation ( CBI ) on Wednesday arrested an Assistant Garrison Engineer and a Junior Engineer from the Dehradun Garrison Engineer office for accepting a bribe of Rs 40,000 from a Delhi-based contractor for clearing his payment of over Rs 20 lakh.

According to CBI officials, the firm had written a complaint against the two engineers and also submitted an audio recording of the two demanding bribe. Providing details, a senior CBI official said, “The complainant is a registered Military Engineering Service (MES) contractor who was awarded two contracts in 2018 but his payments were due.”

The complainant had visited the offices of the accused where they demanded bribe of Rs 20,000 each to clear the payment. After verifying all evidence and documents, a CBI team under the leadership of Sunil Kumar Lakhera laid the trap and nabbed the two engineers while accepting the bribe. The CBI team also searched the offices and residences of the two engineers. The details of recoveries made from the houses and offices of the two erring officials are yet to be known.

A case was registered under Section 120-B of IPC and Section 7 of PC Act. The two accused were arrested and produced in the CBI court in Dehradun on Wednesday.

Title: Maharashtra: Resident doctors affected with TB to get special leave
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

NAGPUR: In a major respite for more than 4,500 resident doctors in 17 government medical colleges in state, the Directorate of Medical Education and research ( DMER ) and ministry of medical education have agreed to sanction a special 2-month leave for resident doctors in case they get affected with tuberculosis (TB) while on duty.

While treating TB patients in hospitals, at least 100 resident doctors fall prey to tuberculosis every year. TB-affected doctors cannot work in hospitals. So, they go on leave until they recover up to the level that their infection report comes negative. This period varies from three weeks to four months.

As per old rules, residents going on TB leave had to compensate this period by working additionally after the end of their three-year tenure. But now, there will be no need to compensate this leave as it will be considered as part of their tenure. Doctors will get up to two months of such on-duty leave. This was one of the long-pending demands of the Maharashtra Association of resident Doctors (MARD).

“TB has been recognized as occupational disease by various authorities including Maharashtra Univeristy of Health Sciences. Resident doctors working in TB wards are on high risk of TB. Long working hours, poor living conditions are already taking toll of our health. In such condition, TB treatment needs to be given proper recovery period,” said Dr Kalyani Dongre, President of central MARD.

“While redressing a case filed by a resident from Nair Hospital in Mumbai, the DMER and authorities have allowed 2 months of special leave without extension or compensatory work period to the concerned doctor. This is a milestone decision and we will use it as a reference in future,” said Dr Ashutosh Jadhav, General Secretary of Central MARD who is from Nagpur.

DMER director Dr T P Lahane said that doctors getting infected with TB while they are on duty will get such leave. “Leave up to two months has been permitted for treatment and need not to be compensated by working additionally. This will benefit resident doctors,” he said.

Sharad Pawar to resolve stipend issue

A delegation of central MARD, on Wednesday, met NCP supremo Sharad Pawar in Mumbai. Members of the delegation claimed that Pawar gave them patient hearing and forwarded their proposal of stipend hike to medical education ministry and finance ministry. “We also spoke to medical education minister Amit Deshmukh. He has asked us to present the stipend pattern of central government for his reference. We will give the presentation at the earliest,” said Dr Ashutosh Jadhav, General secretary of central MARD. Residents also issued an official statement thanking Sharad Pawar in advance for forwarding their proposal of stipend hike. “We hope this new government brings change and we get our stipend hike soon,” reads the statement.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man injured in manjuvirattu dies in hospital
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The death toll in the Kandipatti majuvirattu in Sivaganga district , which took place on January 19, rose to two after a young bull tamer, who suffered injuries and was admitted to the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH), succumbed on Tuesday.

The deceased has been identified as A Prasath, 22, from Alangampatti. According to police sources, Prasath, who suffered grievous injuries when a bull gored him was rushed to a nearby hospital in Sivaganga district and was shifted to GRH the same day.

Earlier, C Vijayaragunathan, 46, M Kovilpatti village near Tirupattur was killed on the spot, when a bull gored through his neck. Around 151 registered bulls were let out during the event. However, more than 500 unregistered bulls were let loose by bull owners, which ran ploughing through the crowd. The deaths were caused by the unregistered bulls, let loose out of the ring, police sources said.

Meanwhile, 17 people were injured in the jallikattu event in Ulagampatti village near Thadikombu in Dindigul district on Wednesday. The injured were treated at the medical facility at the venue, while the grievously injured were referred to the Dindigul government hospital.

More than 300 bulls and 400 tamers took part in the event. The tamers were allowed to take part in batches. A large number of police personnel were deployed for safety measures.

Title: Waiting to call off pact, says AIADMK minister; BJP unmoved
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

This image has been used for representational purpose only

MADURAI/CHENNAI: Khadi and Village Industries minister G Baskaran has stirred a hornet’s nest by saying that AIADMK is waiting for an opportunity to break free from its alliance with the BJP as the people had not voted for the party in the rural local body elections because of the alliance. The minister also went on to say that there was a lot of opposition to the Citizenship Amendment Act among the ministers.

Baskaran was speaking at a function to commemorate the 103rd birth anniversary of AIADMK founder MGR at Ilayankudi in Sivaganga on Tuesday. “You have spurned us, but we won’t. We are waiting for opportunity to break off from the alliance with the BJP. All the ministers are opposed to the CAA,” he said.

However, on Wednesday senior minister and AIADMK spokesperson D Jayakumar said Baskaran’s statement may be treated as his individual view and it has nothing to do with the party’s policy decision on the alliance. “Only the party leadership will take a call on the alliance. The leadership will take the final call ahead of the 2021 assembly elections and that will depend on the political climate,” Jayakumar told TOI. When confronted by newsmen on Wednesday at Karaikudi, Baskaran sought to ‘clarify’ that only his comment regarding CAA was correct and that their alliance with BJP was inseparable.

Responding to Baskaran’s claim, BJP general secretaries K S Narendran and Vanathi Srinivasan said the party would prefer to ignore the views of any individual functionary or minister. “The two parties have an electoral alliance which will continue. The ally’s spokesperson has also clarified it and denied the statement of his cabinet colleague over the alliance,” said Narendran. Vanathi Srinivasan said they would be concerned only if they hear it from the “horse’s mouth”. Jayakumar has cautioned party functionaries and ministers from expressing their views on the alliance or internal matters of the party at open forums.

Baskaran had also said that AIADMK candidates had lost by three or five votes in the recently concluded local body elections. This in spite of the district administration being under the control of the ruling party. ``If we wanted we could have turned these losses into victories, but we acted fairly on the directions of chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami,’’ he said. ``Can you expect the same from a DMK government? They will beat you up and make you fall in line,’’ he said.

Title: Madurai has hundreds of share autos, but only 7 have permits, finds RTI
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Only seven of the hundreds of ‘share’ autorickshaws running in the city, have been registered with the regional transport offices in Madurai, a RTI (Right to Information) reply has revealed.

General secretary of the Madurai Consumer Protection Centre, G Muniasamy , had filed the RTI to find out how many share autorickshaws of the total 12,223 three-wheel autos operating with permits in Madurai, had permits. There are three regional transport offices - Madurai South, Madurai North and Madurai Central - in Madurai, which are authorised to provide numbers starting with TN 58, TN 59 and TN 64. The reply to the RTI on share autos says that Madurai north has one share auto plying with a permit, Madurai south six and Madurai central none.

Founder of Makkal Vizhipunarvu Trust K Hakkim, said the RTI shows that there are only 12,223 autorickshaws in the city, but there should be at least 25000 vehicles operating on the city roads. Many of them are three-wheel ‘share’ autos which carry more than the permitted number of three passengers.

“Just stand in front of the Periyar bus stand, where work is underway. There will not be less than 30 share autos at any given time,” he said. Hence, these unauthorised vehicles are posing a risk to the public who travel in them, he added.

The three-wheel autos have permits to carry only three passengers at a time. But, many of them have been altered in the name of share autos, with a two-tier back seat at two levels and they carry more than 10 passengers at a time. “They are cheaper than mini buses and more convenient as they stop wherever we tell them to. So, I take these share autos regularly for just Rs 10 for a four km journey,” said A Selvarani of Anna Nagar.

RTO officials told TOI that the share autos which were given permits were those with five seats, and permission to carry five passengers at a time. “Many so called share autos are violating the rules when they carry more than three passengers. We impound not less than 50 to 100 vehicles per day, but we are not able to control the menace,” they acknowledged.

Title: Black day in history of AP legislature: Buggana
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Andhra Pradesh finance minister Buggana Rajendranath Reddy

AMARAVATI: Finance minister Buggana Rajendranath Reddy has termed the decision of the legislative council chairman MA Shariff to send the bills to the select committee as “very unfortunate”.

Speaking to the media after the council chairman MA Shariff’s decision, Rajendranath Reddy said, “It is black day in the history of AP’s legislature. TDP influenced the chairman to take sides and violate rules.”

TDP supremo Chandrababu Naidu sat in the council gallery and ‘influenced’ the chairman to make the decision, he said. “It would be difficult to run the administration if the council acts like this,” said the finance minister.

He said members of the assembly, who got elected by the people have the right to make the laws and the chairman himself had agreed that there were no rules to send the bills to the select committee but he had taken the decision using his personal discretion, he said. tnn

Title: Linear accelerator arriving at RST Cancer Hosp next week
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: Rashtra Sant Tukadoji (RST) Regional Cancer Hospital, the only charitable cancer hospital in the region having tertiary cancer care centre (TCCC) status, will get an advanced linear accelerator machine used for providing more precise treatment to cancer patients.

Linear accelerator device is used for external beam radiation treatment of cancer patients. It delivers high-energy X-rays or electrons to the patient’s tumour. The device costs more than Rs20 crore.

“The machine will be of great benefit to poor cancer patients coming to the RST from the periphery of Vidarbha. It will reach RST by February 7,” said Dr Subhrajit Dasgupta, director of RST.

Dr Dasgupta also shared alarming facts from the latest figures released in the global adult tobacco survey.

“One good news is that tobacco consumption in Maharashtra has gone down from 31% to 25% in last six years. But, the same has doubled when it comes to the adolescence age of 15 to 17 years,” he said. Prevalence of tobacco use among persons aged between 15 to 17 has increased from 2.9% to 5.5% in last six years.

The RST has planned a series of events from February 2 to February 9 to mark World Cancer Day, which is observed on February 4.

For the first time since its inception, the hospital will organize a national oration in memory of Pt Shivkaran Sharma Chhangani, one of the founder members of the RST. This oration will be held on February 2 at 10am. Dr GK Rath, head of National Cancer Institute of AIIMS, New Delhi, will deliver a talk on ‘Cancer control programme in India’. This oration will be followed by a daylong academic exercise on recent advances in oncology.

National-level faculties will speak on radiotherapy, cancer immunotherapy, nanotechnology, ovarian cancer, colorectal cancers and breast cancer on the occasion.

On February 4, the institute has organized an awareness programme and a human chain will be formed on the hospital premises from 8.30am onwards. On February 9, it will host an academic event along with Indian Medical Association (IMA) Nagpur chapter. Renowned experts in the field of pulmonology, histopathology and medical oncology will share updates on lung cancer.

Dr BK Sharma and Dr Prasanna Joshi, both joint directors of the hospital, and Dr Ramkrishna Chhangani, chairman of the oration committee, informed that more than 20 social organizations and colleges in Nagpur will participate in the public awareness event on February 4.

Some facts about cancer in Vidarbha

Oral cancer is most commonly diagnosed cancer in Vidarbha

Over 30.60% of total cases registered at RST hospital are of oral cancer

In 2018-19, total 3,350 cases were found malignant in the hospital

Out of these, highest — 1,132 — were of oral cancer

Between 2014 and 2018, o total 15,951 cases, 4,881 were of oral cancer

Early exposure to tobacco is major reason for oral cancer in Vidarbha

Against national average age of 17.4 years, mean age of tobacco use initiation in Vidarbha is 12 years

Title: Partial demolition of Nagpur railway station flyover next month
Content:
File Photo

NAGPUR: MahaMetro , which has been asked by Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari to execute Jai Stambh Square traffic improvement scheme, plans to partially raze the Station Road flyover next month. However, opposition by shopkeepers to be affected may stall the plan.A MahaMetro official said that Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) had directed the agency to first rehabilitate the shopkeepers and then go in for the demolition. “There are 72 shopkeepers whom we have to rehabilitate. We have already constructed 40 temporary shops near the railway station and another 20 will be ready by the end of the month. Once the shopkeepers shift to the new shops, we will start demolishing the flyover from one side,” he added.The official said that the remaining shopkeepers wanted monetary compensation instead of shops. “It is yet to be decided as to who will pay the money, MahaMetro or NMC,” he further said.MahaMetro has plans to construct a big commercial complex to house the shops. It will be connected to the railway station by a foot overbridge. The agency will also construct a multi-level parking near the complex. City buses will use the ground floor while upper floors will be used for parking four-wheelers and two-wheelers.The flyover has to be demolished as MahaMetro wants to construct a six-lane road in front of the railway station. As defence land is required for the road, it will first construct a four-lane road and when the land becomes available another two lanes will be added.There are 165 shops below the flyover. The shopkeepers have two unions. The first union has owners of 72 shops, which existed before the flyover was constructed. They were allotted the shops by NMC at a cost of Rs8 lakh each. These shops are located in front of railway station entrances. The other union has 93 shopkeepers having their establishments away from the entrances. They got the shops by paying Rs10.20 lakh.The 93 shopkeepers don’t want new shops, but monetary compensation. They had met Gadkari, who agreed to their demand. They will meet mayor Sandip Joshi in this regard on Thursday morning.Nilesh Khorgade, leader of these shopkeepers, said, “We will be allotted shops at the backside and hence we won’t get any customers. Even now, we don’t get many customers as our establishments are at a distance from the entrance. We, therefore, want cash.”The other set of shopkeepers are not ready to shift to the temporary shops. “There are no drains and water connections in the complex. Most of the shops here are eateries. How will we function without drain and water? NMC must construct the commercial complex first and then demolish the flyover,” said Ramu Wankhede. Another shopkeeper said that he would approach the court if he was forced to shift to the temporary shops.

Title: Tamil Nadu: ‘Existing homebuyers can’t object to increase in units’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: In an order that allows promoters to tweak plans for upcoming phases in a real estate project to increase the number of dwelling units , Tamil Nadu Real Estate Regulatory Authority ( TNRERA ) has said that developers need to execute projects depending on market requirement. The realty regulator also dismissed a complaint by a homebuyer, who owns an apartment in a block, objecting to the developer’s move to raise the number of units, modifying the initial planning permission.

The case pertains to a gated community project, ‘Viva City’, at Kannivakkam near Guduvanchery, developed by XS Real Properties Pvt Ltd. According to complainants J Sethu Ragu Raman and D Sathiyapriya, who purchased an apartment in the project, the gated community was advertised as a development comprising seven blocks with 352 units, with two and three BHK apartments ranging from 583 sqft to 1,084 sqft having various common amenities.

While 176 dwelling units were built as per the approved DTCP plan in 2013, the developer obtained a revised planning permission to increase the number of dwelling units to 571, a rise of 219 units or more than 50%, for the new project, ‘En Veedu’, on the same premises. Noting that the developer was duty bound to get the consent of the purchasers before modifying the plan, the complainant said it was illegal.

In response, the developer said due to recession and depressed market conditions, they could not proceed with the phased development as planned “originally”. With the Centre launching the PMAY scheme that facilitates subsidy on EMI on housing projects for first-time buyers in 2016, the developer, through a subsidiary, obtained a revised approval for two existing blocks and fresh approvals for upcoming phases from DTCP in October 2017. The size of the apartments was tweaked — measuring 60 square metres per dwelling unit — to make the buyers eligible under the PMAY scheme. The homebuyers gave their consent for changes in undeveloped portions, the developer said, adding that the revised plan was as per the rules and regulations of DTCP, which has been registered with TNRERA.

After hearing the arguments, TNRERA said the developer completed and handed over the apartments to the complainants three years ago. Stressing that real estate market conditions are dynamic and the builder has to construct apartments according to market needs, the order said the authority was unable to find fault with the developer’s decision to go in for larger number of smaller apartments taking advantage of the Centre’s scheme on affordable housing.

“Therefore, the complaint is devoid of merits and hence it is dismissed,” the order added.

Title: Economic census begins, enumerators told to clear misconceptions too
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mysuru: The Economic Census 2020 began on Wednesday in the city with the launch of a mobile application by commissioner of Mysuru City Corporation Gurudatta Hegde.

The enumerators and supervisors who conduct door-to-door survey of houses and commercial establishments to collect data have also been given the task to clear misconception that the census is linked to CAA, NRC or NPR.

The IT-enabled economic census is done by the Common Service Centres (CSC). The CSC has hired 220 supervisors and 890 enumerators who have been trained to collect data on mobile application developed for data capture, validation, report generation and dissemination. They would collect data through door-to-door survey of each household and commercial establishment.

CSC district manager Mahantesh told TOI that the census will be conducted block-wise. “Each block will have 66 investigator units (IV) and each unit will have nearly 400 households and 2,000 people. The survey map has been provided by National Sample Survey Organisation (NSSO) and Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI). The enumerators are being trained to create awareness to the public on the census and clear the misconception,” he said.

After launching the census, commissioner Gurudatta Hegde said that the public should provide accurate information to the enumerators as the data will be used for implementation of development programmes by the government.

“The census is not related to CAA or NRC or it is done to track the tax defaulters. The enumerators will ask basic questions to which the public should give accurate details. The data collected will be kept strictly confidential and used only for development planning. The enumerators will visit each block thrice during the census to avoid any miss out,” he said.

As there were reports that the enumerators were verbally and physically attacked by miscreants in few districts, commissioner Gurudatta had written to the police to provide necessary security to the enumerators during the door-to-door visit in certain sensitive areas.

In the sixth Economic Census which was held in 2014, there were 1.4 lakh commercial establishments–88,062 in rural and 52,170 in city–in the district.

MCC deputy commissioner (administration) B C Shivananda Murthy was present.

Box

Swachch assessers complete the task

Commissioner Gurudatta said that Swachh Survekshan assessors who had visited the city to inspect cleanliness have concluded the work and have returned.

“Nearly 45,000 people have given their feedback by participating in the survey. We have set a target of more than one lakh feedback. We have organised programmes at Infosys and L& T on Thursday where we encourage them to participate in the citizen feedback to vote for Mysuru,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus alert: Cial opens health counters
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: As part of the precautionary measures in the wake of Novel Coronavirus (nCoV) disease outbreak, the Cochin International Airport Ltd (Cial) has opened special health counters to check passengers at its immigration desk. Passengers coming from Far East and Southeast Asia will be screened at these counters for fever or any other ailments, which are considered symptoms of the disease. The move was after instructionsfrom the ministries of civil aviation and health affairs to mandatorily implement preventive measures following high alert around the world.Passengers coming from suspected areas, mainly China, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore, are being briefed about the health issues and the precautionary measures to be followed. There are no direct flights from China to Kochi and those passengers from China would have to come via Southeast Asian nations or Sri Lanka. Hence, passengers travelling in those flights from these countries are also monitored. There are around eight flights from these countries to Kochi daily.“Special health counters with doctors and paramedical staff have started operating near the immigration desk throughout the airport working hours. Passengers are asked to fill up a form seeking health details. Also, an isolation ward has been set up at the Government Medical College, Ernakulam. So far, 28 passengers (coming indirectly from affected areas) have undergone screening tests. All tests were negative,” said an airport official.The passengers’ passports are being checked to know whether they have been to any of the affected areas recently. Special masks and gloves were distributed to officials deployed in the international arrival area. Special transportation arrangements, including a sterilized ambulance, were made ready to transport suspected passengers to the medical college isolation ward,” an official said.

Title: JS, BJP to hold march in support of farmers
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vijayawada: Jana Sena and BJP have decided to conduct a ‘ Kavathu ’ (long march ) from Prakasam barrage to Swaraj maidan in the city in support of Amaravati farmers on February 2.

Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan, who spent a busy day in the national capital on Wednesday, met senior leaders of the BJP, including finance minister Nirmala Seetharaman. Later, talking to reporters along with state BJP president Kanna Lakshminarayana, BJP leaders D Purandarswari and GVL Narasimha Rao, he announced that both parties are committed to fight against the state government’s decision on shifting the capital from Amaravati.

Pawan said the long march is aimed to give moral strength and support to the Amaravati farmers who sacrificed their valuable lands for the welfare of future generations of the the state. The 5km-long march with start from Seethanagaram lakulu at Prakasam barrage and conclude at Swaraj maidan, where Mahatma Gandhi addressed a few meetings during the freedom movement.

Jana Sena leaders said they will seek all necessary permissions from the police for the peaceful march. Around 2 lakh farmers besides activists from the two parties will participate in the long march, they added.

Title: Special buses to ferry visitors to Kolkata International Book Fair
Content:
The transport department will run 400 dedicated buses for Kolkata International Book Fair from 3pm to 9pm. Tra... Read More

KOLKATA: The transport department will run 400 dedicated buses for Kolkata International Book Fair from 3pm to 9pm. Transport minister Suvendu Adhikari on Wednesday published a booklet detailing the routes in presence of Booksellers and Publishers’ Guild president Tridib Chatterjee and general secretary Sudhanshu Shekhar Dey .The buses will cover all major destinations – Sealdah, Howrah, Parnashree, Behala, Shakuntala Park, Thakurpukur, Garia, Jadavpur, Kamalgazi, Raja Bazar, Habra, Chiria Mor, Barasat, Bally, Baruipur, Barrackpore, Santragachhi, Rathtalam Belgachia, Titagarh, Dankuni and Park Circus. Special shuttle service will be run from Sealdah, Kamalgazi, Tollygunge, Rathtala, Ultadanga.The 44th Kolkata International Book Fair is slated to start on January 29 and end on February 8. The fair will be inaugurated by chief minister Mamata Banerjee.Meanwhile, the Guild has decided to list all old-age homes in the city and donate mini-libraries to them. This, they feel, can be an antidote to loneliness that grips elderly citizens who live away from family. “No one can keep company better than books. “Neither can they visit libraries as frequently as possible nor can most homes afford a library. So we have decided to step in,” said Dey.Efforts are being made to make the event eco-friendly, though the details are not known yet. Guild members said that the state urban development department has laid out elaborate plans for this and is about to announce them soon. CESC, which partners thefair, is doing its bit to serve the environment. It will publicise the use of electric vehicles and will also have an electric two-wheeler parked at the fair along with a charging point to encourage book lovers to vote for these emission-free modes of transport.The theme country of the fair this year is Russia. “We will have the ambassador of Russia to India, Kudashev Nikolay Rishatovich, and many dignitaries and writers from Russia at the fair,” said Chatterjee. Other than Russia, 20 countries will participate in the fair. There will be at least 40 publishers from Bangladesh who will participate this year.

Title: Panel set up to monitor pollution in Tamirabarini river
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

MADURAI: The National Green Tribunal (NGT), southern zone has directed the constitution of a joint committee comprising the district collector of Tirunelveli, senior officer of the Central Pollution Control Board , executive engineer of the public works department and others, to monitor the mixing of sewage in Tamirabarini river, and submit the action taken report to prevent the same, in two months’ time.

In a petition filed before the tribunal, S P Muthuraman, expert member, had stated that the discharge of untreated sewage into the Tamirabarini in Tirunelveli district was polluting the river. It is not just a source of irrigation but also caters to the drinking water needs of Tirunelveli and Tuticorin districts. The pollution control board has a duty to monitor and regularise the issue and take action against the Tirunelveli Corporation for dumping sewage into the river, he said.

Justice K Ramakrishnan and expert member Saibal Dasgupta directed the formation of the committee, as directed by the principal bench of the NGT, New Delhi. The committee should monitor the water quality of the river, including TDS, BOD, COD, total coliform, fecal coliform and other hazardous metals and specify if the untreated effluents or sewage still continues. The report on the action taken should be filed before the tribunal in two months. The TN pollution control board will be the nodal agency and will provide logistics, the order said.

Title: Hand over all wards of Eden Hindu Hostel to us: Presidency University students
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

File photo

KOLKATA: Presidency University students continued with their demonstration on Wednesday to demand immediate handover of all the wards of Eden Hindu Hostel .

“We immediately need to start boarding of the hostel, which has five wards. Only two are operational,” said students’ union president Mimosa Garai. The boarders also want an increase of staffers, like cooks and attendants, at the hostel.

“Vice-chancellor Anuradha Lohia had requested the students to meet her and resolve the problem. But the students have declined to meet her,” said dean of students Arun Maity.

A boarder claimed that the wards which are kept open have an acute space crunch. “The VC has to give us assurance that the problems will be taken care of,” he said.

Title: ‘Transparency needed in functioning of public trusts’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: A public trust means an entity express or implied for either a public, religious or charitable purpose or both, and includes a temple, or any other religious or charitable endowment and a society formed either for a religious or charitable purpose or for both. A trust is registered under the Societies Registration Act of 1860. There is no central act to govern public trusts, but various states have enacted their own laws according to their conditions and administration. The funds belonging to the trust need to be spent on the objects stated for the trust. This can be ensured if required transparency is maintained in the day to day operations of trusts, said additional commissioner of income tax (exemption) Dr Kishor Dhule.

He was addressing a seminar on public trusts organized by Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) as a chief guest.

Dhule said a public trust is set up for the specific benevolent purpose for the benefit and need of the beneficiaries who may not be specifically defined in the trust deed. Management of the trusts should not be left unchecked, so that the purpose for which the trust is set up is not vitiated.

Title: Woman and son attacked with acid for delay in clearing bills
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vijayawada: A 60-year-old woman and her 40-year-old son sustained serious burn injuries after they were attacked with acid at Voletivaripalem village in Prakasam district on Tuesday. The injured were identified as Puvvada Ramesh (40) and his mother Lakshmi Kotamma (60), both from the same village and they run a private business.

According to Voletivaripalem police, the incident happened at around 6.30 pm when the accused Medikonda Anjaiah (28), who runs a milk booth, had a heated argument with them over delay in payment. Cops said that the victims had gone to Anjaiah’s milk booth to repay the balance amount they owed him, when tempers flared and Anjaiah abused both the mother and son over the delay in payment. He even threatened to attack them with the acid that was lying on the side.

Cops said that when Ramesh was leaving, Kotamma, provoked by Anjaiah’s arguments, dared him to try throwing acid at them.

In a fit of rage, Anjaiah took the bottle of the concentrated acid and threw it on the mother and son, causing grievous injuries.

Locals rushed the two victims to a local government hospital. Both of them have been declared out of danger, but Kotamma, being a senior citizen, is still struggling to respond to treatment.

Cops arrested Anjaiah and registered an attempt to murder case against him. Further investigation is still on.

Title: South traffic guard black spots keep cops worried
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolkata: The south traffic guard — comprising some of the posh zones, including Park Street and Maidan — is now home to Kolkata’s latest accident black spots. Review meetings on fatal accidents in November and December at Lalbazar have revealed that there have been nine deaths under this guard, most of them involving bus passengers. Worse, the trend continues in the new year as well.

Most of these deaths were reported from two important thoroughfares —JL Nehru Road (at the Park Street crossing) and AJC Bose Road (a part of it is under Vidyasagar traffic guard too). Accidents were also recorded on Mayo Road and Dufferin Road.

Sources said that an analysis of CCTV footage showed that the bus bay at the Park Street crossing was proving to be inadequate to accommodate so many vehicles during peak hours. “Some buses, especially government buses, tend to use the car lanes and stop in the middle of the road. Buses on same routes also race with one another, forcing passengers to get off or board on road. In their hurry, they become careless. Some trying to board with luggage fell on the road, leading to accidents,” said a police officer.

The erratic pedestrian movement — like getting off moving bus and trying to cross over, turning a blind eye to signals — has also led to accidents, claimed an officer present at the review meeting. “The failure to dereserve tram tracks on Dufferin Road to facilitate bus movement has also contributed to the rising number of accidents in this area,” said an officer from the south traffic guard.

“Both RR Avenue and Dufferin Road are death traps. Several accidents have been reported earlier — two persons losing their arms and a sergeant losing his leg — from these areas. For the time being, we want the buses to stop at the designated stop on RR Avenue. The usual practice is to race out of SN Banerjee road, use the middle flank and try and cross the Curzon Park signal in a jiffy. With the road now further constricted due to Metro works, monitoring the zone is a challenge. We will also try to restrict pedestrian movement,” said an officer.

Title: Ensuring basic amenities local body chief’s duty: Minister
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

MADURAI: Panchayat representatives are instrumental in taking various government schemes to the people and making them benefit from the same. The role of panchayat presidents and vice-presidents is crucial for the development of panchayats, minister for revenue, disaster management and IT, R B Udayakumar said on Wednesday. He was speaking after inaugurating a one-day training programme for elected local body representatives, including panchayat presidents and vice-presidents in Madurai. Udayakumar said that chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami had ordered the programme for all elected representatives to inform them of their duties. The central and state governments are implementing many welfare schemes through the rural local bodies, for the social and economic upliftment of the people in villages.

It is the responsibility of the president to ensure that there is potable water, street lights and other basic amenities in the villages. Udayakumar said that the panchayat representatives should give priority for the implementation of various government schemes, including Mahatma Gandhi Rural employment generation scheme, greenhouse scheme, Swachh Bharat mission, in their villages. Village panchayat presidents and vice-presidents from Thirumangalam, Kallikudi, T Kallupatti, Sedapatti, Usilampatti, Chellampatti and Thiruparankundram were also told that they should work and perform with an aim to receive awards for best panchayat chiefs in the next Republic Day, when their services would be evaluated and recognised.

In Dindigul, district collector M Vijayalakshmi presided over the meeting. The collector said that local bodies were the basis of the democratic set up of the country. By enhancing basis infrastructure and facilities, social justice and economic upliftment can be established in villagers. Income of villagers have been enhanced through government schemes. Kudimaramathu works, power supply, and solid waste management was implemented well in the villages. Also, all financial transactions in villages must be done through electronic transactions, so panchayat representatives should be prepared for the same, she said.
