In 2017, Goel was diagnosed with stage two breast cancer. Instead of several chemotherapy sessions, she chose to undergo two surgeries, radiation therapy for a few days and healthy living and positive thinking.

Now 42, Goel says that she has been given a second life, in which she has chosen to follow her childhood passion for biking. On January 26, she will embark on her maiden long-distance bike ride—a distance of around 3,000 km—to give strength to cancer patients and spread cheer among them.

Along with AP’s first female solo biker Vaishalli Kulkarni More, Goel will embark on the Coromandel to Konkan ride that will be flagged off from RK Beach Road on January 26.

Speaking to TOI, Goel said, “I have now a reason to chase my passion and to prove that women are strong. This ride will be my milestone and I have future plans to ride to other cities of north India.”

She added, “It took me six months to get back to normal life without chemotherapy. I was able to win this battle only because of a healthy lifestyle, positive thinking, inner strength and family support. I also urge every person to spend time with themselves and to do what they love. Physical activity should be a part of the daily routine of every individual.”

Title: Two arrested for killing teen over affair
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Prime accused in Samakhiyali police custody on Wednesday

Rajkot: Two persons who killed a 19-year-old youth in Shikarpur village of Bhachau taluka in Kutch district on Tuesday morning over a love affair, were arrested on Wednesday. Police said the accused duo, Mustaq and Imran Traya, had stabbed Jadeja to death.

Slain Kripalsinh Jadeja had eloped with Mustaq’s sister on January 19. They were caught from Momaimora village of Rapar taluka in Kutch district on January 20. On Tuesday, Mustaq and Imran went to Jadeja’s house and called him up to strike a compromise, said cops.

“The accused first allegedly kidnapped Jadeja in their car, took him to Bhachau-Bhuj highway where they slit his throat and then dumped the body in the main bazaar of Shikarpur village,” said A P Jadeja, sub-inspector with Samakhiyali police station, adding that Mustaq and Imran were arrested on the complaint by Jadeja’s brother Rajendrasinh.

“When Jadeja and Rajendrasinh came out of their house, they asked them to sit in their car and drove the brothers to the highway. On the way, they stopped the car and at knifepoint asked Rajendrasinh to go away. They then killed Jadeja,” said the police official.

The police have deployed bandobust in Shikarpur to maintain law and order after the situation turned tense, after the news of Jadeja’s murder spread. Cops have also seized the car belonging to Imran in which Jadeja had been kidnapped.

Title: Many highrises still at high risk
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vadodara: Besides fighting regular fire incidents, Vadodara Fire and Emergency Services biggest challenge lies in making high rise buildings equip themselves with proper fire fighting infrastructure — a battle that they have been waging for past several years to no avail.

According to the fire department records, city has around 643 high rise buildings. Of these, only 350 have fire fighting equipment in working conditions as well as fire department’s no-objection certificate. Eleven buildings in different areas are among those that have never installed any fire fighting equipment since inception.

“New buildings which have come up after GDCR (General Development Control Regulations) and after the National Building Code came into effect, have all infrastructure in place. The problem lies with old buildings as the builders then never installed any of these measures and occupants now find it expensive to install everything from a scratch,” said a fire officer.

There are high rise buildings which have come up in past 10 years and have the infrastructure to tackle fire, but its occupants’ lackadaisical attitude towards regular maintenance render these useless, he added.

The GDCR have several details regarding construction of building including lobbies and corridors, installation of elevators, staircases among others so that losses in case of fire can be minimal.

Fire department sources said that as the power with them is limited, nothing can be done besides serving notices to the properties. “In the past we had sealed buildings, which we are not supposed, and snapped water connections but the owner would use political connections and our efforts turn out to be futile,” another fire officer said.

“We have chalked out a list of buildings which do not have no-objection certificates and respective fire stations will issue notices to them. However, this time we will be talking to the municipal commissioner to snap water connections of such buildings that fails to act within 30 days of our notice,” said in-charge chief fire officer Parth Brahmbhatt.

Title: Breast cancer cases in Tamil Nadu rising by 4% yearly: Data
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A recent data presented by the Union health minister, Dr Harsh Vardhan, in reply to a question in Parliament on December 13 shows that the estimated number of breast cancer cases in Tamil Nadu has been steadily increasing by 4% every year.

As per the data, taken from the National Cancer Registry Programme, Tamil Nadu is estimated to have the fifth highest number of breast cancer cases in the country. It is the only state in South India to feature in the top five list.

Oncologists say that there seems to be no specific reason for Tamil Nadu’s numbers to be high. But attribute the increase to multiple factors - increasing obesity rates, increasing infertility rates among women and mutations of BRCA genes affecting more Indians. They say better reporting and diagnosis of cases could also lead to the number.

As per the registry, Tamil Nadu had around 10,269 breast cancer cases in 2018. In 2016, the state had 9,486 cases, which went up to 9,870 in 2017.

Dr R Swaminathan, who heads the Madras Metropolitan Cancer Registry in Adyar Cancer Institute and contributed to the National Cancer Registry’s data, confirms the data.

“In Chennai alone, the incidence of breast cancer in every 1 lakh women is increasing by 2%. Breast cancer has been increasing every year,” he says.

Tamil Nadu’s numbers are only lower than Uttar Pradesh, which had the highest number of estimated cases at 24,181, Maharashtra 16,358 cases, West Bengal 12,234 cases and Bihar 11,378 cases. While Karnataka’s figures are at least 10% lower than Tamil Nadu’s figures, Andhra Pradesh and Kerala’s estimates in 2018 are at least 40% lower.

“The Globocan 2018 data also found breast cancer to be the most common form of cancer in Tamil Nadu, and we think multiple factors contribute to this largely hormone driven cancer,” says consultant oncologist and associate professor at PSG Hospitals, Dr Kiruba Shankar.

“There are studies that show Tamil Nadu has high rates of obesity due to the growing affinity towards fast food and junk food. This eventually affects your hormones,” Dr Shankar says.

Growing rates of infertility and more people opting for hormone replacement therapy are also among the reasons for high breast cancer cases, say doctors. “Breast cancer is of three types and mainly hormone driven. We believe that increased exposure to estrogen in a woman’s lifestyle can increase risks. This happens due to too many menstrual cycles. Not having children or not breast feeding, and late menopause could also lead to increase in breast cancer,” says director of Sri Ramakrishna Institute of Oncology and Research, Coimbatore, Dr P Guhan.

Oncologists say what is more worrying is that breast cancer is affecting women in late twenties and early thirties, who ignore it as screening for breast cancer is usually advocated only after 40. “Even in the West, breast cancer is seen more in women’s end of fifth decade and sixth decade, but in India we are seeing a majority in the fifth decade, and number of women getting it in their third and fourth decade itself. So, more women should do self-examinations after they turn 30 and importantly approach at least their family doctor if they notice any abnormal swelling, lump or nipple discharge,” says Dr P Guhan.

However, doctors say all the above issues are present in other states too. “It could be a hereditary factor with many women today getting the gene mutation from their mothers or grandmothers, but we don’t see too many breast cancer cases due to this in Tamil Nadu. It could be better reporting of cases and more diagnosis also contributing to the numbers,” says Chennai-based oncology consultant Dr Bellaramine.

Title: Pune: Casual worker dies after assault, college student, 6 teens held
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

PUNE: A 21-year-old man was arrested and six boys — all school students aged 14 to 17 and coming from well-to-do families — were detained for allegedly assaulting a 24-year-old casual worker, who later succumbed to a head injury at the Sassoon hospital.

The assault took place at the Munjaba vasti chowk in Dhanori shortly after Tuesday midnight. The victim, Sagar Mahadev Bhalerao, was walking to his house at the vasti when he allegedly abused the arrested suspect, Pritam Rajkumar Jagdale, for riding his motorcycle close to him, an officer from the Vishrantwadi police said.

Citing preliminary investigation, assistant commissioner of police Laxman Borate told TOI, “Jagdale and one of the minor boys was heading home on his Royal Enfield motorcycle when he drove close to Bhalerao. The latter reacted instantly by allegedly abusing and threatening Jagdale. Jagdale challenged Bhalerao and told him to meet him at the nearby chowk. On the way to the chowk, Jagdale and his minor associate phoned the other boys, who gathered at the chowk. As soon as Bhalerao reached there, they launched a brutal assault on him.”

Borate said, “One of the assailants attacked Bhalerao with a bicycle chain, another hit him with a stick while the others dealt him kicks and blows. Bhalerao was initially admitted to a private hospital and later shifted to the Sassoon hospital where he died around 4.30am on Wednesday.”

Senior inspector Arun Avhad of the Vishrantwadi police told TOI, “We are waiting for the post-mortem report. However, doctors at the Sassoon hospital, in their preliminary opinion, have cited head injury as the primary cause of death.” A senior doctor at the hospital also confirmed to TOI that the victim had died of a head injury.

Borate said the fathers of three of the detained minors are state government officers while the other three fathers are employees of prominent private companies. “The six boys study in different schools but stay in the same neighbourhood. Jagdale is pursuing his graduation studies from a city college,” he said.

“There were a few paan kiosks open around the spot, but none of the local residents intervened in the fight. The boys left after Bhalerao fell on the road,” he said.

“A passerby called the police control room following which beat marshals from the Vishrantwadi police reached the spot. Bhalerao was sitting on a cement fence along the road. When the police asked him about his injuries, he said he had fallen on the road. He said that he was fine and would like to go home. He made no mention of the attack. On reaching home, Bhalerao narrated the incident to his younger brother Shubham, who took him to hospital,” Borate said.

The police arrested Jagdale on Wednesday morning.

Title: Touts, illegal vendors stay put at airport 14 days after FIR
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolkata: Unauthorized parking, touts pestering and conning flyers, illegal food stalls and unauthorized structures: everything that the city airport authorities had lodged a complaint against at the Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International Airport police station a fortnight ago continued to operate with impunity on the airport premises.

To highlight the extent of the problem, the authorities had even attached a copy of the TOI’s report on taxi touts fleecing passengers published on December 30, 2019. Following the FIR registered on January 7, police had started a case under IPC sections dealing with extortion, criminal trespassing and criminal conspiracy and assured the authorities of taking strict action. But when TOI visited the airport on three consecutive days between January 20 and January 22, nothing seemed to have changed. In fact, some of the problems, like VIP vehicles blocking the area in front of the gates, were back. After TOI had earlier reported extensively on the illegal parking of VIP vehicles, the authorities had ensured that the cars waited at their designated lot, but the watch was ostensibly not maintained and the vehicles were back to flouting rules.

“We have asked the police time and again to take action against these illegal activities, which have not only been causing heavy losses to AAI revenue but have also been maligning the image of the Kolkata airport, considered the gateway to the east. They are also a big security threat to our passengers,” said airport director Kaushik Bhattacharjee.

The authorities in the complaint mentioned encroachment by food vendors , some of whom have set up temporary stalls in the area opposite the old terminal building, an unauthorized canteen being operated out of the building that housed the police station, an unauthorized car rental company—M/S Helpline—occupying the counters in the arrival lane and that they illegally operated their taxis. The complaint also mentioned two problems that TOI had highlighted time and again: vehicles being parked at non-designated places, like the area in front of the existing and old terminal buildings and taxi touts fleecing passengers right under the nose of the cops. Stating that the encroachments in front of the old domestic terminal and the city side area in front of it came in the way of the expansion work of the new terminal building, the letter, signed by deputy general manager (commercial) V Nandhini requested the authorities to make arrangements and evict the squatters at the earliest.

But police claimed they had started a case under IPC sections 384 (extortion), 447 (criminal trespass), 120B (criminal conspiracy) and 34 (common intention). “We have taken action against touts, clearing the airport premises of such men carrying out illegal activities. Also, we have made a dedicated parking bay for VIP vehicles and our personnel have been directing the VIP cars, clogging the area in front of the terminal, there. As for the other irregularities mentioned in the complaint, we undertake regular drives against all squatters,” a senior officer at Bidhannagar Commissionerate said.

However, when TOI visited the airport on Monday and Tuesday, the correspondent found VIP cars still clogging the area in front of the arrival gates of the terminal building for hours without anyone booking them, a number of suspicious-looking men standing outside Gates 2A/2b and 3A/3C, approaching fliers coming out of the airport and asking them to book cars with them. TOI also found scores of temporary stalls in front of the old domestic terminal, selling food, like rice and curry to fries and dosa, and a number of other stalls, selling tea and cigarettes. Asked, the owners said they regularly paid some men, who allowed them to operate out of there and that even if they had to move out during police drives, they could be back in a few days. A representative of M/S Helpline claimed they had the necessary authorization and allegedly paid an annual GST of Rs 4.5 lakh.

Title: Unreserved tickets help fill South Central Railway coffers
Content:
272 trains were running during Sankranti last year

SECUNDERABAD: South Central Railway (SCR) zone witnessed a footfall of 91.3 lakh unreserved passengers from January 11 to January 20, owing to the Sankranti festive rush . The unreserved segment brought in Rs 45.7 crores to SCR’s revenue. SCR has announced 456 special trains from January 5 to January 25 to take care of the extra passenger rush.“The increase in the number of unreserved passengers commuting through the zone is 2.4 lakh more than last year and around six lakh more than regular average,” SCR officials said.Passengers travelling to and from their native places and the regular weekend rush contributed to the substantial rise in numbers, officials said. They added that the rush is expected to continue till the end of the month.“Daily travellers at premier stations such as Secunderabad and Kacheguda are expected to touch four lakh, which is double the usual number. We have, therefore, made additional arrangements, such as erecting extra counters, ATVMs, and CoTVMs. The dissemination of information was done through print, electronic, and social media and by putting up signage at prominent places,” said a senior SCR official.The zone almost doubled its running capacity this year, amid complaints of crowded compartments in reserved bogies, high ticket prices and insufficient trains.“It is hard to grab a ticket in Suvidha category. Some say that the first 20 per cent of tickets can be bought at tatkal rates, after whichcost goes up in increments,” said Raja M, who had to purchase a ticket to Vijaywada at three times the normal rates.

Title: Heroin route: Uttar Pradesh to Bangladesh via Kolkata
Content:
Moulana Fayazuddin

KOLKATA: The special task force of Kolkata Police , probing into the heroin haul worth Rs 105 crore in the international grey market, found that the contraband was to reach the city from UP where it was mingled with the mixture coming from northeast before being smuggled across “international borders”.“Such a huge consignment cannot be meant only for this city or the state. We believe this was to be taken to the border areas for smuggling into Bangladesh . Such a corridor has been in existence from early 2000 when we busted a gang that used a similar modus operandi. There was even a shoot-out with gang members and the UP STF,” sources said.Cops are certain that both the accused — Maulana Fayazuddin (49) from Manipur and Juber (40) from UP — were trying to mix two types of drugs following the demands of different customers from across the country.“The two were mere carriers but even reaching them is a difficult task. The chain started when we nabbed a local dealer from AJC Bose Road. From there we reached his dealer in Tiljala. This led us to the UP linkman who finally spilled the beans and our sources worked accordingly on the leads,” said a police officer.Though the suppliers relied more on traditional methods of communication, those who had procured the contraband used encrypted messaging platforms like Telegram and WhatsApp.Sources ascertained the value of the seized heroin following its rate per kilogram as mentioned on the website of the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime. “As per the website, one kilogram of heroin is around Rs 40 lakh at the selling point where the raw form of the contraband is produced and processed.The drug has to pass through six or seven channels to cross Indian borders. Drug dealers have to bear 30% to 40% illicit value in addition to the actual rate at each channel. Eventually, when the contraband reaches India, it costs between Rs 3.5 crore and Rs 4.5 crore per kilogram, depending on quality,” said the police officer.According to the police, the increase in drug addiction among youngsters has become a major issue in the past few months. “Recently, several drug dealers and drug peddlers have been arrested for selling the contraband to school and college students. To curb the menace, we are planning to get in touch with school and college authorities and conduct counselling sessions for students to prevent them from getting addicted to drugs,” said a narcotics cell officer.

Title: Secunderabad: Woman in search of job raped, two held
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

Title: Valparai man sentenced to life in prison for killing live-in partner
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 38-year-old Valparai resident was sentenced to life imprisonment on Wednesday for murdering his live-in partner.

The convict, Vijaykumar of Murugali Estate in Valparai, was staying with 32-year-old Nalini, a married woman, at the Sendur Velavan Poultry Farm in Oddakkal Palayam. “During a quarrel on November 21, 2018, Vijaykumar attacked Nalini using an iron rod. Nalini passed away at the Coimbatore Medical and Hospital. Vijaykumar claimed that Nalini died after consuming poison due to harassment by their employers at the poultry farm,” a police officer said. However, postmortem confirmed that it was murder. Inspector Vetrivel Rajan, who spoke to witnesses at Nalini’s work place, confirmed that Vijaykumar used to frequently get drunk and abuse her. Justice Tr Gunasekeran of the additional district judge court 1 sentenced Vijaykumar to imprisonment and also slapped him with a fine of Rs 1,000.

Title: CTET application process to start tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

VISAKHAPATNAM: Central Board of Secondary Education ( CBSE ) will conduct the 14th edition of Central Teacher Eligibility Test ( CTET ) on July 5. The test will be conducted in twenty languages in 112 cities all over the country.

The information bulletin containing details of the examination, syllabus, languages, eligibility criteria, examination fee, examination venues and important dates will be available on CTET official website www.ctet.nic.in from January 24. Aspiring candidates are requested to download the bulletin from the given website and read the same carefully before applying.

Candidates have to apply online through CTET website www.ctet.nic.in. The online application process will start on January 24 and end on February 24. The fee can be paid up to February 27 till 03.30 pm.

The fees for taking paper I or II is Rs 1,000 and for taking both papers is Rs 1,200 for general and OBC categories. The same is Rs 500 and Rs 600 for SC, ST communities and differently-abled persons.

Title: Ensure basic amenities to people, min tells new panchayat heads in dist
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Coimbatore: Local administration and rural affairs minister S P Velumani on Wednesday called on the newly-elected village panchayat presidents and vice-presidents to remain directly in touch with the public and take care of their basic amenities.

He was speaking at the one-day training programme that the district administration organized for them. The event was attended by more than 300 panchayat presidents and vice-presidents from the district. They were trained in fund management, taxation, prioritization of funds and other administration related issues.

The minister also urged them to become good and able administrators. “Unlike MLAs who win with party support, you have won independently because you have already done service to the people. So, continue doing that and ensure that people’s basic amenities like roads and water are taken care of.”

Velumani said it was former chief minister, the late Jayalalithaa, who initially put in place a legislation reserving 50% of panchayat presidents’ posts for women. “It was she who gave me the strength and backing to pass the legislation. Compared to earlier times when panchayat presidents had no funding, as local minister I always allocate lots of funds for local bodies,” he said.

The programme at Kalai Arangam mainly focused on training the new panchayat heads in managing funds, as it was critical to take up development and infrastructure works in their villages. “They were mainly taught about the funds that they are entitled to as a local body and other funds that they could access if required and how to apply for the same. They were also trained in how to handle tax revenue and how to prioritize spending and implementation of various projects,” said an official with the district administration. “They were also told about how to organize a gram sabha, its frequency, ways to conduct it and how to choose beneficiaries for government welfare schemes.”

Title: Vizag cops arrest three TDP youth leaders
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: Three Telugu Yuvata leaders, including Greater Visakha Urban TDP president Lodagala Krishna, were arrested by the city cops when the TDP leaders were trying to lodge a complaint at the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) against chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy and minister Botcha Satyanarayana .

The leaders told the media that the YSRC’s decision of having three capitals in the state would do nothing but create unrest between the regions and castes, and would also only benefit YSRC leaders.

“Amaravati Metropolitan Region Development Area (AMRDA) had no legal sanctity like the Andhra Pradesh Capital Region Development Authority (APCRDA), which was set up by the central government’s special development authority,” they alleged, adding that AMRDA had no power to cancel APCRDA.

Even before the yuvata leaders lodged their complaint, cops arrested them.

Title: Pune: Truck runs over pillion rider at Katraj crossing
Content:
Man killed when a truck hit the two-wheeler at the Katraj Chowk signal

PUNE: A 25-year-old man riding pillion on his friend’s motorcycle was killed when a truck hit the two-wheeler at the Katraj Chowk signal and ran over his head on Tuesday night.Police said Nilesh Daund of Katraj fell from the bike when the rear end of the truck hit the two-wheeler after the driver of the heavy vehicle jumped the red signal and took a sharp turn from the crossing towards the Pune-Satara highway.As the driver failed to control the truck on the gradient, it started rolling back and went over Daund’s head, the police said. Bike rider Lahu Kondhalkar (28) of Ambegaon Khurd escaped unhurt.The police arrested truck driver Mani Palani (29) of Tamil Nadu from the spot for causing death due to negligence under the Indian Penal Code and Motor Vehicles Act on Wednesday night. A local court on Thursday released Palani on bail.Kondhalkar in his FIR said the accident occurred while he was waiting at the crossing. Though TOI contacted Kondhalkar on his phone, he refused any comment.Investigation officer Mohan Deshmukh from the Bharati Vidyapeeth police station said the accident occurred at the point from where the gradient towards the Pune-Satara highway started.“Investigations revealed that the motorcycle was headed for Dattanagar and the truck was proceeding towards Guzarwadi. Four witnesses, in their statements to the police, blamed the truck driver’s negligence for the accident. We have seized the truck. The Regional Transport Office, Pune, will inspect the truck,” he said.The Sassoon General Hospital, in its advance post-mortem report, stated that Daund died due to multiple injuries. Pune Municipal Coroporation officials and traffic branch and Bharati Vidyapeeth police station police officers jointly inspected the accident spot on Thursday.Assistant inspector Shrishail Chiwadshetti from the Katraj police chowkey said, “The pillion rider was holding a machine used to cut window glass. As the truck hit the bike, he lost balance and fell on the right side of the road. By then the truck had started rolling back on the slope and ran over his head. On reaching the spot, we stopped an autorickshaw and took Daund to a nearby private hospital. But the doctors in the hospital said he was dead by then.”Truck driver Palani told TOI that he had taken the turn after the signal turned green. “The biker was coming from the rear and hit the truck. The pillion rider lost balance and fell on the road. I am not responsible for the accident.”Sanjay Khopade, who runs a sugar cane juice stall near the crossing, said, “I came out of my shop on hearing a loud noise. I saw the man lying on the road, bleeding profusely. By then, some other people had gathered at the spot. We told the truck driver not to leave the spot.”Satish Mulay, owner of a paan stall, said the accident occurred because the truck did not stop at the signal. “The narrow bypass was widened a few years ago. The slope should be further reduced,” he said

Title: 10 new e-buses hit the streets, fleet swells to 80
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolkata: The number of AC electric buses in Kolkata swelled to 80 on Wednesday, with the transport minister Suvendu Adhikari inaugurating 10 more vehicles.

The West Bengal Transport Corporation (WBTC) plans to run only electric buses, after phasing out the existing diesel-run vehicles.

While most of the new buses will ply existing routes of AC12 and AC23A, a new route, from Howrah Station to Salt Lake’s Karunamoyee (AC59A) was also introduced. “Electric buses will reduce the carbon footprint of WBTC, which serves the Kolkata metropolitan area. We aim to be a zero-emission corporation by 2030,” said a senior WBTC officer, adding the plan was to have an entire fleet of 5,000 electric buses in a decade.

With the e-buses replacing the old, fume-spewing vehicles, the carbon dioxide emission will be cut down by 7,82,560 tonnes a year. But the shift would be gradual, said a senior transport official. A total of 100 new e-buses are being bought for Haldia and Durgapur-Asansol and the government is ready to set up 241 charging stations in Kolkata. New Town, which also houses a booming IT hub, already has a fleet of e-buses and the number will go up to 50.

“The state has got approval for another 150 electric buses under the Fame II scheme,” an official said. All depots of West Bengal Transport Corporation at Tollygunge, Kidderpore, Kasba, Gariahat, Park Circus, Rajabazar, Lake Gardens, Belgachia, Nabanna and Santragachi, have been provided with charging infrastructure. Some private organisations are also setting up facilities for charging in the city.

The transport department on Wednesday also granted sanction letters to 1,500 beneficiaries under Gatidhara scheme and distributed 10 trauma-care ambulances to different organisations under road safety programme. The Howrah City Police got 10 motorcycles and CCTV cameras for traffic management. Two long-distance permits for AC buses, one from Santragachi to Patna and the other from Contai to Puri, were also given.

Title: Revenue board stays JDA housing scheme
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Jaipur: The revenue board has stayed the Jaipur Development Authority (JDA)’s recently proposed housing scheme, Shiv enclave in Zone-8, which was receiving tremendous response from residents.

The civic body had launched the scheme in December 2019 and invited applications to allot a total of 346 plots. The last date of submitting applications is 25 January. The scheme will be developed on the land of village Ganpatpura on at Goliyavas Circle near Prithviraj Nagar.

An official said the dispute cropped up over ownership of the land. Farmers who once used to cultivate this land has approached the Revenue Board claiming the ownership. However, the title of the land is recorded in JDA's account. A senior official said, “We would draw the lottery on the scheduled date. JDA’s point of view was not taken into consideration. We are confident that stay will be vacated as ownership and possession of land is with JDA.”

Official claimed the dispute would be settled before issuing the lease deeds to successful applicants.

Till Wednesday, the JDA received 17,700 applications. The scheme is receiving tremendous response as after long the civic body has proposed to develop the scheme inside the city near Muhana Mandi.

The civic body has fixed a reserve price of Rs 25,000 per square-metre. The plots, sized between 45 square-metre to 220 square-metre, will be developed in the colony. Officials claimed there was an overwheleming response as it is situated on the 200-Feet Road connecting Muhana and Gopalpura Road. A senior official said, “The move is expected to boost revenue that will be utilised to develop infrastructure. As the market condition has improved, the JDA will also fill its coffers after auctioning plots in other old scheme,” he said.

Title: Is Gujarat MLA Ketan Inamdar eyeing some prized post in the govt?
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Savli MLA Ketan Inamdar

VADODARA: Savli MLA Ketan Inamdar may have grabbed headlines by tendering his resignation as an MLA on Wednesday, but this is not the first time that he has gone against the party. He is a known rebel who has contested twice against party candidates.

Also, Inamdar has expressed displeasure over the state of affairs earlier too. In June 2018, he had gone into a huddle with Raopura BJP MLA Yogesh Patel and Waghodiya BJP MLA Madhu Shrivastava over similar issues. He had then rued that MLAs were not respected by officials who dilly-dallied with works suggested by legislators

Notably, Patel was subsequently made a minister and Shrivastava was made the chairman of the Gujarat Agro Industries Corporation. Inamdar did not find favour for a post at that stage and was left sulking.

Inamdar began his political career by contesting gram panchayat polls that are not contested on party banners. An independent candidate initially, he later contested that district panchayat polls in 2005 on a BJP ticket but was not successful. He was suspended from the party later due to indiscipline, but joined it again in 2009. This stint with the BJP too proved short

Inamdar was denied a district panchayat election ticket in 2010 and contested as an independent. Many believed that Inamdar was a strong candidate despite his shortcomings and deserved a district panchayat ticket. He proved them right and won the polls. Once again, he joined the party in 2011.

But when he was denied at ticket for the 2012 assembly polls, he rebelled again and contested as an independent. He was the only independent who was successful in the polls in the state. He joined the party again after winning the polls and has remained with it since then.

He won the 2017 assembly polls from the BJP.

According to top party sources, Rupani and Vaghani have called Inamdar to meet them in Gandhinagar on Thursday. They have reportedly also asked him to refrain from speaking with media persons.

Amit Chavda, state Congress president said, “BJP MLAs are clearly frustrated with the functioning of their own government. Inamdar is only the beginning. Many many more senior MLAs and BJP leaders are also fed up of the government’s misrule”.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Pawn broker shop owner held for duping customers
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The district crime branch police arrested a 28-year-old man on Wednesday afternoon for duping the customers of his pawn broker shop of Rs 25 lakh. Police identified the arrested as M Sakthivel , of Housing Unit at Anna Nagar near Kavundampalayam . He was running the pawn broker shop titled Beema Gold at K Vadamadurai near Thudiyalur .

A police officer said Sakthivel was held based on a complaint lodged by Lawrence, of Anbu Nagar at Podanur. In his complaint, Lawrence said Sakthivel used to offer loans at lowest interest rate to the people who pledge gold ornaments with his pawn broker shop. Lawrence, the officer said, pledged 15 sovereigns of gold and obtained loan from Sakthivel. “When Lawrence tried to get back his gold by paying the loan amount, he came to know that Sakthivel had sold them to other people.”

Based on Lawrence’s complaint, the district crime branch police registered a case and conducted an inquiry. The preliminary investigation revealed that he had received gold ornaments from various people and sold them to others. A team led by sub inspectors Arun and Lenin subsequently arrested Sakthivel on Wednesday. He was later produced before a judicial magistrate court and lodged in jail under judicial custody.

Title: 94 MSU students to get PhD degrees
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vadodara: A total of 94 students will receive their PhD degrees at the 68th annual convocation ceremony of M S University to be held on January 29.

Professor D P Singh, chairman of the University Grants Commission (UGC) will be the chief guest of the convocation for which preparations have already been started.

Of the 94 PhD students, 48 are girls. Students of faculty of science will bag the maximum number of PhD degrees with a total of 32 students including 17 girls and 15 male students.

From the faculty of arts, 21 students including 13 male and eight female students will receive PhD degrees while 13 students including eight male students and five female students from the faculty of technology and engineering, will receive their PhD degrees.

Eight and seven students respectively from faculty of family and community sciences and faculty of pharmacy will receive PhD degrees. Four students from faculty of education and psychology and three from law faculty will be conferred PhD degrees.

Title: Goa: Church to hold public meet against CAA, NPR on Friday
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Catholic Church to hold public meet against CAA NRC and NPR

PANAJI: The Council of Social Justice and Peace (CSJP), which is the social work wing of the Catholic Church , will protest the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and the National Population Register (NPR) at a public meting at Lohia Maidan, Margao, on Friday. The group will be joined by the National Confederation for Human Rights (Goa unit) and Concerned Citizens for Democracy.

“It is our common conviction that these measures are unconstitutional and, therefore unacceptable. The government must listen to the voice of the people and withdraw the Act. It can then engage in wide consultation if it still wishes to proceed with any form of legislation regarding citizenship,” CSJP’s executive secretary Fr Savio Fernandes told reporters at Margao on Wednesday. He said the government should also take note that this is the first time since the Partition that people across the country have demonstrated an unyielding show of unity to register their protests on the streets.

Educationist Prabhakar Timble and social activists Oscar Rebelo, Rama Kankonkar, Muzafar Shaikh are scheduled to speak at the Margao rally.

The council has stated that the government is resorting to the abuse of law and order mechanisms and intelligence agencies to suppress this people’s movement. “We have noticed how, in many parts of the country, the government has been high-handed in undermining the protests. It has unleashed violence and adopted intimidating tactics against peaceful protesters. Here in Goa, conceding to threats by a fringe group, permission granted to citizens of Mapusa for a peaceful protest was revoked on flimsy grounds,” Fernandes said.

“It is unlawful to disenfranchise genuine citizens whose legal rights to stay in this country cannot be challenged. In view of this vicious and deceitful method of de-citizenising millions of people, must not only reject the proposed NPR process but refuse to cooperate,” he added.

Title: Coimbatore's Race Course police station best in Tamil Nadu, bags award
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The Race Course police station is equipped with a library, pantry, gym, creche and lactation room apart from r... Read More

COIMBATORE: The Race Course police station (C2) in the city has bagged the award for the best police station in the state.

The station earned 4,212 points to rank in the top while the Dindigul town north police station was placed second with 4,034 points and the Dharmapuri police station bagged the third place with 2,512.5 points.

City police commissioner Sumit Sharan and Race Course police station inspector Sakthivel will receive the ‘Tamil Nadu Chief Minister’s Trophy for the Best Police Station’ from CM Edappadi K Palaniswami in Chennai on Sunday.

The Race Course police station is equipped with a library, pantry, gym, creche and lactation room apart from ramps for disabled people, reception room, waiting hall, toilets, conference hall, investigation rooms and CCTV cameras. There is even a lawn.

The British Government had set up the facility, called B4 police station, in 1913. The old police station building was demolished, and a new building was constructed in November 30, 2015, when it was renamed C2 police station. It houses law & order, crime and traffic wings.

It was in 2018 that the state government set up the award to honour three best performing police stations.

Under the guidance of the city police commissioner, deputy commissioner L Balaji Saravanan took measures to modernize policing and created awareness among the personnel on the need to solve cases in a time-bound manner and the importance of treating visitors politely.

The RS Puram police station (B2) in the city had received the award for the best police station in the country in 2018.

Title: Tamil Nadu government empowers more officials to check bonded labour system
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

CHENNAI: After framing a standard operating procedure ( SOP ) to identify, rescue and rehabilitate bonded labourers, the state government has taken yet another progressive step to check bonded labour in industries by empowering the directorate of industrial safety and health (DISH) to check for such practices during inspections on industrial premises.

The ministry of labour and employment has passed an order to this effect. Following the government order, the directorate has asked its officials to invoke the provisions of the Bonded Labour System (Abolition) Act, 1976, during inspections. “The authorities have acted upon repeated pleas from the stakeholders,” said an official in the department of labour and employment.

The scheme, according to the department, is aimed at transparency in inspections by adopting computerised risk-assessment-based inspections and random allocation of inspection officers. It would be conducted once in two years in factories under high and medium risk categories, and once in five years in low-risk industries, said an official.

The team assigned for the task will check whether the industry complies with the provisions of 18 Acts including The Factories Act, 1948; The Minimum Wage Act, 1948, and The Child and Adolescent Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986, and ensures safety and welfare of the workforce.

Now, the Bonded Labour Act has been added to the list. “This will go a long way in eradicating bonded labour. The standard operating procedure to deal with bonded labourers will also give the necessary push to end the menace in organised sectors,” said the source.

Officials from DISH have also attended special training programmes on bonded labourers and SOP in the first week of January. “Bonded labour prevails in many forms, from forced labour to denial of basic rights. We have explained to them in detail the indicators of bonded labour in organised sector. Most of the officials were under the impression that bonded labour exists only in unorganised sectors like brick kilns,” said an official.

“Once the team finds elements of bonded labour in industries, the SOP will come into play,” he added.

Going by the SOP, the district collector would form a multi-disciplinary team comprising police, revenue and labour department personnel along with two eye-witnesses. They would take further legal action and rehabilitate rescued labourers, said the official.

Title: Coimbatore: Man held with red sanders worth Rs 4.27 crore
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 44-year-old man has been arrested with 9.5 tonnes of red sanders worth Rs 4.27 crore at Kaniyur Toll plaza on the outskirts of the city. They have also seized the truck used to smuggle the red sanders.

A Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) official said they nabbed Rajkumar, of Vellore , while he was smuggling red sanders to the district from his hometown on Tuesday.

S Balasubramanian, special public prosecutor for customs and DRI, said Rajkumar was produced before the chief judicial magistrate court on Wednesday and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under judicial custody.

The DRI officials have launched a probe to find out other people who are involved in the smuggling.

Title: Kolkata News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolkata: Mayor Firhad Hakim on Wednesday directed the civic electrical department to conduct a health study of all the lamp posts in the city and submit a report on the findings by next one month. The move came two days after a five-year-old boy was killed when an old lamp post broke in two and fell on him at Ekbalpore on Monday. Hakim also told his officials to cut off the wires that some cable TV operators had illegally bunched up on lamp posts, adding load to the structures and making them vulnerable.

Hakim said a borough-wise survey of the existing lamp posts should be carried out to find any fault in the structures. “I have asked senior KMC officials to conduct a detailed survey of the city’s lamp posts. If any lamp post anywhere in the city is found to bear extra load or structurally unsafe, it will be pulled down,” he said.

About the huge mess of cables being bunched up on lamp posts, he said, “Some cable operators have been flouting rules and using our lamp posts to string up their wires. This must stop. I have asked the KMC electrical department to snap all such wires ,” Hakim said.

According to a KMC electrical department official, the survey will focus on some essential facts: the age of the lamp posts, the state of maintenance and to what extent the cable wires have been damaging. “We will consider all such factors while conducting the survey. If need be, we will cut off cable wires, where they have become a threat to the lamp posts,” he said.

Title: Anna University will remain a state varsity, says official
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Anna University

COIMBATORE: Anna University would remain a state subject even after bifurcation, said Mangat Ram Sharma , principal secretary to the department of higher education, on Wednesday. He said the fear that the university would come under the Centre’s control after bifurcation was unfounded.

The state government had in December decided to bifurcate Anna University with one section getting the Institute of Eminence (IoE) status and the other providing affiliation to engineering colleges across the state.

Pointing out that there was an impression that the university would come under the Centre’s control by according it the IoE status, he said, “These are unfounded fears. It would always remain a state university and it will be bound by all state university laws.”

He was speaking to reporters on the sidelines of the inaugural session of the 33rd Biennial Conference of Home Science Association of India that was held at the Avinashilingam Institute for Home Science and Higher Education for Women in the city.

He said a decision on bifurcating Anna University was likely to be arrived at after one or two more meetings by the committee of ministers formed for the purpose and discussions with academicians.

Title: In distress? ‘Bhai’ is here to help
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: Six BTech and BCom students from the city have designed an app—Bhai—to reach out to men and women in distress, such as victims of accidents or someone stranded in an unsafe situation. By pressing the alert button of the pre-installed mobile application, the user’s location will be sent to the nearest police station within a 20-km radius and some trusted contacts will be alerted.

Explaining the app, its designers E Jeevan , an engineering graduate from Gayatri Vidya Parishad , and his friend BCom student Atchuta Shiva Shankar said that following instances of assaults on women, especially after the Disha incident in December, they started designing an app for the safety of women and men.

“The central idea of the app is to react, respond and rescue before damage is done. This will be useful for any individual who travels alone to new places and requires help. This app is also useful for anyone in case they meet with an accident or require medical attention in remote or unknown areas,” explained Jeevan, who also runs NGO ‘Bhai’ (Begging Hands Abolition in India) to rescue child beggars and enrol them in school.

Twenty-two-year-old Shiva Shankar, who conceptualised the app, said, “The app has been devised in such a way that basic details of the user such as name, age, residence will be registered while installing the app. Police can verify the profile of each user to check any fraudulent or hoax calls. In the future, we plan to update the app to differentiate between medical and non-medical alerts. We have also spoken to the city police commissioner about the app and he has been supportive.”

Others associated with the Bhai app include Aedidea Innovations, KSG Sarma, K Lohit Sai, A Praveen and K Umesh Chandra – all are students of Gayatri Vidya Parishad Engineering College , Kommandi.

Title: Team Safe to educate 1.5 lakh school kids on traffic safety
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vadodara: School students across the city are set to get some basic education in traffic safety. The police department has launched an initiative along with Team Safe to make them aware of safe driving on city roads. Fifty students from M S University will visit hundreds of schools throughout the year to teach them about road rules.

“The team will reach out to 350 schools and educate nearly 1.5 lakh students. The team of college students has been trained by the traffic police department. The teams will be divided into two students each who will go to the schools,” said Anupam Singh Gahlaut, city police commissioner.

“The idea is to catch them young. If school children are educated about safe driving and traffic rules, the city roads will become safer in the coming years,” said Satyen Kulabkar, a member of Road Safety Council. The school students will also be made aware of traffic signs. tnn

Title: Pune: Woman robbed of gold chain worth Rs 2.2 lakh on Pashan hill
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

PUNE: The Chatushrungi police are on the look out for an unidentified man, who robbed a 37-year-old woman from Baner of her gold chain worth Rs2.20 lakh. The woman was out for a morning walk near Biodiversity Park on the Pashan–Baner hill on Tuesday when the man attacked her.

The woman, despite being pushed by the robber, managed to grab him for a while before he was able to free himself and run away. She chased him for some distance but in vain. The woman sustained a few bruises around her neck in the scuffle with the attacker.

In her FIR, the woman has stated that she left home to drop her children at their school around 8.30am. At the school gate, she met her friend and they decided to go for a walk on the hill before returning home. They started climbing the hill from the Baner side and reached a small temple near the Biodiversity Park around 9.40am, the report states.

The complainant said that they took a few photographs and selfies at this spot and started walking ahead around 9.45am when she realized that a man was following them. Soon, the man charged at her, she stated. Before she could gather herself, he grabbed her gold chain. The woman held on to one end of her chain and tried to pull down the suspect by catching his hair but the suspect managed to push her away, the FIR stated.

According to the police, the man managed to snatch her gold chain weighing 110gms and ran downhill. The woman attempted to chase him for a distance.

When contacted, the complainant told TOI, “I meet my friend regularly near the school but this was the first time we decided to go for a walk on the hill. We climbed the hill and halted near the Biodiversity Park. There were a few people present at the spot. We decided to walk a little ahead to the small temple. While walking, I realized somebody was following us. My friend had walked a little ahead of me and just when I stopped, the man charged at me, pushed me and grabbed my chain. I decided to retaliate but he managed to snatch the chain and ran away towards the Baner-end.”

Sub-inspector Mohan Jadhav of Chatushrungi police station said, “We have noted down the suspect’s description as provided by the complainant and her friend. We suspect the man may be a criminal on record. We will soon arrest him.”

Title: Chennai: Musicians to hold mega event in June
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

UDHAGAMANDALAM: Global Carnatic Musicians’ Association (GCMA) has decided to hold a mega event in Chennai in June.

The executive meeting of the GCMA took the decision on Tuesday. President of GCMA and well-known Carnatic musician Sudha Raghunathan said, “Compilation of thought process of the artists for the mega event is underway. It is certainly going to be one of its kind.”

General secretary of the association and Carnatic musician Nithyasree Mahadevan said, “In the past six months we have organized three events, including a musical prayer, ‘Mega Raga Varshini’ in last July and a lecture demonstration series at Tamil Nadu Government Music College in last September.”

The executive committee members of GCMA include musicians such as Unni Krishnan, Guru Saran, Sowmya, and Priya sisters, besides mridagnists K V Prasad and Muruga Bhoopathi, among others.

Title: Hi-tech exam complex for 25k students in city soon
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Patna: The Bihar School Examination Board (BSEB) will construct a first-of-its-kind exclusive examination complex in Patna having the seating capacity of more than 25,000 examinees at a time. “It will be the biggest examination complex in the country,” said a senior BSEB official on Wednesday.

Equipped with CCTV cameras, cellphone jammers and webcasting facility to check unfair means, the examination complex will come up on a plot of 6.79 acre land near the Old Bypass, around 100 metres before the connecting road to Mahatma Gandhi Setu.

“The complex will have 44 halls with the seating capacity of 20,680 offline examinees. Besides, another premises will have 20 separate halls with a seating capacity of 4,400 online examinees. A total of 25,080 examinees can sit in all the halls at a time,” BSEB chairman Anand Kishor told CM Nitish Kumar while making a presentation about the proposed complex here on Wednesday.

“A police barrack for at least 52 police personnel will also be built up there to ensure 24X7 security in and around the examination premises. Moreover, the premises will have residential quarters for supporting employees,” Kishor said.

The BSEB chairman also informed the CM that the board has already got possession of 5.78 acre land and a proposal for transfer of another 1.11 acre has been sent to Patna district magistrate.

After reviewing the presentation, the CM told the BSEB officials that there would be no difficulty in transferring 1.11 acre land as it is ‘gairmazarua’. He said since a big pond is existing on the land, the BSEB should ensure its proper beautification during the construction of the examination premises.

The CM also suggested for construction of a pathway around the examination premises so that visitors can walk around it. He said the boundary wall of the complex should be so strong that there would be no chance of any irregularities during examinations.

Nitish asked the officials to ensure proper road connectivity and metro connectivity to the examination complex. He said officials of road construction department and building construction department would make an on-the-spot survey of alignment of proposed Patna metro and ensure its proper connectivity with the examination complex through a wide road.

Title: Pune: 2 college students held for stealing smartphone
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representational Image

PUNE: The Yerawada police on Thursday arrested two college students and detained their minor accomplice for robbing the smartphone of a car driver from Aurangabad.

The incident occurred near Gunjan talkies chowk here around 4.30pm on Tuesday.

The driver, Afsar Sharfuddin Shaikh (36) from Beed bypass in Aurangabad district, had come to Pune for some work.

“Afsar left for Aurangabad from Pune when he stopped at an eatery for a cup of tea. The men riding triple seat on a motorcycle came from behind. One of them robbed his smartphone and sped away,” said senior inspector Yunus Shaikh, in-charge, Yerawada Police Station, on Wednesday.

Shaikh told TOI, “Afsar raised an alarm when a beat marshal passing through Gunjan chowk intercepted the students and brought them to the police station. The motorcycle used in the crime was seized.”

“Both of the students are in standard XI and study in different colleges. They are known to each other. Investigations revealed that they snatched the driver’s phone but ran out of luck after they were caught by the beat marshal,” he added.

An offence has been registered under sections 392 (robbery) and 34 (common intention) of the Indian Penal Code.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Curbs on palm oil import will push up subsidy burden
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

CHENNAI: The Centre pressuring traders not to import palm oil from Malaysia , world’s second largest producer of the commodity, is likely to increase Tamil Nadu’s food subsidy from March.

The state buys palm oil at Rs 90 per litre and supplies it through PDS shops at Rs 25 a litre by subsidising the commodity. It supplies pulses and other essential commodities also at subsidised rates with a view to keeping prices of essential commodities under check in the market. More than 35,000 PDS shops across the state supply about 1.5 crore litres of palm oil every month. The present contract for procurement of palm oil ends in February. “We will continue with the special PDS supplies and edible oil will be very much part of it, irrespective of the price hike of the commodity. We foresee a price rise on account of imports from Malaysia virtually coming to a halt. Palm oil from Indonesia is coming at a higher price. But that won’t deter us from supplying palm oil through PDS,” said a senior official.

The civil supplies corporation buys imported oil from a private supplier – chosen through an open tender in December for three months. Including 67.5% import duty, the procurement price is Rs 90 a litre. The consumption pattern varies from district to district. The poor in Tamil Nadu prefer to cook using palm oil and PDS shops have been supplying it for more than a decade. “The supply is maintained through periodical tenders. Whether it comes from Indonesia or Malaysia is not our concern. When fresh tenders are floated for future supplies, the rates could go up further depending on the price of Indonesian oil,” another official said.

A senior official in civil supplies corporation said they were looking at other alternatives for palm oil. “We have rice bran, sunflower and groundnut oils as alternatives. If need be, we will procure them,” said the official. The government has allocated Rs 6,000 crore food subsidy for the current financial year. Of this, subsidy for palm oil is roughly Rs 500 crore.

Title: Official held accepting bribe
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vadodara: An official of the Singvad taluka panchayat in Dahod were held while accepting a bribe for clearing bills for making toilets in houses in villages in the taluka panchayat area under the Swachh Bharat Mission (SBM).

The toilets for the left-out beneficiaries in the taluka were to be made by Om Sai Mahila Mandal based in Pipaliya. The organisation had also signed a memorandum of understanding with the taluka panchayat to prepare 99 such toilets.

The organisation made 12 such toilets in a month’s time. It prepared a bill of Rs 1.2lakh that was submitted to the taluka panchayat. Supervisor and in-charge cluster coordinator (SBM) Chandrasinh Patel allegedly sought a bribe of Rs 11,000 to clear the bill.

The complainant was not willing to pay the bribe and approached the Dahod Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) with a complaint. ACB laid a trap to nab Chandrasinh and when the complainant went to give the bribe, Chandrasinh sought an additional Rs 500 for accounts assistant Haresh Patel.

The complainant gave Rs 11,500 as bribe to Chandrasinh who was nabbed red-handed while accepting the cash. Sleuths could not nab Haresh during the raid as he was not present at the spot where the bribe was accepted.

Title: Soon, bill to give statutory status to madrasas: Min
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Jaisalmer: Minority affairs minister Saleh Mohammad on Wednesday said soon a bill would be brought to give statutory status to madrasas.

After the bill is passed, modern facilities will be provided at madrasas so that children get better education.

He said this while inspecting a minority hostel in Barmer on Tuesday. He said chief minister in his budget announcement had made provision of Rs 10 crore to make madrasas smart.

Mohammad said madrasa Act was being prepared for multidimensional development of madrasas. Teachers at the district and state level will be awarded for providing quality education.

He said the state government had prepared the draft of the bill. He said those madrasas where the number of parateachers was more will be sent to other madrasas after rationalisation.

madrasas will be given budget for computers along with smart rooms and sports items will be given.

The number of seats at the minority hostel, which currently has 150, will will be increased to 200. He directed district minority welfare officer to maintain basic facilities of the hostel and conduct regular inspection. On reaching Barmer, the minister went to MLA Mewaram Jain's house and expressed condolences on the demise of his mother.

Title: 90 days after chip-tagged bird found dead, Russian experts wait for tracker
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The carcass of the chip-tagged endangered black stork

JAIPUR: Around three months after a satellite-tagged black stork was found dead in Jaisalmer, Russian researchers are waiting to get back their instruments, which were attached to the bird.

The carcass of the endangered species, ringed and tagged by the Russian Raptor Research and Conservation Network (RRCN), was recovered by the Border Security Force (BSF) on October 23, 2019. The bird reportedly died after collision with a barbed wire fence near the border.

Sources said BSF on suspicion of it being an avian spy handed over the stork to local police along with the instruments, which in turn sent these to the Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL).

The bird was ringed by researcher Alexey Ebel. It was marked with the Ring RRRCN Moscow Russia 139 and the tracker of the Max Planck Institute 6633 as part of a project to study the migration path.

Dau Lal Bohra, who is associated with RRCN to study the migratory path, told TOI, “The black stork was marked as part of a project to study the migration of the Siberian stork. The tracker is the property of Tigirek Reserve. The Russian research centre has authorised that the tracker on the bird be handed over to me, so that I can send it back to Russia. I have written to the superintendent of police, Jaisalmer, and also met the local police in this regard. However, even after two months I am waiting to get the possession of the tracker.”

SP Jaisalmer, Kiran Kang, on the possibility of the tracker being returned, said, “As the bird was found in border district, the tracker recovered had to be sent to FSL, the report of which takes time. I will send a reminder, but at this point cannot confirm when the FSL report will be prepared.”

Researchers said the bird is protected under the agreement of African-Eurasian Migratory Waterbirds (AEWA) on the international trade of endangered species of wild fauna and flora. Its population has witnessed continuous decline across Europe and Siberia. Elaborating further, Bohra said, “The bird is rarely spotted in Rajasthan as it needs a lot of water. Barmer-Jaisalmer is the passage for this bird to travel to Pakistan, Afghanistan and Kyrgyzstan. It is crucial to recover the instrument as there is no fresh study or data on this bird.”

Title: University campuses should not be used for political agitations, says UGC vice-chairman
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

COIMBATORE: University campuses should be used for academic purposes and not for political agitations, vice-chairman of the University Grants Commission Bhushan Patwardhan said here on Wednesday.

“Universities should not be converted into battlegrounds for any reason or ideology. When students come to university campuses, they should restrict themselves to academics. They are free to do whatever they want to do as citizens outside. It is their individual right,” he told reporters on the sidelines of the 33rd Biennial Conference of Home Science Association of India held at the Avinashilingam Institute for Home Science and Higher Education for Women in the city.

“If students are given a better opportunity to connect with the community, they would be better placed and would not agitate. If students from urban areas stay with farmers for a month, they will never agitate,” Patwardhan said.

Speaking of new reforms in higher education, the academician said the UGC has finalised two new programmes in the idea-level National academic credit bank and semester outreach programme.

The national academic credit bank will allow students to earn credits from any course at any university across the country or even abroad. “Universities should decide how many credits are needed for degree and how many of these credits need to be from that university to get the degree of that university. Students can earn the remaining credits from any course in institutions in the country or even abroad. There would be a mechanism to process the credits,” he said. “This would enable a multi-disciplinary approach and liberate students towards a multiple-entry multiple-exit process.”

The UGC would implement it in a pilot scale either with only postgraduate-level courses or with a new liberal education programme or selected universities.

Under the semester outreach programme, students will be sent outside the campus to get experiential learning from various sectors, such as banking, agriculture and community work. “While such activities are now being done as NCC and NSS programmes or as extra-curricular activities, we seek to make it a structured credit-based course,” Patwardhan said.

The UGC has formed teams to frame regulations for the programmes and it would be finalised in six months. “These programmes are challenging to construct and implement. But these will not be made compulsory.”

A one-month structured residential programme will be made mandatory for teachers. They should complete the course within six months of joining. UGC is also framing learning outcome-based curriculum for various verticals.

The three-day conference on ‘Trends for Futuristic Development in Home Science: Research and Innovation’ was inaugurated on Wednesday at the institute. As many as 200 faculty members and 400 students from various institutions across the country are attending the event.

Title: ‘Manja ripped leather jacket, slashed my neck’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Satender Tiwari had to undergo a surgery after suffering a critical neck injury from nylon manja

NAGPUR: Bank manager Satender Tiwari, 32, was on his way to work. Shraddha Shende, 24, was returning home after giving an entrance exam for bank recruitment . Out of nowhere, a sharp kite manja slashed their necks, drenching their clothes in blood within seconds.

This year too, the Makar Sankranti festival turned bleak for many citizens who fell victim to the continued persistent use of nylon manja. Satyendra and Shraddha had a miraculous escape despite being critically injured.

After being discharged from hospital, the victims recounted their close shave with TOI.

Satender, who met with the accident on January 15 and came home three days back, says that the manja ripped off his leather jacket first and then slit his neck. “I had just crossed Manewada Square on my two-wheeler when I spotted a loose kite coming in my direction. I was focusing on avoiding it when suddenly I felt a strong force pulling me back,” he says.

The pain that Satender felt was past bearing. He stopped driving to check in the rear view mirror. “I was bleeding profusely so much that the blood entered my shoes in no time. Balancing the vehicle with my right hand, I made an attempt to remove the manja with the left one. But it was so sharp that my thumb got a deep cut,” he says.

Satender was rushed to a nearby hospital. “The doctors gave me first-aid but they informed that the cut was very severe and I needed immediate surgery. I was then taken to Orange City Hospital and Research Institute,” he adds.

When Satender returned home three days back, he was shocked to see a long deep cut on the collar of his leather jacket. “It’s frightening to imagine how sharp the manja was. It can’t be a cotton one,” he says, expressing resentment over nylon manja being sold and used despite the ban.

“Apart from the manufacturers and sellers, strict action should be taken against the users of the killer thread who put so many lives at stake every year. Immense awareness is needed,” adds Satender.

Shraddha’s family shares the same sentiment. “People who continue to use sharp-edged manja despite so many deaths and accidents should know that tomorrow someone close to them can also suffer. Thinking that such unfortunate things happen only to others is wrong. I never thought I would see my daughter soaked in blood,” says her mother.

Like Satender, Shraddha too was wearing a helmet and had wrapped a scarf around her neck. But in vain. “Tearing her scarf, the manja slit her throat. She was bleeding profusely,” her mother adds.

Shraddha was returning home from the examination centre with three friends when the incident took place near Katol Road on January 19. She was rushed to Suretech Hospital where she underwent a surgery. Now back home, she is still unable to talk due to unbearable pain. “She is not even able to tell us how she fared in her exam,” her mother says.

Title: Delhi: Here’s why you had to wait forever for your flight
Content:
Heavy fog disrupted flight operations at the Indira Gandhi International Airport in Delhi (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Over 300 flights were delayed and at least five flights were diverted at Indira Gandhi International Airport in the early hours on Wednesday after dense fog enveloped the capital.Visibility remained in the range of 0-50 metres for at least seven hours between 3.30 am and 10.30 am, during which five flights were diverted to Jaipur and Amritsar as the pilots were not CAT-III compliant, airport officials said. Among the flights diverted were three international flights and two domestic flights.Things became even more difficult with airspace closure of 105 minutes, which has been mandated for seven days on January 18, 20-24 and 26 due to the Republic Day celebrations. Airspace closure occurred between 10.35 am and 12:15 pm, with the ripple effect occurring in terms of flight delays through the day.Trains too were impacted by the fog, with at least 22 trains delayed in the morning, Northern Railway officials said.Given that airspace over Delhi usually remains closed for 105 minutes daily in the window of January 18-26 due to the Republic Day flypast, most airlines tend to schedule their plans in advance.According to a notice to airmen (NOTAM), which was issued by the Airports Authority of India (AAI) last week, “No landing and take off would be permitted at Delhi International Airport between 10.35 am and 12.15 pm on January 18, 20-24 and 26, due to the Republic Day celebrations”.RK Jenamani, scientist at the National Weather Forecasting Centre, said this was the third worst ‘dense fog’ spell this season in terms of both the intensity and the duration, after the spells of December 20 and 30, 2019. “CAT-III conditions prevailed for around seven hours till 10.30 am, with visibility hovering in the range of 0-50 metres,” said Jenamani.According to him, while the dense fog on December 20 lasted nearly nine hours, the spell on December 30 lasted close to 10 hours.Airlines also took to Twitter, informing passengers of the possible delays. Vistara tweeted: “Due to poor visibility in Delhi today morning, arrivals/departures from Delhi may get impacted throughout the day with consequential impact across the network. Please visit the website.”“Tough travel day for all of us due to dense fog in the northern region this morning and airspace closure in lieu of the Republic Day preparations. This has caused disruptions to several flights across the network. We’re doing our best to recover, however, there will be consequential delays throughout the day. Do keep a track of your flights through our website,” stated IndiGo.A few passengers who were stuck at the airports for hours also took to Twitter to vent their ire. “Stuck at Abu Dhabi airport since flight from Delhi EY 211 was delayed.. no support in providing connecting flight to Athens as that was missed because of the delay. Told the staff that we are facing loss of approx 50-60k since we have non-refundable bookings from Athens #Etihadhelp, (sic)” tweeted Krati Gupta.

Title: Vadodara: Two held for smuggling sim cards inside jail
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: The detection of crime branch (DCB) arrested two men for conspiring to smuggle sim cards inside the central jail. The police said that the duo had planned to bring sim card inside the jail and hand it over to a prisoner. Investigations revealed that 22-year-old Shahrukh Sindhi had smuggled the SIM inside the jail. Sindhi’s father is often called in the jail premises for chopping off trees. The police have been investigating the racket of smuggling SIM cards inside the jail over last few days. It has recovered several SIM cards and phones from the jail premises.

Title: Pune: Uruli residents want no waste in village
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

PUNE: Residents of Uruli and Phursunsgi are unhappy with the civic body for keeping garbage for treatment at a waste processing plant near its trash depot.

Members of citizens’ group Garbage Depot Sangharsh Samiti visited the area on Tuesday and complained about trash piling up at the processing unit site.

Bhagwan Bhadale, a resident of Uruli Devachi and member of the citizens’ group, said keeping the garbage at the processing site contradicted the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s (PMC) claim of completely stopping open dumping of the garbage in the area.

“The PMC is still bringing garbage in the area. We do not want any garbage reaching Uruli and Phursungi,” he said.

Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of the PMC’s solid waste management department, said the administration was not dumping garbage at the Uruli depot from January 15.

“The garbage is now being transported to the bio-mining processing unit site, located next to the trash depot. We are producing refuse-derived fuel and manure by processing about 400 tonnes of garbage at the site,” he said.

“Processing of garbage at the bio-mining site is also a temporary measure. Once the new processing units start functioning, garbage will no more be transported to the shed in Uruli,” Molak said.
