Title: Overbridge, underpass at Guirim opens for traffic
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

5 coconut saplings have been planted along this route

PANAJI: Both lanes of the approximately 250-metre-long overbridge-cum-underpass at Guirim were thrown open for use recently. Thirty-five coconut saplings have also been planted in the structure’s median by the road works contractor to replace the trees that perished while construction was on.

In the last week of December 2019, only one two-lane section of the overbridge proceeding towards Panaji had been opened, while the lane leading towards Mapusa was opened just two weeks ago. However, although both lanes are operational, there has neither been an official inauguration nor has any signage been erected to indicate that the road can now be used. This has left motorists confused and the frequency of vehicles on the lane leading towards Mapusa remains low. Most vehicles travelling towards Mapusa continue to crowd the narrow service road below the overbridge.

PWD principal chief engineer Uttam Parsekar confirmed that both two-lane sections of the overbridge could now be used. While the overbridge is 27m wide, the underbridge has a width of 12m. It is not yet known when the requisite signage is expected to be erected near the new structure.

Environmentalists had raised objections during construction of the project and had asked PWD officials to rework the alignment to retain the existing coconut trees on the stretch. The structure was designed accordingly to keep the coconut trees in the median of the overbridge. Parsekar told TOI that as promised, the road works contractor has planted 35 coconut saplings in the median of the Guirim overbridge-cum-underpass to replace those that perished during construction.

He also said that construction of the other overbridge-cum-underpass at the Green Park road intersection is expected to be ready for use by December. This is expected to further ease congestion on this route.

Both, the Guirim and the Green Park structures, are part of the ongoing highway four-/six-laning work in Goa. The work has been taken up as per estimated vehicle density in Goa up to the year 2030.

The overbridges-cum-underpasses are meant to avoid slowing down of traffic at road intersections and also to reduce accidents.

While the Karaswada-Bambolim highway expansion contract is worth Rs 850 crore, the Patradevi to Karaswada project has been awarded for Rs 630 crore.

Title: Centre has become an agent of Vedanta: Narayanasamy
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Puducherry: Chief minister V Narayanasamy expressed deep concern over the proposed hydrocarbon project by the Union government arguing that the project will spell doom for agriculture besides depleting groundwater resources leading to intrusion of seawater into the groundwater table and turning potable water saline and urged the Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union petroleum minister Dharmendra Pradhan to scrap the project in the Union territory of Puducherry.

Speaking to reporters on Tuesday, Narayanasamy said he has written letters to Modi and Pradhan on shelving the project after the Centre amended the environment impact assessment notification 2006 exempting prior environmental clearance and public hearing for hydrocarbon project.

Narayanasamy said the Centre roped in a private firm Vedanta Limited to explore hydrocarbon at 339sqkm onshore site spread in the districts of Karaikal and Puducherry in the Union territory and Nagapattinam and Villupuram in Tamil Nadu and at 4,047sqkm offshore site along the coast of these districts. The Centre has identified 2sqkm site at Bahour in Puducherry and 39.8sqkm site at Karaikal to explore hydrocarbon.

He said the firm will dig wells that run 3,500m to 4,500m deep leading to the depletion of groundwater. Moreover, the firm will use toxic chemicals in the drilling operations to explore hydrocarbon that will lead to severe air, land and water pollution.

“The project sites are fertile agricultural lands in the fag-end of the Cauvery delta in Karaikal and pockets with high population density in both regions. The project will wipe out agricultural activities, lead to severe environmental pollution, deplete groundwater resources, lead to intrusion of seawater into the groundwater table and turn potable water saline,” he said.

He said he wrote to Pradhan on May 20 last year and to the Union home ministry on June 10 last year registering Puducherry's stiff opposition for the project. “The legislative assembly also passed a unanimous resolution on July 27 last year against the project outlying its ill-effects,” he said.

He pointed out that Pradhan made an assurance in the Parliament that the Centre will scrap the project if people were against it.

“The Centre’s amendment exempting prior environmental clearance and public hearing for hydrocarbon project is nothing but curbing the rights of the states and Union territories. The amendment exposed the autocratic attitude of the Centre, which has become an agent of private firm Vedanta,” Narayanasamy charged.

He reiterated Puducherry government’s decision of not permitting hydrocarbon project in the Union territory.

Title: Use of construction debris in road works to continue: PWD
Content:
The segregated material from construction debris has been used as base in the road from Green Park to Karaswad... Read More

PANAJI: Since deciding to accept the research findings of the Indian Road Congress and opting to use aggregate from construction debris as a base layer in roads in the highway expansion work, such material has been used in four major road stretches, PWD chief engineer Uttam Parsekar told TOI.The segregated material from construction debris has been used as base in the road from Green Park to Karaswada and Bambolim to Panaji, in the Canacona bypass road and also in parts of the western bypass road in South Goa .Parsekar said that the use of construction debris will continue wherever required.“As of now, we have been able to clear a considerable part of the construction debris lying across the state. The problem was most pronounced near Karaswada road stretch where a major part of the debris was lying and it has now been cleared with use of its aggregates in the road works,” he said.The PWD decided to accept the research findings of the Indian Road Congress last year as a solution to the growing problem of construction debris in Goa .In 2018, the high court of Bombay at Goa took note of this problem where construction debris was being clandestinely and illegally dumped by miscreants in any open space available across the state. To address this desecration of public and private spaces, the high court issued directives to the state government to identify sites where the construction debris can be offloaded after informing the authorities.Accordingly, the state government identified 13 sites by the sides of the national highways where the construction debris could be dumped. As land in these 13 sites was already acquired for the ongoing highway expansion work, dumping debris there was seen as a good temporary solution.But the issue resurfaced with the 13 sites getting filled sooner than the state had anticipated. Work of the highway expansion also progressed during 2019, which meant that the land acquired for the road widening needed to be cleared of the debris.As a result, both the district collectors, along with the director of mines and geology and PWD officials began working on identifying sites like abandoned mining pits and laterite quarries where such waste could be dumped.The mounds of construction debris piled up along the highway also made for an ugly sight.All this forced the PWD to look for other solutions and finally officials decided to adopt findings of the Indian Road Congress.Now, debris such as broken tiles, concrete and plaster of Paris are broken down and laid as base for the road.

Title: Number of Neet applicants in Tamil Nadu decreases by 17%
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The number of students applying for Neet-2020 from Tamil Nadu has dropped by nearly 17% over 2018-19, against an increase of 74,000 nationwide, as per National Testing Agency data.There are 1.17 lakh applications this year against 1.4o lakh in 2019, the first time a dip has been registered since 2016. This, say teachers and counsellors, is due to many reasons including increasing cut-off, which proved tough for state board students, and more repeaters getting seats. The huge demand-supply gap in the number of seats has also discouraged aspirants from writing Neet without preparation.In 2019, of the 4,202 students who joined MBBS after writing Neet, 2,916 (70%) were old students. This year, many said they would take a break and apply in 2021. R Vivek Kumar of Chennai said, “I have been attending coaching class and preparing for the exam. But I am not confident of getting into a medical school this year. I want to perfect my scores in mock test before I write my entrance.”N Vijayan, principal of Zion Matric Higher Secondary School in Tambaram, said many students were disheartened last year after cut-offs increased, by 80 to 100 marks, across categories. “Since a majority of repeaters got seats, many students wanted to take a break to prepare for medical entrance. We counselled them to apply for Neet this year.”P Swaminathan, secretary of SRV Schools in Namakkal and Trichy, said more than 50% of their students appearing for Neet 2020 were repeaters. “The attitude towards MBBS is changing . Current batch students are looking for options other than medicine.” The cut-off for BC students, which was 475 marks in 2019, could cross 500 this year.While the number of students joining biology stream or science stream in Class XI is declining every year, the number of Neet aspirants from government and government-aided schools has dropped drastically this year. “Even our teachers are not very enthusiastic due to the results. The government should fix a cap on attempts,” a government school HM said.

Title: CB yet to get nod to prosecute Devassy
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kochi: The crime branch (CB) team probing the construction of apartment complexes in violation of the Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) norms in Maradu is yet to get the local self-government department’s approval for prosecuting former Maradu panchayat president K A Devassy. The permits for building the demolished buildings were issued during his tenure.

Sources said the agency sought permission in the first week of December to prosecute Devassy , who is now a serving councillor of the Maradu municipality. “The government has sought a legal opinion from the director general of prosecution,” said a senior official.

Crime branch claims it has enough evidence to prosecute him in all three cases registered in connection with the construction of the apartment complexes. Devassy has claimed that he had no role in the unauthorized construction and the responsibility rested on those who approved the plan.

Though those who had worked with him has given statements against him, the agency is unsure whether the prosecution can guarantee his conviction.

The agency has so far collected the statements of about half of the 250-odd owners of the demolished apartments.

Title: Jaipur cops to launch Golden Hour app for smooth ambulance operations
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Rs 42 lakh has been okayed for project

JAIPUR: Golden Hour app will be launched by the city traffic police which will help ambulances get clear passages even in heavy traffic hours. The traffic police will connect private hospitals and ambulances with the app. Also, the app will help in creating green corridors depending on the need of the patients. The traffic police on Tuesday issued the proposal inviting private players.

The police have invited request for proposal from private players to provide them design, development and commissioning of Golden Hour app with monitoring system with an estimated cost of Rs 42 lakh. With the app, the traffic police are aiming to save life of the patients while they are being transported from the point of accident or any other pick up point to the hospital within one hour, which is known as ‘Golden Hour’. “We have received approval of Rs 42 lakh for the project from Road Safety fund,” deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Rahul Prakash said.

According to proposal, the traffic police will conduct vehicle profiling of ambulances, fire brigade and other emergency vehicles using the application, which will be designed for the purpose. Once the information is uploaded and submitted to the server, the vehicle will be registered for availing the service of the app. Each vehicle record will be assigned with a unique QR code that will be pasted on each vehicle. At a time, when every second is important, the app will help ambulances search for a hospital directly or add a stop to pick up a patient for pick up from either their residence or accident spot. The application will automatically detect the user’s live location. The user has to input the destination in the search field.

The admin of the app will provide a safer route for any active requests thus making the user take a route that can save time in case of emergencies. The live movement module of emergency vehicle will be based on Google map along with live traffic status, which will be capable of showing movement of multiple emergency vehicles. The module will contain user friendly option of changing the heavy traffic route by the traffic control room based on traffic movement.

Title: Jaipur Literature Festival : 15,000 visitors will be allowed at venue to prevent chaos
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Vehicles parked outside Diggi Palace in the city on Wednesday

JAIPUR: City police will step up security around Diggi Palace hotel, the venue for the 13th edition of the Jaipur Literature Festival beginning on Thursday.

Since a lot of visitors are expected, police have decided to put a cap on the number. At a time, police will allow 15,000 visitors inside the venue. They have also installed counting scanners at the entry points for the purpose. Police have already assessed the capacity of the venue and decided to limit the entry of the visitors. Police have put this cap citing security reasons and to prevent chaos, which could cause law and order situation.

More visitors will be allowed only when the number of visitors inside the venue goes below 15,000. Moreover, only those who have registered for the event will be given entry.

City police will also make use of drone cameras for aerial surveillance of the festival. Besides, at every nook and corner of the venue and outside, police will install CCTV cameras. “We have taken a series of measures for strengthening security around the venue as a lot of people are expected to visit. One senior police official of the rank of superintendent of police and three senior police officials of the rank of additional superintendent of police will be deployed as part of security measures,” said additional commissioner of police (law and order) Ajay Pal Lamba. Over 250 speakers from 20 countries are expected to take part in the event, which will conclude on January 27. The police commissionerate has alerted nearby police stations and have deployed extra forces in the area. “Over 500 policemen will be deployed at the festival venue. Policemen in mufti will keep a watch on trouble-makers,” Lamba said.

Title: Tejas Express travellers to get Rs 100 for 80-minute delay
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Passengers must make a claim to get refund

Some 630 passengers of the Ahmedabad-Mumbai Tejas Express are eligible to get compensation of Rs 100 each, after the train was delayed by more than 80 minutes while on its way to Mumbai Central on Wednesday.

Western Railway services were affected after a technical problem in the overhead equipment (OHE) between Mira Road and Bhayander from 12.38pm to 1.30pm on a Churchgate-bound fast train. As a result, four long-distance trains, including Tejas Express were delayed.

IRCTC’s public relations officer said, “Due to a technical problem in the overhead electric wire the train got delayed. The passengers are entitled to get compensation of Rs 100 as the train was delayed by over 75 minutes.”

Passengers will have submit claims before they can be given the money. IRCTC has estimated that around 630 passengers are eligible to get the compensation.

Customer can register their claim by calling a call-centre on 1800-266-8844 or an email to irctcclaim@libertyinsurance.in. They will have submit their PNR number along with certificate of insurance number and cancelled cheque. The claim will be process within a day of all details being submitted.

A compensation of Rs 100 is provided if the train delayed by more than one hour and Rs 250 for two hours. Tejas Express was flagged off from Ahmedabad on January 17 and this the first time that compensation for a delay is being paid to passengers. Tejas Express is the only class of train on Indian Railway in which passengers are eligible for compensation in case of delay.

IRCTC offers travel insurance to the passengers of Tejas Express through Liberty General Insurance Company Limited, a Mumbai-based private insurance company.

The Tejas Express also made an unscheduled halt at Andheri station, as many passengers feared their flight would be missed due to the delay. He said, “Some passengers who had flights to catch requested us make an unscheduled halt at Andheri station. Based on their request, the train was halted at Andheri stations for two minutes,” an official said.

Title: Auto Expo 2020: Chinese rescue auto expo, book 20% space
Content:
File photo used for representation.

NEW DELHI: The Chinese dragon has come to the rescue of India’s prestigious Auto Expo. With a large number of manufacturers giving the event a miss in this year’s edition, including top names such as BMW, Audi, Jaguar and Land Rover, Honda, Toyota and Ford, the biennial event has literally been rescued by the Chinese makers that includes top companies such as SAIC (China’s biggest seller and owner of MG Motors ), FAW (entering through the Haima brand), Great Wall (largest Chinese SUV maker), and BYD (maker of electric buses and batteries).Apart from this, a number of Chinese companies have partnered smaller Indian makers and start-ups for electric two-wheelers.More than 20% of the space — over 8,000 sq mtrs of the total 40,000 sq mtrs at hand — has been reserved by the big Chinese firms at the Expo venue. “They are coming here with new technology, electric cars, and a number of model unveilings,” Sugato Sen, deputy DG of industry body Siam — that organises the event along with CII and ACMA – told TOI.The Expo (held at Greater Noida, on the outskirts of Delhi) kicks off for the media on February 5, and will showcase launches and new unveilings on the next day as well. For the public, the event opens up on February 7, and will run till the 12th of the month.Absentees apart, the event will surely have its share of action and will witness unveilings and model launches from companies such as Maruti Suzuki, Hyundai, Tata Motors, Mahindra & Mahindra, and foreign makers like Renault, Volkswagen, Mercedes Benz, and Skoda.While generally being seen as the Indian version of some of the world’s biggest vehicle extravaganzas such as those held in Detroit, Geneva, Tokyo and Paris, the expo this time has been bogged down by the nagging slowdown that has hit the auto industry. Much of the players, battling slowdown and poor buyer sentiments, feel it better to avoid the ‘auto carnival’ as they focus on maintaining profitability and managing marketing budgets. This despite the fact that Siam is literally throwing in a red carpet for the event, and offering attractive discounts to those committing a larger presence.“It doesn’t make much sense for us to spend extravagantly at the expo when sales are not happening in the market. Conserving cash is critical at these times and we intend to spend it judiciously rather than invest heavily only on one property (read the Expo),” said a senior official of top company that has given the event a miss.Many companies who are not showing up also blame the ‘mega transition’ that they are undertaking as the industry migrates from BS4 to BS6 emission vehicles . New vehicles are not ready, and plans are still being firmed up. The crunch is felt even more in two-wheelers where the entire industry seems to be missing with brands such as Hero Moto, TVS, Bajaj Auto , and Royal Enfield staying away (the last two were not present even in last edition).“The domestic two-wheeler industry has been passing through a time of volatility, with market demand still continuing to be sluggish. Notwithstanding these challenges, Hero Moto — and indeed the entire industry — is gearing up for the migration to the new emission norms ahead of the mandatory deadline of April 1, 2020. At a time such as this, it is prudent for us to prioritise our resources towards meeting business objectives for the benefit of our customers and other stakeholders,” a spokesperson for Hero Moto said.Siam’s Sen, however, feels that the event retains its charm, and will surely pick up at the next edition. “It’s not a dead-end. India is growing, and our market will remain robust.”

Title: Auto Expo 2020: Chinese rescue auto expo, book 20% space
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

File photo used for representation.

NEW DELHI: The Chinese dragon has come to the rescue of India’s prestigious Auto Expo. With a large number of manufacturers giving the event a miss in this year’s edition, including top names such as BMW, Audi, Jaguar and Land Rover, Honda, Toyota and Ford, the biennial event has literally been rescued by the Chinese makers that includes top companies such as SAIC (China’s biggest seller and owner of MG Motors ), FAW (entering through the Haima brand), Great Wall (largest Chinese SUV maker), and BYD (maker of electric buses and batteries).

Apart from this, a number of Chinese companies have partnered smaller Indian makers and start-ups for electric two-wheelers.

More than 20% of the space — over 8,000 sq mtrs of the total 40,000 sq mtrs at hand — has been reserved by the big Chinese firms at the Expo venue. “They are coming here with new technology, electric cars, and a number of model unveilings,” Sugato Sen, deputy DG of industry body Siam — that organises the event along with CII and ACMA – told TOI.

The Expo (held at Greater Noida, on the outskirts of Delhi) kicks off for the media on February 5, and will showcase launches and new unveilings on the next day as well. For the public, the event opens up on February 7, and will run till the 12th of the month.

Absentees apart, the event will surely have its share of action and will witness unveilings and model launches from companies such as Maruti Suzuki, Hyundai, Tata Motors, Mahindra & Mahindra, and foreign makers like Renault, Volkswagen, Mercedes Benz, and Skoda.

While generally being seen as the Indian version of some of the world’s biggest vehicle extravaganzas such as those held in Detroit, Geneva, Tokyo and Paris, the expo this time has been bogged down by the nagging slowdown that has hit the auto industry. Much of the players, battling slowdown and poor buyer sentiments, feel it better to avoid the ‘auto carnival’ as they focus on maintaining profitability and managing marketing budgets. This despite the fact that Siam is literally throwing in a red carpet for the event, and offering attractive discounts to those committing a larger presence.

“It doesn’t make much sense for us to spend extravagantly at the expo when sales are not happening in the market. Conserving cash is critical at these times and we intend to spend it judiciously rather than invest heavily only on one property (read the Expo),” said a senior official of top company that has given the event a miss.

Many companies who are not showing up also blame the ‘mega transition’ that they are undertaking as the industry migrates from BS4 to BS6 emission vehicles . New vehicles are not ready, and plans are still being firmed up. The crunch is felt even more in two-wheelers where the entire industry seems to be missing with brands such as Hero Moto, TVS, Bajaj Auto , and Royal Enfield staying away (the last two were not present even in last edition).

“The domestic two-wheeler industry has been passing through a time of volatility, with market demand still continuing to be sluggish. Notwithstanding these challenges, Hero Moto — and indeed the entire industry — is gearing up for the migration to the new emission norms ahead of the mandatory deadline of April 1, 2020. At a time such as this, it is prudent for us to prioritise our resources towards meeting business objectives for the benefit of our customers and other stakeholders,” a spokesperson for Hero Moto said.

Siam’s Sen, however, feels that the event retains its charm, and will surely pick up at the next edition. “It’s not a dead-end. India is growing, and our market will remain robust.”

Title: AAP: Govt controlled by mining lobby
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Panaji: Stating that the order by the Lokayukta to file an FIR against former chief minister Laxmikant Parsekar and others was no surprise, Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) said it reconfirms the extent to which the elected government of Goa is controlled by the mining lobby.

Party general secretary Pradeep Padgaonkar said despite umpteen opportunities to reform the mining industry under the guidance of the Supreme Court judgements, the BJP government (and Congress government in the past) continued to make decisions in favour of its mining lobby friends.

“Because of this complete capitulation by elected leaders, today not only are the mining dependents in the state suffering, but also the state is in serious financial crunch,” Padgaonkar said.

Title: ‘Blue corner notice out for Nithyananda’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nithyananda

AHMEDABAD: The Interpol has issued a blue corner notice for Nithyananda on a request from Gujarat police to locate him, because he is considered the prime accused in the criminal case of illegal confinement of children and putting them to forced labour at his ashram in Ahmedabad.

The police informed a local court about the blue corner notice being issued because it has mentioned Nithyananda as an absconder in the chargesheet, which was filed last week. The chargesheet mentions that since Nithyanada’s location could not be found, the investigation officer obtained an arrest warrant against him from the court under provisions of Section 70 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

Besides Nithyananda, charges have been filed in a local court by Vivekanandnagar police against two of his ashram administrators, his sadhvis Harini Chelappan alias Pranpriya and Riddhi Ravikiran alias Priatatva. They have been in judicial custody ever since their arrest upon an FIR lodged by a parent, whose four children were at the Nithyananda ashram in Ahmedabad, which is named ‘Sarvagnapeetham’. The complainant’s two adult daughters are missing and he has filed a habeas corpus petition in the Gujarat high court.

The man lodged an FIR in November after the ashram management refused to give custody of his two minor children to him. He accused the ashram authorities and Nithyananda of illegally confining, beating and abusing the children as well as of forcing them to do labour.

Title: Chennai: Metro drops plan to link High Court station with Fort St George
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

High Court metro station

CHENNAI: It is either a long walk or wait for multiple modes of transport for visitors and staff to reach Fort St George from the nearest metro station everyday. They are not likely to get any relief soon as Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) has dropped the plan to build a foot overbridge (FoB) or a skywalk to link High Court metro station with Fort suburban station or the secretariat. Instead, CMRL is operating feeder services to the state administrative headquarters from Government Estate metro station, which commuters call an ‘erratic’ service.

A year ago, CMRL officials were mulling over the idea of constructing an FoB or a pedestrian subway, whichever is feasible, to encourage government staff to use the facility. High Court metro station, which is about less than 2km from Secretariat, is linked to Broadway bus terminus, NSC Bose Road and Esplanade Road through access points.

Metro rail officials said they dropped the plan as an FoB or skywalk to link High Court metro with Fort suburban station across North Fort Road was not feasible. “We thought about building an FoB initially but we found it is structurally not feasible. We have built footpath and started feeder services exclusively to Fort St George from Government Estate metro station since August 2019,” the officials said.

CMRL also operates feeder cabs from Government Estate metro station to the Secretariat. But Secretariat staff said the service was irregular. “The CMRL mobile app shows there is feeder service from Central metro to Secretariat, but we have not seen it,” said G Venkatesan, a former secretary, Tamil Nadu Secretariat Association. “CMRL could provide us a link to access High Court metro station which is closer than Government Estate. A regular feeder to Central metro will also help as our staff who come from Anna Nagar and those from suburban areas could travel faster to work because there is barely any MTC service from Central to Fort St George,” he added.

Sources said the idea to link the secretariat with a metro line was dropped after the new legislative assembly complex was inaugurated at Government Omandurar Estate in 2010.

Title: Four more arrested anti-CAA protesters get bail in Sambhal
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Sambhal: The court of Sambhal district and sessions judge, Ashwani Kumar Tripathi, on Wednesday granted bail to four more protesters arrested during the December 20 anti-CAA rallies in the city, taking the total number of protesters getting bail to eight. On Tuesday, the court had granted bail to four protesters.

Speaking to TOI, defence counsel Zaki Anwar said, "The court has granted bail to Aamir, a resident of Hillal Sarai; Waseem and Furqan, both residents of Mian Sarai; and Mohsin, a resident of Hindukhera in Deepa Sarai locality, after hearing the arguments on their bail applications."

Anwar said, "The court granted bail to all the four accused, against two sureties of Rs 60,000 each. As per the bail conditions, the accused will have to cooperate with the investigation, cannot tamper with evidence and cannot make any threats against the witnesses.”

Anwar Ali, father of Aamir, said, "My son Aamir is a student of LLB first semester at S M College, Chandusi. He was on his way to deposit his college fees when he was arrested and sent to jail." "Aamir was also tortured in police custody, and his money and mobile phone were snatched by police personnel," Anwar added.

Another defense counsel, Tausef Hassan Khan, said, "Another bail application is pending before the court of Additional District and Sessions Judge that had asked police to produce video footage of the violence that took place during anti-CAA protests."

Those who were granted bail were among the 27 people arrested for violence during the anti-CAA protest at Chandusi Chauraha on December 20. SHO of Sambhal Kotwali police station, Ravindra Pratap Singh, had lodged the FIR against the protesters under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapons), 149 (every member of unlawful assembly), 307 (attempt to murder), 332 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt to deter public servant), 336 (endangering life or personal safety of others) and sections 3 and 4 of Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984. Section 7 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act was also invoked. All the protesters arrested from Sambhal were lodged in Bareilly district jail.

Title: Under wraps for 43 years, major glitch in revenue official’s hiring leaves UP admin shocked
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Bareilly: Under the wraps for the last 43 years, a shocking glitch in the service record of a lekhpal-- revenue official-- came out in open with his retirement, leaving the local administration and the revenue department UP’s Bareilly district perplexed. While disbursing the post-retirement remunerations to Shivkumar, the local treasury carefully examined his records and found, to their shock, that he had joined the service at an age of 16 years in 1976. But, according to the government norms, no revenue official can be hired before hitting the age of 21 years.

After serving for 43 years and a few months, Shivkumar retired on March 31, 2019.

Now, the Bareilly’s treasury department has forwarded the Shivkumar’s file to additional district magistrate’s (ADM) VK Singh. The ADM, on his part, has written to state revenue board seeking directions in this matter.

When contacted, ADM Singh on Wednesday said, “We have written to additional commissioner (finance) of UP revenue board seeking guidance in this matter. We want to know what amount of money could be recovered and on which grounds.”

“For fresh recruitment for the post of lekhpal, the minimum age required is 21. While in case of giving job on the humanitarian ground to kin of a deceased government official, some relaxation in age limits may be given. But, even in case of appointing kin of a deceased government official, the minimum age cannot be less than 18. We are examining if it was a matter related to fresh appointment or he was given job in place of his father after latter’s demise,” SDM Singh said.

According to the service book of Shivkumar, his date of birth is April 1, 1959. And he was appointed lekhpal on March 15, 1976. After completing probation period of nine years, he got permanent status on July 1, 1987.

Title: Eight get bail in Rs 2.73 crore forgery case
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Puducherry: A Puducherry court on Monday granted bail to eight people including Puducherry women's commission chairperson Rani Rajan Babu, her sons – Ashok Thuyavan and Balaji Raja and a tahsildar from Tamil Nadu R Banumathy in a Rs 2.73 crore forgery case in the Union territory.

The CBCID had booked 11 people including the eight people on charges of forging the document of a grove in Puducherry and receiving compensation of Rs 2.73 crore from the government. The erstwhile grove is popularly referred to as 'Kuyil Thoppu' where the nationalist Tamil poet Bharathiyar penned most of his poems during his 10-year stay in Puducherry.

The CBCID booked them under sections 120B (punishment of criminal conspiracy), 193 (punishment for giving false evidence in a judicial proceeding), 209 (dishonestly making false claim in court), 210 (fraudulently obtaining decree for sum not due) and 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property) of the Indian penal code.

The agency’s action came after a direction from Puducherry chief judicial magistrate. As per the complaint, the 11 people forged the document of a 4.34-hectare of land belonging to P Aravamudhu and two others represented by their power agent V Seenuvasamoorthy Reddiar and received a compensation of Rs 2.73 crore from the government after the government acquired 2.5 hectares of land.

The government acquired 1.46 hectare for constructing a memorial for late Congress stalwart Kamaraj, 0.61-hectare for the East Coast Road project and 0.43-hectare for the construction of the interstate police wireless quarters. The accused people made a fake certificate dated January 30, 1935, claiming that the land was sold to them. They made a false claim for compensation based on the forged sale certificate before the court and received the compensation without the knowledge of the complainants.

Title: City’s oldest ayurveda college to be relocated
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Ahmedabad: The state government plans to relocate the city’s oldest ayurved college, which lies in ruins, from the Walled City area to a new campus on SG Highway. The college, Akhandanand Ayurved Mahavidyala, established more than half a century ago, is located near Bhadra fort. The five-storey building is in a dilapidated state and needs urgent repairs. The renovation of the college has been a challenge as it lies in the vicinity of a heritage property and any new construction or makeover is not permitted, said government sources.

“The college building was severely affected during the 2001 earthquake in Gujarat,” said a government official. “Numerous attempts to repair it since then have failed. The government has recently decided to relocate the college operations by building a new campus close to Sola Civil Hospital on SG Highway.” A team of officials from the state government’s health department had visited the college to inspect the building, the official said.

The college, affiliated to Gujarat Ayurved University, Jamnagar, has 500 students pursuing various undergraduate and postgraduate courses. The college is associated with an ayurved hospital which lies in the vicinity. “The current plan is only for the relocation of the college. It does not include the hospital,” a source said. About a decade ago, the government had begun work to shift the college to a new location.

Title: Maoist’s AK-47 looted from CRPF after ’14 Sukma ambush
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The crime branch confirmed that the AK-47 rifle recovered from slain Maoist leader Manivasagam in Manjikkandy , Palakkad in October last year were among those that were seized by Maoists from CRPF personnel who were ambushed and killed within Tongpal police station limits in Sukma, Chhattisgarh, on March 11, 2014.

In the report prepared by crime branch chief and ADGP Tomin J Thachankary after verification by a crime branch team, it has been said that the serial number of the AK-47 rifle (BE 385377) which was recovered from Manivasagam, who was killed in a police encounter, matched with one of the six AK-47 rifles seized by Maoists after the Sukma attack in which 11 CRPF personnel, four policemen and one civilian were killed. There are cases charged under IPC and Arms Act, in this regard, at Tongpal police station, the report said.

A team of 40 men from 80th Battalion of CRPF and police were on a search operation when they were trapped and ambushed by Maoists. After inflicting heavy casualties, the Maoists had taken away weapons and wireless sets from the troopers, and later distributed among the Maoist cadres.

The crime branch report also confirmed that the two .303 rifles recovered from Maoists in Manjikkandy were among those looted from Koraput town police station, Sadar police station, Lakshmipur police station, Kakiriguma police station and Narayanpatna police station by armed Maoists. The Maoists had then attacked district treasury and district armoury and had seized 500 guns and more than 25,000 ammunitions.

The police had seized as many as seven guns, including the AK-47 rife, two shotguns, two .303 rifles and two country-made guns, from the LWE cadres after the Manjikkandy encounter. Sources in the police department said that the remaining arms and ammunitions also were either stolen or smuggled from Nepal.

Four Maoists were killed in the encounter with the police at Manjikkandy in Palakkad, and the police had subjected the arms that were seized from them to ballistic examination. The police had then contacted police forces of all the other states to check the origin of the seized weapons.

Title: Cong: Will file plaint with CBI to initiate probe
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Margao: Welcoming the Lokayukta's recommendation to the government to entrust the probe into the renewal of 88 mining leases to the CBI and for filing an FIR, state Congress president Girish Chodankar said that the party would soon lodge a complaint with CBI seeking a probe.

Addressing reporters on Wednesday, Chodankar pointed out that Congress had in 2018 filed a complaint in the matter with the governor as well as the DGP, but none of the authorities initiated any action.

Chodankar said that while they had specifically named former chief minister Manohar Parrikar in their complaint, the probe will also lead to links of the incumbent chief minister Pramod Sawant in the case.

“I am sure Parrikar will be indicted in the case if an inquiry is initiated,” Chodankar said.

He also condemned Sawant’s statement to the effect that the Lokayukta’s order was recommendatory in nature and not mandatory on the government.

Pointing out that the then SP (crime) Karthik Kashyap had replied saying that there was no prima facie case made out in the Congress’ complaint, Chodankar said that Lokayukta’s order indicated that the police were acting under pressure not to act on their complaint.

Title: GST officers camp at trader’s home, criminal offence says Gujarat high court
Content:
Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court on Wednesday condemned state GST officials for camping at a trader’s house for eight days and said that the officers were liable to be punished under the Indian Penal Code.A bench of Justice Harsha Devani and Justice Sangeeta Vishen held that intimidating the trader’s family to extort confessions was tantamount to an offence under section 348 of IPC — wrongful confinement to extort confession or compel restoration of property. This is punishable with a jail term of up to three years.The matter involved Paresh Chauhan, who is behind bars at present. The goods & services tax officers conducted a search on his premises and stayed at his house from October 10 to October 18, 2019. The stay came to an end only after the HC issued a notice deeming their stay at Chauhan’s house illegal. His relatives were kept under house arrest with SRP guards outside 24X7. His relatives were not permitted to leave home without permission.This incident shocked the HC and it said, “It would be failing in its duty as a sentinel on the qui vive [meaning ‘on the alert or lookout’] if it were to turn a blind eye to the violation of the legal and fundamental rights of citizens by authoritarianism and remain a mute spectator.” The court said that it passed the order “to curb any further abuse of powers in this manner by the authorities under the GST Acts”.The court opined that the GST officials’ work could have been concluded on Day 1, but they chose to stay for eight days with the SRP outside the house to scare the family. This is abhorrent and cannot be countenanced, the court said. It further said, “No provision of the Code of Criminal Procedure, for investigation, search or seizure, empowers a police officer to remain a moment longer at any premises once the search is over.”The HC said that the officials were trying to extract information from the family members, and not to trace hidden documents. The officials already had information about documents secreted by Chauhan when they talked to his mother and took away her phone, but they did not bother to use the details.The HC observed, “In this case, all statutory requirements are thrown to the winds and in flagrant violation of the powers vested in them, the concerned officers have resided in the residential premises of the petitioner for eight days and confined and intimidated his family members...This is nothing but a blatant abuse of powers.”

Title: Madras high court upholds election of minister V Saroja
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

V Saroja

CHENNAI: Trashing poll-time malpractice complaints against Tamil Nadu social welfare minister V Saroja , who was elected MLA from Rasipuram constituency in 2016, the Madras high court on Wednesday upheld her .

The election petition was filed by DMK candidate VP Duraiswamy, who lost the election by a margin of 9,631 votes. His primary contention was that Saroja bribed voters and was involved in various other election malpractices to ensure her victory.

Rejecting the plea, Justice V Bharathidasan said, “To prove the charges of corrupt practice in an election petition, the proof of commission of corrupt practices must be clear, cogent, specific and reliable as the charge of corrupt practice is almost like a criminal charge and the onus is on the person who brings forth that charge to prove it by leading reliable, trustworthy and satisfactory evidence.”

Noting that the election cannot be set aside on mere possibilities, unless the allegation of corrupt practices is satisfactorily proved, the court held that the election of the returned candidate cannot be set aside.

Relying on media reports, the petitioner claimed that when former chief minister J Jayalalithaa visited Salem for election campaign Saroja ferried 5,000 voters from Rasipuram to Salem through vehicles arranged by her. Refusing to accept such allegations, the court made it clear that the petitioner cannot merely rely on newspaper reports without evidence to substantiate the same.

“In the instant case the evidence is hopelessly wanting. The petitioner has come out with vague pleadings in his election petition and absolutely there is no substantial evidence to substantiate the allegations of corrupt practice,” the judge said. With the available evidence on record, it is not possible to connect the returned candidate with any of the corrupt practices alleged in the election petition. The petitioner has miserably failed to prove the allegations made in the petition with clear and cogent evidence, Justice Bharathidasan said.

Title: With ‘josh’ and ‘hosh’, we will reach our goal: Uttarakhand BJP chief
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

After taking over the reins of the state unit, Bansidhar Bhagat , newly-elected president of Uttarakhand BJP , spoke to TOI’s Yogesh Kumar about the challenges being faced by the saffron party in the Himalayan state and how he plans to steer the party ahead of the 2022 assembly polls. Excerpts:

What will be your priorities for the party?

I have asked all district-level office-bearers to identity 25 workers in each booth in their area to have ‘chai pe charcha’ with them to know what are their expectations from the party in their region. This would help us in fixing goals at the booth level.

Any specific strategy that you have in mind for the 2022 assembly polls?

To reach any goal, one needs both josh and hosh (passion and wisdom). This synergy is necessary to win any political battle and I think that along with the support of my party workers, we will register a landslide victory in the 2022 elections.

How do you rate your main opposition — the Congress party — in Uttarakhand?

Congress has become politically irrelevant both ideologically and organisationally. In Uttarakhand, it is rudderless and has no vision for the state’s development. On the other hand, the BJP government under CM Trivendra Singh Rawat has delivered what it promised to the people.

Title: Man gets life for murder of wife
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Puducherry: Second additional district judge M Suba Anbumani sentenced a 50-year-old man to undergo life imprisonment for murdering his wife following a petty quarrel.

According to the prosecution, Velu, a pushcart vendor used to quarrel frequently with his wife V Valli, 45. In one such quarrel on April 3, 2017, he brutally attacked his wife and slit her throat with a sharp-edged weapon. The woman succumbed to the cut injuries. Mudaliarpet police registered a case and arrested him.

Convicting him of the charges, the judge sentenced him to undergo life imprisonment and also slapped a fine of Rs 1,000.

Title: Kochi: ‘Operation Breakthrough’ kicked off, first phase to end by March 31
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

District collector Suhas S and other officials inspect works under Operation Breakthrough at Panampilly Nagar ... Read More

KOCHI: Works related to ‘Operation Breakthrough’, the project planned to resolve waterlogging in the city, kicked off on Wednesday. All the 36 works under the first phase of the project will be completed by March 31.

Though most of the works pertain to cleaning of drains and canals, the district administration is learnt to have decided to invoke provisions of the Disaster Management Act for evicting encroachments in certain areas, including those along Vivekananda Thodu near the KSRTC bus station and Karanakkodam Thodu near Kaloor.

“In certain areas in Kaloor, owners of some of the apartment complexes have covered Karanakkodam Thodu in front of their residences using concrete slabs. The slabs have reduced the canal’s depth. We will send notices to the owners,” an official associated with the clean-up project said.

“Similarly, some small shops have been set up after encroaching upon the Vivekananda Thodu. We will be sending notices to them as well. If they don’t abide by our instructions, the district administration may invoke the provisions of Disaster Management Act,” the official said.

District collector Suhas S visited some of the areas where works were being carried out on Wednesday. He personally monitored the works at HIG in Panampilly Nagar, Paradise Road in Ponnurunni, Karanakkodam Thodu and Vivekananda Thodu.

The district administration has given instruction to the corporation for carrying out works suggested by the people’s representatives and the public on a priorit basis.

Title: Now, shahar qazis to educate people on drawbacks of CAA, NRC
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Bareilly: After a delegation of Jamat Raza-e-Mustafa, a prominent group of Sunni Barelvi Muslims, recently met clerics and people protesting against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) in Delhi, shahar qazis who also met the group’s members have now decided to spread awareness among people in their area on the drawbacks of CAA and NRC .

The shahar qazis stressed on “holding peaceful protests till the government gives in and announces a rollback”.

On Wednesday, national vice-president, Jamat Raza-e-Mustafa, Salman Hasan Khan, said, “Our delegation met protesters at Shaheen Bagh, Jamia Millia University and Jawaharlal Nehru University and also conducted a meeting with shahar qazis. As shahar qazis hold sway in their respective areas, it has been decided that they will brief the people about drawbacks of CAA and NRC. We want people to carry on with silent protests against CAA and NRC across the country.”

Khan added, “We fear that ‘doubtful’ citizens would be identified during National Population Register (NPR) exercise by local officials who may put a large number of people in this category.”

Maulana Ikram Raza Khan, who was also part of the Jamat Raza-e-Mustafa delegation, said, “We will intensify our peaceful protests across the country to put pressure on the government to rollback CAA and NRC.”

Meanwhile, a delegation of Jamat Raza-e-Mustafa met Maharashtra chief minister Uddhav Thackeray in Mumbai on Wednesday and requested him to reject CAA, NRC and NPR. Khan said, “If Maharashtra government refuses to pass CAA and NRC, it will create an environment of trust and peace among the people of state and country.”

Notably, criticising the CAA, Sunni Barelvi cleric Mufti Asjad Raza Khan in his statement issued last month had said, “This is not a Hindu-Muslim matter, but is about the country’s Constitution. The country can only be run by the Constitution, not by dictatorship. People who are protesting against NRC and CAA are praiseworthy. Silent protest is our right.”

Title: Bitumen laying work will be completed in two months, says Madurai corporation
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

TRICHY: The officials from the engineering wing of Madurai Corporation said that work is expected to begin in the first week of February and all the bitumen laying work will be completed in two months. It will take one month more for the paver block roads to be completed.

The tender procedures were already over and the pre-bid meeting has also been conducted. Officials said that bids will be opened in the presence of bidders on January 28 and tenders would be awarded to the chosen bidders.

"We will provide three months’ time for the contractor to complete bitumen laying work and paver block roads. One more month leniency can be given for the projects taken up at places, where works are affected due to the upcoming Chithirai festival," said an official from engineering wing.

Officials said that once a road is laid, the same road cannot be taken for re-laying for 5 years. Contractor’s defect liability duration is only for one year. The contractor can be pulled up for liability if the road gets damaged in the first year.

Title: Admin assures NGO of inquiry & action against Delapir pond encroachment
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Bareilly: The district administration has assured an inquiry and relevant action in the case of encroachment upon Delapir pond in the city, after a local NGO lodged a complaint against the illegal occupation of the pond by colonisers, land mafias and shopkeepers.

Pradeep Kumar, secretary of NGO Jaagar Jan Kalyaan, told TOI, “We have submitted a memorandum to Bareilly district magistrate Nitin Kumar, seeking action against the encroachment on Delapir pond. In a similar case of encroachment on a pond in Agra, the high court in September 2019 had ordered that if a place is recorded as a ‘pond’ in revenue records from before 1951, it should be restored to its original shape by removing all encroachment. The order was further extended by the HC across the state. We have requested the administration to take cognizance and relevant action in the case.”

Kumar added, “We have affixed copies of a demolition order passed by BDA for the Delapir pond site in 2017, as well as the copy of revenue records, stating that the place, spread over 1.965 hectare in plot number 133 of Delapir, has existed as a ‘pond’ since before 1951.”

As per the HC order of 2019, “All collectors of each district in the state shall entrust the additional district magistrate (finance and revenue) to make a list of ponds in existing revenue records in the year 1951-52. He shall also prepare a list of ponds which are under encroachment, or in respect of which, lease has been granted. The collectors shall proceed to cancel the lease of these ponds and restore them in accordance with law and directions issued.”

Bareilly SDM Ishan Pratap Singh told TOI, “A survey will be conducted to ascertain the encroachment status of the pond, following which relevant legal action will be initiated.”

For quite some time, builders, shopkeepers, land mafias and colonizers have encroached upon Delapir pond, in Biharman Nagla area of Bareilly. BMC environment engineer Sanjeev Pradhan said, “Plans are afoot to renovate Delapir pond and convert it into a tourist spot, with a shopping complex, food court, parking facility and space for boating likely to come up. The pond area will be restored and brought into its original shape. The plan is under consideration and once finalised, work will be taken up.”

Title: Dengue scare in Shirol puts officials on alert
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolhapur: Officials from the district health department of the Kolhapur zilla parishad (ZP) have advised extreme precaution to the residents of Shirol after reports of two deaths due to dengue-like symptoms in the past week.

Even though the officials are denying that the deaths were caused due to dengue , claiming that the diagnosis of the said deceased patients was not done, they admit that the situation needs urgent attention.

Vinod More, the district malaria officer, Kolhapur ZP, told TOI, “Considering the current situation, we have started door-to-door survey across Shirol, which has a population of around 30,000 residents. We have also collected blood samples of four patients who were showing symptoms matching dengue-like infection. The reports are likely to be confirmed by Thursday morning.”

More further said that the inadequate efforts from the Shirol nagar parishad staff members have also contributed to the deteriorating situation.

“We have formed 15 different teams. They are surveying the area. They have already found around six spots that are mosquito breeding sites with live larvae. These sites are being destroyed,” he said.

According to the health department officials, citizens have a lot of complaints with respect to the town’s hygiene, which seems to be an increasing concern for the administration officials too. He added that they are closely monitoring the houses which have reported breeding sites.

He said the incubation period of dengue, after the bite of a virus-carrying mosquito, can be anywhere between three and 15 days. The symptoms may show in parts. They usually beging with more begin symptoms such as headache, chills, fever, pain in eyes, loss of appetite and backache. Patients can also be affected by joint pain in the first hours of dengue.

Title: Two used banned chemicals to make artificial milk, held
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Kolhapur: Pandharpur rural police have arrested two people, who were found using two banned chemicals for production of artificial milk. One of the suspects has two previous milk adulteration cases against him.

Acting on a tip-off, the food and drugs administration (FDA) officials conducted a raid at a private dairy at Sugaon Bhose village last week. The FDA team found more than 2,719 kg of chemicals at the dairy, including melamine, which has been banned in the country. They found three bags of melamine, each containing 25 kg of the banned substance.

Food Safety Officer Prashant Kuchekar told TOI that melamine is banned India since 2008 and its use to manufacture artificial milk was a serious offence. Melamine can be used only for industrial purpose in India.

FDA officials then lodged a complaint with the police and a case under sections 188 (disobedience of order), 272 (adulteration of food or drink with intent to sale), 273 (sale of noxious food or drink and 328 (causing hurt by means of poison, etc with intent to commit crime ) of the IPC, along with section 59 of Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006, was registered against ten suspects.

The police have arrested two of them — identified as Dattatraya Mahadeo Jadhav and his driver Ganesh Gawli. Both are currently in the judicial custody.

Pandharpur rural police have registered various offences against ten persons, two of them arrested under various sections of Indian Penal Code and Food Safety and Standards Act 2006.

Prashant Patil, assistant police inspector of Karkamb police station, told TOI that they had identified a person from Mumbai, who had supplied melamine to the suspects. “We visited his Mumbai house thrice, but he is not traceable,” he said and did not rule out possibility of large racket of use of banned chemical in the country.

Patil said that preliminary investigation has revealed that Jadhav had studied up to class X and had completed some diploma in veterinary. Investigation has also found that Jadhav was involved in two milk adulteration cases – one in Pandharpur in 2009 and another in Phaltan in 2016. Both the cases are currently pending before the court.

Officials of FDA, who conducted the raid, said that the suspects had already used 23 kg of melamine to manufacture artificial milk. Considering that 20 mg of melamine is used to manufacture one litre of milk, police officials apprehend that the suspects could have manufactured more than 50,000 litres of milk by using the banned chemical. Apart from melamine, paraffin and non-edible oil was also found.

FDA officials said that three bags of melamine, which were found during the action, were imported from Iran. Police investigation has revealed that Jadhav used to send money to a supplier in Mumbai through hawala racket. Police have zeroed down a transport company, which used to supply melamine to the suspect.

Title: AAP, BJP in war of words over Shaheen Bagh protests
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

NEW DELHI: Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia’s remark that he stood with Shaheen Bagh protesters triggered a controversy on Thursday with BJP leaders unleashing an attack on him and chief minister Arvind Kejriwal.

BJP spokesperson Sambit Patra called Aam Aadmi Party an anti-Hindu party, while Hari Nagar candidate Tajinder Singh Bagga said that BJP stood with India and AAP with Shaheen Bagh protesters.

Asked during a talk on a television channel about the absence of AAP functionaries at Shaheen Bagh, the deputy CM said he stood with the protesters. He added that it was beyond him to open the road closed due to the protests.

While Sisodia came out in support of the protesters in the morning, Kejriwal, at a town hall with Times Now, said that protesting was everyone’s right, but people should not be inconvenienced. Asked why the blockade of the arterial road had not been lifted, the chief minister said it was beyond his jurisdiction to remove the barricades on the Kalindi Kunj road.

In the ensuing showdown, Patra asked Kejriwal to clarify on Sisodia’s statement. “AAP was behind provoking and instigating people. The reality has come out of Manish Sisodia’s mouth. These are the people who feel proud in claiming to be anarchist. We are watching the height of anarchy in Shaheen Bagh and Sisodia’s statement has proved that one anarchist is in support of another,” Patra told media persons.

The BJP spokesperson also accused Congress and AAP of creating confusion on CAA. “All these things are being done for vote-bank politics. I want to ask Kejriwal that if you stand with the Shaheen Bagh protesters, why are you not with the people of Sarita Vihar, Jasola and Madanpur Khadar who are suffering because the roads have been blocked,” Patra said, adding that Delhiites were ready to give a befitting reply to those misleading people with the politics of appeasement.

Title: Civic body recruits ex-Army personnel for anti-encroachment drives in city
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Bareilly: Moradabad Municipal Corporation has roped in retired military personnel to assist them in the enforcement activities in the district, starting with maintenance of law and order during an anti-encroachment drive on city rods.

According to information from the municipality, they earlier had to rely on the overburdened city police during such drives, which meant work was shoddy. They also said this move will help curb disputes with encroachers and other problems that MMC faced during earlier evictions.

Gambhir Singh, additional municipal commissioner, Moradabad, said, “The MMC anti-encroachment team is too understaffed to take up enforcement tasks in the city. Therefore, retired military personnel have been recruited to assist us in eviction activities. This should also help make the enforcement process smoother, as we’ll no longer have to rely on cops. It should also make launching crackdowns on encroachers, who often get into brawls with our staff during anti-encroachment drives, easier.”

Singh added, “Retired colonel Shivendra Shahi has been appointed as chief of the enforcement wing. A team of 12 retired military personnel, including among others section commander rank officers, will assist the MMC enforcement squad.”

MMC officials said a detailed plan is being chalked out, as per which, eviction drives will soon be conducted to free the city of encroachments of various kinds, including permanent constructions, hawker’s stalls, unauthorised shops, etc. “There have been many occasions when the MMC squad had to return after encroachers attacked our field staff. All that should now end. Several city areas, especially interior roads and other MMC properties are covered with encroachments. They will soon be freed,” he added.

Title: Gujarat gears up for coronavirus threat
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Gandhinagar: The deadly coronavirus outbreak in China has led the Gujarat government convene a meeting of district CDHOs and municipal corporation health officers two days ago. Since Monday, the state commissioner of health instructed that prior to the intimation from central health authorities, infrastructure and the manpower required for screening fevers be readied.

“The principal focus will be city airports. Since there are no direct flights to or from China in Gujarat, we will be dependent on inputs from metro cities like Mumbai, Delhi,” says a senior state health official.

The authorities also discussed whether there were previous cases of the viral disease in neighbouring states or in Gujarat. The official also added that the paramedic staff required for patient care in the wake of an epidemic has been earmarked. “The WHO has already instituted a protocol which is widely followed and we plan to rely on it till further intimation from the central health authorities,” adds the official.

He added that Gujarat authorities are closely studying the handling of Kerala’s Nipah virus outbreak to control spread of the virus. “We have made provisions for isolation wards in major city hospitals across the state,” adds the official.

Title: Get ready for Speak for India’s grand finale today
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

(Left to right, standing) S Sivabalan, Arun Gokul B, Kaaviya Baskaran, Achudha V. (Left to right, sitting) A B... Read More

CHENNAI: The second edition of India’s popular intercollegiate debate competition, Speak for India, will conclude in a grand finale on Thursday. Of the total 38,000 students representing 860 colleges from 32 districts in Tamil Nadu, 28 were selected for the semi-finals held in Chennai on Wednesday through prelims, district and zonal events.

An initiative by Federal Bank in association with The Times of India, Speak for India aims to encourage young, enthusiastic minds across the state to raise their voice on pertinent issues and become changemakers in society.

It also provides college students an opportunity to enhance their awareness and insight on contemporary issues, and identifies the state’s best debaters through rigorous competitions.

S Sivabalan, Arun Gokul B, Kaaviya Baskaran, Achudha V, A Britto, Roshini Priya K, Nandhitha M and Akash G , will participate in the finale that will be broken into two competitions under the pre-finals and one under the grand finals.

The pre-final competitions will have four participants each, talking for and against the notion. Two finalists from here will make it into the grand finals, which will also feature a Q&A session with the judges, wherein their arguments will be discussed.

“Debating has always been a passion for me and this has been a great platform to exhibit my skills. The open house held on Wednesday was a brilliant test of speed and wit. I want to become a public speaker and Speak for India has provided the right path to this,” says Kaaviya, a student of Sri Venkateswara College of Engineering.

Actor R Sarathkumar and minister for Tamil language and Tamil culture K Pandiarajan will be the chief guests for the event, and orator Bharathi Baskar, film director Karu Pazhaniappan and director of Bharath University S Praveen Kumar , will be the judges.

Title: 50% of female sex workers face violence, finds survey
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A survey of female sex workers (FSWs) conducted by an NGO has brought to light the adversities they face in their line of work and personal life for choosing sex work as a form of livelihood.

According to the survey conducted among 1,000 women sex workers in Tamil Nadu , Karnataka and Pune in 2019 by South India AIDS Action Programme (SIAAP), 50% of them face some form of violence. The objective of the study was to assess the impact of the sex work on the quality of their life.

“Most of them face domestic violence from the family members, particularly husbands for earning through sex work to make ends meet. Violence from customers is very less. Some clients would refuse to use condoms leading to arguments and violence,” project officer of SIAAP Janani Venkatesh told ToI in Trichy on Tuesday on the sidelines of a press conference.

Almost 46% sex workers (TN – 40%, Karnataka – 9 % and Pune 5 %) have experienced violence in the last six months. However, only 2% of them, sex workers from Tamil Nadu, took legal action because they fear that they will be arrested for indulging in sex work though it is not illegal and done without violating the clauses of Immoral Traffic (prevention) Act, 1956.

Out of the 1,000 FSWs, the survey covered 398 FSWs in Tamil Nadu, while the rest were from the two states.

The survey also revealed the story of some FSWs facing violence from police, healthcare providers, clients, rowdies and pimps, but most of them avoid taking legal action fearing negative consequences.

As per the survey, 40% doctors did not like to treat sex workers because it would reduce their clientele.

District program manager (DPM) Dr S M Manivannan of the District AIDS Prevention and Control Unit (DAPCU), Trichy, was of the view that the introduction of several government programmes to sensitize the FSWs prevents them from being at the mercy of any doctors outside. “Our programs clearly cover their needs. They get sensitization from our staff and get regular treatments at sexually transmitted infection (STI) clinics to prevent them from being infected by HIV,” he told ToI.

The survey also elaborated about the empowerment of the FSWs through sex work to face life more confidently to help their peers. The study also had detailed information of the healthcare of the FSWs.

Senior officials from the social welfare department said that they are planning to come up with a separate policy to protect the rights of women sex workers in the state, so that they can avail medical care, legal aid and other benefits provided to women without being excluded.

“The state also has Ujjawala homes, which is meant to help women sex workers. Those in-charges of these homes are regularly conducting awareness programmes. But they can also help only when the workers come forward,” the official said. Ujjawala homes are also meant to provide rescue and rehabilitation facilities to sex workers. However, there are only six such homes in the state. Officials said that the risks involved in running such homes have been deterring organisations from taking up the task.

“If the state agencies did their duties they wouldn’t be struggling this way. But sadly, authorities too are still stuck in the medieval era, where they look down on these women,” said Sujata Mody, president of Penn Thozhilalargal Sangam. Sujata further elaborated on the stigma associated with them and criminalisation they face in their daily lives, with very little or no help from the state.

“In countries such as Norway and Sweden it’s illegal to seek paid sex, but here the victims are criminalised no matter what the situation is. These women are adults and should be allowed to do what they want, and they want dignity and acceptance,” she said.

Isabel Richardson, director of Madras Christian Council of Social Service, the lone Ujjawala home in Chennai, said that most workers came to them seeking alternative employment and rehabilitation. “From our experience we have seen that women are mostly forced into this job by their kin and they are often exploited, they go into depression, substance addiction, etc. And they all want to come out of it and lead a better life.”

Title: LED bulbs of required watt to be installed before Feb 28: Kalshetti
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolhapur: The action of blacklisting the firm appointed for installation of 24,000 LED bulbs across the city has been deferred by a month.

The proposal to blacklist Energy Efficiency Services Limited (EESL) was tabled before the corporators for the approval after the recommendation of the standing committee.

The previous state government had made it mandatory for civic bodies to appoint EESL for installing LED lights. At the time, the corporators had objected to this; however, since the decision was taken by the state government, the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) entered into an agreement with EESL.

During the agreement, the corporators had suggested that the bulbs to be fitted on the poles should be based on the width of the road. For instance, they suggested that LED bulb of 75 watt should be installed for roads with width more than nine meters.

However, the corporators claimed that the bulbs of less watt were installed, leading to black spots on roads. They also said that several accidents took place on major roads in the city owing to these black spots.

Sharangdhar Deshmukh, chairman of standing committee, said, “The committee recommended the blacklisting of the firm due to fault in their work. We have found that at least 50% of the bulbs fitted by the firm have less watt than prescribed by us. The road passing through some wards is illuminated unevenly owing to the LED bulbs of uneven watt. We want this firm to be blacklisted and the appointment of a new firm by the civic administration. If that is not possible, we have our own engineers and staff members to take the project forward. We have observed that in one day, civic staff can fit 130 bulbs. On the other hand, this firm has not been able to install even 30 bulbs in a day.”

Congress corporator Bhupal Shete said that by the end of seven years when the contract ends, the KMC will end up paying Rs 40 crore more to the firm which means equal amount will be lost by civic body. He also said that the the municipal corporation can complete the project in just Rs 4 crore.

While many corporators supported blacklisting of the firm, some claimed that blacklisting will not do any good.

Ajit Thanekar, Bharatiya Janata Party’s leader in the KMC, said, “It is the municipal corporation’s responsibility to get the work done. I do not know why this big step to blacklist the firm is proposed? There are other projects too that have been stuck. No good company will be ready to take up the projects.”

Title: Corpn receives Rs 34.72 cr centre grant, to re-lay city roads
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Madurai: City residents will have a reason to cheer as the civic corporation will take up laying bitumen and paver blocks on city roads utilising the Rs 34.72-crore fund allotted to the civic body under 14th central finance commission 2019-20. Madurai Corporation has already floated tenders for the work, which is going to be carried out in 41 separate packages at an estimated cost of Rs 35.26 crore.

Officials said that the Rs 34.72-crore grant, which is half of the amount to be allocated by the central finance commission to Madurai Corporation, has been received by the corporation. All the corporations in Tamil Nadu have also received funds for the purposed laying roads. The allocation was made based on the proposal sent by the civic body under three broader categories such as roads damaged due to water supply works, underground drainage system and natural calamities.

City engineer S Arasu told TOI that all the damaged roads, including arterial roads and interior roads, have been listed for the work. Roads from all parts of the city will be covered except for the 15 wards, where the work on constructing underground drainage system (UGD) is to be taken up. The surrounding area of Meenakshi Amman Temple, where various developments works are under way, will also be considered later. Work order will be issued for the new UGD soon.

Another official from Madurai Corporation said that the roads to be laid fresh include the main roads and its cross roads. Meanwhile, patchworks taken up by the corporation is nearing completion. Patch works were taken up to provide temporary relief to residents. Roads, which have not completed five years since they were laid, were taken up for patch works.

Roads including Keelavaithiyanathapuram Main Road, Sambakulam second main road, Race Course Main Road, paver block roads in Vaigai Vadagarai area, New Jail Road, paver block roads in Harijan colony in Virattipathu, KK Nagar West 80-feet Road, Vishwanathapuram Main Road, Maulana Sakib Road in Anna Nagar, Lourdunagar East Main Road, Gandhipuram Main Road, Tamilan Street, New Meenakshi Nagar, Anbu Nagar in Villapuram, Kanagavel Colony Main Road, paver block roads in North and South Avani Moola Streets and Thottiyan Kinattru Street will be taken up for re-laying.

Among 14 municipal corporations in the state (except Chennai), Coimbatore corporation has received the highest amount under the scheme. It has received Rs 43.07 crore, which is followed by Madurai Corporation with Rs 34.72 crore and Trichy with Rs 24.71 crore. In the southern districts, Tirunelveli has got Rs 13.21 crore, Tuticorin Rs 9.93 crore, Dindigul Rs 4.98 crore and Nagercoil Rs 7.43 crore.

Title: 40-year-old inmate of Budaun prison dies in district hospital
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Bareilly: A 40-year-old man, who was lodged in district jail of Budaun, was allegedly found in an unconscious state in the prison barrack on Wednesday. He was later declared dead at a district hospital.

The superintendent of district jail claimed that the man was not physically assaulted as there were no injury marks on his body. According to him, the man may have died of heart attack. Police have sent his body for postmortem.

Notably, when prison staff opened the barrack in the morning, they reportedly found the man in unconscious state. The doctor at jail referred him to district hospital where he died.

According to jail officials, Mukesh, son of Ram Bharose and a resident of Kinhapur village under Ujhani police station of Budaun, was lodged in district jail here on January 10. He was booked under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting armed with deadly weapon), 427 (mischief causing damage), 436 (mischief by fire or explosive substance), 504 (intentional insult with intention to provoke breach of peace) and 506 (criminal intimidation).

District jail superintendent Aditya Kumar said, “Mukesh never complained of any illness when he was lodged in the jail. When our staff went to open the barrack, they saw Mukesh ‘sleeping’ with his face covered with a bedsheet. When they tried to wake him up, they found that he was unconscious.”

Kumar further said, “The doctor at jail referred him to district hospital where he died. He was not physically assaulted as there were no injury marks on his body. We suspect that he died of heart attack. We are awaiting postmortem report to ascertain the cause of death and further measures will be taken accordingly.”

Title: What this 'MBA Chaiwala' is doing at AAP's Delhi headquarters
Content:
Praful Billore from Ahmedabad, who goes by the name of ‘MBA Chaiwala’, will supply tea under AAP's new program... Read More

NEW DELHI: Aam Aadmi Party claims that development is its “cup of tea”. And this particular chaiwala is convinced.
