Title: New book traces history of emancipation of women in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: “Women in Gujarat and in India have not written their own exclusive histories when it came to issues of emancipation or social movements, like the feminist movement of the West. Instead they have shared their space with men in their struggle,” says Shirin Mehta, historian, scholar and teacher, whose mammoth effort of chronicled the role of Gujarat women’s — including the subaltern, depressed classes and Adivasis — in social reforms and freedon movement.

She argues in her new 728-page Gujarati book titled, ‘Gujarat Ma Narichetana ane Vanchit Mahilao No Padkar’ (women’s emancipation in Gujarat and the role of subaltern women), that Mahatma Gandhi is often credited with drawing women into social and freedom movements, but Mehta says, “Women’s participation in these movements was not sudden nor accidental. It was the culmination of a series of ideas and institutional developments that had preceded the Gandhian era,” says Mehta. The event was attended by economist Yogendra Alagh, Lord Bhikhu Parekh, Gandhi scholar Tridip Suhrud and writer Kumarpal Desai.

In her book, Mehta resurrects Dalit women like Shanta Vankar, the 10-year-old girl Bhuri and Hari Vaghri from the 1874 industrial commission inquiry, where these women had come out to complain against the poor working conditions in the textile mills. In 1891, women from the Devipujak, Koli, Muslim and Bavcha communities, along with their men and children took out a protest rally against low wages and retrenchment.

Title: Udaipur man names son ‘Congress’ Jain
Content:
Vinod Jain with his son Congress

Birth certificate of

Congress Jain

His family opposed the idea of naming the child

Vinod Jain with his son Congress Jain

Congress Jain

UDAIPUR: His family opposed the idea and relatives and friends ridiculed him. But nothing deterred this 46-year-old man to name his only son ‘Congress’ who was born after 22 years of marriage.Vinod Jain, a building material supplier in Udaipur and a staunch Congress worker, has been ecstatic after receiving the birth certificate of his six-month-old son recently.Jain faced severe opposition from his two college going daughters Prarthana and Priyanshi who were very excited to get a little brother after so many years. “It is natural and rightful on their part to nurture a desire to name their baby brother. So, they were quite upset when I announced my decision to name him ‘Congress’. They quarrelled with me over the name and even did not speak to me for days but I was adamant and managed to convince them,” Jain said. The idea struck him from the BJP punchline- “Congress Mukta Bharat”. “Today, I have named my child and in the coming years, many others may do the same because ideas spread like fire. Congress ideology will never die,” said Jain.His wife Vandana was understanding, he claimed, as she knew his dedication towards the party and hence stood by his decision. He has been receiving congratulatory calls ever since the birth certificate has gone viral on the social media.“It may sound weird or funny today, but it is my gut feeling that soon, the Congress party would regain its glory and make a remarkable comeback. I hope when my son becomes 18-year-old, there would be Congress Raj in the entire country and people would forget the saffron party,” he says.

Title: Hi-tech corridor: Nod for draft shareholders’ pact
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state cabinet on Wednesday approved the draft shareholders’ agreement for developing the high-tech industrial corridor from Palakkad to Kochi.

The shareholders’ agreement will be inked between the state and national industrial corridor development and implementation trust (NICDIT) under the ministry of commerce and industry. The hi-tech industrial corridor is part of the extension of Bengaluru-Chennai corridor to Kochi, via Coimbatore. The length of the corridor from Kochi to Coimbatore is 160km. There will be six integrated manufacturing clusters (IMCs) in this corridor. In the corridor at Palakkad, food processing, rubber, electronics, general machinery and electrical machinery industries will be given top priorities.

The cabinet had last week decided to acquire 1,351 acres for setting up the IMC at a cost of Rs 1,038 crore through Kerala infrastructure investment fund board (KIIFB) in Palakkad for the project. Land will be acquired at Kannambra-Alathur, Puthussery-Chittoor, Uzhalapathy-Chittoor and Kanjikode. The state government’s request for extending the corridor to Kochi was earlier cleared by NICDIT.

The government expects to attract an investment of more than Rs 10,000 crore to the IMC and create more than 10,000 jobs. The project is envisaged to be run by a special purpose vehicle formed jointly by the state and Centre. The state’s investment will be the land while the Centre will develop it.

The cabinet on Wednesday also decided to give approval to Kerala urban service delivery project to strengthen institutional and service delivery systems of urban local bodies in the state, in such a way that World Bank funds can be provided to local bodies for the project, in addition to the Plan funds. The World Bank has agreed to provide Rs 2,100 crore as loan at 2% interest for 25 years for the project.

Physical investments will take place in a limited number of medium or small cities (with population less than 1 lakh), which have not received previous support for reforms and service delivery under national schemes like JNNURM and Amrut.

Title: Nashik: Two held in connection with Rs 2 lakh pickpocket case
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

NASHIK: The Nashik rural police on Tuesday arrested two people from Malegaon in connection with a pickpocketing case amounting to Rs two lakh in Igatpuri last week.

The suspects are identified as Abdul Rehman alias Natya Mohammad Farooq (25) of Azadnagar and Hamidali alias Daliya Mohammad Umar (40) of Tadvi Nagar.

The police said that the crime was committed by three people out of which is currently absconding. Senior officials of the Local Crime Branch (LCB) said that on January 15, the villagers of Igatpuri taluka had organised a felicitation of Harshvardhan Sadgir, who recently won the Maharashtra Kesari Wrestling Championship earlier this month in Pune.

Many villagers from Igatpuri had arrived to see the felicitation including a trader from Nandgaon Sado village. Taking advantage of the rush, the suspects stole the cash from the trader’s trouser pocket and vanished from the scene.

A complaint was lodged by the trader with the Igatpuri police and police immediately swung into action.

Title: In a 1st, passengers of Ahd-Mumbai Tejas to get Rs 100 each for train delay
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Mumbai: In a first for the city’s railway network, around 630 passengers of the Ahmedabad-Mumbai Tejas Express are eligible to a compensation of Rs 100 each for a delay of more than 80 minutes on the train ’s run to Mumbai Central on Wednesday.

Tejas Express is the only class of trains on Indian Railways whose passengers are eligible for compensation in case of a delay—Rs 100 if a train is late by more than one hour and Rs 250 in case of two hours. This is the second instance in the country of passengers of Tejas Express getting compensated. In October 2019, 950 passengers of the Delhi-Lucknow Tejas Express got Rs 250 each after the train reached it destination three hours late.

In the Ahmedabad-Mumbai train’s case, Western Railway services were affected after a technical problem in the over head equipment between Mira Road and Bhayander from 12.38pm to 1.30pm, which threw Churchgate-bound fast trains off schedule. As a result, four long-distance trains, including Tejas Express, were delayed too. IRCTC public relations officer said, “The train got delayed due to a problem in an over head electric wire. Passengers are entitled to a compensation of Rs 100 as the train was delayed by over 75 minutes.”

Passengers must make a claim for refund . IRCTC has estimated around 630 passengers are eligible for compensation. Passengers can call 1800-266-8844 or email irctcclaim@libertyinsurance.in. They must submit their PNR number along with the insurance number and a cancelled cheque. The claim will be processed within a day of submission of these details.

IRCTC offers travel insurance to passengers of Tejas Express through Liberty General Insurance Company.

Tejas Express was flagged off from Ahmedabad on January 17. This the first time that compensation for delay is being paid for it.

Tejas Express also took an unscheduled halt at Andheri as several passengers feared they would miss their flight due to the delay. IRCTC official said, “Some passengers who had a flight to catch requested us for an unscheduled halt at Andheri station. Based on their request, the train was halted at Andheri station for two minutes.”

Title: KMC drafts Rs7.55cr plan to upgrade pumping stations
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolhapur: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has drafted a proposal of Rs 7.55 crore for upgrading all three pumping stations and improving city’s water supply system.

During the general body meeting of the KMC held on Wednesday, the corporators claimed that water supply in their localities has been irregular for the last few months. Most of the corporators who complained about poor supply were from E ward and internal parts of the city.

They claimed that supply of water has stopped in many areas for the last four to six days and demanded starting alternate day supply to ensure every part of the city gets adequate supply.

The water supply department had tabled a proposal of utilising Rs 60 lakh for emergency repairs of the water treatment plants located in the city. Last month, a delegation of corporators had visited the water treatment plants (WTP) and found that the main reason for supply of contaminated water was decline in the efficiency of the WTPs

Satyajit Kadam, Tararani Aghadi corporator, said, “No water is being supplied in the E ward. Every time we are told that there is some technical glitch at the pumping station.”

Shekhar Kusale, another corporator, claimed that carrying out repair works will not work. “In order to ensure continuous supply the pumping stations at Balinga and Nagdevwadi should be upgraded immediately. We had requested drafting of estimates for the work since the last three months but nothing has been done yet.”

In the last three months, water supply has been cut for at least four to eight days a month owing to shutting of pumping stations. Next week, the KMC has planned another water cut that may last for two days for repairing the pumping stations.

Responding to the concerns, the civic officials in the meeting claimed that another proposal of Rs 7.55 crore is ready with the KMC through which the pumping stations will be upgraded and new pumps and systems will be installed.

Title: Road works to be completed in three months
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Madurai: The officials from the engineering wing of Madurai Corporation said that works are expected to begin in the first week of February and all the bitumen laying works will be completed in two months. It will take one month more for the paver block roads to be completed.

The tender procedures were already over and the pre-bid meeting has also been conducted. Officials said that bids will be opened in the presence of bidders on January 28 and tenders would be awarded to the chosen bidders.

“We will provide three months’ time for the contractor to complete bitumen laying work and paver block roads. One more month leniency can be given for the projects taken up at places, where works are affected due to the upcoming Chithirai festival,” said an official from engineering wing.

Officials said that once a road is laid, the same road cannot be taken for re-laying for 5 years. Contractor’s defect liability duration is only for one year. The contractor can be pulled up for liability if the road gets damaged in the first year.

Title: Cycling expedition begins in Jaisalmer
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

JAISALMER: The Battle Axe Sappers’ Next of Kin Outreach Cycle Expedition was flagged off under the aegis of Battle Axe Division from Jaisalmer Military Station on Wednesday. The expedition was flagged off by Major General Rakesh Kapoor, General Officer Commanding Battle Axe Division. The team will reach out to various interior locations of the five Southern states as majority of troops of the Battle Axe Sappers hail from these states — Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Tamil Nadu and Kerala, covering a distance of 1,401km in 25 days. The expedition team aims at educating the ‘Veer Naris’, next of kin of battle and physical casualty soldiers about grants and benefits entitled to them. The team will also motivate the school-going children and local youth to join the Indian Army, thus garnering goodwill for the armed forces and the country as a whole.

Title: 40-year-old inmate of Budaun prison dies in district hospital
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Bareilly: A 40-year-old man, who was lodged in district jail of Budaun, was allegedly found in an unconscious state in the prison barrack on Wednesday. He was later declared dead at a district hospital.

The superintendent of district jail claimed that the man was not physically assaulted as there were no injury marks on his body. According to him, the man may have died of heart attack. Police have sent his body for postmortem.

Notably, when prison staff opened the barrack in the morning, they reportedly found the man in unconscious state. The doctor at jail referred him to district hospital where he died.

According to jail officials, Mukesh, son of Ram Bharose and a resident of Kinhapur village under Ujhani police station of Budaun, was lodged in district jail here on January 10. He was booked under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting armed with deadly weapon), 427 (mischief causing damage), 436 (mischief by fire or explosive substance), 504 (intentional insult with intention to provoke breach of peace) and 506 (criminal intimidation).

District jail superintendent Aditya Kumar said, “Mukesh never complained of any illness when he was lodged in the jail. When our staff went to open the barrack, they saw Mukesh ‘sleeping’ with his face covered with a bedsheet. When they tried to wake him up, they found that he was unconscious.”

Kumar further said, “The doctor at jail referred him to district hospital where he died. He was not physically assaulted as there were no injury marks on his body. We suspect that he died of heart attack. We are awaiting postmortem report to ascertain the cause of death and further measures will be taken accordingly.”

Title: Upset over marital discord, man cuts vein in Beawar court
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Ajmer: A 34-year-old man attempted suicide by cutting a vein on his wrist on the premises of a court in Beawar, around 55km from Ajmer, on Wednesday. Mahendra, a resident of Shahpura Mohalla, was going through marital problems and was at the court for a hearing. Sub-divisional officer Jasmeet Singh Sandhu, who saw him in blood, rushed him to a nearby hospital in his vehicle. Police reached the hospital and recorded Mahendra’s statement to register a case. Mahendra had an altercation with his wife and her relative outside the court. He started shouting at her and later took out a blade and cut his vein. The incident created panic among the litigants and advocates on the court premises. Though there was a verbal duel between the couple, nobody interfered to stop them. SDO Sandhu took the man to the hospital where he is said to be in critical condition due to severe blood loss, said an eyewitness.

Mahendra’s counsel Sanjay Nahar said he was having a marital dispute and the case was pending in court. Both parties appeared in court on Wednesday. City police said they are waiting for Mahendra’s statement, but have registered his wife’s statement. TNN

Title: Two people killed in separate road accidents
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nashik: Two people died in separate road accidents in the Adgaon area on the Mumbai-Agra highway on Saturday and Monday.

A 30-year-old identified Vishnu Thakre riding pillion on a bike died when the bike on which he was riding pillion was hit from behind by a truck driver on Monday. In another accident, a 38-year-old cleaner identified as Mohammad Ajmer Amir Khan died after the truck lost control and crashed.

Title: Andaman, it is: BMC reverts to original venue for study tour
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

BMC headquarters

MUMBAI: The BMC ’s civic works committee, which had changed its study tour venue from Andaman Islands to Chandigarh last week following the BJP’s opposition, reopened the proposal on Wednesday and reverted to its original plan with a majority vote. It will now visit Andaman as was planned earlier.

The works committee had initially intended to visit Andaman to study their drainage system but the BJP had taken strong objection to the expenditure citing reduced BMC tax collections. A Shiv Sena member in the committee had then suggested that the venue be changed to Chandigarh and the proposal was cleared despite the BJP’s opposition.

Several members were not happy with the change, though, and insisted that they visit Andaman. An urgent meeting was called on Wednesday to reopen last week’s proposal. The works committee cancelled the Chandigarh tour proposal and brought back the earlier Andaman plan on board. The members voted with 17 from the Sena, Congress and NCP supporting the Andaman proposal and seven from the BJP opposing it.

Title: Amdavadis habituated to blocking left turn
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Ahmedabad: Amdavadis are habituated to blocking the left turn at crossroads. This has been revealed by figures from city traffic police, which indicates that at least 16 cases of blocking the left turn have been registered every day for four years.

According to the figures, the city reported 23,747 cases between 2016 and 2019, and offenders blocking left turns at crossroads, had to cough up Rs 25.25 lakh in fines to traffic cops.

“Though the number of such cases have decreased and increased, many people break the about rule keeping the left turn lane free. The police and Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation are also at fault, as there have not been any campaigns to make commuters aware about the need to keep the left turn free at crossroads,” said a police official.

In 2019, the city reported 3,060 cases for blocking the left turn and offenders paid total fines of Rs 4.50 lakh. Two-wheeler riders were the top violators, with 1,363 cases reported against them.

There was a decline in such cases in 2019, compared to 2018. In 2018, as many as 7,536 cases for blocking left turns were reported and fines of Rs 7.58 lakh were paid. Two-wheeler riders again topped the charts, with 3,930 cases reported against them.

The number of cases in 2016 was the highest of the last four years, with 9,681 cases registered and Rs 9.69 lakh collected in fines by city traffic police. The number of such cases fell in 2017, with just 3,470 registered and fines of Rs 3.47 lakh imposed.

Title: Action against illegal transport, change in KMT ops soon: Desai
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

KOLHAPUR: Action against illegal transport in the city is expected soon.

The corporators raised the concerns related to the illegal mode of transport and its effect on the revenue of the Kolhapur Municipal Transport (KMT) during a meeting of the general body of Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) on Wednesday.

They claimed that the KMT is financially weak and certain steps need to be taken to make the transport utility financially viable.

Shiv Sena corporator Niyaz Khan, who is a former chairman of the transport committee, said, “Around 2,000 people directly depend on the KMT for their livelihood. The KMT is making huge losses. Since the new chief of the KMT is from the transport office, we expect him to take effective action against the illegal transport, especially autorickshaws.”

The KMT officials too agree that the illegal transport is causing decline in the passenger count of their buses. The autodrivers pick up passengers waiting at the KMC bus stops even though they have their own separate stop.

At present, the KMT is making losses in tune of Rs 2.5 lakh per day. The KMC grants funds to the KMT for paying the salaries of the drivers and ticket collectors.

Subhash Desai, transport inspector and newly-appointed additional manager of the KMT, said, “Soon, corporators will witness change in operations of the KMT. We will take all measures suggested by them and those of urgent necessity.”

Some corporators welcomed Desai and said he was the first person having sound knowledge and experience of the transport systems to be appointed as the additional manager of KMT.

Khan claimed that there were limitations in effective management of the KMT when civic officials headed it and there was lack of expertise.

Title: EC ready with catalogue of errors for glitch-free Delhi elections
Content:
A senior official said the catalogue had been prepared on the basis of “hands-on experience” of the officials ... Read More

NEW DELHI: To avoid glitches due to “mishandling” of electronic voting machines and voter verified paper audit trail, the Delhi election office has prepared a “catalogue of errors”.A senior official said the catalogue had been prepared on the basis of “hands-on experience” of the officials in the 2019 Lok Sabha election in Delhi when VVPATs were used for the first time at all booths. The catalogue will serve as a dos and don’ts guide for over 80,000 polling staff entrusted with the responsibility of conducting elections at 2,700-odd booths where votes will be cast to elect the 70-member Delhi assembly.According to officials, several “distress” calls were made by presiding officers and polling teams to the central control room while setting up the polling booths during the parliamentary election in May last year. VVPAT , which is considered a sensitive machine, and EVMs malfunctioned at several places and were replaced before the voting began.The polling teams also forgot to delete the records of the mock poll before the actual polling started, which forced EC to order a re-poll at one booth, while at four other stations, the paper trail and the EVM data had to be separately matched. This had delayed the counting process. At some places, the polling teams found it difficult to connect the two equipment.“VVPAT has to be handled carefully. It cannot be kept under direct sunlight. While transporting, it has to be carried vertically. It also reacts to the climatic conditions. All these things have been included in the catalogue, which will be given to the polling officials during their training slated to start next week,” a senior election official said. About 1,000 sector officers have been trained under Phase 1.The polling teams also erred in completing the paperwork before the start of the voting process and while handing over EVM machines at the strong rooms. EC has also decided to dispatch teams a day before and has made arrangements for their lodging and food at the polling booths.

Title: PCB chief quits, says no ‘enabling environment’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

KOCHI: Ajit Haridas , chairman of the Kerala pollution control board has resigned from the board citing ‘absence of an enabling environment’. A special board meeting on December 27 had passed a resolution expressing lack of confidence in the chairman, whom they accused of taking unilateral decisions without consulting board members.

According to board sources, Haridas was in trouble for inviting the CPM’s wrath after the board issued a notice to Thiruvananthapuram corporation in October last year asking it to pay an environmental compensation of Rs 14.5 crore under the polluter pays principle. What angered the party was the timing of the notice: CPM was fighting a crucial bypoll and V K Prasanth popularly known as ‘Mayor Bro’ was the candidate in Vattiyoorkkavu constituency.

Ajit Haridas could not be reached for a comment but his resegnition was confirmed by principal secretary in charge of environment Usha Titus. While the resignation letter did not elaborate on the reasons behind the resignation, a covering letter attached to it denied the allegations raised against him as vague and unspecific.

Title: Traffic police writes to NMC for removing encroachments at Nepali Corner
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nashik: City traffic police has written to the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ), asking them to remove the encroachments in Nepali Corner area of the city which is hindering smooth flow of vehicular traffic.

“Hundreds of hawkers occupy the road at Nepali Corner near Regional Referral Hospital,” a senior official of the city traffic branch said, adding that they have communicated with the civic officials to start an anti-encroachment drive in the area.

Police inspector Bharatkumar Suryawanshi of the city traffic branch said, “The Nepali Corner area has huge flow of vehicular traffic from the Main Road area. However, due to encroachment there is hardly any space left for vehicular traffic. In view of this, we have communicated with the NMC to take up the anti-encroachment drive.”

Suryawanshi has been appointed as a special officer of the city traffic branch for streamlining vehicular traffic at Ashok Stambh, Raviwar Karanja, Shalimar, Nepali Corner, Ramkund area and other congested parts in the old city.

“Our aim is also to do away with encroachments around Nehru Garden area that becomes crowded during the evening hours,” he said.

“The entire compound of Nehru Garden is surrounded by vendors during the evening hours, while the roads have busy traffic movement. These encroachments pose a major obstacle for the movement of vehicular traffic on account of which we have also suggested to take up an anti-encroachment drive around Nehru Garden as well,” he added.

Suryawanshi said they have removed encroachment from Shivaji Garden area along the Shalimar-CBS road which has eased the movement of traffic to some extent.

“The traffic police have started taking strict action against those violating the no-entry norm from Nehru Garden towards Shivaji Road area. Apart from booking motorists for violating the no-entry rule, we are also penalizing those riding two-wheelers without helmets,” he said.

Areas like Shalimar, CBS and Red Cross Signal witness heavy traffic throughout the day and encroachment is a serious issue in these areas. “We are communicating the infrastructure problems with the NMC so that the roads are made clutter-free for smooth flow of traffic,” he said.

Title: Kolhapur: RTE admission process begins with verification of schools
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

KOLHAPUR: The Right to Education (RTE) admission process for academic year 2020-21 began on Tuesday with registration of private schools across the district.

In the first phase, according to district primary education department, the schools involved have been asked to register on the RTE portal and get verified by the Block Education Officer (BEO) of that particular taluka.

A circular from district primary education officer Kolhapur zilla parishad Asha Ubale stated that registration and verification of schools has to be completed by February 6.

The registration of parents will start from February 11 and will conclude on February 29. The first lottery is likely to be drawn on March 11. “All unaided, permanently unaided and self-financed schools have been advised to register via the online mode for the said admission process,” the circular added.

An official from the education department said help centres will be set up at respective talukas in the district wherein the parents can get all information required for the admission process.

“Under the RTE Act, 2009, it is mandatory for private schools to reserve 25% of their seats for children from underprivileged section. The schools will also have to ensure that the information related to the admission process is advertised accordingly,” he said.

Last year, over 300 schools had registered for admissions under the RTE. As per the act, economically and socially disadvantaged children, as well as those with disabilities, can be admitted in Class I or at pre-primary stage of private, aided and unaided schools. These children receive free education, including textbooks and other facilities.

Title: EC ready with catalogue of errors for glitch-free Delhi elections
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

A senior official said the catalogue had been prepared on the basis of “hands-on experience” of the officials ... Read More

NEW DELHI: To avoid glitches due to “mishandling” of electronic voting machines and voter verified paper audit trail, the Delhi election office has prepared a “catalogue of errors”.

A senior official said the catalogue had been prepared on the basis of “hands-on experience” of the officials in the 2019 Lok Sabha election in Delhi when VVPATs were used for the first time at all booths. The catalogue will serve as a dos and don’ts guide for over 80,000 polling staff entrusted with the responsibility of conducting elections at 2,700-odd booths where votes will be cast to elect the 70-member Delhi assembly.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

According to officials, several “distress” calls were made by presiding officers and polling teams to the central control room while setting up the polling booths during the parliamentary election in May last year. VVPAT, which is considered a sensitive machine, and EVMs malfunctioned at several places and were replaced before the voting began.

The polling teams also forgot to delete the records of the mock poll before the actual polling started, which forced EC to order a re-poll at one booth, while at four other stations, the paper trail and the EVM data had to be separately matched. This had delayed the counting process. At some places, the polling teams found it difficult to connect the two equipment.

“VVPAT has to be handled carefully. It cannot be kept under direct sunlight. While transporting, it has to be carried vertically. It also reacts to the climatic conditions. All these things have been included in the catalogue, which will be given to the polling officials during their training slated to start next week,” a senior election official said. About 1,000 sector officers have been trained under Phase 1.

The polling teams also erred in completing the paperwork before the start of the voting process and while handing over EVM machines at the strong rooms. EC has also decided to dispatch teams a day before and has made arrangements for their lodging and food at the polling booths.

Title: Police seize gutka worth Rs 42.71L
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nashik: Police on Wednesday seized gutka worth Rs 42.71 lakh from a truck in Gaulane village on the outskirts of the city.

“DCP Vijay Kharat of zone II received information that a truck loaded with gutka has come from Gujarat and was on its way to Mumbai. After verifying the information, police laid a trap at Gaulane village and intercepted the truck,” a police officer said.

The truck driver, who initially refrained from giving any information about the goods loaded in the truck, gave in to the barrage of questions posed by the police and told that he was carrying gutka to Bhiwandi. There were a total of 98 bags of the banned tobacco product inside the truck.

“The truck driver said that he was told that the place where gutka was to be delivered would be given told to him after reaching Bhiwandi. An offence has been registered against the suspect driver under various sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006,” the officer said.

Title: Pune: Changing wind pattern blows away colder nights’ forecast
Content:
Representational Image

PUNE: This year’s Republic Day won’t be as cold as was forecast earlier. So, the extra woollies people may have pulled out can be stashed away for now.The likely formation of an upper air cyclonic circulation at a lower atmospheric level over Maharashtra has partially negated the state’s chances of experiencing a significant fall in the night or minimum temperature till the month end.In fact, Shivajinagar and Lohegaon recorded their highest day temperature on Wednesday for this month at 31.4 degrees celsius (1.3 degrees above the normal) and 31.3 degrees celsius (1.3 degrees above the normal) respectively.Shivajinagar also registered the second highest night temperature for January on Wednesday at 15.3 degrees celsius. The highest was on January 8 at 17.4 degrees celsius.The India Meteorological Department had forecast a drop in the minimum temperatures to single digits across Maharashtra around Republic Day between January 25 and 27.Though the minimum temperature may fall to some extent on January 25 in the northern parts of the state, it may rise after that and there seems to be less possibility of a significant fall in night temperature till the month-end.Such weather conditions may keep night temperatures above the normal for some time and chances of a fall below 10 degrees celsius is unlikely.Already, parts of the state, including Pune, are experiencing a rise in humidity levels as well as night temperatures. With day temperatures having crossed 30 degrees celsius, a warmer than normal winter could be experienced in the state for the next few days though the nights will record marginally low temperature in the morning from January 23 to 25.Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune told TOI that partial clouding in the morning and the evening that keeps night temperatures warm may reduce slowly from January 23-25. Minimum temperature may fall gradually, but not below 10 degrees celsius , he said.“January 26-27 may again register a marginal rise in minimums due to various weather systems, including an anti-cyclone over Rajasthan and adjoining Madhya Pradesh, a trough-line forming over South Maharashtra and an upper cyclonic circulation over Rajasthan. All these factors will change the wind pattern over most parts of the state to southeasterly, southerly and easterly, which are warm and moist winds,” Kashyapi added.

Title: Kolhapur: Woman killed, three injured in accident
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

KOLHAPUR: A 52-year-old woman was killed and four others injured in a road accident at Shiroli phata area on Pune-Bengaluru national highway at wee hours on Wednesday.

The injured have been shifted to the Chhatrapati Pramila Raje (CPR) civil hospital and are under observation, said the police.

The deceased, identified as 52-year-old Savita Shantinath Bedkihale was a resident of Bhoj village, Chikkodi taluka, district Belgaum, Karnataka.

According to the police, all the passengers are relatives and were resident of Karnataka. Two of them are from Hatkanangle taluka. On Tuesday, they had gone to Pune to meet one of their relatives and left for their home on Tuesday night.

“At around 3am, when the car arrived at Sangli phata, Shiroli Pulachi on Pune-Bangalore national highway, the driver lost control of the vehicle and rammed into the tractor trolley carrying sugar cane, which was going on the left lane. Savita died on the spot and others including the driver sustained injuries. With the help of the passers-by, we admitted them into the hospital and they are under observation,” said a police officer attached with Shiroli MIDC police station.

“The tractor was on its way to Jawahar cooperative mill, Hupari, and the initial investigation suggests that the tractor was travelling on the left lane but the driver of the car lost his control and rammed into the trolley,” he said.

Satyawan Dashrath Budhawale (20), who is a resident of Mhaswad, Satara district, driver of the tractor lodged a complaint in this regard.

Police have booked the driver of the car for rash driving. Several sections of IPC including section 304 (A) (Causing death by negligence), 279 (Rash driving or riding on a public way), 337 (Causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others), 338 (Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) and section 184 of the Motor Vehicle Act have been invoked against him.

The issue has again highlighted the importance of reflectors for the vehicles which carry canes during the night. Police are investigating if the tractor had put reflectors on the backside of the trolley, as per the rule.

Title: Kerala child returns from Nepal, unaware of gas leak tragedy
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Praveen and Saranya with their kids Sreebadra (9), Aarcha (7) and Abhinav (3)

KOZHIKODE: Seven-year-old Madhav , the sole surviving member of his family, reached Nedumbassery airport late on Wednesday night without knowing that the tragedy in Nepal had claimed the lives of his parents ( Ranjith Kumar and Indu Lakshmi) and younger brother Vyshnav (2). He survived as he slept in another room at Everest Panorama Resort in Nepal’s Daman during the fateful night.

Madhav had gone to sleep as soon as the four families checked in at the resort in Nepal on Monday night. As it was biting cold at the popular tourist destination, his parents and his brother went to their family friend Praveen’s room where a heater was available.

The child, who is unaware of the tragic chain of events, was brought to New Delhi from Nepal by some members of the travelling group. Madhav’s uncle Aneesh, who is serving in the Army in Uttar Pradesh, received him in Delhi and accompanied him on the flight from Delhi to Nedumbassery (via Bengaluru). They are expected to reach Madhav's maternal home at Mukavoor early on Thursday.His family had flown to Delhi for the holiday trip from Nedumbassery on Friday.

Aneesh told over the phone from New Delhi airport that Madhav was continuously asking about his parents and younger brother. “We haven’t told him about the incident despite his repeated queries. He is asking for his parents and younger brother,” he said. Aneesh is the husband of Chitra Lakshmi, Indu’s sister.

Ranjith Kumar’s brother-in-law Peethambaran said that the child was told that his parents would be coming home in another flight very soon. Relatives back home in Kunnamangalam are at pains on how they would console the little child when he would see the bodies of his parents and brother on Friday.

Madhav's class teacher Simmi S Nair from Silver Hills Public School in Kozhikode where he is studying in Class-II said that the kid had told her a lot about his trip during class last Thursday.

“When I made the announcement in the class on Thursday that all students should wear school uniform for the annual day programme on Saturday, Madhav came to me and said that he will not be there for the event as he and his family were going on a pleasure trip to Delhi. So I wished him a happy and memorable trip,” she said.

She said that Madhav's parents had shown keen interest and involvement in his studies.

Title: UP seizes 104-bigha land, semi-constructed building in Azam’s Ali Jauhar university
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Rampur: Administration in UP’s Rampur on Wednesday took the possession of 104-bigha land inside Mohammad Ali Jauhar University campus on the directions of revenue board court in Prayagraj, which has found that rules were flouted while purchasing the patch of lands from a bunch of Dalit farmers.

When contacted, Deepak Saxena, government counsel at board of revenue in Prayagraj, said, “Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act bars small land-owning Dalits from transferring their land to non-Scheduled Castes. And if they do, it has to be approved by the district administration.” No such permission was taken by the Jauhar Trust, run by local MP and senior Samajwadi Party leader Azam Khan.

“The revenue board had quashed the order of the Moradabad Commissioner court, which had granted permission for sale of the land in 2013,” Saxena said.

On Wednesday afternoon, the administration also sealed a semi-constructed building inside the varsity campus over non-payment of Cess.

Led by Rampur’s sub divisional magistrate (SDM) Prem Prakash Tiwari, a team of officials reached the campus and started the procedure to seize the building and confiscate the land.

Rampur’s district magistrate (DM) Aunjaneya Kumar Singh told TOI, “The process to take the possession of the land was started after we received a copy from the board of revenue, which found that Jauhar Trust flouted the UP Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act while acquiring 104-bigha land.”

The officials also seized a building of the university.

The DM added, “One of the buildings of Mohammad Ali Jauhar University has also been seized after the Jauhar Trust failed to deposit a cess of Rs 1.37 crore for the construction of the varsity.”

Under the Building And Other Construction Workers Regulation of Employment and Conditions of Service Act 1996, all buildings, above the cost of Rs 10 lakh, constructed in the state have to pay a cess of 1% to the board that spends it on welfare measures for workers.

The DM added, “The officials went to seize the administrative block of the university, but the vice chancellor Sultan Mohammad Khan said that seizure of the administrative block will hit ongoing examination. So, the decision was taken to seize some other building.”

The university, whose chancellor is Azam Khan, was established in 2006. Spread in over 500 acres, it is run by Maulana Mohammad Ali Jauhar Trust.

Title: Kolhapur likely to see increase in minimum temperature
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representational Image

KOLHAPUR: The city is likely to see an increase in the minimum temperature in the coming days, stated the India Meteorological Department, New Delhi.

With the region witnessing dry weather from past few days, the minimum the temperature on Wednesday was recorded at 18.8 degrees Celsius while the maximum was 31 degrees Celsius.

The met department has predicted a rise in both-maximum and minimum temperatures across the region by January 28. The maximum temperature is likely to reach 32 degrees Celsius, while the minimum temperature is likely to touch 21 degrees Celsius. The sky, according to the met department will remain clear during all this while.

The weather report from the Regional Meteorological Centre, Mumbai on Wednesday stated that the temperatures were appreciably above normal over Madhya Maharashtra, above normal over south Konkan-Goa, Marathwada, and south Gujarat region and normal elsewhere over the region.

The weather forecast report from IMD said there will be no large change in minimum temperatures over the Maharashtra region during the next 48 hours.

Title: Pune: Domino effect of dense fog in north India delays flights
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Pune airport

PUNE: Dense fog in north India, especially in Delhi and the NCR region, triggered the delay of 10 flights — both inbound and departing — at the Lohegaon airport on Wednesday morning.

The delay, of more than two hours in some cases, irked passengers. No flights to/from Pune were diverted but the Delhi airport reported diversions of five flights in the morning.

Between 6am and 9am, three flights of IndiGo, SpiceJet and Air India to Delhi were delayed by 50 minutes to more than two hours. In the same duration, two flights of IndiGo and Air India — coming to Pune from Delhi — were delayed by over two hours.

City-based businessman Amar Tripathy said, “My flight was supposed to take off at 7.40am from Pune but has been delayed by more than two-and-a-half hours. I had an important meeting with a client at 11am in Delhi, following which I had planned to return in the evening. Now, I might have to cancel the return flight, which will cost me more money.”

Between 9am and noon, two flights, one to Delhi and another to Jodhpur, were delayed by over an hour. At the same time, three flights coming to Pune from Delhi were delayed by an hour-and-a-half to more than two-and-a-half hours.

Somesh Jain, travelling to the city from Delhi with his family, said, “Many passengers on various flights faced difficulties in the morning.”

From noon to 3pm, many departing flights to Bhopal, Delhi and Kolkata were delayed. An Air India flight to Pune from Bhopal was delayed by over three hours, while the flight from Kolkata to the city was delayed by close to an hour-and-a-half.

Poor visibility in Bengaluru, Delhi, Bagodara and Patna on Wednesday had an impact on flight movements. Advisories were sent out by airlines, including IndiGo, Vistara, GoAir and SpiceJet.

Sources in the aiport said 20 flight delays were recorded till 6pm.

Title: Kolhapur: Youth killed to recover stolen gutka, 6 arrested
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

KOLHAPUR: The Jaysingpur police on Wednesday arrested six people for allegedly kidnapping and beating a youth to death at a farmhouse in Danoli village in Shirol taluka.

The deceased have been identified as Arjun (27, resident of Nandini Layout taluka, district Bangalore, Karnataka). All six of them were produced before the local court and were sent to police custody till February 3.

According to police, the youth along with two others were transporting 104 bags of gutka through their truck from Tumkur MIDC to Athani in Karnataka. When they reached Athani they found that 53 bags of gutka were missing from the truck. They informed the incident to the truck owner and the supplier of the gutka who blamed the trio of stealing the gutka.

“The trio was then kidnapped by a gang of ten people on January 20 and were taken to an undisclosed location in Miraj. The gang beat the trio and asked them to reveal the whereabouts of the bags. They were later taken to another farmhouse at Danoli and further beaten. On January 21 night Arjun died off his injuries. When they were destroying the body we rushed to the spot and nabbed the accused,” said a police officer.

The police suspect that the suspects were part of contract gang and were appointed by truck owner and gutka supplier to get the whereabouts of the missing bags.

Title: Health dept takes up mop-up polio drive in Nashik
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representational Image

NASHIK: The health department undertook the mop-up round of the national pulse polio drive across the district on Tuesday to adminster the dose to those children who were left out in the earlier drive conducted across the city and district on January 19.

While the mop-up round in the rural areas will be held for three days, in the city limits, the vaccination round will be held for five days, said health officials.

The district health department said that the National Pulse Polio Campaign was held across the district with more than 10,000 health workers and officers working for the success of the campaign.

The aim was to administer polio dose to over 4.57 lakh children below the age of five years in the city as well as the district. To serve this purpose, 3,561 booths were set up all over the district.

Senior health officials said that they set the target of administering polio dose to 4,57,860 children and that the department achieved 95% of the said target.

Health workers said that they will visit every household to check if any child under the age of five has been left out in the pulse polio drive.

Officials said that the pulse polio campaign was implemented in the state since 1995.

Meanwhile, due to the huge success of the government in administering polio doses to children below five years of age, not a single case of polio was detected in the country after January 2011, following which India was declared as a polio-free nation in March 2014.

Title: MSC, Rupee banks submit joint merger plan to RBI
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

File Photo

PUNE: The Maharashtra State Cooperative ( MSC ) Bank and the Rupee Cooperative Bank have submitted a joint merger proposal to the RBI , giving hope to over half-a-million depositors of the Pune bank.

The proposal was submitted on January 17. Bankers said the RBI could take about six months to give its approval to the merger.

The proposal, if approved by the RBI, will grant relief to over half-a-million depositors of the Rupee Cooperative Bank whose deposits have been stuck since the bank was put under RBI directions in February 2013.

The two banks said the depositors would not lose any money due to the merger. “Those with less than Rs 1 lakh in deposits can withdraw the amount within the first year of merger in five tranches of 20% each time at a gap of two months between two withdrawals. And those with over Rs 1 lakh in deposits can withdraw their money over five years in slabs of 20%/year,” the MSC Bank said in a statement.

Vidhyadhar Anaskar, chairman, MSC Bank, told TOI that the RBI wanted the two banks to submit a joint proposal so that the process can move fast.

MSC Bank said it would give 6.5% interest or higher prevailing rates on the deposits kept with it after the merger. “This will be the best possible option for the depositors. A liquidation might have meant that those with more than Rs 1 lakh in deposits get only 35% of it,” Sudhir Pandit, chairman of the board of administrators, Rupee Cooperative Bank, said.

Title: Rajasthan: 83 per cent voter turnout reported in phase two
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Long queues of voters were seen across the day at many polling stations in Jaipur, which witnessed 86% turnout... Read More

JAIPUR: The state recorded a polling of 83% till end of the second phase of panchayati raj elections , on Wednesday. In Jaipur, polling stood at 86.27%, with Sanganer panchayat samiti recording 87.71% and Govindgarh registering 85.48% voter turnout till the end of voting. Hanumangarh registered highest polling with 91%. Long queues of voters were seen waiting outside polling stations even at 5 pm, the closing time.

In Alwar district's Ramgarh panchayat samiti, over 700 voters boycotted polling in Kareeriya village. A large number of voters gathered outside the Kareeriya Government Upper Primary School and shouted slogans against local MLA Safiya Khan and Congress leader Zuber Khan. The villagers alleged that the local MLA, in order to favour the people belonging to Muslim community, had used political links to add three Muslim-dominated villages to the newly created gram panchayat during the delimitation process. Due to this, people were not coming to vote out of fear, they said.

Miscreants set the bus of a polling party on fire outside a polling station in Udaipur's Rishabhdev.

Title: 52 Independents try their luck for New Delhi seat
Content:
Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal filed nomination papers from New Delhi assembly seat on Tuesday (File photo)

NEW DELHI: While an average of 21.8 nominations have been filed in Delhi's 70 constituencies , New Delhi seat from where CM Arvind Kejriwal is contesting saw 88 candidacy documents being filed.Kejriwal waited six hours to file his nomination papers on Tuesday as a large number of aspirants, particularly from economically disadvantaged backgrounds and fighting as independents, enlisted themselves as contestants. Most of the candidates in New Delhi have categorised themselves as private company employees, housewives, NGO workers and many even as unemployed people. Of the hopefuls, 14 are women and an overwhelming 52 will fight the February 8 poll as independents.Complete Coverage on Delhi ElectionsOn the day of scrutiny of the papers on Wednesday, three nominations had been rejected till late night. The process was still under way.Contestant Ajay Tiwari, 36, is a garments businessman from Gandhi Nagar in east Delhi. He is a member of the Right to Recall Party. “We want to create a system in which a voter passbook is maintained and any voter can recall his/her vote in the municipal, assembly or parliamentary elections,” Tiwari explained. “The power in such a system is vested in a voter, not the party.”Among the independents, Pradeep Kumar, a mechanic who makes mechanical grinders to process spices, revealed that he did not have a permanent home but moved from place to place to find work. “I live wherever I get an order to fabricate a grinder,” Kumar said, and to explain why he is a candidate, said, “We are tired of Kejriwal. Everyone has a right to fight elections and I am standing against him because I had hoped his nomination would be cancelled.”Some of the nominees could not be contacted on the number provided in their affidavits. AAP had alleged on Tuesday that the extraordinary queue to file papers was a BJP ruse to delay the chief minister’s submission.Also in the reckoning were the customary mavericks, among them Daya Shankar Agarwal, 70, who said he was a retired professor from Delhi University’s PGDAV College. Last year, he sought to fight Modi from Varanasi, but his papers were rejected. “I also filed my nomination to challenge Pranab Mukherjee and Ram Nath Kovind in the presidential elections,” Agarwal said.The septuagenarian added that he was not fighting against Arvind Kejriwal, but for Delhi. “I was there when AAP party was launched, but it has failed in its ideals. Everyone has a goal when they arrive on prithvi lok (earth), and my goal is to take on a failing AAP,” Agarwal declared.Overall, 1,029 people filed 1,528 sets of nomination papers in the 70 constituencies, of whom 278, or 27%, were women. At the last available count, 333 papers had been rejected during scrutiny, while three candidates had withdrawn. The lowest number of nominations are in Kasturba Nagar, Patel Nagar and Ambedkar Nagar, where 12 declarations were submitted.
