Title: State’s first public-pvt work in water sector begins in Nashik
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: First work of the water resources department under a public-private partnership has begun in Nashik with the augmentation of Godavari right bank canal, which will reduce water scarcity in various towns, including Shirdi.

The partnership aims at roping in non-profit organisations and individuals ready to spend on building infrastructure without eyeing any benefit. An NGO from Sinnar — Yuva Mitra with the help of Tata Trust — has come forward to start the work.

“The need to augment the carrying capacity of the canal was felt due to urbanization and increased agriculture activity. Under PPP model, the entire project of 110 km is expected to be done in less than Rs 4 crore, which could have otherwise cost the state exchequer at least Rs 30 crore,” Sagar Shinde, executive engineer, Nashik Irrigation Division, said.

Under the project, the government will spend on the fuel costs for the machinery and the operator will be deployed by the NGOs. The augmented canal will provide water to parts of Niphad, Sinnar talukas in Nashik district and Kopargaon, Rahata and Srirampur in Ahmednagar district.

The 110-km Godavari right bank canal was constructed by the British in 1911 at Nandurmadhmeshwar pick-up weir. Then, the capacity of the canal was 384 cubic feet per sec (cusec). It was augmented again in 1963 to 534 cusec. The current work will increase the capacity to 750 cusec. The increase is capacity will also cut down water losses in the transit.

The construction, widening and strengthening of aqueducts that were old and needed repairs was already carried out. Now, the earthen structure has to be augmented. This a major activity and would require the use of earth excavators.

Farmers from Rahata have collected funds for the development of the canal. “We collected Rs 11 lakh and will be giving it to the government,” said Uttam Nirmal, secretary of the farmers association, Rahata, who is former executive engineer of water resources department.

The 90-km long left bank – GLBC was constructed in 1916 to provide water to Vaijapur and other regions in Aurangabad district.

Title: Pune: Man held for marrying 16-year-old, five others in net
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

Title: Pune: Automobile company’s DGM duped of Rs 2.94 lakh in I-T refund fraud case
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

PUNE: A deputy general manager (54) of an automobile company was duped of Rs2.94 lakh after he clicked on the link of a text message, seeking his personal and bank details for processing income tax refund.

The Sinhagad Road resident on Tuesday lodged an FIR with the Dattawadi police, stating that the incident occurred in the early hours of September 9 last year, when he was sleeping. When he woke up and checked the text messages on his cellphone, he found that Rs3.92 lakh had been debited from his bank account through five transactions.

The complainant immediately alerted the bank and requested to block his account. Subsequently, Rs98,000 was credited to his account, said an officer from the Dattawadi police.

The complainant had immediately filed an application to the cyber police station. The probe revealed that the money was transferred to four bank accounts in Pune and Hyderbad. One of the four account holders was a woman. “The case was transferred to the Dattawadi police on Tuesday for further probe,” said an officer from the cyber police station.

The complainant stated in his complaint lodged with the Dattawadi police that since his company had given him a cellphone number for professional use, he had given his personal cellphone to his wife. “His personal cellphone number was connected to his PAN (Personal Account Number). So, his wife received messages from the income tax department,” he said.

On September 3 last year, the complainant’ wife received a text message under the message header QP-ITDEPL, requesting to fill up a form to get income tax refund. “Two days later, the complainants’ wife forwarded him the message to his ‘business’ number. Thinking that the message was important, the complainant clicked on the link and gave his personal information as well as account details,” the officer said.

Four days later, the complainant received five messages on September 9 last year from his bank that Rs3.92 lakh had been debited from his account between 2.30am and 3am. “When the complainant saw the messages, he immediately contacted the bank and blocked his account. It helped him save Rs98,000 as the bank refunded that amount. In all, the complainant lost Rs2.94 lakh to the online fraud,” the officer said.

Title: Pune civic chief to focus on ease of commute, adequate water supply
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Shekhar Gaikwad (right) is now the new PMC commissioner

PUNE: Traffic, transportation and water supply are priorities for the new municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaiwkad who took charge on Wednesday. He said he needed some time to come up with a concrete plan for the city.

Gaikwad, who replaced Saurabh Rao, said he wants to minimize the hardships citizens are facing every day while commuting in the city. He also plans to work for better water supply. The new civic chief is expected to table the draft budget for 2020-21 in the next few days.

“I am also planning to hold talks with a maximum number of institutes from the fields of education, business and other sectors to get a feedback on the issues the city is facing,” Gaikwad told reporters after he taking charge.

A 2002 batch IAS officer, Gaikwad was at the sugar commissionerate. He said he plans to address the issues of citizens. “I will try to resolve issues they face. Commuting has become a challenge. Many are spending two hours commuting to office and back home, every day. These issues need to be addressed,” Gaikwad said.

He said he would also look to explore new revenue sources for PMC . “Income can be increased even from smaller sources. I will hold talks with the elected representatives on how the civic body can explore new ways to get more income,” Gaikwad added.

He also addressed the civic staff at a function at the PMC building where he told them to ensure better services to citizens and avoid unnecessary delays to reduce the complaints.

Saurabh Rao, who will take over as sugar commissioner, said his tenure of 21 months at the PMC was a learning experience.

Title: BJP chief to address public meeting in Agra today in support of CAA
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Agra: Newly elected BJP chief JP Nadda will address a public meeting in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in Kothi Meena Bazar ground here on Thursday. Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath, deputy CM Keshav Prasad Maurya and state BJP president Swatantra Dev Singh will also be present.

BJP district president Giriraj Kushwaha told TOI that around 1 lakh people are likely to attend the meeting. He said, “People from 19 assemblies across five districts, including Agra, Mathura, Firozabad, Hathras and Etah will come out in support of CAA.”

He said that all arrangements have been made for welcoming the newly appointed party chief, CM and other party leaders in Agra. “We have invited people by distributing pamphlets among public and also released Tricolour balloons with the message of “We support Citizenship Amendment Act”. Large hoardings, inviting public to participate in the meeting, have also been put across the city,” he said.

This will be the first public address by Nadda after being elected as BJP’s national president. “The leaders will dispel the misinformation spread by political rivals on CAA,” said BJP office bearers in Agra.

This pro-CAA rally has been organised in Braj region, which is close to Firozabad, where half a dozen people were killed as protesters clashed with police on December 20 after Friday namaz.

Meanwhile, elaborate security arrangements have been made by the police in view of pro-CAA rally in the city. Five companies of PAC have been deployed along with additional force from neighbouring districts, said ADG Agra zone Ajay Anand.

Title: History of golden era of Hindi songs unfolds at ‘Geetyatra’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Litterateur Ambarish Mishra delivered Mukund Naniwadekar commemorative lecture ‘Geetyatra’, on Wednesday (Pic ... Read More

Nagpur: Many interesting anecdotes about the golden era of Hindi movies hidden in the pages of history, values yesteryear artistes held close to their heart and their magnanimity were beautifully chronicled by writer Ambarish Mishra at a programme held at Press Club, Civil Lines, on Wednesday.

Delivering a lecture ‘ Geetyatra ’, organized in memory of Mukund Naniwadekar, former secretary of Rajaram Library, Mishra traced the musical journey in his lucid style that contained songs and stories behind towering personalities of the film industry.

“Music director Madan Mohan once called Lata Mangeshkar to his place where lyricist Raja Mehdi Ali Khan and producer Raj Khosla were seated. She found on her arrival the room was filled with cigarette smoke. She noticed palpable tension as they were working on a composition which was difficult to come by. The nightingale then requested Madan Mohan to give her the lyrics.

“After some time, Mishra said, Lata sought permission of Madan Mohan whether she could give it a try. A few minutes later, Lata started muttering ‘Tu jahan jahan chalega’. Madan Mohan liked the tune so much that he retained it in the movie “Mera Saaya’. Lata did not claim the right on the composition she made. Such was the sense of belonging the legends had for each other,” Mishra said.

V Shantaram was one of the visionary filmmakers who thought ahead of time and made movies that promoted brotherhood, highlighted glaring discrepancies in society, and great music. After getting independence, the producers were keen to showcase aspirations of a young India instead of depicting a society that bled during the freedom struggle, Mishra said.

It was during this time composers like Naushad, C Ramchandra and Anil Biswas emerged. It was OP Nayyar who spotted talent of Asha Bhosle as a singer, Mishra said.

Very particular about time, Nayyar did not give even a single song to Mohd Rafi for three years as he got delayed for recording, he said.

Sharing lighter moments, Mishra said, producers Yash and BR Chopra pampered lyricist Sahir Ludhianvi to the extent that they even applied oil to his head and pressed legs.

Mishra played a few songs on his mobile in between the lecture and made the audience soak in the magic of music. With ‘Suhani raat dhal chuki’, he explained the mood of each song he played.

Filmmakers, lyricists and musicians of that era took Hindi cinema to greater heights with the mastery they had on the craftsmanship, Mishra said.

Songs like ‘Kuchh aankh mein aasu aate hai, seene main sulagte hain arman, ‘Shola jo bhadke’, ‘Dheere se aaja ri ankhiyan mein nindiya’ and ‘Sar jo tera chakraye’ were a package of good lyrics, music direction and singing, he said.

A short film on Naniwadekar’s life, made by Ajay Rajkarne, was screened.

Mrunalini Naniwadekar conducted the proceedings. Noted playwright Mahesh Elkunchwar, Shripad Joshi and Waman Telang were present.

Title: Four killed in cave-in at Gandhinagar building site
Content: Ahmedabad: Four men were killed after they were buried under loose earth when a cave-in occurred at a construction site at Kudasan village in Gandhinagar on Wednesday afternoon.The deceased include a junior engineer and three surveyors, who were sitting on a heap of soil when it caved.The deceased were identified as the junior engineer Parth Haresh Patel, 25, and Rajesh Chauhan, 25, both residents of Dehgam, Vasantji Thakor, 20, and Pravin Sondha, 27, residents of Mahemdavad in Kheda district.Inspector Sumit Rajput of Infocity police station said Patel and three others were surveying the land at the site in Kudasan where digging was under way.“They had surveyed the spot where work for a basement was underway and sat on some soft soil. Suddenly, a cave-in took place and they were buried under loose earth, as deep as 25 feet,” said Rajput.Rajput said the preliminary inquiry did not suggest any negligence by the construction site owner, where a mall us being built. “At present, we have filed a case of accidental death and began an investigation. Further legal action will be taken after thorough investigation in the case,” said Rajput.Another policeman said the site owner used a JCB to dig out the men. “The four men were rushed to a nearby private hospital and were later declared dead by doctors at the Gandhinagar Civil Hospital. Postmortems were conducted later,” said a cop.Sources in the police said that Patel was a permanent employee of the construction site owner, whereas three others were called occasionally for surveying.

Title: Rajasthan HC notice over encroachment in Luni river
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

JODHPUR: The Rajasthan High Court on Wednesday issued notices to the divisional commissioner (Jodhpur), district magistrate (Barmer) and other officials seeking a reply on encroachments in Luni river by the land mafia by January 27.

In a PIL, petitioner Sumer Gaur said the land mafia had encroached huge land parcels in Luni river and constructed houses on the plots.

“Not only this, they have also started sand mining in the river, which was detrimental for the water body,” the petition said, alleging that repeated complaints against rampant encroachment to revenue officials of Balotra, district magistrate of Barmer and the divisional commissioner of Jodhpur fell on deaf ears.

Arguing on the petition, advocate Vipul Singhvi said the land in river was a gair-mumkin land, which could not be used for any purpose and any activity of construction or mining was illegal. “But this has been continuing in Luni river since long. The petitioner had submitted representations to the administration and a list of encroachments had been prepared in pursuance of these representations but encroachments continued to thrive,” argued Singhvi. He said the inaction indicated that there was a direct or indirect support to the encroachers by the administration.

“Besides representations, the officials were given many applications and complaints in person, but all these endeavours of the petition failed to bring any results,” he said.

The petitioner also submitted facts and records in support of the petition after which the division bench of justice Sangeet Lodha and justice P S Bhati admitted the petition and issued the notices to the divisional commissioner (Jodhpur), district magistrate (Barmer), SDM (Balotra) and tahsildar and nayab-tahsildar seeking a reply by January 27.

Title: Rajasthan: Ghoonghat practice can’t be abolished soon, will take time
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Many believe that only education can help eradicate the regressive practice which has been around for centuri... Read More

JAIPUR: Recently, chief minister Ashok Gehlot had appealed to women to refrain from wearing ‘ghoonghat’. However, a large number of women turned up at polling stations with ‘ghoonghat’ for the second phase of panchayat elections on Wednesday.

While some believed that this was a “traditional practice” and they would continue to wear it, few others felt that “the practice should go and will be eradicated over a period of time and not overnight.” However, they also said that this was an age-old practice and was adopted to show respect to the elders in the family and was not a "regressive practice". “More the women get educated, more would desist from wearing ghoonghat.

“Wearing ‘ghoonghat’ is a 'traditional practice' and it is a way of showing respect to the elders in the family. The women who have been wearing since ages, will not give up ghoonghhat. For them, it would be violation of the age-old tradition. By giving it up, they don't want to disregard the elders in the family. But, the girls of our generation will never wear a ghoonghat," said Sumitra Kumari, who is pursuing masters from R L Saharia government college.

Meanwhile, at a polling station in Sargoth panchayat, Govindgarh, among the women clad in ghoonghat in one of the long queues waiting for her turn was Mohri Devi, who believed that the practice can't be eradicated overnight. “It will happen gradually. Women are shy to remove it. But, eventually the practice of wearing ghoonghat will be abolished from the society and it should get eliminated,” she said.

However, a middle-aged woman, Kesar Devi, believed that the practice won't get eradicated. "I will not remove my ghoonghat. This is an age-old tradition," she said.

Following chief minister Ashok Gehlot’s call to eradicate the practice of ‘ghoonghat’, Jaipur district administration had kicked off its ‘Ghoonghat Mukt Jaipur’ campaign in the city.

“It is a good initiative taken by the government. Awareness should be created among women through this drive. It will take time to completely abolish the practice. Can't happen overnight. But, at the same time, this is not a regressive or a bad practice. This has been going on since ages as a part of age-old tradition in our society," said Rekha Bohra and Meenakshi Nandwana, who had come to vote at a polling station in Muhana gram panchayat , Sanganer.

Title: Telangana HC to NIT: Harbour no ego, solve student suspension issue by January 24
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Stating that authorities should not hold grudges and ego hassles when people try to avail statutory remedies provided by the system, the Telangana high court on Wednesday directed authorities of National Institute of Technology ( NIT ) to ensure that the University’s academic senate committee decides on the appeal filed by a suspended B Tech first year student on January 24 and convey the decision to HC by January 27.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy gave this direction while hearing the plea of the parents of the student who was suspended by NIT authorities. The student was among 34 students facing disciplinary action for resorting to unlawful activities such as Ganja consumption, ragging etc.

T Mahender Rao , the NIT counsel, handed over a letter written by authorities to the bench,which stated that they respect the high court, but expressed reservations about the student’s decision to approach the court when the appeal filed by him is to be decided by senate committee.

The NIT counsel insisted that the decision making process be left to institute’s discretion. “ Majority of the 34 students who are facing the disciplinary proceedings from rich families. Some of them were using drugs too”, the NIT counsel said.

Appearing for the petitioner, senior counsel D V Sitarama Murthy said that authorities must keep in mind the students’ future before subjecting them to such harsh punishments.

The bench also observed that the tone and tenor of the letter written by NIT authorities reflects an ego hassle.

“The institute has already spoken its mind and it appears that even senate may not be of much help”, the bench said before posting the case to January 27.

Title: Alas, ex-HC judge also involved in the crime with police: Gujarat high court
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court has, for the first time, stated that its former judge, R R Jain, was involved in the crime along with police officers including ex-IPS officer Sanjiv Bhatt in the alleged drug planting case in Palanpur .

In his order dismissing Bhatt’s request to cancel the order and thereby the investigation and the case itself, Justice Pardiwala said, “The facts of this case need not be repeated. The more they are recalled, it is more painful. Unfortunately, the police officers are involved in this crime along with a former judge of this High Court.”

In this case, the HC had in 2018 ordered an SIT probe into the 1996 drug planting case in which an ‘A’ summary was filed by police by exonerating Rajasthan-based lawyer, Sumersingh Rajpurohit. The investigation as well as a complaint filed by Rajpurohit in Rajasthan had revealed that Bhatt and his subordinate officers had allegedly planted opium at Hotel Lilawati in Palanpur to frame the lawyer, in order to get him to vacate a shop in Pali town. The shop belonged to the sister of former Gujarat HC judge R R Jain, who had allegedly requested Bhatt to resolve the issue of the possession of the shop.

The HC said that the request to recall the order was one more attempt by Bhatt to create unnecessary hindrances and obstructions in the conduct of the trial proceedings of the NDPS case in Palanpur court, which has already framed charges. “I have no hesitation in observing that the filing of applications of the present type is nothing but last ditch efforts on the part of the applicant to see that the trial does not proceed further. Such attempts needs to be condemned in strong words,” the court said.

The court finally warned Bhatt saying that it would take “stern action” against him, if he continues to resort to delaying tactics.

Title: Fog and cold wave: Schools to remain closed today
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: The district administration on Wednesday ordered schools up to Class XII to remain shut on Thursday, after dense fog and cold wave conditions were reported in the district. The order, issued by additional district magistrate (ADM) Prabhakant Awasthi, said strict action will be taken against school authorities found violating the order.

On Wednesday, both maximum and minimum temperatures remained below the normal, with maximum temperature at 19.1°C, 4°C below normal and minimum at 6.7°C, 1°C below normal. Due to fog, over a dozen trains, including Gatiman Express and Shatabdi Express, ran behind schedule.

Besides Agra, the cold wave swept across Firozabad, Mathura, Etah, Aligarh and Mainpuri. In Aligarh, the maximum temperature was 17.8°C, 3°C below normal, while the minimum remained at 7.2°C.

According to the Meteorological department, the Agra region is likely to witness moderate fog with cloudy skies till January 24. There may be mild sunshine in the afternoons.

Meanwhile, Wednesday’s air quality index (AQI) in Agra was recorded in the “poor” category, at 287. According to Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), PM2.5 remained the prominent pollutant. AQI in poor category can cause respiratory illnesses on prolonged exposure.

Title: OU & UK univ to study bat species
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Hyderabad: Researchers from Osmania University and University of Bristol, United Kingdom, visited the Hanumanahalli Conservation Reserve to understand ecological studies required to initiate long-term scientific actions to conserve Kolar leaf-nosed bat .

The Kolar bat is one of the rarest bat species of India and is currently spotted only in Mulbagal taluk of Kolar district in Karnataka.

“The district administration should take steps to curb stone quarrying activities in areas near the roost,” said Chelmala Srinivasulu, a bat biologist from OU who is leading the research. The Kolar bat was rediscovered in 2012 by OU researchers. TNN

Title: Agra: District administration to launch campaign against ‘jugaad’ vehicles
Content: AGRA: The district administration, taking cognizance of a TOI report which appeared on Wednesday, has decided to launch campaign against the unauthorised ‘jugaad’ vehicles operating in the city. The transport department and traffic police will have to ensure that the pollution causing jugaad vehicles do not operate in the eco-sensitive Taj Trapezium Zone. In Agra, additional district magistrate (city) will monitor the campaign.Deputy transport commissioner (Agra Zone) JS Kushwaha stated that orders will be issued to all the regional transport officers to ensure jugaad vehicles do not operate. In this regard, action taken will be monitored on a monthly basis.The term jugaad refers to an innovative fix or a simple work-around, a quick solution that bends rules or resource that can be used in such a way. There are at least 10,000 jugaad vehicles operating in the city, according to estimate.Jugaad vehicles are basically old, modified two-wheelers, tempos or rickshaws fitted with motor engine. These are extensively used for ferrying goods. Besides being a threat to road safety, the jugaad vehicles are causing pollution in the eco-sensitive Taj Trapezium Zone (TTZ).Talking to TOI on Wednesday, additional district magistrate (city) Prabhakant Awasthi said, “Jugaad vehicles are illegal and will not be allowed to operate. Soon, a campaign will be launched to seize all these vehicles. Manufacturers of such vehicles will also be identified. Strict action will be taken against them.”Regional transport officer (administration) Ashok Kumar Singh said, “It is illegal to modify old vehicles and use them for loading purposes as jugaad. All such vehicles will be seized and dismantled. Besides, action will be taken against the owners of these vehicles.”While the jugaad vehicles may be cost effective for users, they are not good for road use. They cause accidents and are known to have poor brake mechanism.Since jugaad do not conform to specifications of a motor vehicle, they are not covered under the Motor Vehicles Act. Therefore, RTOs do not have any record of the actual number of jugaad on the roads. These vehicles, hence, do not have any vehicles registration plate. As a result, owners do not pay any road tax.Also, they do not have to undergo any pollution test and follow anti-pollution norms, mandatory for vehicles. That is why it is essential to ban them from plying in the Taj Trapezium Zone to protect over 40 monuments, including Taj Mahal, Agra Fort and Fatehpur Sikri.According to sources, an old scooter can be turned into a jugaad by spending as little as Rs 10,000. A jugaad auto-rickshaw can be developed for Rs 20,000. With minimum requirement of maintenance, jugaad vehicles can easily operate for three to five years.

Title: Man held for celebratory firing in Dholpur district
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

ALWAR: Dholpur police arrested a man whose video of indulging in celebratory firing following the panchayat election went viral on social media.

In the video, the accused could be seen dancing on top of a vehicle and firing in air with a country-made weapon.

The accused was identified as Atar Singh who was dancing and firing in air after the result of Chauhanpura gram panchayat election were declared which went to polls in the first phase on January 17.

Dholpur SP Mridul Kachawa said “We have arrested the accused under the Arms Act for firing in air and further investigation is underway.”

For this gram panchayat, seven candidates were contesting the election out of which 27-year-old Gajna Devi was declared the winner after she garnered 732 votes out of 2,291. The video which showed Singh firing following the result also showed a woman dancing alongside him while another man showered her with rupee notes.

Title: One dead, many injured in four accidents due to dense fog
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Agra: One person died and several others were injured in four road accidents on Agra-Lucknow expressway, Yamuna expressway and National Highway-2 (NH-2). Police said, on Wednesday, the main cause of the accidents was dense fog.

The first accident occurred late on Tuesday near Mainpuri-Firozabad border under Karhal police jurisdiction, when a van suffered head-on collision with another car near expressway service lane. Victim was identified as Vijay Kumar (50) of Khodai Ajnaura villager under Nagla Khangar police jurisdiction of Firozabad. Deceased Kumar was returning home after attending a relative’s funeral in Mithepur area of Karhal.

Police stated, “While on the way back to Firozabad, Kumar was about to reach the expressway through the service road when a car hit his van head-on in dense fog. Kumar died while being taken to hospital.”

The second accident occurred on milestone 78 of Sirsaganj police jurisdiction of Firozabad on Agra-Lucknow expressway around 5:30 am, when a pick-up truck ferrying several quintal of fish from Rajasthan’s Tonk Bisalpur Dam to Bihar’s Majhepur turned turtle on Agra-Lucknow expressway after hitting a parked truck. After the accident, the entire stretch was covered with fish and local villagers rushed to grab some for home. Fortunately, only three persons received minor injuries.

The third accident occurred near milestone 93 of Mannt police jurisdiction of Mathura district on Yamuna expressway, when three cars hit each other due to poor visibility around 9:30 am. In the accident, at least six persons of Delhi and Firozabad sustained minor injuries.

Also, on National Highway-2 near Runkata area of Agra district, a fuel tanker and truck ferrying buffalo met with a road accident. Three persons sustained injuries in the accident, again caused due to dense fog.

Title: Spurned, lover attacks girl before killing self
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A 21-year-man attacked an 18-year-old girl with a knife before jumping in front of a train and killing himself at S Kota in Vizianagaram on Monday night.

The deceased has been identified as 21-year-old P Koteswara Rao. The girl who from Jami area in Vizianagaram district was staying at her uncle’s place at Vepada. Rao, also from Vepada, was stalking her for the last few months. Police sources say that Rao had approached the girl in a bid to initiate a romantic relationship with her. When the girl refused his proposal, Rao developed a grudge against her. On Monday night, Rao attacked the girl and attempted to slit her throat with a knife. However, the girl managed to flee with minor injuries to her neck and hands.

B Srinivasa Rao, inspector of S Kota police station said that after attacking the girl, Rao jumped in front of a passing goods train and killed himself. The injured girl has been admitted to a government hospital in S Kota and her condition is stable, he informed.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Manish Sisodia and Raghav Chadha sell development in campaigns
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Manish Sisodia

NEW DELHI: Stressing on the development plank, senior AAP functionaries campaigned for their party in different assembly segments on Wednesday. They appealed to the voters to keep in mind the work done by AAP government in the education and health sector, infrastructure in unauthorised colonies, free electricity and water scheme, etc, when they go to the polling stations on February 8.

Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia travelled to Karol Bagh and Rajendra Nagar on Wednesday. AAP has fielded its young face, Raghav Chadha , from Rajendra Nagar while sitting MLA Vishesh Ravi has been re-fielded from Karol Bagh. Sisodia said that voting for AAP candidates will help the government keep “the good work it has done going.”

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

AAP’s sole Lok Sabha MP Bhagwant Maan also canvassed for the party’s Mehrauli candidate, while the party’s Rajya Sabha member Sanjay Singh campaigned at Sangam Vihar, which has a sizable Poorvanchali population.

Meanwhile, several Congress workers quit the party and joined AAP on Wednesday. “The workers are of the opinion that the work done in the education, healthcare, transport, power and other sectors has transformed the system and lives of people,” AAP said in a statement.

“The schemes designed and delivered by Arvind Kejriwal have benefited people irrespective of religious caste, class and political affinity,” one of the new members said.

Title: NCDEX for relook on CTT
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: In the run-up to the forthcoming budget, the National Commodities and Derivatives Exchange (NCDEX) has demanded that banks should be mandated to extend farm credit only against e-negotiable warehouse receipts (e-NWR). There has to be a strong credit guarantee structure that would further enhance the banks’ confidence to boost farm lending.

The Commodity Transaction Tax (CTT) levied on processed commodities has increased the impact cost of market participants. The Indian commodity market has immense potential as many of these commodities can set Indian prices as a benchmark for the global market. Hence, the government should have a relook at CTT, said a NCDEX press release over budget expectations.

While SEBI has opened the gates for the commodity markets by allowing mutual fund, indices and options participation, the government should reframe its regulatory policies and start taking positions on the exchange platforms for procurements or sales, moots NCDEX for the budget.

It has also called for implementation of modified and stringent borrowing policy by RBI which could reduce NPAs. This would be possible if borrowers are obligated to decide minimum hedged positions and disclose their hedge positions, says NCDEX.

If these propositions are implemented in the right direction, we are hopeful that it will help commodity markets to grow in a vibrant ecosystem, inducing positive sentiments among our entire value chain and participants.

Title: WEF Davos: CM promotes MP as emerging economic force, warehousing hub
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Chief minister Kamal Nath

Bhopal: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Wednesday promoted Madhya Pradesh at World Economic Forum in Davos as an “emerging economic force” that has potential of becoming India’s warehousing hub .

The CM held one-on-one meetings with investors and addressed business sessions on the second day of the forum. “Madhya Pradesh is geographically located at the centre of India. It has the potential to emerge as a logistics hub in the near future. This will help the state become the warehousing hub of the country,” Nath said during discussions with investors, seeking their active participation in Madhya Pradesh’s growth plan.

Contrary to the slack mood in the country, MP is likely to gain overwhelming support from investors to survive adversities and mobilise economic growth, the CM said in Davos, tweeting: “We are moving towards a sustainable world with technology transformation.”

At the annual meeting of WEF, Nath discussed investment plans with globally renowned industrialists and investors in information technology, hospitality and tourism. Investors expressed full cooperation to the state’s economic endeavours.

Among the prominent investors who held discussions with the CM include Antonio Neri, president and CEO of Hewlett Packard Enterprise Division, Magesvaran Suranjan, president of Procter and Gamble Asia Pacific and Middle-East Africa, Abidali Neemuchwala, CEO and MD of Wipro, Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum, chairman and CEO of Emeritus Airlines, Dr Shamsheer Vayalil, president and MD of VPS Health Care Group and 2000 W Founder Andreas Bilkert.

The prospects of setting up data centres, hardware manufacturing units and developing an IT park were discussed with Antonio Neri. “Madhya Pradesh has the most favourable environment for investment in the IT sector as there is a large number of talented young IT professionals available in a peaceful state,” said Nath. Abidali Neemuchwala also discussed the possibilities of setting up IT service units and parks.

President of Inter-Continental Hotels Group (IHG), Patrick Cescau and CEO Keith Barr expressed their willingness to invest in the hospitality industry said sources. The two discussed a number of issues with the chief minister, primarily setting up world-class resorts in wildlife tourism sector and construction of heritage hotels at major tourist destinations.

On Tuesday evening, Nath had held one-to-one discussions with Pawan Goenka, MD of Mahindra and Mahindra Group. The two discussed possibilities of investment in automobile, agricultural equipment, irrigation and agro-chemical sectors in Madhya Pradesh. The CM also elaborated upon the operation of logistics hub and creation of IT delivery centre in Madhya Pradesh. Investments in manufacturing units for electric vehicles, passenger cars and commercial vehicles were also discussed during the meeting.

Title: Man kills wife in Fatehpur Sikri
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Agra: A man killed his wife in a remote village under Fatehpur Sikir police jurisdiction on Tuesday evening.

Identified as Satyapal (25), currently pursuing nursing assistant course, was charged under IPC section 302 (murder). After the murder, the accused went absconding.

According to police, Satyapal was living with his wife Suman (23) in Nagla Sarai village. “At around 4:30 pm on Tuesday, the accused hit his wife on her head with an axe which killed her on the spot. Reason behind the murder is yet to be known. Our team is searching for the accused,” station house officer Bhupinder Singh Baliyan said.

Police claimed that the couple was married during teenage. Six months back, Suman moved in with Satyapal. Deceased was native of Nagla Khatka village of Bharatpur district in Rajasthan.

Title: Saranya Sasi was a topper and role model
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Saranya Sasi

KOCHI: “I will be joining the eight of you for the Thiruvananthapuram trip tomorrow,” said Saranya Sasi ’s teacher at Amrita School of Pharmacy in Kochi on Wednesday afternoon while discussing the plan to visit Saranya’s funeral during their class. “Madam, there are only seven of us now,” said a friend, unable to hold back his tears. Saranya’s friends and teachers, who are in a state of shock, are yet to accept the fact that she is dead.

For classmates and some faculty members, Saranya was their ‘chechi’ as she was pursuing her second-year in MPharm course, nine years after completing her BPharm from Thiruvananthapuram Government Medical College in 2009. She was the eldest one in her class and some of the faculty members were her juniors during their college days.

For her teachers, she was one of the most hardworking and determined students they had trained. Despite being out of touch with pharmacy science for nine years after her marriage, the 33-year-old mother of three became the topper in the first year of the course for which she won a gold medal.

“Usually, most people would hesitate to pursue postgraduation in pharmacy science after such a long gap, but Saranya was determined to fulfill her dream. She was my junior in college and one of the most-active students I knew. She was an allrounder with good leadership and presentation skills. Last week, she received much praise from us after her third-semester mid-thesis presentation. We are yet to accept that she left us, just like that...,” said Dr Aneesh TP, a faculty at Amrita.

Saranya had applied for a week’s leave in advance for the Nepal trip. “After that she told us her husband had come home (from abroad) and the family was planning to visit Nepal. I granted her the leave and she was supposed to join us on Friday. Besides being a brilliant student, she was a mentor and elder sister for her classmates. Being the only day-scholar, she used to bring homely food for them. Students are still in a state of shock,” said Sreeja C Nair, Saranya’s project guide.

“I was her junior during the BPharm course and chechi was a mentor for us since college days. Though I was her faculty at Amrita, she was still the same old sister. She was a role-model for all those women who dream of pursuing higher studies after marriage,” said Prashant Sadanandan, another MPharm faculty at Amrita.

Faculty members and students will visit her home once the bodies are brough to Thiruvananthapuram. The teachers of Saraswati Vidayaniketan School, where Saranya’s three children studied, will also pay homage. The school observed a holiday on Wednesday.

Title: Jaisalmer: Military intelligence detains man for ‘Pakistan links’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

JAISALMER: Military intelligence agency on Tuesday night detained a contractual worker at Jaisalmer military station on the suspicion of having links with Pakistan. He was handed over to police on Wednesday.

Prima facie, there is information that he was associated with many Pak and Indian groups through his mobile phone, which had many Pak contacts. Apart from this, there is information about him downloading many videos of Pak women on his phone.

Currently, he is being inquired. However, no evidence of him sending any secret or confidential intel across the border has come to light yet, said sources.

According to sources, Dashrath, 35, has been working at the military station for many years. He was also part of the team worked for the Army Scout Master Competition last year.

Recently, it came to light that he is connected to a few Pak numbers and groups through his mobile, which he has confessed. Military intelligence personnel detained him late on Tuesday night. He was brought to JIC on Wednesday where he is being questioned.

SP Kiran Kung said many WhatsApp groups on his phone were being managed from Pakistan.

Title: Agra parking fee row: Over 1,100 traders end loyalty towards BJP
Content: AGRA: Over 1,100 traders of Sanjay Place market signed on a declaration to end their loyalty towards the BJP. Majority of the traders kept their shops shut till afternoon on Wednesday. They gathered at the dharna spot in the parking area to join the protest.Later, they took out a rally across the market raising slogans against the Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration and mayor Naveen Jain. They also burnt an effigy of ‘corruption’ in the AMC.Trader’s indefinite strike completed nine days on Wednesday. Traders have been protesting against the AMC administration for charging parking fee at 44 places in the market since January 14.President of Sanjay Place market association KN Agnihotri said, “Businessmen have been supporting the BJP in every possible manner. It is very unfortunate that despite having the BJP government in the Centre and in the state, we are being exploited. None of the nine BJP MLAs and two MPs of Agra district has come forward to address our issues. We feel cheated. Around 1,123 businessmen of Sanjay Place have signed a declaration to end loyalty with the BJP. In this regard, a letter has been sent to the top leadership of the party.”Secretary of the Sanjay Place Market Association Hiren Agarwal said, “We have received support from over two dozen organizations and all the major opposition parties. However, no BJP leader has come forward to support us. We find it illogical to continue our loyalties with the party. We are not going to tolerate the AMC administration’s dictatorship at any cost. Parking mafia will not be allowed to operate in Sanjay Place.”Association’s treasurer Vinay Mittal alleged, “Despite the ongoing case at the sessions court, the AMC administration issued parking contracts for three years to people associated with the BJP. AMC officials also get a share of the parking fee illegally collected from the market. We will not withdraw our protest till the AMC rolls back its decision.”BJP city president Bhanu Mahajan said, “I am busy with arrangements for the public meeting of our national president JP Nadda in the city on Thursday. I am not aware of the issues of traders. I would not like to comment in this regard.”

Title: Stand-off between AMU VC, medicine students continues
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Agra: Students of medicine in Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Wednesday gave some anxious moments to their vice chancellor Tariq Mansoor when they confronted him over his decision to invite police inside the campus, “which called them Pakistani and Bangladeshi”.

The VC went to the students to convince them to call off their stir. The students are demanding resignations of the VC and of the registrar for inviting police into the campus. One of the medical students questioned the vice chancellor as to why they should accept his leadership when police can enter the campus and call them “Pakistani” and “Bangladeshi”.

The agitated students also shouted slogans against the vice chancellor. They also expressed their anger against the newly-appointed director of social welfare (DSW), Prof Mujahid Beg.

When students pointed the alleged police crackdown in which several hostel inmates were injured and one of them lost his hand, Beg allegedly told them to be thankful to the God that “no loss of life was reported in the campus.”

One of the medical students from faculty of medicine, Adnan, told that the vice chancellor wanted to interact with them. But DSW interrupted several times and “indirectly threatened them”.

“We were not expecting such language from DSW,” he said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Techie clicks link, loses Rs 2 lakh
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: An employee of an IT company in Gandhinagar on Tuesday filed a complaint of cheating with Infocity police, stating that she lost Rs 2 lakh to cyber cheats after she clicked on a link sent to her from an unknown number.Priyanka Verma, 26, who lives in the Infocity area and is from Khandwa in Madhya Pradesh, stated in her FIR that she had on January 16 received a call from unknown number. “The caller asked her if she had got any coupons from an online payments application, Google Pay. She told the caller that she had received coupons and ended the call,” states the FIR.After a while, she received a text message containing three hyperlinks, which she clicked on. “At around 12.06am on January 19, she learned that Rs 75,000 had been debited from her bank account,” the FIR.Verma then blocked her debit card to prevent further transactions, but money kept getting debited from her account. In two other transactions on January 20, she lost Rs 24,000 and Rs 1 lakh,” the FIR states.She then approached Infocity police and filed a complaint for breach of trust and cheating along with charges under the Information Technology Act.Infocity police began their investigation but have not identified the perpetrators.

Title: Bhopal’s e-waste collection goes the hi-tech way
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Interiors of the e-waste information and collection vehicle

Bhopal: Electronic waste collection and disposal is set to get makeover, with introduction of e-waste information and collection vehicle by the Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC). The vehicle is expected to be taken up as a model project by central pollution control board.

“Currently, electronic waste is being dumped in unscientific manner. Besides sensitising people over proper disposal of e-waste, the collected waste would be sent to Alwar in Rajasthan for scientific disposal,” said MP state level waste management committee, member, Imtiyaz Ali.

E-waste is often mixed with local garbage like other solid/semi-solid waste. “Only 1.5% of e-waste generated in India gets recycled. Consider the number of mobile phone and other tech, the need for proper disposal of e-waste is an urgent need. We expect to recycle or scientifically dispose in Bhopal e-waste,” said Ali. The civic body is aiming to make the city the first state capital to attain 100% scientific disposal of e-waste. Bhopal produces upwards of 250MT of e-waste each year. It includes extremely toxic and harmful materials such as lead, cadmium and brominated flame retardants.

Last year, BMC stepped up its campaign for improving cleanliness and hygiene in the state capital.

“It is important to separate e-waste from daily domestic waste. There are serious health and environmental impacts in case of improper disposal of e-waste,” said BMC additional commissioner Rajesh Rathore. E-waste or electronic waste comprises old electronic goods, CDs, durables, computers, mobile phones and other items that contain non-biodegradable materials and can release toxic elements into the environment, if not disposed of properly.

Title: Express your political views outside campus: IIT-B director
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

IIT-Bombay, director Subhasis Chaudhuri (File Photo)

MUMBAI: In an open house organised by the student body at IIT-Bombay , director Subhasis Chaudhuri said the institute must be free of any kind of political endorsement and students could express their “individual” views on political issues outside the campus. These opinions should be made in their individual capacity and not be attributed to the institute.

The open house was organised by students’ representatives on the campus to discuss issues related to the students. While responding to a question on the ongoing protests on the campus, the director is said to have told the students that the institute was funded by the Government of India and was an institute of eminence and its primary mandate was to produce high-quality manpower and do research that benefitted people at large.

The director also said just as a section of students had a right to express their opinion, others also had the right to not get disturbed.

During the session, Chaudhuri is said to have reiterated that the institute was strictly apolitical and that it did not endorse any views on politics. He added it needed to be completely free of any kind of political endorsement. “While expressing your views, you cannot say that it is from IIT-Bombay or you are representing IIT-Bombay. No one can say that IIT-Bombay is for or against any political views,” said a student, quoting the director.

TOI tried to contact the director, but he remained unavailable for comment.

Chaudhuri said the students were free to assert their opinion outside the campus or even write about it, adding that “at the end of the day, the pen is mightier than the sword”.

On Tuesday, the students of IIT-Bombay received a mail from the general secretary of the students’ council, which said, “In light of the various activities that have been happening in the institute recently, the general secretaries have requested the director to be part of an open house meeting on Wednesday.”

Sources said Chaudhuri reminded the students that the classrooms, the hostels and everything on the campus was funded by the Government of India and it was the taxpayers’ money. He told them it was the students’ responsibility to maintain the reputation of the institute, which was one of the best in the country. He then added there could be difference of opinion on the campus and students should understand each other’s viewpoints.
