Title: Can’t convert playgrounds to gardens: HC
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Nagpur: Ruling that playgrounds cannot be converted into gardens, the district court has stayed Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) plan to develop a garden in one of the open spaces in Kukde Layout in South Nagpur. The move is likely to save playgrounds across the city.

Hearing a petition filed by Ajay Chaudhary, a resident of Kukde Layout, joint civil judge PP Naigaonkar passed an order on March 8, 2019, saying, “The Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court in PIL No. 40/2013 by order dated September 12, 2017 has specifically stated that playgrounds are not to be allotted to any private or public institution(s). Playgrounds should be meant only for children, without any kind of hindrance or obstacle.

According to the orders mentioned in the PIL, defendant No. 2 (civic chief) and defendant No. 3 (garden superintendent) cannot convert land meant for playgrounds.

The plaintiff prime facie established the fact that the defendants are acting contrary to the rules and have undertaken the work of converting a playground into a garden.

Defendants No. 2 and 3 or anybody else have been restrained through a temporary injunction from carrying out any work which leads to conversion of a playground into a garden or any other work till the final disposal of the suit, said the order .

As per the details in the petition as well as the order, the NMC’s garden department had proposed to develop a garden and a green gym on the open space (No. 392) in Kukde Layout. The civic body had sanctioned Rs29.77 lakh and even issued a work order to a private contractor for execution of the project in March 2018.

When the NMC’s engineers and contractor arrived at the site to begin work on the project, local residents, including Chaudhary, opposed the move and lodged a complaint with the civic body. Later, Chaudhary filed a petition in the district court, pleading conservation of playgrounds for sports activities.

The district court’s order has come as a shot in the arm for those in favour of playgrounds. Naresh Pandey, a resident of the same layout, lodged a complaint with the NMC. Citing the court order, Pandey demanded that work on the garden, walking track and the green gym on open space No. 225 which is on the adjacent playground should be not begin.

“It’s a contempt of the court order by the NMC. It could not convert playground No. 392 into a garden. It also failed to install a green gym due to the court’s order. Therefore, NMC started work on playground No. 225. After we opposed the move, the NMC assured us that the playground would not be converted into a garden. Despite the assurances, the NMC went ahead and installed a green gym and started the construction of the walking track on the playground. NMC norms say that construction on only 15% of playground is permissible and that too related to sports only. Over here, construction has crossed the 15% mark,” Pandey said.

He added that NMC engineers threatened to cut trees on the playground for construction activities. “Many pipes (big in size) were also dumped on the playground. Children can no longer play and neither can senior citizens take their walks,” he said.

Engineers from the NMC’s garden department told TOI that the plan to develop the garden has been dropped. “The green gym and the walking track are meant for fitness and activities related to sports. The pipes will be removed soon. We also dropped the plan to lay a storm water drain along the walking track in the playground,” they said.

One of the biggest layouts of South Nagpur, Kukde Layout is running out of playgrounds. The Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) had developed a garden on the sprawling playground of the layout. The remaining playgrounds have green gyms and religious structures. In one playground, two library buildings have been constructed adjacently.

For decades, the NMC has been converting playgrounds into gardens. It has even permitted construction of religious structures and community halls. In Dhantoli, the NMC and the NIT are using land reserved for playgrounds for parking of city buses, slums and commercial shops. It has started the process to convert the city’s biggest playground into a commercial zone.

NMC PLAYS SPOILSPORT

* NIT sanctioned Kukde layout as part of West Babulkheda Precinct in February 1946

* Sprawling open spaces were reserved for railway police station, home for beggars, a primary school and a hospital

*An open space converted into a playground

* NMC and NIT permitted religious structures, library buildings in three open spaces. One of them has two library buildings attached to each other

* Green gyms installed on the school premises, garden and three open spaces

* Two open spaces were vacant and used as playgrounds

* NMC sanctioned funds for converting one playground into a garden, installing a green gym and constructing a walking track with storm water drain

* One of the residents filed a petition in the district court pleading conservation of playground for sport activities

* The court observed that the playground cannot be converted into a garden and imposed a stay

* NMC shifted the work to the adjacent playground where too it faced opposition

* NMC dropped the garden plan but installed a green gym and constructed a walking track

* NMC also laid pipelines in the playground but did nothing to redevelop the surface layer

Title: Gujarat: Another Goswami gang member arrested
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: City crime branch on Wednesday arrested another member of the Vishal Goswami gang, for an alleged extortion racket run from Sabarmati Central Jail .

The accused was identified as Alok Verma, who allegedly provided weapons to the Goswami gang and was involved in a robbery at Ognaj, said a crime branch official.City crime branch had on January 15 booked seven persons including Vishal Goswami under the new anti-terrorism law, The Gujarat Control Of Terrorism and Organised Crime (GujCTOC) Act, for allegedly running an extortion racket. This was the first recorded use of GujCTOC, since the it was passed in 2015 and brought into effect from December 1, 2019.

Title: Long, chilly winter hots up room heater mkt
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Kolkata: The prolonged and chilly winter has hot up some segments of brown goods sector in the country, especially in the east. The room heater business has witnessed the biggest surge in demand in the last 10 years or so in West Bengal and eastern region while there has been a multi-fold growth across India. Once an unorganised market, the room heater business in India is now ruled by four major organised players — Bajaj Electricals, Orient Electric, Havells India and Usha.

An official of Bajaj Electricals said that in most of the states, the company is experiencing a heavy demand. “There is no stock in most of the eastern states because nobody has anticipated so huge demand,” he added.

According to him, there has been more than 100% growth nationally in the segment. North and east India taken together comprise 80% of the room heater market.

Salil Kappoor, business head (home appliances), Orient Electric, pointed out that there has been a 150% growth in oil-based room heater in India. “In December, there has been a 70% growth in West Bengal, which this year has become a major market. Now there is supply bottleneck in most of the markets,” he added.

According to him, the size of the room heater market in India is Rs 400 crore, while in West Bengal it is worth Rs 30 crore.

Havells has seen growth from not just consumers, but several corporate sectors as well. Rajiv Kenue, senior vice president, Havells India, said, “We are one of the top players in oil-filled radiator and room heaters in India. With sharp a dip in temperature and intense cold waves spreading through North India, we have seen a surge in consumer demand compared to the last year. Delhi-NCR is one of the top-three regions driving demand for oil-filled radiators and room heaters. Most of our stocks of heaters and OFR in retail stores and Havells outlets are on the verge of being sold out. Consumer sentiments have picked up with regard to these purchases.”

Pulkit Baid, director of Great Eastern Retail, one of the leading electronics retailers in east, pointed out that there has been an unprecedented demand for room heaters this year. “What we sell in four months, this year we sold in one month only. This is a record in 15 years,” he added. Baid also admitted that most of the retailers are running out of stock.

Title: Harvey Weinstein rape trial begins in earnest, 2 years after #MeToo wave
Content: Harvey Weinstein's rape and sexual assault trial began in earnest in New York on Wednesday, with the defence expected to detail "loving" emails between the once-mighty movie producer and his accusers. A frail-looking Weinstein, 67, walked slowly into the court premises, but without the walking frame he has used for recent proceedings.He faces life in prison if convicted of predatory sexual assault charges related to two women in a case seen as key to the #MeToo movement.In opening arguments, prosecutors will argue that the former Miramax Films boss was a sexual predator who made a career out of abusing women trying to make their way in Hollywood Weinstein's attorneys will try to convince the court that his two accusers engaged in consensual relationships with the defendant and only later claimed the incidents were forced.Lawyer Damon Cheronis said Tuesday the defense had "dozens" of emails sent by the women to Weinstein which undermine claims of non-consensual sex.Justice James Burke ruled that the defense team could cite these emails in its opening arguments, dealing a blow to the prosecution which had objected to their inclusion."What we will counter with are their own words, their own words where they described loving relationships," Cheronis told the court, US media reported.On Wednesday, about 100 reporters waited in line from dawn to secure a prized seat in the Manhattan Criminal Court.Weinstein is accused of forcibly performing oral sex on former production assistant Mimi Haleyi in his New York apartment in July 2006.An unidentified woman says Weinstein raped her in a New York hotel room in March 2013.The prosecution will call four other accusers to the stand as it tries to convince the 12-member jury that Weinstein engaged in a pattern of predatory sexual behaviour.Supporting witnesses will include actress Annabella Sciorra , who says Weinstein raped her in the winter of 1993-94.The identity of three other alleged victims, including one who says she was raped by Weinstein in California in 2013, are unknown.High-profile women's rights attorney Gloria Allred , who represents two women involved in the trial, has said the accusers must prepare for a "brutal cross-examination."Manhattan Assistant District Attorney Joan Illuzzi-Orbon is leading the prosecution, while Chicago lawyer Donna Rotunno, who has defended numerous men accused of sexual assault, leads the defense.More than 80 women have accused Weinstein of sexual misconduct since claims against him ignited the #MeToo movement in October 2017.But many of the alleged crimes fall outside the timeframe for bringing charges.Seven men and five women make up the jury in the trial which is expected to run until March 6.The defense was successful in keeping young white women, viewed as sympathetic to the #MeToo movement, off the jury, following an acrimonious two-week selection process.

Title: If not answered, NPR query will be considered dropped: Javadekar
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Union Information and Broadcasting minister Prakash Javadekar (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: Information and broadcasting minister Prakash Javadekar on Wednesday said questions pertaining to date and place of birth of parents in the National Population Register ( NPR ) could remain while furnishing such details — as made clear previously — will be optional.

Responding to questions at a briefing on Cabinet decisions on Wednesday, he said if a person doesn’t share details the questions will be “considered as dropped”. His remarks came a day after consumer affairs minister Ramvilas Paswan said that the query would be dropped from NPR.

Responding to a specific question, Javadekar said, “No no...It’s not like that. It will be considered as dropped if someone doesn’t remember the date and place of birth of his/her father and mother and can’t share.”

The questions on date and place of birth of parents had triggered fears that the exercise might be a precursor to the preparation of National Register of Citizens (NRC). Paswan told TOI on Wednesday, “There should be no need to show any document so far as the date of birth of the person or his/ her parents are concerned and I feel these won’t be required when information will be collected. Information provided by people must be trusted and you can check them by talking to their neighbours.”

Talking to reporters on Monday, Paswan had said even he didn’t know the date of birth of his parents. “Do I cease to become a citizen on that account? I had told the home ministry that these things will cause confusion,” he had said.

The minister also said the question on citizenship of a person born in India cannot be raised due to lack of such documentary evidence. “How can anyone’s citizenship be snatched on this ground? The government has reiterated this on several occasions,” Paswan said.

Title: Congress neta’s remark gives BJP ammo: ‘Call party Muslim League Congress’
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

BJP spokesperson Sambit Patra (ANI Photo)

NEW DELHI: Accusing Congress of playing politics of religion and Muslim appeasement , BJP on Wednesday said the opposition party should be renamed ‘Muslim League Congress’.

Addressing a press conference, BJP spokesperson Sambit Patra slammed Congress after Ashok Chavan said his party formed an alliance with Shiv Sena on the insistence of Muslims.

Patra said it was nothing but appeasement. “Two days ago, Ashok Chavan said ‘we formed the government in Maharashtra with Shiv Sena on the appeal of our Muslim brothers. Muslims were saying that BJP is their prime enemy’. This is an appeasing statement from the former CM,” Patra said.

“Does this mean Congress forms government asking Muslims and Muslims only? Do they not care about Hindus or other communities? Congress party should be renamed from Indian National Congress to MLC — Muslim League Congress. They only talk about Muslims and try to polarise them,” he added.

Patra claimed Congress did “Muslim appeasement” for votes but never did any good for the community.

He referred to comments of several opposition leaders, including those from NCP and AIMIM, to allege that they were “abusing” Hindus in the name of anti-CAA protests and sought an apology from Congress president Sonia Gandhi and NCP’s Sharad Pawar.

Asked about Congress functionary Mallikarjun Kharge’s jibe at RSS for its “non-participation” in the freedom movement, Patra asked if parents of Sonia Gandhi, who is of Italian origin, had fought in India’s independence struggle.

Highlighting a report in an Urdu daily, Patra said Rahul Gandhi had once described Congress as a “party of Muslims” and its functionaries had coined terms like “saffron terror”.

Patra claimed a video of Shaheen Bagh protests purportedly showed children talking about “murdering” the Prime Minister and the home minister and asked who had spread such “poison”. “It is a tragedy that poison against Hindus is being sowed in the country,” he said.

Title: Security at commercial complexes in twin cities under police scanner
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Hubballi: In the recent past, commercial complexes have mushroomed across Hubballi, and these establishments are collectively the most significant testament to the city’s growing tryst with progress. Now, in the wake of a crude bomb being found and subsequently defused in Mangaluru, the spotlight has turned on these complexes, but for an entirely different reason: Hubballi-Dharwad police are subjecting the security arrangement at these establishments under a lens.

The growth of Hubballi, coupled with its bright prospects, has drawn many investors to the city, with real estate developers showing a keen interest in initiating development projects. Many developers are eager to build commercial complexes in Hubballi-Dharwad, which together have 2,500 commercial complexes between them. However, the profusion of such establishments in the twin cities has cut out the work in front of the cops.

Hubballi-Dharwad police commissioner R Dileep was quick to point out that securing the safety of citizens was a continuous process. “But the incident in Mangaluru has necessitated the need to review security in crowded places in the twin cities. We will have to keep a close watch on anti-social elements,” Dileep told TOI.

The commissioner lamented the failure of many commercial establishments in the twin cities to comply with the guidelines laid down by law enforcement agencies. “In most complexes, there is no sign of a closed circuit television (CCTV) camera. This poses a huge problem when police initiate a probe. It also makes it difficult for us to monitor the movement of those people listed on our records as anti-social elements,” said Dileep.

He said that, owners of commercial establishments had been directed to install CCTV cameras in the building. “We had not set them a deadline, but we are trying to motivate them now to install these cameras at the earliest. We will be paying a visit to these establishments again to see if the owners have complied with the rules. If we find that they have still not installed CCTV cameras, we will be compelled to set a deadline,” the commissioner added.

Dileep admitted that police did not have in their possession knowledge about the exact number of commercial complexes in the twin cities. “We will seek these details from the Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation (HDMC). We will hold a meeting with HDMC officials to review security measures in the twin cities, which will be followed by another one with the owners of commercial complexes,” said Dileep.

A Hubballi-Dharwad police official rued the fact that a mere five to 10% of the commercial establishments in the twin cities had installed CCTV cameras on their premises. “In some cases, the cameras that the complexes have are defunct, while there is no facility to store old footage in some among other problems. Such being the case, all owners have been directed to install quality cameras on their premises,” said the cop.

Title: Initiative to equip rural schoolchildren with key skills meets with success
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Hubballi: Lack of adequate libraries and an equal lack of books in existing ones often stunt the growth of students , and in government schools, this rings truer. However, access to internet in many state-run institutions is looking to offset this limitation.

“Google is my best friend,” gushed Jyoti Bennur, a class VIII student at the Government Higher Primary School in Ballarwad village in Navalgund taluk. Jyoti has a tablet and is well-acquainted with all the apps on the device. “I get all the answers I need, and additional information along with it using the tablet,” said Jyoti in fluent English , who also shared her aptitude in the use of Email. The tablet helps her stay abreast of current affairs.

Jyoti is one of the many beneficiaries of an initiative, ‘Skill-in-Village’ undertaken by the Deshpande Foundation to enhance skills of schoolchildren in Dharwad, Haveri and Gadag districts. The programme envisages equipping students in rural areas with all the skills their urban counterparts are presently being trained in, in addition to which efforts are being made to turn them into effective, and more importantly, confident speakers.

Manager for the ‘Skill-in-Village’ project Harish MH said that improving communication skills of rural students was one of the primary objectives of the initiative. “Improving their English was the key to building their confidence. Our project also focuses on improving skills in computer and overall digital literacy. We have been working in 42 villages since the launch of the initiative in 2017. Some of the villages we have worked in are Karadigudda, Honnapur, Chabbi, Abbigeri and Bannikoppa. The initiative has yielded desired results with many students in these villages now seeming at ease in English, and very comfortable with operating tablets and computers,” said Harish.

The foundation has roped in 42 teachers, who are deployed to rural schools in the three districts, where they first conduct a survey, following which confer with the elders in the village and parents, before hitting the ground. “We roll out the initiative in those villages where we are guaranteed of maximum support from the local governing bodies such as the gram panchayat,” added Harish.

One of the teachers working in the villages is Laxmi Bhovivaddar, presently working with students of a government school in Ballarwad. “We focus on teaching the kids English grammar and other communication techniques. We train them in essential skills such as introducing themselves, deliberating on subjects among others. We also teach them how to use computers, using Google , etc,” she said.

Manjunath Baligar, another teacher working with the Deshpande Foundation on the project, said that the children were being taught other skills that help them in life before and after school. “We hold a workshop each month wherein students are called on to make a presentation to help us assess their skills. We also teach them lessons from their syllabus,” said Baligar.

Title: Inmates at Hindalga Central Prison tailor uniforms for schoolchildren, stitch new life for themselves
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Belagavi: Prison reforms, more often than not, aim not merely at improving conditions within the walls but also to markedly enhance their prospects for a life beyond, so as to complete the process of their transformation. In keeping with this vision, inmates of the Hindalga Central Prison in Belagavi are, besides equipping themselves with a useful skill that is bound to come handy in their life once out of prison, are performing a service for society while at it. For the past four years, inmates of Hindalga Central Prison have been stitching uniforms for schools.

Working at the garment factory within the premises of the prison, the inmates have been stitching, on average, 1,000 clothes for students. What started off as an exercise to equip the inmates with vocational skills turned into an endeavour that could be utilised for the benefit of others as well. Over the years, the prison authorities have purchased more advanced tailoring machines, and have roped in the department of textiles for their project. The garment factory inside the prison has only grown bigger, the scope of the project expanding with it.

Chief superintendent of police (prisons) Krishna Kumar did not conceal his delight with the industry of the inmates of Hindalga. “In the past four years, the inmates have stitched more than 3,000 clothes, which is an astounding achievement. What is more, some of them have grown into really skilled tailors. More than 60 inmates are working at the tailoring centre in the jail, with 37 advanced tailoring machines,” Kumar told TOI.

The senior official said that clothes stitched by the inmates were being sold to a wholesale shop in Belagavi, contracted by many schools in the district for uniforms. “This was a business deal that was negotiated by the skill development arm of the department of textiles,” said Kumar.

He said that demand for uniforms peaked during April, May and June, although the prison received orders for other clothes for the reminder of the year. “The inmates stitch skirts, leggings, knickers, trousers and shirts. They feel proud to contribute their bit for nation-building,” Kumar added.

Uniforms for home guards

Hindalga Central Prison has recently been tasked with stitching pants for home guards. The home department has placed the order with the prison authorities, seeking 3,000 pants. The inmates have previously stitched pants for home guards, although they were only for those in Belagavi.

Title: Any time, any place, opposition tells Amit Shah on CAA debate
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Union home minister Amit Shah during a rally in support of CAA, in Lucknow. (PTI photo)

LUCKNOW/HYDERABAD: A day after Union home minister Amit Shah dared the Opposition for a debate on the amended citizenship law (CAA), BSP chief Mayawati and AIMIM president Asaduddin Owaisi on Wednesday accepted the challenge. Samajwadi Party (SP) chief Akhilesh Yadav, however, threw down the gauntlet to BJP for a debate on ‘development’.

Addressing a rally in Lucknow on Tuesday, Shah had challenged Rahul Gandhi, Mamata Banerjee and Akhilesh Yadav to debate CAA with him.

Putting out a tweet, Mayawati said: “BSP accepts Centre’s challenge to debate the controversial CAA/NRC/NPC, against which there have been protests across the country, especially by women and youth. The debate can take place on any platform and anywhere.”

On his part, Owaisi said: “People from the media informed me that the Union home minister is ready to debate CAA with Rahul Gandhi and Mamata Banerjee. I told them I am there, right? Let him debate with the dariwala (bearded man) first.”

Talking to reporters in Hyderabad on Wednesday, he said, “Call Asaduddin Owaisi and Union home minister, and let’s debate. Let’s debate everything, including CAA, NPR (National Population Register) and NRC (National Register of Citizens).”

Akhilesh, however, did not mention CAA while challenging BJP for a debate. “Let them determine the place and platform, we are ready. BJP is running away from a discussion on economy, jobs and demonetization,” he said while talking to reporters after paying tributes to socialist leader Janeshwar Mishra in Lucknow on Wednesday.

I am telling BJP members to decide the venue and platform for a debate. They can also call their favourite channels and anchors, and debate on development),” he said.

Lashing out at UP CM Yogi Adityanath , Akhilesh said, “The CM failed on governance, leave aside fulfilling aspirations of people. We are ready to debate on development. Don’t forget, we took the state to newer heights during our tenure.”

Title: Mumbai: Unlimited-ride Metro passes from today
Content:
Representative image

4.5 lakh commuters use Metro every day

MUMBAI: Starting today , commuters of Metro One can enjoy unlimited travel by upgrading their monthly 45-trip passes for an additional Rs 25. The monthly passes cost Rs 1,375 for a journey between Versova-Andheri, while the new scheme offers commuters unlimited travel across the entire network for Rs 1,400.The scheme is expected to benefit commuters who have to make multiple trips that involve breaking their journey.The popular 45-trip monthly pass will, however, continue to be available.In the popular 45-trip scheme, commuters can make 45 trips, but are charged for only 30 trips. About 50,000 commuters make one lakh trips on a weekday using this pass.In 2019, Mumbai Metro One Pvt Ltd (MMOPL) on an average carried 4.5 lakh commuters per day on weekdays in more than 400 services.Metros in India and abroad offer two ticketing products – token for single journey travel and a card.Looking at the needs of Mumbaikars, Mumbai Metro One had introduced two additional travel products –return journey token and trip pass. All four products are currently available in physical form (Paper QR, token or cards) and also through smart phone apps (mobile QR Ticket).A week ago, MMOPL had announced QR-coded tickets as a replacement to the plastic token system.An MMOPL official said, “We will launch a new product in the form of monthly pass from January 23, which will allow commuters to take unlimited rides during the validity period of the pass. The pass will not be transferable.”The product will initially be launched for six months and extended based on commuter feedback.An MMOPL spokesperson said, “We are confident commuters will find immense benefit in this product and travel without having to think about the number of trips.”

Title: Tricity joins hands to improve law and order
Content:
UT administrator V P Singh Badnore chaired the meeting

TimesView The rise in incidence of crime in the Tricity can only be combated through greater coordination among the police forces of Chandigarh, Mohali and Panchkula. The criminals have always taken advantage of the twin facts of contiguous boundaries and jurisdiction barriers to make a quick getaway. The Tricity police departments had created WhatsApp groups to share information on crime in their area about over a year ago following the Punjab governor’s suggestion for fighting crime jointly. The proposed coordination meetings of DGPs will further boost and streamline the enforcement agencies' joint fight to keep criminals at bay in the Tricity.

UT call on first flyover: Punjab, Haryana

CHANDIGARH: The DGPs of Punjab, Haryana and Chandigarh will meet once every three months and the Tricity SPs once a month to tackle inter-state criminals involved in heinous crimes and snatchings and to improve law and order.The decision was taken in the second meeting of the Coordination Committee of the Tricity on Wednesday held under the chairmanship of Punjab governor-cum-UT administrator V P Singh Badnore.At the outset of the meeting, Badnore thanked everyone for their active participation in the meeting, the main objective of which is to work for the coordinated development of Chandigarh and the satellite cities in Punjab and Haryana.The meeting discussed law and order issues like the participation of both the neighbouring states in tackling crime, snatchings and thefts.UT DGP Sanjay Baniwal suggested the use of emergency response support system (control room no.112) and e-beat book extension in the Tricity. It was also decided that field officers would meet more frequently for better coordination and cooperation.Concerned about multiple shootings by inter-state gangs — some in broad daylight in the past year — the administration had proposed the formation of a special unit of Tricity police. According to the proposal, the special unit would comprise superintendent of police (SP)-level officials from Punjab, Haryana and Chandigarh to specifically coordinate in gang-related crimes.On UT administration seeking Punjab and Haryana response on the construction of the proposed flyover and underpass at the Sector 29-31-Industrial Area roundabout, both the states said it is for the UT administration to decide, and they have nothing to do with the matter. UT adviser Manoj Kumar Parida, reportedly, brought the Sector 29 flyover and underpass for discussion in the Coordination Committee meeting. Punjab representatives maintained it for the administration to decide on to how to solve the problem of traffic congestion at the roundabout.Haryana representative too maintained it is the responsibility of the UT to resolve the traffic issues as it deems fit. But a senior Haryana official said the administration should explore other alternatives like removing the rotary at the intersection and installing traffic lights, as was done at the Sector 9-8-17-18 intersection.A proposal to impose uniform speed limits on major roads connecting Chandigarh, Panchkula and Mohali was also tabled in the meeting. But it was decided that the UT adviser Manoj Parida will hold a separate meeting with officials to resolve the issue. In the next meeting, Punjab will be asked to resolve the traffic congestion due to traffic signal installation at Chandigarh-Zirakpur barrier opposite Makkar farmhouse.The issue of beggary was also highlighted, with UT DGP stressing on working together for tackling the issue.It was also proposed that the security audit of public places for women safety should be done on various safety parameters like lighting, openness, visibility, security, public transport and setting up of powerline for women and child safety and to adopt the best practices on same lines from other states, including Uttar Pradesh.

Title: 100m ESZ plan not on, administration tells Punjab, Haryana
Content:
The final notification for Punjab and Haryana will be issued by the central government, the 100m proposal of P... Read More

Don’t accept Punjab 100m ESZ plan: UT

CHANDIGARH: The 100-metre radius of eco sensitive zone (ESZ) around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary is not acceptable to Chandigarh and is a major threat to Sukhna Lake and the sanctuary. This was submitted by the UT administration in the meeting of the Coordination Committee of Tricity on Wednesday.UT chief conservator of forests Debendra Dalai made these submissions in the meeting chaired by Punjab governor-cum-UT administrator V P Singh Badnore and attended by UT adviser Manoj Parida, Haryana chief secretary Keshni Anand, Punjab chief secretary Karan Avtar and other senior officials.Though final notification for Punjab and Haryana will be issued by the central government, the 100m proposal of Punjab is not acceptable to the administration, Dalai told TOI. The administration has already written a letter to the ministry of environment, forest and climate change in this regard, he said.In the recent letter to the director general of forests and special secretary, the UT had opposed the Punjab government's plan.The administration had termed Punjab's 2013 proposal to declare only 100-metre of state's area around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary as an ESZ a threat. Punjab chief minister Capt Amarinder Singh had recently backed the state government's proposal.The administration has already notified 2 to 2.75km radius around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary as an ESZ. The environment ministry had also issued a final notification on ESZ around the sanctuary for Chandigarh, but Punjab and Haryana have so far not declared these zones in their jurisdictions.The UT is pushing for Punjab and Haryana to leave a matching area from the lake boundary as restricted development zone. UT, in a letter written on January 14, stated, “The ESZ for the area falling in Chandigarh around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary has already been notified by the ministry on January 18, 2017, wherein ESZ has been kept 2 to 2.75 km and regulating/prohibiting various activities therein. However, the proposal of Punjab is not in line with the proposal of Chandigarh… Further, it is to reiterate that similar proposal of the Punjab government, which was sent to the government in 2015, was not accepted by the Centre. In 2018, the government once again turned down the proposal of Punjab government proposing only 100m width as ESZ from Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary. In case only 100m is left as ESZ, it will have serious adverse impact on Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary as well as Sukhna Lake (sic).”The UT has requested the ministry not to accept Punjab’s proposal in the interest of wildlife conservation in the sanctuary as well as for Sukhna Lake, which is being declared as a wetland, draft notification for which has already been issued by the administration.Earlier on December 27 last, the Punjab CM wrote to the Union minister of environment, forest and climate change Prakash Javadekar, “In the light of recommendations made by the Punjab government, the ministry has already notified ESZ of 100m width around all the wildlife sanctuaries of Punjab. However, the proposal of Punjab government in respect of declaring 100m ESZ around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary has not been agreed upon by the ministry on the basis that Chandigarh had proposed ESZ of 2 to 2.75km, and therefore the ministry advised Punjab to explore the possibility of declaring 1km ESZ instead of the proposed ESZ of 100m.The Punjab government reconsidered its decision of declaring 100m ESZ and it was found that the decision taken by the government on August 8, 2013, was in line with the recommendation of the central-empowered committee of the Supreme Court.”

Title: Sikh neta in Pak flees country after threats
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

AMRITSAR: Pakistani Sikh politician Radesh Singh Tony, who had contested the 2018 general polls as an Independent candidate but lost, has fled the country along with his wife and three sons due to threats from fundamentalists .

The move comes barely a year after Tony, chairman of the Khalsa Peace and Justice Foundation , fled to Lahore in November 2018 from his native city of Peshawar , leaving behind his business and property. Tony told TOI on Wednesday that minority communities in Pakistan, including Sikhs, Hindus and Christians, were living under constant threats from fundamentalists who he claimed enjoyed the Pakistan government's sup port.

After the gunning down of Peshawar's prominent Sikh leader Charanjit Singh in May 2018, a large number of Sikhs and Hindus had migrated from Peshawar to safer places in Pakistan with sizeable populations of their communities.

Title: Ghana seeks India's help for its own Ujjwala
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

NEW DELHI: Ghana has sought to take a leaf out of the Narendra Modi government's 'Ujjwala' scheme for giving poor households access to clean cooking fuel at affordable rates and sought India's assistance for building systems and infrastructure to promote LPG as household, industrial and commercial fuel in that country.

IndianOil and National Petroleum Authority of Ghana on Wednesday exchanged an MoU in the presence of oil minister Dharmendra Pradhan and Ghana high commissioner Michael Aaron here. The MoU paves the way for IndianOil to help Ghana implement its National LPG Promotion Policy. The MoU also allows IndianOil the option to open a business in Ghana's downstream sector.

Ghana is the second country to have sought India's expertise in giving citizens access to clean fuel. In March 2017, Nepal sought IndianOil's expertise for rolling out LPG-for-poor schemes similar to the Ujjwala programme envisaging giving poor households LPG connections free of cost.

Title: Maintain status quo on Tarun Gogoi security: Gauhati high court
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

The Gauhati high court on Thursday directed the government to maintain status quo regarding the security cover... Read More

GUWAHATI: The Gauhati high court on Thursday directed the government to maintain status quo regarding the security cover of former Assam CM Tarun Gogoi .

Gogoi, a three-time Congress CM, had approached the HC after his security cover was downgraded to "Z" with CRPF cover from "Z plus" recently. The hearing was done in the court of Justice Prashanta Kumar Deka.

Advocate Atul Chandra Buragohain, appearing for Gogoi in court, said, "The court has asked the government to maintain status quo. The next hearing of the case is on February 12. During the period, the court has asked the government to file an affidavit."

This is the second time that Gogoi's security cover has been downgraded by the government. In 2016, after the defeat of Congress in the assembly election, Gogoi's security cover was scaled down from "Z Plus" security cover with NSG to "Z plus" with CRPF cover.

Title: Assam, Tripura litigants hail SC for segregating anti-CAA cases
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

GUWAHATI: Anti-CAA petitioners in Assam and Tripura on Wednesday gave a thumbs up to the Supreme Court ’s decision to treat their reservations about the new law as distinct from that of the rest of the country and, therefore, hear those cases separately and on priority.

“We have been asking for separate hearings for Assam and the northeast as our issues are entirely different,” Lurinjyoti Gogoi, the general secretary of the All Assam Students Union (Aasu), said. “We have been the worst victims of illegal migration from Bangladesh and cannot afford to take in a single extra illegal migrant — be it a Hindu or Muslim. We believe the Supreme Court will give us justice.” In its petition, Aasu has questioned the logic of considering illegal migrants eligible for citizenship even if they entered the state after the Assam Accord cut-off of March 25, 1971.

Congress’s Pradyot Deb Barman, a scion of the Tripura royal family and one of the petitioners against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, said he felt reassured by the apex court taking cognisance of the fact that the issues raised by anti-CAA campaigners in his state and neighbouring Assam were not the same as those echoing elsewhere.

Title: West Bengal: Two cops held over missing Lalgarh arms
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Representative image

LALGARH: Two policemen, including a sub-inspector, have been arrested along with two villagers after 18 single-barrel guns went missing from the armoury of Lalgarh police station in Jhargram .

The guns belonged to people with arms licences who had deposited them, said a senior officer. In most cases, the deposit is done under orders issued before elections, sources said. Many owners don’t collect their arms for months.

Among those arrested are SI Tarapada Tudu, who was in charge of the armoury till January 16. Tudu’s assistant Lakshmiram Rana (37), a National Volunteer Force jawan, was also arrested. Sleuths also nailed villagers Sudhangshu Senapati and his son Dilip, suspected arms suppliers.

The missing arms were noticed by Biswajit Panja, who took charge after Tudu. He brought it to the notice of Lalgarh IC Arindam Bhattacharya, who initiated a suo motu case. An FIR was registered against Tudu and Rana, who were picked up late on Tuesday. Investigators found they had links with Sudhangshu and Dilip, who were arrested on Wednesday. All four were produced in a Jhargram court and remanded in 5-day police custody.

Jhargram SP Amit Kumar Bharat Rathore said: “We will interrogate them in our custody.”

Title: 70L infiltrators in Bengal, most vote for TMC: Ghosh
Content:
This story is from January 23, 2020

Falakata (Alipurduar): Th-ere are 70 lakh Bangladeshi infiltrators in Bengal, a majority of whom are Trinamool Congress voters, BJP president Dilip Ghosh claimed at a pro-CAA rally in Alipurduar’s Falakata on Wednesday, providing a glimpse of the political calculation behind the battle over the new citizenship law in the state.

Citing the 2019 Lok Sabha poll figures, Ghosh claimed Trinamool got 2.5 crore votes in Bengal while BJP finished the race with 2.3 crore. What he left unsaid was that CAA would come in handy to remove names of “infiltrators” from the voters’ list and bridge the gap between his party and Trinamool before the 2021 assembly polls.

“As many as 70 lakh Bangladeshi infiltrators are living in Bengal, of whom 50 lakh are Trinamool voters. These people are taking away a large chunk of the subsidised ration meant for bona fide residents. They are claiming a portion of your PM Awas Yojana allotments for dwelling units and also 100-day work. How long will you allow this when there no jobs in this state?” Ghosh said.

Referring to the arson at railway stations in Bengal after the passage of the citizenship bill in Parliament, he said: “Can a citizen damage public property or lay siege to railway stations? They (the arsonists) are all Bangladeshi infiltrators for whom the Trinamool chief, Congress and CPM have taken to the streets. Their brethren in Bangladesh poured poison in your ponds there, misbehaved with your wife and daughter, and forced you to leave the country and settle here.”

Ghosh also claimed that the Trinamool chief was “desperately walking the streets” because she can read the writing on the wall once the infiltrators are removed from the voters’ list.
